column2: The Xerox Corporation swung to a first-quarter profit on Thursday as revenue climbed and the company cut costs related to its acquisition of Affiliated Computer Services. Net income was $281 million, or 19 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $42 million, or 4 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Excluding some costs, profit was 23 cents a share. Analysts estimated 21 cents on average.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. -- What do you do after you make a mistake that costs your team a crucial playoff game? What do you do when fans, who are already on your case for general underachievement, plaster Twitter with messages calling for your head? Those are the unsettling questions Marian Gaborik faced after his mistake in the second overtime period Wednesday led to the winning goal by Washington forward Jason Chimera.
To the Editor: Re ''College Loans Weigh Heavier on Graduates'' (front page, April 12):

There's an emotion when you come here. A tear comes to your eye for all that started here. LILY TOWNSEND,of Pensacola, Fla., on the newly renovated Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. preached. [A1]
MY NEW AMERICAN LIFE By Francine Prose

Jason Bay arrived at Citi Field on Thursday ready to play in his first game since July 25, but hoping he will not be the same player he was before a concussion sustained two days earlier ended his disappointing 2010 season. This year Bay was just starting to feel good at the plate in the last week of spring training when he strained the intercostal muscle in his left side rib cage just two days before the end of camp. He was placed on the disabled list.

8:34 p.m. | Updated NYSE Euronext on Thursday dug itself in for a fight against the Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange, again rejecting its rivals' $11.2 billion unsolicited bid in favor of a merger with Deutsche Borse.

LOS ANGELES -- When the State of California began handing out i.o.u.'s in 2009 because of a cash shortage, taxpayers were predictably aghast. But few knew at the time that even as pay-you-later notes kept going out, state agencies were also doling out millions of dollars in interest-free loans in the form of salary and travel advances to employees without collecting repayment. Now, with the state budget facing a devastating $26.5 billion deficit, Gov. Jerry Brown is demanding that agencies immediately stop the practice and determine how much money employees with unpaid loans owe the state.
7:17 p.m. | Updated Stocks continue to surge, and BlackRock is reaping the benefits.

At first Christopher Tierney's doctors said that he wouldn't be able to rejoin the cast of Broadway's ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' until midsummer at the earliest, only after he had pins removed from his lower back and finished physical therapy to recover from a 30-foot fall off a platform during the musical's Dec. 20 performance. Yet Mr. Tierney, who managed to be up and walking two weeks after sustaining four broken ribs and three fractured vertebrae, had the pins taken out two weeks ago and is healthy enough to return to rehearsals for ''Spider-Man'' on Monday, his father, Tim, said in an interview on Thursday. ''The doctors originally thought he'd have the pins in for another three months, but his physical comeback has gone well and they gave him the O.K. early this week to go back into the cast,'' Tim Tierney said. He acknowledged that the return was unusually quick, but noted that Christopher would not perform again without his doctors' clearance, given that all shows require insurance for their cast members. (His son was not available for an interview on Thursday.)

NEW YORK Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the decision by Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem to provide bail for a teenage girl facing drug and weapons charges referred incorrectly in two instances to the Rev. Eboni Marshall Turman, an assistant to the pastor. She is a woman.
Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

Monday, you'd have to imagine, was a pretty exciting day for Jennifer Egan, when her novel ''A Visit From the Goon Squad''won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. The rest of the week hasn't been a letdown either: on Wednesday evening the agency International Creative Management, which represents Ms. Egan, said that the novel, a sprawling series of stories about interlocking characters connected to the San Francisco punk-rock scene, has been optioned by HBO, which plans to adapt it into a television series. How exactly the novel, which chronicles more than a dozen characters from the 1970s to the year 2019 or so, will be turned into TV fare is not entirely up to Ms. Egan, who will be a consultant on the project. (Michael London, a producer of films including ''Win Win'' and ''Sideways,'' is its executive producer, and Jocelyn Hayes Simpson, a producer of the television version of ''This American Life,'' is co-executive producer.)
Because of Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Friday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

When Clorox introduced Green Works, its environment-friendly cleaning line, in 2008, it secured an endorsement from the Sierra Club, a nationwide introduction at Wal-Mart, and it vowed that the products would ''move natural cleaning into the mainstream.'' Sales that year topped $100 million, and several other major consumer products companies came out with their own ''green'' cleaning supplies.

BUSINESS An article on Thursday about a National Labor Relations Board complaint seeking to prevent Boeing from moving some airplane production to a nonunion plant in South Carolina misstated the status of a rule to require private sector employers to post a notice about workers' right to unionize. An N.L.R.B. proposal for such a rule is pending; it has not been made final.

LAS VEGAS -- Dropped calls. Maps that take eons to load. Echoing voices on a mobile phone. And, as iPhone users know, the dreaded ''Cannot Open Page.'' Those annoyances are likely to get worse, as airwaves that carry cellphone signals and wireless Internet connections grow ever more crowded.
YURAN--Roslyn Adler, from Paterson, NJ passed away Wednesday, April 20. Service will be at Schoems Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ at 11am on Sunday April 24.

In 2002, when Lee B. Farkas was running a relatively small mortgage company, it got caught selling eight fraudulent mortgages to Fannie Mae. To make things even worse, the mortgages -- all of which defaulted without a single payment being made -- listed Mr. Farkas as the borrower. Fannie Mae stopped doing business with the firm, called the Taylor Bean & Whitaker Mortgage Corporation.

The latest battle front over limitations on unions has opened in New Hampshire, where a law is expected to be adopted that would prohibit unions from collecting mandatory fees and disallow collective bargaining agreements that require employees to join a labor union. The State Senate passed the bill Wednesday -- by a veto-proof vote of 16 to 8 -- that would make New Hampshire the 23rd right-to-work state, and the first in the Northeast. The House passed a similar bill in February.
9:13 p.m. | Updated Raj Rajaratnam's lawyer on Thursday concluded his defense with the argument that Mr. Rajaratnam took advantage only of publicly available information

MILWAUKEE -- The aspiring lawyer in the third row of Room 267 at Eckstein Hall had a question for Bud Selig. She wanted to know if a story she read was true, if he was, indeed, the happiest commissioner in sports. The notion of a word like happy describing Allan H. ''Bud'' Selig -- as the signature printed on every ball reads -- seems incongruous with his public image. Selig became baseball's commissioner after the ouster of Fay Vincent in September 1992, and two years later, labor strife led to the cancellation of the World Series. The rampant use of steroids during his tenure further tarnished the game.

EGYPT A judge ordered the removal of the names and photographs of the former president, Hosni Mubarak, and his wife, Suzanne, from streets, squares, schools, libraries and all other public institutions in the country. LIBYA The government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi suffered setbacks on multiple fronts: rebels seized a border crossing with Tunisia, fighters in Misurata said they were gaining ground and President Obama authorized the use of drones for close-in fighting.

When it comes to art and art galleries, Chelsea is the land of wild, mind-bending discrepancies. You know the drill. There are mega-bucks, big-box spaces on the same block as holes in the wall not much larger than a walk-in closet; great work within a stone's throw of schlock; older art alongside the freshly minted; and blue-chip brand names across the street from young and emerging artists or forgotten and overlooked ones. Chelsea's inconsistencies and jarring juxtapositions give it the air of a permanent, slightly crazed art fair for which all entrance requirements have long since been abandoned. After nearly 20 years as a gallery destination, and despite a spate of sleek new apartment buildings, it is still nothing but art, and it still feels surprisingly raw -- gentrified but not especially gentled. This may be partly a function of its wide streets, its riverside perch and its often brusque winds, but some of the rawness has to do with the staggering quantity and diversity of the art that confronts you at every turn, and what it says about the human urge to make art and have it seen.

In 1973, when PBS broadcast ''An American Family,'' that documentary series about the Loud family of Santa Barbara, Calif., seemed like television engagé: a camera-armed rebellion against the scripted contrivances of canned and conventional television. So it's telling -- almost a signal of surrender -- that ''Cinema Verite,'' an HBO movie about the making of that legendary documentary, falls back on the scripted contrivances of premium cable.

YOUNG--Maria, passed away on Palm Sunday, April 17, 2011. Maria was the beloved mother of Michael, Kevin, and Ryan, loving daughter of Helen Lombardi and the late Louis Lombardi, caring sister of Joseph Lombardi, sister-in-law to Regina Lombardi, loving Aunt of Katherine and Chloe Lombardi, and devoted friend to those extraordinary people who know who they are. Maria graduated Boston College and received her Masters in Education from NYU. An accomplished Special Education teacher, Maria gave up her teaching career for the greatest love of her life, being mother to Michael, Kevin and Ryan. She understood a parent shows their love by paying attention to the smallest details, and always being there, whether at school or on the Lacrosse field. The consummate mother, Maria raised her sons in Manhasset to be fine young men. Maria asked no less of those she loved, than that they live life to the fullest and be the best they could be. Whether enjoying summer vacations in Montauk with her sons, planning holiday gatherings, traveling to Italy with her close friend Suzanne, or decorating with Nancy, Maria knew how to be in the moment and enjoy life to the fullest. She lived and taught a profound understanding of the importance of Family, Faith, and Friendship, and this is the legacy she gives to her sons, and all of us. She will be loved and remembered always. Maria's Mass will be Monday, April 25th, at 1pm, at St. Mary's Church, at 1300 Northern Boulevard Manhasset, NY 11030. For information regarding memorial contributions, please see www.Fairchildsons.com obituaries.

WALSH--James A.H.,a resident of Rye, NH, died suddenly on April 20, while on a business trip in Linyi, China. He was born in New York City on January 26, 1967, the son of Jerome K. Walsh and former Cynthia Hamlin. He was educated at St. Bernard's School, Philips Exeter Academy, Duke University (B.A.) and the University of Washington (M.B.A.). A founder and Managing Partner of Sinova Capital, LLC, a merchant bank focusing on the "clean technology" sector, he was deeply passionate about the environment. At the time of his death, he was in the final stages of closing a fund dedicated to converting waste to energy in China. He is survived by his wife, Colette Dumont, daughters Ella Clare and Audrey, son Henri, his parents, sisters Lawler W. Parker and Katherine W. Fernie, three nieces and a nephew.

Buildings in New York City will be required to phase out using the most-polluting grades of heating oil under a new regulation that is expected to improve air quality significantly and make black smoke billowing from smokestacks a thing of the past. The new rule, announced on Thursday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as part of an update to his environmental agenda, known as PlaNYC, affects about 10,000 buildings that burn the dirtiest types of heating oil: No. 6, the cheapest oil pumped into aging boilers; and No. 4, another heavy oil that is only slightly less noxious.

A SONGWRITER sips a latte while composing music on a laptop. His companion is so engrossed in a novel that her mouth is frozen midbite into an almond croissant. It sounds like a typical morning at Starbucks, but it's actually a scene from the lobby of the Classic Stage Company, one of a handful of New York theaters that have discovered how concession stands can extend the life of their spaces beyond that night's curtain to become community-building places where patrons are encouraged to sit awhile, often during the day. When the managers of New York Theater Workshop, an Off Broadway company a few blocks away from Classic Stage in the East Village, decided to revamp its concession stand for its recent production of ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' they considered concepts more likely to come from the mouths of foodies than theater geeks: handmade, artisanal, local. The snacks and drinks for sale in the lobby are from New York companies that supply menu items at Fab Cafe, a few doors down on East Fourth Street.

EARTH DAY AT THE NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN While many children will hunt for Easter eggs this weekend, those visiting the New York Botanical Garden on Friday will seek other treasures. These won't have anything to do with candy or the Easter Bunny, though a rabbit might appreciate the leafier discoveries.
To the Editor: Re ''Patently Obvious'' (Op-Ed, April 16):

Mason Rudolph, a golfer who surged to prominence as a youthful amateur, became rookie of the year on the PGA circuit, then settled into a rock-solid 23-year PGA career, winning five tournaments and almost never missing the cut or hitting a ball out of bounds, died Monday in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 76. Vanderbilt University, where he coached the golf team for five seasons, announced his death. He had had two heart attacks last fall.

Thierry Henry scored two first-half goals, both off crosses from defender Jan Gunnar Solli, and Joel Lindpere and Juan Agudelo added second-half goals as the Red Bulls defeated host D.C. United, 4-0, on Thursday night. Henry, who did not score a goal in the first four games this season as the Red Bulls scored only twice, now has three goals in two games. The Red Bulls (3-1-2, 11 points) defeated San Jose, 3-0, last Saturday and have moved past Philadelphia and into first place in the Eastern Conference.

SALEM, Ore. -- They govern by hyphen. Try to arrange an interview with Bruce Hanna, the new Republican co-speaker of the Oregon House of Representatives, and odds are good you will be asked if you would also like to meet with Arnie Roblan, the new Democratic co-speaker.

The Lyric Opera of Chicago has named a new general director, Anthony Freud, who has been running the Houston Grand Opera for the past five years. Mr. Freud, 53, will take over in the fall for William Mason, 69, the general director since 1997, who said in July he would retire after this season. Mr. Freud, a onetime record company executive and former chairman of the jury for the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World Competition, ran the Welsh National Opera before coming to Houston in 2006. A Londoner, he has become a key insider in the American opera world and is chairman of the Opera America service organization. In Houston, he was credited with increasing attendance and fund-raising; overseeing premieres by Jake Heggie and Andre Previn; programming a survey of Benjamin Britten operas; and planning for the company's first ''Ring'' cycle, which is scheduled for 2014. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Mid-20th-century textiles, although often dismissed as poor relatives of abstract paintings, are headed for gallery walls and fair booths in quantities not seen since the 1970s. They are coming to light partly because two major weavers, Lenore Tawney and Annabert Yoors, died in the last few years, and historians and dealers have started poring over their archives and surviving works. Ms. Yoors, a Dutch designer who died last year at 83, was the first wife of Jan Yoors, a charismatic Belgian artist. He had escaped from Nazi prisons and lived in Gypsy camps before settling in New York in 1951. The couple collaborated on tapestries up to 20 feet long in bright shard patterns, some based on Himalayan mountain ranges, others on plowshare blades and still others on jungle tree trunks.

The first time you hear the rumble in ''Jerusalem,'' the magnificent play by Jez Butterworth, you don't think that it's just a good sound effect or a subway passing beneath. A thundery whisper, like a premonition of earthquakes, fills the air every time someone looks deep, but really deep, into the eyes of Johnny Byron. And since Johnny Byron is portrayed by Mark Rylance, in a seismic performance that threatens to level the old Music Box Theater, this registers as utterly natural cause and effect. Sounds like a joke, doesn't it? I mean, the idea of someone making the earth move when you look into his eyes is the sort of notion you find in cheap romance novels or a sci-fi comic book. And Mr. Rylance's character in ''Jerusalem,'' which opened on Thursday night in an enthralling production directed by Ian Rickson, seems on first acquaintance like a pretty sad joke himself: a boastful wreck of a man held together by drugs and drink, existing as a 24-hour party guy in a squalid mobile home in the English countryside.
KLEIN--David. We will always miss and remember your kind and gentle ways and your so constant devotion to the love of your life, Renee. All our love, Jean and Charlie Baraf

COMBAT OUTPOST ZEROK, Afghanistan -- Nestled amid the pine-studded mountains in eastern Afghanistan, this small base a dozen miles from the Pakistan border was once one of the most dangerous places in Afghanistan. Insurgents nearly overran it in 2009. Last year mortars rained down on the base nearly every other day. But security has vastly improved here. The outpost, in the northeastern mountains of Paktika Province, has not been shelled since late last summer, due largely, soldiers here believe, to a shift in tactics that started when a new unit came in and began relentlessly patrolling the surrounding mountains, always on foot and usually at night. The incessant patrols took away the insurgents' vantage points, and they have barely engaged since.

The first quarter is always weak one for airlines, as travel drops with the start of the new year. But this one was especially difficult, the airlines reported Thursday, as fuel prices spiked and Middle East unrest and the earthquake in Japan cut into demand for international flights. The rise in jet fuel prices -- up 50 percent in the last year -- has been particularly tough, airline executives said. And even though the airlines have repeatedly resorted to fare increases this year, higher fuel costs have largely eroded their revenue gains. Fuel now accounts for about 40 percent of an airline's costs, up from about 30 percent last year.

When Clorox introduced Green Works, its environment-friendly cleaning line, in 2008, it secured an endorsement from the Sierra Club, a nationwide introduction at Wal-Mart, and it vowed that the products would ''move natural cleaning into the mainstream.'' Sales that year topped $100 million, and several other major consumer products companies came out with their own ''green'' cleaning supplies.

WHITE--Anne Holmes, Devoted mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, aunt and special friend died peacefully at her home in Watch Hill, RI on April 18, 2011 after a long illness. She is survived by her children, Starr White Snead, Cassandra (Candy) White Sweeney, William King White; her grandchildren, Angus W. Dwyer, Duncan W. Dwyer, Eleanor (Nellie) G. Dwyer, Keelin M. W. Sweeney, Charles (Charlie) B. White II and Molly K. White; her great grandchildren, Prudence V. Dwyer and Benedict A. Dwyer; her sons-in-law Philip T. Snead, Robert J. Dwyer and Thomas J. Sweeney, III and her daughter-in-law Kathleen P. O'Donnell. Her husband, Charles B. White, and daughter, Marice (Muffy) White Dwyer predeceased her. Services will be held on Monday, April 25, 2011 at the Watch Hill Chapel, Watch Hill, RI at 1:00pm.

It sounds like a typical morning at Starbucks, but it's actually a scene from the lobby of the Classic Stage Company, one of a handful of New York theaters that have discovered how concession stands can extend the life of their spaces beyond that night's curtain to become community-building places where patrons are encouraged to sit awhile, often during the day. When the managers of New York Theater Workshop, an Off Broadway company a few blocks away from Classic Stage in the East Village, decided to revamp its concession stand for its recent production of ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' they considered concepts more likely to come from the mouths of foodies than theater geeks: handmade, artisanal, local. ATLANTA -- Each of the 90 federal historic sites in the United States has its appeal. But for all their cultural value, the sites don't change much. A studious tour given by a park ranger. A plaque to read. Another note in a travel journal. But this week, one of the sites held the sort of electric charge usually not found among dusty period chairs and explanatory dioramas.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. -- After having two days to recuperate from injuries, narrow losses and second- and third-guessing, the Knicks will play their first home playoff game in seven years Friday with their dimming chances connected to the status of their stars. Amar'e Stoudemire is probable, Chauncey Billups is doubtful and Carmelo Anthony will try to compensate if one or both are absent from the third game of the team's first-round series against the Boston Celtics.

It was the city's worst fire in years, an enormous blaze that raced through one century-old building in Chinatown and jumped to another and then another. On that Sunday night a year ago, the Fire Department sounded seven alarms and a boroughwide call that jammed Grand Street with more than 60 fire trucks and scores of firefighters. Some of them were still spraying water on the rubble more than 10 hours later. Since then, two of the three buildings have been demolished. The third, on the corner at Eldridge Street, is a different story. It is still standing, but repairs have yet to begin and the tenants in its 13 apartments have yet to return to their homes.

At first listen it can be hard to put your finger on what exactly Mucca Pazza is. A 30-member music ensemble from Chicago, it includes the usual brass and percussion, with what it calls its ''freak'' section -- guitars, mandolins, violins and accordions amplified with speakers in the musicians' helmets. The band's name means ''mad cow'' in Italian and is what one member, Sharon Lanza, described as ''silliness that stuck.'' But don't be fooled: these mad hatters with instruments deliver, banging out unique renditions of 20th-century music, television-show themes, car-alarm melodies and original tunes with skill and the help of a couple of cheerleaders. (Thursday, 7 p.m., $12; Santos Party House, 96 Lafayette Street, Lower Manhattan; 866-777-8932, santospartyhouse.com.) It's Easter weekend, and that means, among other things, chocolate. Bruce Scher and Walking Tours Manhattan are back with a delicious trek through Gramercy Park and Greenwich Village, where you can sample goodies like a chocolate mouse at L. A. Burdick, chocolate pizza from Max Brenner, cakes and pastries at Black Hound and a sea salt and caramel pretzel with chocolate shell from Bespoke. (Sunday at 11 a.m.; $5 donation goes to the Food Bank of New York City; goodies are extra. Meet at L. A. Burdick, 5 East 20th Street, Flatiron district; 917-842-4319, walkingtoursmanhattan.com.)

House Republicans are seeking to abolish the federal Election Assistance Commission -- as if the nation is fully recovered from the hanging-chad nightmare of 2000. The 9-year-old commission was created in bipartisan Congressional resolve to repair the nation's crazy quilt of tattered election standards and faltering machinery. The commission was charged with upgrading the mechanics of voting by certifying electoral equipment, channeling needed federal aid and guidance to states, and developing a national mail-in voter registration system. After a slow start, it has made progress as the 2012 elections loom. But there is still a lot more that needs repairing.

POWERS--Seymour. American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev mourns a true friend and longtime supporter. Seymour Powers played an integral role in our organization's Florida region, lending his business and marketing acumen to help raise the profile of both AABGU and the University it represents. His generosity of spirit, experience and funds was awarded with an honorary doctorate from Ben-Gurion University in 2004 for his passionate commitment to fulfilling the Zionist vision of developing the Negev and building an Oxford in the desert. We extend our deepest condolences to his loving wife Alice and all his bereaved family. May his memory be a blessing. Alexander M. Goren, President Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President

Neil Paine is an analyst at Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues. Mired in a 5-13 start despite having the seventh-highest payroll in baseball, the Mets once again project to be among the least cost-effective teams in the major leagues. Since 2009, the Mets have paid more than $297 million in player salaries - only the Red Sox, Cubs, Phillies and Yankees have spent more - but have a measly .450 winning percentage to show for it. But as bad as that is, it's nothing new for the Mets, whose current run is the latest in a long tradition of poor spending decisions.
Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week. FORT STOCKTON

9 P.M. (The Weather Channel) CHANGING PLANET In honor of Earth Day, Tom Brokaw moderates a town-hall-style symposium at Yale University to encourage student dialogue about climate change and its impact on health, economic opportunity, and moral and religious values, as well as to brainstorm about solutions. Sponsored by NBC Learn, the educational arm of NBC News; the National Science Foundation; and Discover magazine, the meeting brings together more than 100 students with Rajendra K. Pachauri, who heads the Yale Climate and Energy Institute; Billy Parish, a founder of the Energy Action Coalition, a youth advocacy organization working on climate change issues; Katharine Hayhoe, a research associate professor of geosciences at Texas Tech University; and Linda J. Fisher, vice president for safety, health and environment at DuPont. (Above, drought in the Southwest, among the topics addressed in the program.) 8:45 A.M. (Vme) ANIMALITOS EXPLORADORES Translated as ''Wild Animal Baby Explorers,'' this first Spanish-language children's television show from the National Wildlife Federation introduces five natural-science investigators -- Benita the Beaver, Skip the Rabbit, Izzy the Owl, Sammy the Skunk and Miss Sally the Salamander -- who will show youngsters that every backyard, playground and flower bed is worthy of exploration. Other Earth Day shows for children include ''Jake and the Never Land Pirates,'' at 8:30, and ''Handy Manny,'' at 9:30, on Disney Junior; and ''Sid the Science Kid,'' at 11 a.m., and ''Arthur,'' at 3 p.m., on Channel 13.

FISH--Florence Bette, on April 20 in Folsom, California. Widow of the late Herman Lewis Fish, and the youngest child of Joseph Rabinowitz and Mary Lesitzky, Florence was born in San Francisco on December 1, 1918. After graduating from James Monroe High School in 1936, Florence worked for West Virginia Glass, and subsequently became the New York representative for the Bartlett-Collins Company, for whom she was consistently salesman of the year. She completed an undergraduate degree from Queens College magna cum laude, and attended the graduate program in psychology at St. John's University. After retirement, Florence and Herman moved to San Francisco in 1987 where they were members of Temple Emanuel. Florence was a volunteer for the San Francisco Opera and Ballet, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, and Haas Lillienthal House. Florence is survived by her children, Victoria Fisch of Folsom, California, and Kenneth Fish of Urbana, Maryland, her grandchildren, Sterling, Sheridan, and Skye Reed, Tatiana Fish, and a nephew, Ernest Mendeloff. A memorial will be held in San Francisco.

HANLEY--Charles E. Beloved and best friend to Kevin P and Joan D Wait and family. Patriarch of the Hanley Family of Brookville and Windham, New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Three generations of Hanley's and Waits have formed a unique bond of friendship, love and loyalty with one another. Holy Child, Nassau CC, Brookville, Windham, and Jackson Hole are special places and times where the bonds between our families were cemented together. Uncle Charlie was a compassionate and patient man who always had a kind word and helping hand to all. A lifelong traveler with his bride Jane, Uncle Charlie enjoyed exploring and learning. His loyalty to the New York Islanders and Mets ran deep despite long draughts of winning. Uncle Charlie's magic was his smile and laugh that made everyone feel his warmth. Through the ups and downs of life, Uncle Charlie's deep faith in God, family, and friends provided a steady compass to all around him. His love and rock solid friendship to the Wait Family, will never be forgotten. God Bless Uncle Charlie and Go Islanders! Jarett, Younghee, Unjo and Uno Wait

In Tuscany region of Italy, the way to transform leftover bean and vegetable soup into the ultimate comfort food is to reheat the soup with dry or toasted bread, then blend it into a thick, comforting pap. This is called ribollita, which means ''reboiled.'' 6 ounces (1 scant cup) white or borlotti beans, soaked, if desired, for four hours and then drained

A cheery, chummy documentary about the pastoral patterns inaccurately described as crop circles, Suzanne Taylor's ''What on Earth?'' musters a gaggle of enthusiasts to dish on the phenomenon. They're a diverse bunch -- farmers and philosophers, scientists and a singer-songwriter -- and Ms. Taylor, a former actress who first became involved with the group in the early 1990s, uses her familiarity to encourage them to open up. Merging homey interviews with photographs and film of the hundreds of varieties of patterns (which pop up mysteriously overnight and are found all over the world), the film makes no pretense of objectivity or analysis. Everyone on screen -- most sporting little blue flowers in their lapels, like a club insignia -- is convinced of an intelligence behind the designs.

The N.F.L. argued Thursday in court papers that players were not entitled to further damages -- either compensatory or punitive -- in the case in which the United States District Judge David Doty ruled that the league violated agreements with players when it negotiated TV contracts that would pay owners even if games are missed during a lockout. While the papers do not reveal the amount of damages being sought -- all figures are redacted -- they make reference to players seeking compensatory damages of ''hundreds of millions of dollars.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Geoffrey Mutai's performance in the Boston Marathon, the fastest marathon ever run, misstated a reason that his time, 2 hours 3 minutes 2 seconds, was not an official world record. In addition to the course's elevation drop, it is because its start and finish are separated by more than 50 percent of the race distance; the type of course -- whether point-to-point or loop -- is not a determining factor. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the article and in the On Running column.

A day after Commissioner Bud Selig moved to take control of the Los Angeles Dodgers, a raft of questions remain unanswered about the future of one of baseball's elite franchises. Who will serve as Selig's trustee, the person put in charge of daily operations of the club?
International KURDS RENEW MOVEMENT

It was just after dawn last Sunday when a pair of pilgrims lighted incense on the shore and dropped two coconuts into the sacred waters, otherwise known as Jamaica Bay. The shells bobbed in the surf, not far from clay bowls, rotting limes and waterlogged rags that had washed back ashore, flotsam from previous Hindu ceremonies to mark festivals, births, deaths and everything in between.

The time to finish cleaning the basement of the former Deutsche Bank building in 2006 was so short that supervisors were getting antsy. Salvatore DePaola, an asbestos abatement foreman, constantly urged his team to hurry, Adolpho Ortiz, one of the cleaning workers, testified on Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The director of the abatement work, Mitchel Alvo, angrily gestured and told workers to pick up the pace, Mr. Ortiz said. Mr. Alvo even slammed his construction helmet once, Mr. Ortiz said.

SÃO PAULO, Brazil -- A missing witness to the death of a Roman Catholic bishop during Argentina's military dictatorship was found safe early Thursday after unknown people took him hostage and warned him to back down from testifying in an inquiry into the death, the witness's lawyer said on Thursday. The witness, Víctor Martínez, 52, had been missing since Monday afternoon and the Argentine president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, had ordered the country's security forces to try to find him, fearing he could be killed.

LIEBERMAN--Myra (nee Schonbar), after a long and debilitating illness on April 19, 2011. She is survived by her husband of 62 plus years Emanuel (Mannie) after a three month courtship. Devoted mother of Paula and Dr. Daniel Glicklich. Adored grandmother of David Glicklich. A mourning period will be observed at Paula's home. "Muvvy" will be missed by so many, especially her family to whom she gave so much.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about denials by Goldman Sachs that it had bet against the mortgage market before the housing collapse, misspelled, on second reference, the surname of the author of ''Money and Power: How Goldman Sachs Came to Rule the World.'' As noted on first reference, he is William D. Cohan, not Cohen.

Sometimes an impenetrable dance piece seems a lot more graspable a day later. Fragments cohere and take on a life of their own; strange bits of movement stick in your mind; a spoken phrase resonates and will forever remind you of a particular moment. Perhaps that's what all successful performance does. It pulls you into the specificity of a moment. But although MGM Grand's ''Nut,'' which opened a three-night run at the Kitchen on Wednesday, possesses the requisite impenetrability, it never achieves specificity. Instead, it keeps floating vaguely around ideas that are quite possibly perfectly obvious to MGM's female trio -- Biba Bell, Jmy Leary, Piage Martin -- but annoyingly opaque to the audience.

James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, received some bad news earlier this year. A joint venture controlled by Mitsubishi UFJ Financial in Japan was facing huge losses, which would drag down earnings at the American investment bank. But Mr. Gorman used the situation as leverage, striking a deal that frees Morgan Stanley from paying roughly $800 million a year to Mitsubishi, the costly overhang of a cash infusion made during the financial crisis.

KAMPALA, Uganda -- Riots broke out in downtown Kampala on Thursday as another round of street demonstrations over commodity prices spread after a leading opposition politician was arrested for the third time in two weeks, significantly heightening tensions here. President Yoweri Museveni addressed the nation on Thursday evening, defending his government's action against protesters and the spending decisions that the protesters blame for the rising cost of living.

General Electric, the conglomerate that is closely watched because of its diverse products, reported first-quarter results on Thursday that showed gains in most businesses, including aviation and health care. The results easily topped the forecasts of Wall Street analysts, but its shares ended 2.2 percent lower on Thursday, reflecting concern about a decline in industrial margins, some analysts said.

One Friday morning this month, a security guard showed up at the office of Antonio Calvo, a popular Spanish instructor at Princeton University, to escort him from the building. Friends and former colleagues say Dr. Calvo was abruptly dismissed from his job, and because he lived in the United States on a temporary visa, he faced a compulsory return to his native Spain. Four days later, on April 12, he fatally slashed himself in his Manhattan apartment.
“He picked the chorus line but didn’t attempt to dance.”

Mike Tanier will provide live analysis of the N.F.L. draft, starting Thursday night. He notes that N.F.L. teams talk about drafting quarterbacks or pass rushers, but they may have more pressing needs:Bills An inhabited region to play in. When future archaeologists excavate the Buffalo area, the pottery shards will reveal that the population disappeared in 1974.Dolphins Some retro-chic offensive gimmick to distract us from how boring the rest of the team is. How about the wishbone option?Patriots Anything except comeuppance. They received plenty of that in the last four years.Jets A Cone of Silence that fits snuggly over team headquarters.Ravens They must draft Pittsburgh running back Deon Lewis and Texas Tech receiver Detron Lewis to fill the roles Jamal Lewis and Jermaine Lewis used to play. For the Ravens, the Super Bowl comes with a three-Lewis minimum.Bengals A magic lantern that grants Carson Palmer wishes. With his luck, the genie will emerge and demand the ball.Browns Peyton Hillis must win the Madden 12 video game cover contest because he is the Butler Bulldogs of meaningless fan balloting.Steelers Videographers for Ben Roethlisberger’s bachelor party. BALTIMORE — When it was relayed to Robinson Cano on Saturday that he had the second-highest average at Camden Yards since the ballpark opened in 1992, curiosity overcame him. Wondering who surpassed him, Cano correctly guessed the answer — Ichiro Suzuki of Seattle — and then brushed off his success here.

8:21 p.m. | Updated The producers of Bloggingheads.TV invited me to join Abrahm Lustgarten of ProPublica in a discussion of the drilling boom aimed at the vast deposits of natural gas identified in deep shale layers and other deposits around North America and, increasingly, the world. Lustgarten is a lead reporter and writer in ProPublica’s ongoing Buried Secrets project on environmental problems related to the gas boom.

Although loaded with defensive-line talent, this N.F.L. draft class is not considered strong. It includes a record 56 underclassmen, many of whom are difficult to evaluate because of their limited college experience. There is no clear-cut No. 1 pick because of quarterback Andrew Luck’s decision to remain at Stanford and because of the uncertainty about what the Carolina Panthers will do. There is a dearth of N.F.L.-ready quarterbacks, but Auburn’s Cam Newton may rise to the first overall spot if his extraordinary athletic ability outweighs concerns about how quickly he can learn a pro-style offense and questions about his character. There are so many questions about players projected to be picked in the first round that Charley Casserly, the former Redskins and Texans general manager, said, “There’s a lot of guys that are kind of scary.”
The Times’s Judy Battista is breaking down each team’s weaknesses heading into Thursday’s N.F.L. draft. Read Part 1 on A.F.C. team-by-team needs here.

Celtic and Rangers will renew their ancient rivalry Sunday in Glasgow, days after the revelation that package bombs had been sent to several prominent Celtic supporters and the Celtic manager, Neil Lennon. John F. Burns of the Times checks in with Lennon, who has called the mail bombs “a tipping point,” and with Ranger Manager Walter Smith, who says the Old Firm’s bitter environment has become too toxic to enjoy. Read the full article, and come back here to comment.

SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Caleb Madison is one of the Young Turks of crossword construction, but don’t think for a second that his head is swelled. Just because he was one of the youngest people to have a crossword puzzle published in The New York Times for a very long time doesn’t mean that he doesn’t give back. One of his pet projects is teaching a class in crossword construction at the Jewish Association of Services for the Aged called, appropriately, “Get A Clue!”
Map of areas taken by rebels around Misurata.

My Sunday column looks at human trafficking — but in America. This is a subject I’ve written about a good deal in Cambodia, India, Pakistan and elsewhere abroad, and there’s sometimes a tendency to think that the problem just exists overseas, or just among foreign women smuggled in the the U.S. It’s true that the worst places in the world for forced prostitution maybe Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Cambodia, Burma, and so on. But we also have significant problems in the United States — particularly among home-grown young teenagers — and we don’t have the credibility to address the problems abroad unless we clean up our act at home.

It seemed like all of New York turned out for the April 20, rally in support of the Union. The event, which appropriately took place at Union Square, prompted diarist George Templeton Strong to suggest that “[f]ew assemblages have excelled it in numbers and unanimity.” Men, women and children carried flags or wore cockades, the Stars and Stripes hung from buildings and impromptu renderings of “The Star-Spangled Banner” echoed through the streets. “The city,” observed Strong, “seems to have gone suddenly wild and crazy.”

Following five families over the course of a school year, the documentary “The Bully Project” tackles the issue of bullying and how it affects students, their families, the schools and society at large. The director Lee Hirsch filmed in Georgia, Mississippi and Oklahoma, and was given access to shoot in two schools in Sioux City, Iowa. In this video, he discusses his ideas behind “The Bully Project,” what the process was like filming moments of bullying as they were happening and what he hopes the film will achieve.

Mike Schmidt, a three-time National League most valuable player, is remembered primarily as a slugger. In 18 seasons with the Philadelphia Phillies, he hit 548 home runs and led the league in home runs eight times. But he also had a keen sense of plate discipline (.380 career on-base percentage) and was a stellar third baseman (10 Gold Gloves).

The most eye-catching theme in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs has been the comebacks staged on three consecutive nights by the Sharks (from four goals down to beat the Kings), the Capitals (from three goals down to shock the Rangers) and the Bruins (from three goals down to defeat the Canadiens).

The idea behind Gravy, which has had some dinners for friends of the restaurant and is opening Saturday, is to bring Southern touches to New York food. For Michael Vignola, the executive chef who worked at Michael Jordan’s The Steakhouse NYC, the culinary definition of the South goes beyond hush puppies and gumbo. “There are all the African, Spanish and French influences and all the ingredients involved,” he said. The a la carte menu has Louisiana crawfish gumbo fritters, oysters with chayote mignonette, scallops with honey grits, and cornflake-crusted chicken stuffed with andouille and cheddar. For a more New York approach there are also red snapper served like sashimi, black-eyed pea hummus, Long Island duck with green tomato relish and blackened king crab legs.
Lee Hirsch, the director of “Bully,” discussed his film about the issue of bullying in schools during last year’s Tribeca Film Festival.

BUSINESS An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about debate over a plan to build another cruise ship terminal in Charleston, S.C., misstated the terms of an informal agreement between the city and the State Ports Authority over the frequency of port calls by the ships. It allows 104 calls annually; it does not limit them to two a week.

''The Dark Knight Returns,'' by Frank Miller, is one of the seminal stories of the 1980s. Along with ''Watchmen,'' by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, it introduced a new level of mature storytelling to comic books. And a Dark Knight fan (with deep pockets) now has a chance to own a part of history. The original artwork for the splash page from issue No. 3, which features Batman leaping through the skyline along with his new Robin, Carrie Kelley, the first female to hold that role, is up for bidding at Heritage Auctions. The bid is currently at $100,000. The page will be on view beginning April 27 at the offices of Heritage Auctions and then at the Fletcher-Sinclair, the home of the Ukrainian Institute of America, from May 1 through the auction on May 5. ''The Dark Knight Returns'' depicts a bleak future in which an older Batman comes out of retirement to clean up a Gotham City run amok with a new breed of mutant lowlifes. Adding to the tension: a new cold war is brewing that pushes the world to the edge of nuclear strife. There's also a conflict with Superman, who remains young and is one of the only heroes still active. ''I've always loved that drawing,'' Mr. Miller said when asked about its impending auction. ''Danced around my studio like a fool when I drew it. I hope it finds a good home.''

An article on Page 30, about President Obama's mother, Stanley Ann Dunham, misstates the title of the book from which the article is adapted. It is ''A Singular Woman: The Untold Story of Barack Obama's Mother,'' not ''A Single Woman: The Untold Story of Barack Obama's Mother.''

People waited for hours in frigid temperatures to see it; now museums are jockeying to buy it. It is Christian Marclay's video artwork ''The Clock,'' which features 24 hours of film and television clips woven together to reference, often with a shot of a watch or a clock face, a fictional moment in time that corresponds to the actual minute of the day in which the viewer is watching the work. Six editions of ''The Clock'' were for sale, and all but one will end up in a museum, said Steven Henry, a director of the Paula Cooper Gallery, which represents Mr. Marclay in New York. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art acquired one of the six pieces, the Los Angeles Times reported, and, according to the Art Newspaper, the Tate and the Museum of Modern Art are in negotiations to buy two of the others. Mr. Henry said he couldn't name the other museums because of the ongoing negotiations. Asked if some museums that wanted to buy ''The Clock'' were told no, he said: ''Yes, of course. It's a pretty desirable piece.'' And the price? The Los Angeles Times reported that the Los Angeles County Museum paid less than $500,000. Mr. Henry declined to comment.

The acrostic answers last Sunday, for the acrostic puzzle of April 10, omitted the final two solutions. For letter V, with the clue ''Distinctive features of the primitive reptilian archaeopteryx,'' the answer was ''Feathers.'' For letter W, with the clue ''Admit to being wrong,'' the answer was ''Eat crow.''

New Yorkers will be happy to learn that they can still catch a performance of Bruce Norris's ''Clybourne Park,'' this year's Pulitzer Prize winner for drama, in a much-lauded production in a big, up-scale theater. The only problem is that they'll have to cross the Atlantic Ocean. ''Clybourne Park,'' an acid-washed diptych of a play about American race relations, is playing not on Broadway, but in London's West End, at the venerable Wyndham's Theater, to be exact (where it runs through May 7). Earlier this year, Mr. Norris's stinging satire picked up the Olivier Award for Best Play. That's the British equivalent of the Tony, a prize that ''Clybourne Park'' never had a shot at, since it never made it to Broadway. It opened and closed Off Broadway last year, after a limited run at Playwrights Horizons.

COLTON--Joel, born August 23, 1918, New York City passed away on April 17 in Durham, NC. Specializing in modern and contemporary European history, he taught at Duke University from 1947-1989, chairing the History Department from 1967-1974. The author of numerous articles and books on French history, he became known to generations of students as co-author of the college textbook, A History of the Modern World. Used in over 1000 high schools, colleges and universities, it has been translated into 10 languages. From 1974-1982, he served as Director for Humanities at the Rockefeller Foundation and returned to Duke in 1982 where he taught until his retirement in 1989. He graduated from City College of New York in 1937, receiving his B.A. magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa. He earned his M.A. in history in 1940 and his Ph.D. in 1950, both from Columbia University. During WWII, he was commissioned a military intelligence officer and served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1946. He published his first book in 1951, Compulsory Labor Arbitration in France, 1936-1939, followed by Leon Blum: Humanist in Politics in 1966. For Time-Life, he wrote The Twentieth Century in 1968. His articles and book reviews appeared in the American Historical Review, Journal of Modern History, Yale Review, and New York Times Book Review. His awards include fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, Rockefeller Foundation and National Endowment for the Humanities. In 1979, he was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Other awards included a Townsend Harris Medal as a distinguished alumnus of City College of New York; elected to the Fellows of the Phi Beta Kappa Society; a distinguished teaching award from Duke; honored by the Western Society of French History; and the Enno Kraehe Distinguished Service award from the Southern Historical Association. He taught as a visiting professor at numerous universities around the world and was fluent in 5 languages. He was married in 1942 to Shirley (Baron). She died in 2003. His daughter, Valerie Woodbury of Durham, his son, Kenneth of Montclair, NJ and five grandchildren survive him. The Joel and Shirley Colton Fund for European History has been established in his memory. Please send contributions to: Duke Library, P.O. Box 90197, Durham, N.C. 27708.

INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday about the participation of women in Easter week processions by religious brotherhoods in Seville, Spain, that had once practiced gender-based discrimination misidentified the brotherhood of the women shown. It is Los Javieres, one of the first to end such discrimination, not the Brotherhood of Silence, one of the last to do so.

The restaurant review, such as it was, started with the bagels. ''I think the bagels from the street cart on that corner,'' it said, with an arrow pointing helpfully west across Avenue of the Americas to the breakfast cart Maruf Saidi has run for 11 years, ''are better than the bagels on this corner.''

The order to destroy Stanley, the rolling toolbox that had become a bullpen mascot for the Mets in spring training, came right from the top. Jeff Wilpon, the Mets' chief operating officer, who is in charge of the daily operations of the team, ordered the demolition Thursday as a way to turn around the team's atrocious luck. After watching the Mets lose 12 of 14 games and fall to the worst record in baseball, and with everyone on the team searching for real or symbolic methods to change the fortunes, Wilpon issued a simple decree: ''Get rid of Stanley.''

It was a small leap for Karl Lagerfeld to make from photography to filmmaking, and hardly a surprising one for a designer with a penchant for multitasking. Last year, he created a short film for Chanel's Web site, called ''Remember Now,'' and this year he is following up with a 30-minute movie called ''The Tale of a Fairy.'' On Thursday, Mr. Lagerfeld introduced a series of commercials, which he billed as an ''original film series,'' at a party in Chelsea as part of the Tribeca Film Festival. They will be shown at some of the screenings next week. The American actress Rachel Bilson (most notably of ''The O.C.'') appears in each commercial, portraying a fashion model, an art student and a ballet dancer. For whatever reason, each of those characters ends up eating an ice cream bar. (Obviously, Mr. Lagerfeld was playing against stereotypes.)

KOZTOWSKI--Janet. April 17, 2011. Friends and family mourn Janet's passing after her long battle with lung cancer. She led Human Resources at New York University Libraries for more than a decade and was a loving aunt and dedicated friend to many. Her laughter, her biting wit and her passionate embrace of life will be sorely missed. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will withdraw from performances with the company this spring. In a statement released by the company on Friday, Mr. Stiefel, 38, said he had decided to withdraw so that he could focus on his duties as dean of dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. This is Mr. Stiefel's final year as dean. He is to take on the role of artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in September. ''Leading the U.N.C.S.A. School of Dance through a critical period of transition has required the type of energy and attention that has kept me from properly focusing and physically preparing for my upcoming performances,'' Mr. Stiefel said in the statement. ''I am truly disappointed not to be performing with my colleagues at ABT and for the New York audiences.'' This season he was scheduled to dance opposite Alina Cojocaru in ''Giselle'' in May and Natalia Osipova in ''Coppelia'' in June. Mr. Stiefel, who joined Ballet Theater in 1997, has also withdrawn from American Ballet Theater's tour of Japan in July. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BOSTON -- The two-hour marathon may be the modern-day equivalent of the four-minute mile before Roger Bannister smashed through the barrier in 1954, followed in the years since by thousands of other men. ''The two-hour marathon is the same in that people believed it impossible for so long,'' said Mary Wittenberg, president of New York Road Runners and director of the New York City Marathon. ''And I think in just the last 10 years we've gone from thinking, 'Is it possible?' to, 'It's a matter of when.' ''

9 P.M. (Starz) THE OTHER GUYS (2010) Will Ferrell plays Allen Gamble, and Mark Wahlberg, far right with Mr. Ferrell, is Terry Hoitz, deskbound police detectives who get a chance to work on a real case and try to emulate the gunslinging machismo of the cops they idolize. Eva Mendes portrays Gamble's unlikely wife. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the movie raised ''expectations that it has no real inclination to fulfill.'' The film, directed by Adam McKay, is reminiscent of the kind of verbal riffing and broad slapstick that Mr. McKay presents on the Web site Funnyordie.com, Mr. Scott said. ''A feature film made out of such bits combined with overscaled, unimaginative action sequences will make more money, of course, which is something of a scam in its own right.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Michael Levine, executive director of the Joan Ganz Cooney Center at the Children's Television Workshop, discusses how ''growing up digital'' can be good for youngsters, as long as the Web sites and games involved have clear educational value and connect activities children enjoy in their informal time to the more structured curriculum at school.

JONES--Gordon L. A former director and senior executive of Hearst Corporation, died April 20, 2011, at home in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. He was 85. Jones, who retired from Hearst Corporation in 1995 and served on the Corporation's Board of Directors beginning in 1982, joined Hearst in 1979 and was instrumental in building Hearst's book and business publishing businesses. Most recently, he was a vice president of Hearst Corporation and group head of Hearst Books/Business Publishing. During his tenure, Hearst acquired William Morrow & Company and added it to Avon and Hearst Books to significantly expand its book-publishing activities. After his retirement, Jones served as a consultant to Hearst Corporation. "Gordon was a very important participant in the dramatic growth of Hearst Corporation during the 1980s and 1990s," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. "He was instrumental in building what today are our business media operations. We will indeed miss Gordon." Jones also played a role in the acquisition, from Cox Enterprises, of United Technical Publishing Co., a portfolio of trade publications, technical manuals and marketing data. Diversion magazine and its related activities were also acquired and added to the Group in the mid-1980s. Prior to Hearst, Jones was president of McGraw-Hill Publications Company. During his more than 26 years with McGraw-Hill, he served in numerous positions, including publisher of Electronics magazine; general manager, new products, for BusinessWeek; and senior vice president-marketing of McGraw-Hill Publications. From 1948 to 1950, Jones played professional baseball for the Cleveland Indians. A native of Los Angeles, he received his bachelor's from the University of Southern California. He is survived by his wife, the former Marilyn Holter, and their five children and 14 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 4, 2011, at 11am, at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan in New Canaan, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Jones"s name to The ALS Association or the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

It may not compensate for a total lack of dinosaurs, but the Museum of Modern Art is doing what it can to reach out to more youthful patrons: on Friday, the museum said that Kanye West will perform at its annual Party in the Garden benefit, which takes place this year on May 10 in its Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden. Though Mr. West is perhaps better known for his mercurial temperament and widely hailed albums like ''My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy,'' he gets modern art cred, too, for working with artists like George Condo (who painted the covers for ''Dark Twisted Fantasy'') and Marco Brambilla (who directed the video for Mr. West's ''Power''). You'll have to dig up some serious gold if you want to attend the MoMA performance: tickets are $150 in advance and $250 at the door, while V.I.P. tickets (which include special access to a terrace overlooking the garden) are $500. Sounds like someone's saving up for stegosaurus bones! This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Yet the touring production of ''Black Watch,'' a group portrait of Scottish soldiers in Iraq that was first seen here in 2007, still feels as fresh and raw as the recruits portrayed by its young, open-faced new cast members. These lads of the Black Watch, a centuries-old regiment of the Scottish Highlands, are as spontaneously foul-mouthed, exuberant, angry and frightened as they were four years ago. And stationed once again at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn, they are more likely than ever to break your heart.

NATIONAL An article on Friday about the campaign fund-raising efforts of freshman Republicans in Congress misstated the amount of cash on hand that Representative Charles Boustany, a Republican of Louisiana, reported as of March 31. It was $694,000 -- not $561,000, which was the amount he reported as of Dec. 31, 2010.

An article on Friday about a deal between Morgan Stanley and Mitsubishi UFJ misstated the amount of Morgan that the Japanese bank will own when the transaction is completed. It is roughly 22 percent, not 10 percent.

Prosecutors unexpectedly dropped charges on Friday against a prominent lawyer whose case had drawn nationwide attention. Li Zhuang, 50, a criminal lawyer from Beijing, went on trial Tuesday in Chongqing, accused of inciting a client to falsify evidence. He had been convicted and jailed on similar charges stemming from his defense in 2009 of a convicted gangster. On Friday, however, the court dropped the new charges, saying it lacked evidence. Legal activists had said Mr. Li had been persecuted for defending unpopular clients.

FRONT PAGE Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the poor equipment and training of rebel forces in Libya misstated a problem with the PKT machine gun, which many rebels carry like an infantry fighter's weapon even though it has no manual trigger and is designed to be mounted on a tank and fired electronically by a crew member inside. As explained later in the article, the PKT can be fired manually by releasing a bolt mechanism; it is not the case that ''it cannot be fired.''

Few of us would enjoy parsing the language in our homeowner insurance policies. But Daniel Schwarcz, an associate professor at the University of Minnesota Law School, has spent a lot of time doing just that -- and what he has found is troubling for consumers. Professor Schwarcz found that the wording used in homeowner insurance policies can vary widely among insurers, despite the common belief that such contracts are uniform throughout the industry. And some wording is better for homeowners than others.
An article on Thursday about entrepreneurs who make physical products misstated the location of Peel, a start-up company that makes an iPhone accessory. It is in Santa Clara, Calif., not San Diego.
MAGAZINE An article on Page 24, about the actress Ellen Barkin, misstates the title of a book by Randy Shilts. It is ''And the Band Played On,'' not ''As the Band Played On.''

FREEDMAN--Alfred M. The Board and Staff of the Center for Comprehensive Health Practice are greatly saddened by the recent passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Alfred Freedman. He was a founding Director of our Center and remained active on the Board until his death. We extend our condolences to the Freedman family. Dr. Freedman was a pioneer of the community mental health movement on a national level. His 25 years on our Board also reflect his strong commitment to interdisciplinary health care and to helping those most in need. We will miss his ideas, his loyalty, and his passion for doing the right thing. Roger Frisch, Chairman David Hutson, CEO Dr. Deborah Brotman, Medical Director

Kate Whoriskey, picked by Bartlett Sher to succeed him as artistic director of Intiman Theater in Seattle, is parting ways with that beleaguered institution, at least for now. Faced with a cash crisis, the Intiman board voted last weekend to cancel the rest of the season, which started just last month, and to lay off the theater's staff. While the board hopes to reopen Intiman next year, Ms. Whoriskey said in a telephone interview that she is returning this weekend to New York, where she has an apartment, and will resume her freelance directing career. ''I've never been in a position where I've had to tell so many people that they don't have work, and it's very hard,'' she said. As to whether she would return to Intiman, she said that if the board reached a point where they wanted to rehire her, ''I would be open to a conversation.'' The president of Intiman's board, Bruce Bradburn, said that the board was trying to regroup for now and didn't know what Ms. Whoriskey's future role would be. He said that she had offered various kinds of assistance in the efforts to rethink Intiman's business model, including the possibility of holding a public discussion that she would participate in. ''And of course if she's back freelance directing again, we certainly would like to have her back to do a play,'' he added. ''We've just got to figure out over the next six months where we're going.''Susan Trapnell, a consultant who is working with the board, said that it had a lot of work to do before they could hire Ms. Whoriskey, or anyone else, to run Intiman. ''They have to be 100 percent behind their artist,'' she said. ''There's no reason for Kate right now to sacrifice a career to bringing this theater back, unless she knows the theater is trying to come back or sees a way to come back'' in a form that ''can serve her vision.''

BROWN--Gene A.,age 74 of Pelham Manor, NY passed away peacefully with his loving wife at his side on April 20, 2011. He was born on February 8, 1937 in Bossier, Louisiana to Johnnie L. and Rodessa Jackson Brown. On July 1, 1975, he married Frances A. Gautieri in New York City. He received a Bachelor of Science Degree from Texas Southern University. After graduation he served in the US Army from 1960 to 1962. Gene came to New York City with the Domestic Peace Corps and worked at Harlem Hospital Center, Division of Child Psychiatry, assigned to the innovative Harlem Center for Child Study. Continuing his education, he attended Stony Brook University where he received a Master of Social Work Degree. He began his career as a Social Worker at the Fordham Tremont Community Mental Health Center. He later attended John Jay College of Criminal Justice receiving a Master of Public Administration Degree. He then began work at the New York State Division for Youth in the Long Term Treatment Unit at Bronx Psychiatric Center and later became a Facility Director for many years; following retirement from State service he transitioned to private voluntary Child Welfare agencies including Leake & Watts Children Services where he was the Administrator of Woodfield Cottage in Valhalla, NY and later Director of Residential Services at the main campus. Gene was a member of the Juvenile Detention Association of New York State and the Westchester Council on Crime and Delinquency. He attended the Union Baptist Church in New Rochelle. He is survived by his wife Frances Gautieri Brown of Pelham Manor, a brother, Johnnie (Donella) Brown, his aunt Lee Anna Ali and sisters-in-law; Helen Brown and Barbara Gautieri. Also surviving are his nieces and nephews; Ricky (Vicky) Brown, Debra Brown, Janet (Eric) Johnson, Dona Morgan, Deirdre (John Wilson) Gautieri and Gabrielle Gautieri, several grandnieces and grandnephews, many cousins and a host of dear friends. Gene will be remembered as a mentor and friend to many for whom he provided invaluable support and guidance. Predeceased by his parents, step-father, Nathan Salone, three brothers; Booker Brown, Lee Van Brown and Calvin Salone. Visitation is Monday, April 25th, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Yannantuono Burr Davis Sharpe Funeral Home, 584 Gramatan Ave., Mount Vernon, NY. A Funeral Service will be held on Tuesday, April 26th at the Funeral Home, 10:30am. Interment will follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Westchester Council on Crime and Delinquency, P.O. Box 3300, Mount Vernon, NY; Calvary at Home Hospice Program, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461, or the Union Baptist Church "Rebuilding Fund", New Rochelle, NY.

HANLEY--Charles E. Beloved and best friend to Kevin P and Joan D Wait and family. Patriarch of the Hanley Family of Brookville and Windham, New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Three generations of Hanley's and Waits have formed a unique bond of friendship, love and loyalty with one another. Holy Child, Nassau CC, Brookville, Windham, and Jackson Hole are special places and times where the bonds between our families were cemented together. Uncle Charlie was a compassionate and patient man who always had a kind word and helping hand to all. A lifelong traveler with his bride Jane, Uncle Charlie enjoyed exploring and learning. His loyalty to the New York Islanders and Mets ran deep despite long draughts of winning. Uncle Charlie's magic was his smile and laugh that made everyone feel his warmth. Through the ups and downs of life, Uncle Charlie's deep faith in God, family, and friends provided a steady compass to all around him. His love and rock solid friendship to the Wait Family, will never be forgotten. God Bless Uncle Charlie and Go Islanders! Jarett, Younghee, Unjo and Uno Wait

Los Angeles regained its home-court advantage with a victory against host New Orleans in Game 3 of their first-round playoff series, but hardly looked like the well- oiled machine that had rolled to the past three N.B.A. finals. A Hummer leaking transmis- sion fluid is more like it. Kobe Bryant led the Lakers with 30 points on 10-of-20 shoot- ing and Pau Gasol added 17 points and 10 rebounds as the Lakers took a 2-1 lead in the best- of-seven series, which resumes Sunday at New Orleans Arena. Lakers Coach Phil Jackson had promised that Bryant would take more than the 10 shots he tried in a 9-point victory in Game 2 in Los Angeles when he concentrated on containing the Hornets' Chris Paul. And so it was. After 10 min- utes, Bryant had 10 points and finished the first half with 11 shots. KAREN CROUSE

FISH--Florence Bette, on April 20 in Folsom, California. Widow of the late Herman Lewis Fish, and the youngest child of Joseph Rabinowitz and Mary Lesitzky, Florence was born in San Francisco on December 1, 1918. After graduating from James Monroe High School in 1936, Florence worked for West Virginia Glass, and subsequently became the New York representative for the Bartlett-Collins Company, for whom she was consistently salesman of the year. She completed an undergraduate degree from Queens College magna cum laude, and attended the graduate program in psychology at St. John's University. After retirement, Florence and Herman moved to San Francisco in 1987 where they were members of Temple Emanuel. Florence was a volunteer for the San Francisco Opera and Ballet, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, and Haas Lillienthal House. Florence is survived by her children, Victoria Fisch of Folsom, California, and Kenneth Fish of Urbana, Maryland, her grandchildren, Sterling, Sheridan, and Skye Reed, Tatiana Fish, and a nephew, Ernest Mendeloff. A memorial will be held in San Francisco.

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about the fraud conviction of Lee B. Farkas, a mortgage lender, misspelled part of the name of his firm. It is Taylor Bean & Whitaker, not Whittaker.

An article on April 9 about statements by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that some American troops could stay in Iraq for years misstated the party responsible for the security of a camp there for Iranian dissidents who said they had been attacked by Iraqi security forces. It is the Iraqis, not the American military, which transferred responsibility for the camp in January 2009.

A headline on Thursday with an article about the discovery by a group of scientists that people can be classified by the bacteria in their digestive systems misstated the conclusions of the researchers. They reported finding three ecosystems, each involving a multitude of bacteria species, in the human gut -- not just three types of bacteria.

These three documents were designed to guide military intelligence interrogators and analysts at Guantanamo as they attempted to assess what detainees had done in the past and what risk they might pose in the future. The “Assessment of Afghanistan Travels” — which lists the online encyclopedia Wikipedia as one source — offers background on Afghanistan and Islam and examples of how some detainees may have been trained to resist interrogation. The two “Threat Matrix” documents were aids to gauging whether a prisoner, on release, might pose a a high, medium or low risk to American interests.

It would  be easy to mistake April 30 in Prague for a mad, mistimed Halloween, or perhaps even a return to the Middle Ages. Witches cackle through the parks, and effigies are burned atop blazing pyres. But the annual Carodejnice, or Witches’ Night, is a far less sinister tradition than you might think, one rooted in pagan rituals. Burning the effigy witch means goodbye to winter, and the costumed festivities that take place in Prague’s parks are a frantic welcome to spring, featuring concerts, children’s games, and, of course, lots of beer and sausages. Here is a selection.

ABRAMSON--Abraham, D.D.S.,96, on April 21, 2011 in Montclair, NJ. Survived by his four loving children, David Abramson, Diane and Gary Greenwald, James Abramson and Nelia Sellers, Carl and Adrienne Abramson, nine grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, sisters Elaine Elworth and Rose Feiman, married 67 years to his beloved Lillian until her death in 2004. A proud graduate of the combined NYU undergradute-dental school program, he also served in the WWII Army Dental Corps. He was the neighborhood dentist extraordinaire, who loved to tinker and invent new uses for found items. Known for his dry wit, sense of humor and enjoyment of all things intellectual, he truly will be missed. Services will be held Wednesday, April 27 at 10:30am at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ.

''Airline passengers have a right to be treated fairly.'' Ray LaHood, the transportation secretary, in announcing a new set of passenger protections aimed primarily at travelers' growing frustration over airline fees. ''Apple should know better than to track iPhone users in this way.'' Marc Rotenberg, executive director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center. Apple faced questions about the security of its iPhone and iPad after a report that the devices regularly record their locations in a hidden file.

LONDON -- Outwardly, at least, this week's royal pageant will bear a strong resemblance to the last of the great royal weddings, when Prince Charles married Lady Diana Spencer in 1981. Now, as then, a tall, slim young man in a crisply tailored military uniform will wed a bride so striking she has launched 10,000 magazine covers, offering to Britain and the world the promise of a monarchy alluringly renewed. This time, as last, the congregation will be led by an assembly of the world's crowned heads, with a worldwide television audience of tens of millions. Once again, cheering crowds in central London will greet the newlyweds as a gilded carriage conveys them from their vows to a reception at Buckingham Palace.

10 P.M. (HBO) TREME The reconstruction of New Orleans in the wake of Hurricane Katrina continues, and so does the city's jazz, as this series created by David Simon and Eric Overmyer, of ''The Wire'' fame, begins a second season, with the music and its makers venturing north to the clubs and restaurants of New York City. But first the story resumes in New Orleans as the trombonist Antoine (Wendell Pierce, above, with Phyllis Montana-Leblanc) contemplates a move, while his ex, LaDonna (Khandi Alexander), resists one; the D. J. Davis (Steve Zahn) expands in new directions personally and professionally, with the help of the violinist Annie Tee (Lucia Micarelli); the Indian chief Albert (Clarke Peters) is forced out of his temporary residence; and the lawyer Toni (Melissa Leo), a recent widow, worries about the emotional distance of her daughter, Sofia (India Ennenga), after her father's suicide. Meanwhile, in New York, Albert's son, the trumpeter Delmond (Rob Brown), has just released his new album. And the chef Janette (Kim Dickens), in a story line given a jolt of reality by Anthony Bourdain, who has joined the show's writing staff this season, lands a job in the kitchen of a culinary tyrant whose antics might make even Gordon Ramsay tremble. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Mr. Wallace interviews Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, an independent, about President Obama, the federal budget crisis, immigration reform and his own political future.
