YOUNG--Maria, passed away on Palm Sunday, April 17, 2011. Maria was the beloved mother of Michael, Kevin, and Ryan, loving daughter of Helen Lombardi and the late Louis Lombardi, caring sister of Joseph Lombardi, sister-in-law to Regina Lombardi, loving Aunt of Katherine and Chloe Lombardi, and devoted friend to those extraordinary people who know who they are. Maria graduated Boston College and received her Masters in Education from NYU. An accomplished Special Education teacher, Maria gave up her teaching career for the greatest love of her life, being mother to Michael, Kevin and Ryan. She understood a parent shows their love by paying attention to the smallest details, and always being there, whether at school or on the Lacrosse field. The consummate mother, Maria raised her sons in Manhasset to be fine young men. Maria asked no less of those she loved, than that they live life to the fullest and be the best they could be. Whether enjoying summer vacations in Montauk with her sons, planning holiday gatherings, traveling to Italy with her close friend Suzanne, or decorating with Nancy, Maria knew how to be in the moment and enjoy life to the fullest. She lived and taught a profound understanding of the importance of Family, Faith, and Friendship, and this is the legacy she gives to her sons, and all of us. She will be loved and remembered always. Maria's Mass will be Monday, April 25th, at 1pm, at St. Mary's Church, at 1300 Northern Boulevard Manhasset, NY 11030. For information regarding memorial contributions, please see www.Fairchildsons.com obituaries.

BERNSTEIN--Stanley H.,M.D., FACP, FACC. September 10, 1924--April 21, 2011. In his 86th year, Stanley Bernstein died early in the morning on April 21 at his home in Hollywood, Florida. One of three children born to Hannah Bistrong and Louis Bernstein of Brooklyn, he was a graduate of William and Mary and of the New York University School of Medicine. He served as a U.S. Navy Corpsman during World War II and was recalled to duty as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War. A Fellow of both the American College of Physicians and of the American College of Cardiology, Stanley was also a Diplomate of the American Board of Internal Medicine and of the American Board of Quality Assurance and Utilization Review Physicians. He served as an Attending Physician at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore University Hospital (in the New York City area), and as a Visiting Physician at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences in New Delhi and at the Hebrew University Hadassah Medical School in Jerusalem. In the late 1960s, Stanley pursued his passion for academic medicine by taking up faculty appointment at the new School of Medicine of the University of Connecticut and assuming duties as the Chief of Medicine at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Hartford. Returning to private practice some years later, he was also a clinical faculty member of the University of Miami School of Medicine and, for a time, Chief of Medicine and Chief of Staff at Humana Hospital Biscayne. Late in his active career, Stanley was a Trustee of the Aventura Medical Center. A fine athlete, he played golf exceptionally well something which gave him much joy and several wonderful friends. Stanley leaves many loved ones, including his cherished wife of 35 years, Daria; his siblings Marilyn and Walter (both of New York City); his children Carol and Janet (both of New York City), Victoria (Portland, CT), and Michael (New Orleans); and his grandchildren Samantha (New York City), Claire (Boulder, CO), and Eleanor (New Orleans). Stanley had a special bond with his niece Carly (Auburn, AL) and brother-in-law Fred (Hollywood, FL). Stanley's family are very grateful to the exceptional staff of the Vitas Hospice. In lieu of flowers, please direct donations in Stanley's memory to the New York University School of Medicine, the St. Vincent De Paul Society at the Little Flower Catholic Church (Hollywood, FL), or a favorite charity. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, April 26, at Fred Hunter's funeral home, 6301 Taft St., Hollywood, FL (10am gathering of friends; 11am service). Husband, Father, Grandfather, Brother, Uncle, Comrade, Mensch we will always love you, celebrate you, remember you.

BRANDT--Rheda S.,Of Sag Harbor, NY, passed away March 26, 2011. The cause was pancreatic cancer. Born in Richmond, VA, Ms. Brandt resided in Manhattan as of the early 1980's. An interior designer and agent of artist-made furniture, she founded the firm Grand Design. For the past 15 years, Ms. Brandt was a Senior Vice President in residential sales for Sotheby's. She was a member of The National Arts Club of Gramercy Park. Ms. Brandt is survived by her daughters Laura Brandt, Susan Brandt, Vanessa Wensing and by her sister Elaine Ackman. A passionate supporter of animal rescue, Ms. Brandt initiated the non-profit Mother's Comfort Project, by which volunteers bring homemade beds to animals in shelters. Contributions in her memory may be made to the project at: http://www.rational-animal.org

MULE'--Mary J.,daughter of Girolamo and Anita Mule', sister of Michael Mule' (deceased), and survived by her sister Victoria (Mule') Principe, passed away on April 19, 2011 one month short of her 89th birthday. She served on the Board of the Queens County Women's Bar Association in the 1950's, specialized in securities law as a program attorney with the New York Office of the Practising Law Institute in the 1970's, and was later recruited by the Law Journal Seminars-Press where she served as President. A native of New York with a residence in Jupiter, Florida, Mary was a lover of the performing arts, a world traveler, and an American Civil War enthusiast. A viewing will be held April 26, 9am, Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, followed by a Mass at 11am at St. Stephen's of Hungary Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Historical Society.

THE Coach duffel bag, which was designed in the era of Bonnie Cashin, is just the sort of no-logo, no-hardware, no-nonsense bag that no one is making anymore. Not even Coach, which saw fit to put this workhorse out to pasture in 1997. But starting June 15, Net-a-Porter is bringing back the duffel, as well as four other seminal styles from the 1970s, as the Coach Classics collection. Fans of the original will notice only one minor adjustment: an ad for Neiman Marcus in The Dallas Morning News from the '70s listed the duffel for $36. This summer it will set you back $398. ALIX BROWNE

The schoolhouse at the end of the world is a simple affair. Made of concrete and painted gray, it bears the white star of the Central Asia Institute, the nonprofit group co-founded by Greg Mortenson. The group says it has built more than 170 schools in Pakistan and Afghanistan. This one stands at 12,480 feet in Bozai Gumbaz, a corner of northeastern Afghanistan that is cold, rocky and barren. The clear waters of the Wakhan River flow from a nearby glacier. The school is ringed by brown lunar peaks on a wind-swept plateau, the Little Pamir, the most remote stretch of land in a remote nation. One afternoon last August, after a light snowfall, I walked through the small building. It had no desks and chairs. Wooden planks and sawdust lay on the floor. The schoolhouse, completed in 2009 and the centerpiece of Mr. Mortenson's second book, ''Stones Into Schools,'' had never been used.

MAGAZINE An article on April 10 about Middle School 223 in the Bronx misstated the reasons the school does not qualify for some state financing earmarked for poorly performing schools. It does not meet some of New York State's criteria for failing schools and it is relatively successful on state tests and other measures. It is not because of the school's report card from New York City. The article also omitted an attribution for the increases in percentages of students at or above grade levels in math and English from 2006 to 2010. Those figures came from the New York City Department of Education, which did its own analysis of state testing data using 2010 proficiency levels for 2006 test scores. (Without that adjustment, the percentage of proficient learners in both math and English actually dropped from 2006 to 2010.)

A review on April 3 about ''Bismarck: A Life,'' by Jonathan Steinberg, misstated the political philosophy that, until Bismarck appeared on the scene in 19th-century Prussia, had generally been assumed to represent the political opposite of nationalism. It was conservativism, not liberalism. (Liberalism and nationalism went hand in hand in much of Europe for much of the century.)
Classical Anthony Tommasini

FRIEDMAN--Oscar H. M.D.,departed this life on his 99th birthday April 19, 2011 in New York, NY. Born in New York on April 19, 1912, son of Max Friedman and Blanche Rose Rabinowitz Friedman. Dr. Friedman was a graduate of Columbia University and Baylor University College of Medicine where he received his M.D. in 1936, completed his internship in 1938, and finished his residency in 1939. A member of international medical fraternity Phi Delta Epsilon, he served three years in the U.S. Army and completed a residency program at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in the Bronx. In 1946, he became Associate Attending Physician for Thoracic Disease at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. A year later, he was appointed Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine at Mount Sinai. After a successful career specializing in pulmonary disorders, Dr. Friedman retired in 1988. After the war Dr. Friedman set aside time to serve as a medical consultant to assist returning veterans. His stepdaughters Helen Seplowitz of Stamford, CT and Anita Karo of Langhorne, PA, grandsons Kevin and Eric Seplowitz and families and cousins including Gertrude Lang, Carl Danson, Peter Lang, Jo Lang and their families survive him. His wife of 25 years, Frances Karo Friedman, predeceased him in 2005. Dr. Friedman described her as "the light of my life, and in every sense of the word, an angel liberal, kind, and thoughtful." Together the Friedman's traveled extensively in Israel, Russia, China, Scandinavia, England, and France. They resided in New York and Lauderhill, Florida for many years. Dr. Friedman shared generously with a significant number of charities including Woods School in Langhorne, PA; Rabbi Jacob Joseph School; Congregation Agudath Sholom; United Jewish Federation; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital; Mount Sinai Medical Center, where he was an Alumni Life Member; and Baylor College of Medicine, where he was a proud member of the Jaworski Society and had established the Frances K. Friedman and Oscar Friedman, M.D. '36 Endowed Fund for Pulmonary Disorders. Charitable contributions in Dr. Friedman's memory may be made to any of these fine charities.

The most eye-catching theme in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs has been the comebacks staged on three consecutive nights by the Sharks (from four goals down to beat the Kings), the Capitals (from three goals down to shock the Rangers) and the Bruins (from three goals down to defeat the Canadiens). But through the 35 games played through Friday, teams have not posted comeback victories as frequently as they have in past postseasons. The statistics show that teams scoring the first goal are more likely to win the game than at any time since the 2004-5 lockout, when the N.H.L. instituted new rules and tighter enforcement to benefit offense - or indeed in any playoff year since the turn of the millennium.

Although loaded with defensive-line talent, this N.F.L. draft class is not considered strong. It includes a record 56 underclassmen, many of whom are difficult to evaluate because of their limited college experience. There is no clear-cut No. 1 pick because of quarterback Andrew Luck's decision to remain at Stanford and because of the uncertainty about what the Carolina Panthers will do. There is a dearth of N.F.L.-ready quarterbacks, but Auburn's Cam Newton may rise to the first overall spot if his extraordinary athletic ability outweighs concerns about how quickly he can learn a pro-style offense and questions about his character. There are so many questions about players projected to be picked in the first round that Charley Casserly, the former Redskins and Texans general manager, said, ''There's a lot of guys that are kind of scary.'' ''Quarterback is the highlight of the draft because you've got so many teams that would have filled quarterback needs in the off-season,'' Casserly said. ''Now that they don't have it, do they become more aggressive trading up? I don't see the conviction by people with these quarterbacks.''

I SOMETIMES think there's a cult of Zanini -- Marco Zanini, the creative director at Rochas. He's someone with a solid base of knowledge, a light hand with details and an ego that rarely intrudes. We met in 2008, when he took over Halston. Hardly anyone knew him; he had been Donatella Versace's assistant for many years. But Mr. Zanini brought a clean vitality to Halston, especially to the day clothes. That show remains a favorite of mine -- and it was his only Halston collection, because within a few months he and the owners parted ways. Then he got the gig at Rochas, and he's taken a completely different approach with the sporty French label. Mr. Zanini was in New York recently and we chatted about the business, Dior's next move -- what everybody is talking about. Q. Do you design in Milan?

An article last Sunday about cheating misstated part of the jury's verdict in the Barry Bonds trial. The jury could not reach a verdict on charges that Bonds had lied about using performance-enhancing drugs, and the judge declared a mistrial; the jury did not clear Bonds of those charges.

Solo travelers going on expeditions often must pay additional fees that can significantly increase the cost of a trip. But the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent has a new solo-savings initiative that reduces, and in some cases waives, extra expenses for those hitting the road on their own. About 10 percent of Abercrombie & Kent's bookings last year came from those traveling alone, the company said. ''Solo travelers have been penalized in the past with higher fees, but we wanted to present them with value,'' said Bob Simpson, the company's vice president of business development in the United States.

BECK--Marlene C. Born in Cleveland, OH, April 7, 1941, past Vice President of Elizabeth Arden and icon of the industry passed from this life early Wednesday morning, April 13th, 2011. Her goal in life was the beautification of women. Marlene lived life to the fullest with a large dose of wonderful humor. She is survived by her brother and sister-in-law, Robert and Jeanetta Reed, her daughter and son-in-law, Christina and Mark Fitzsimmons and their sons, Lawson and Griffin. She will be greatly missed by her closest friends Carmen, Joyce, Nick, and Martha, and so many others too numerous to mention.

VALE--Peter Roth. Age 74, a life-long resident of Manhattan, NY, died on April 14, 2011. He was owner and CEO of Valmont, Inc., New York, NY for 40 years retiring in 2010. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor (nee Pavlo), two sons, Anthony Quincy Vale and Nicholas Lance Vale, a sister, Pamela Vale Fletcher, and three grandchildren, Hanover Madison Vale, Maxwell Hitchcock Vale, and Alexandra Rollins Vale. Dear nephew of Virginia Vale, and cousin of Lawrence Vale, Peter Vale, Mira Vale, Aaron Vale, Jonathan Vale, and Jeremy Vale. He attended Ethical Culture Schools, Horace Mann, Trinity School, and was a graduate of Brown University. He enjoyed using his clubs and made many good friends through them. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club for over 50 years, belonged to the Yale Club, and Westchester Country Club. He sponsored a child through World Vision on a monthly basis for more than 10 years. The family is holding a celebration of his life service and reception at the New York Athletic Club on May 15 from 3:00pm to 6:00pm. The family will disperse his ashes in Estoril, Portugal, where Peter lived with his family for five years, and where his son, Nick, was born. In lieu of flowers, the family is accepting donations for the International YMCA, 5 West 63rd Street, New York, NY, 10023.

Here's a sampling of reader responses to Holland Cotter's column on non-Western art and the study of its history. ''By constructing this binary, of traditional versus contemporary, Mr. Cotter doesn't include the intermediary period of modern. This is an area of non-Western art that would help us understand how artists of India, China, Japan, the African nations and others negotiated between their traditions and the facts of decolonization, looting, global art worlds and styles. How can American museums claim to be advancing contemporary non-Western art without first helping us understand that crucial period, from the 1920s to the 1970s, when non-Western artists bridged the gap between tradition and contemporary through their own manifestos, group shows and writings?''

The biggest surprise that most travelers face is a flight delay. But American Express Travel is offering a new twist that promises to introduce some spontaneity: it chooses destinations for you, and shares the details later. The service, called Nextpedition, started this month. Users answer a series of multiple-choice questions to determine their travel style. The results sort travelers into categories like Adrenalistas (outdoor lovers) and Tasteblazers (foodies). Using these profiles, American Express agents design a seven-day, dual-destination trip.

We would love to take day trips from there, and would consider an overnight trip to somewhere amazing. We are in our mid-30s, into art history and love to ride bikes. Do you have any suggestions?
A report last Sunday about the marriage of Sarah Rapawy and Roberto Gonzalez misstated the surname of the bridegroom at one point. He is Mr. Gonzalez, not Mr. Rodriguez.

JONES--Gordon L. A former director and senior executive of Hearst Corporation, died April 20, 2011, at home in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. He was 85. Jones, who retired from Hearst Corporation in 1995 and served on the Corporation's Board of Directors beginning in 1982, joined Hearst in 1979 and was instrumental in building Hearst's book and business publishing businesses. Most recently, he was a vice president of Hearst Corporation and group head of Hearst Books/Business Publishing. During his tenure, Hearst acquired William Morrow & Company and added it to Avon and Hearst Books to significantly expand its book-publishing activities. After his retirement, Jones served as a consultant to Hearst Corporation. "Gordon was a very important participant in the dramatic growth of Hearst Corporation during the 1980s and 1990s," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. "He was instrumental in building what today are our business media operations. We will indeed miss Gordon." Jones also played a role in the acquisition, from Cox Enterprises, of United Technical Publishing Co., a portfolio of trade publications, technical manuals and marketing data. Diversion magazine and its related activities were also acquired and added to the Group in the mid-1980s. Prior to Hearst, Jones was president of McGraw-Hill Publications Company. During his more than 26 years with McGraw-Hill, he served in numerous positions, including publisher of Electronics magazine; general manager, new products, for BusinessWeek; and senior vice president-marketing of McGraw-Hill Publications. From 1948 to 1950, Jones played professional baseball for the Cleveland Indians. A native of Los Angeles, he received his bachelor's from the University of Southern California. He is survived by his wife, the former Marilyn Holter, and their five children and 14 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 4, 2011, at 11am, at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan in New Canaan, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Jones"s name to The ALS Association or the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

SCHOONOVER--Jean Way, pioneer and leader among women in public relations and former president of the YWCA of Greater New York, died on April 3rd at her home in Manhattan. She was 90. Former President of Dudley-Anderson-Yutzy Public Relations and later President of the Public Relations Division of Ogilvy & Mather, she was the winner of many awards for her work. She is survived by her three loving children, Katherine Schoonover of New York City, Daniel Schoonover of Kinderhook, NY, and James Schoonover of White Bear Lake, MN, four grandchildren, Abigail Straus, John, Kevin, and Derek Schoonover, as well as her loving sister and business partner, Barbara Way Hunter of Walpole, NH. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Mark's in-the-Bowery, 2nd Ave. and 10th St. on Saturday April 30th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you consider a contribution to the Way Family Scholarship Fund at Cornell University or to the YWCA of Greater New York.

BINDER--Muriel, on April 22, 2011. Loving and beloved wife of the late David Binder. Treasured mother of Sara Binder Hamilton and Ellen Dubner. Cherished mother-in-law of Stephen J. Dubner. Adoring and adored grandmother of Ethan, Annie, Solomon and Anya. Service on Sunday, April 24 at 10:00am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th. Donations may be made in her memory to The Department of Pediatric Rheumatology at Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital, 3959 Broadway, New York City, Attention: Lisa Imundo, MD.

KOZTOWSKI--Janet. April 17, 2011. Friends and family mourn Janet's passing after her long battle with lung cancer. She led Human Resources at New York University Libraries for more than a decade and was a loving aunt and dedicated friend to many. Her laughter, her biting wit and her passionate embrace of life will be sorely missed. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

Italy is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Risorgimento, the unification of the former patchwork of states up and down the peninsula. Cities are home to a bevy of cultural events -- dinners, concerts, museum shows in Turin; a scholarly walk in Rome -- but a couple of hotels on the Amalfi coast are also celebrating with deals for travelers.
While traditions have changed greatly, flashes of the old Easter season remain: chocolate- shop windows, carousel rides, balloons and a

DEPKE--John E.,44, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, on April 21, 2011. Born Cleveland, OH, partner at international law firm DLA Piper, NYC. Beloved husband of Deirdre Depke. Loving son of Nancy and the late John Depke. Dear brother of Deidre and Meighan Depke and Marianne McComb. Also survived by nephews John, Kyle and Will and nieces Agnes and Frances. Memorial mass St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City, Tuesday, April 26, 2011, 11am. Donations to The Melanoma Research Foundation are appreciated.

EARLY one evening in Bogotá, Colombia, late last year, a tall brunette in her mid-20s, with a Joan Jett shag and in heels, walked with her girlfriends along the desolate streets of La Candelaria, the city's historic neighborhood. A decade ago, when this country was the kidnapping capital of the world, strolling anywhere after dark would have been reckless. But these young women walked with ease, pausing to share text messages and giggle as they made their way to La Dayliciosa, part dance party, part rock show and part art opening. The event, which began in 2007 as a convergence of disparate D.J. nights, has lately emerged as the pre-eminent social event of this once-prohibitively perilous city's burgeoning hipster culture.

THIS is a love story. It began on a hot summer night in Santa Barbara, Calif., when Tamara Langman helped kill the yellow-eyed demon known as Prince Malchezaar. She was logged into World of Warcraft, the multiplayer fantasy game, and her avatar -- Arixi Fizzlebolt, a busty gnome with three blond pigtails -- had also managed to pique the interest of John Bentley, a k a Weulfgar McDoal. A note to the uninitiated: World of Warcraft is a vast online game where monsters are meant to be vanquished, but it is also a social networking experience. When players aren't battling monsters, their avatars are exploring fantastical landscapes (lush jungles, snowy forests, misty beaches), where they can meet and gab via the game's instant message feature, or through voice communication software.

AN unlikely hybrid of curator, hoarder, historian and D.I.Y.-er, extreme hobbyists do not just accumulate memorabilia; they define their existence by it. Occasionally, they overdo it. ''You see them all the time, people with this compulsion to collect,'' says Philip Weiss, the owner of Philip Weiss Auctions on Long Island and a frequent appraiser on the ''Antiques Roadshow'' circuit. He should know: by age 8, he was already appraising other people's stamp collections while honing his own. The essence of the extreme hobbyist is a variable mix of obsession, acquisitiveness and nostalgia, said Allan Spitz, the owner of the Red Caboose, the quirky Midtown Manhattan mecca for discriminating model-builders. ''We are the hedgehogs of the universe,'' he says. ''We know everything about something very small in the big scheme of things.'' The five hands-on hobbyists here exemplify the breed. The intensity of their passion is exceeded only by the scope of their collections. ROBIN FINN

ANDY WARHOL was always a tech nerd. He was obsessed with his tape recorder (he called it his ''wife'') and was rarely seen without his headphones on. Think of how bananas he'd go over the iPhone and all its paraphernalia. Which is why the Andy Warhol Foundation agreed to lend his work to a new series of iPhone and iPad cases, sleeves and bags from Incase. For the first of four, they've chosen the iconic 1966 banana that Mr. Warhol created for the Velvet Underground's self-titled album as well as the artist's camouflage print. Speaking of the latter, what could be more Warhol than neon camouflage? Texting Nicki Minaj. From $49.95 at goincase.com. CATOR SPARKS

BERMAN--Stanley, passed away on Sunday, February 27, 2011. The family will be receiving friends on Monday, May 2 at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street from 5:30 to 7:30pm to honor his memory and celebrate his life.
RUBINSTEIN--Amy. Amy, you were the embodiment of the word friend. We were blessed to know and love you. Susan and Joel Abrahams and Family

GELLER--Daniel 91, died on April 18 in Chapel Hill, NC. Husband for 65 years of Suzanne; father of Jeffrey (Merle Brandzel), Bradley, Matthew (Diana Kingsley); grandfather of Noah, Jesse, Bram, Jamarie, Aubree, Luke. A 1940 graduate of UNC, he served four years in the Army during WWII, discharged as a Captain. He spent his working years in New York at Andrew Geller Shoes, contributing to the success of the family business in retail and manufacturing. Daniel was a champion tennis player, an avid skier, a fine golfer-and he knew his way around a toolbox. Daniel was guided by a sense of fairness and equality. He was an extraordinarily intelligent, caring, well-liked, and quiet man, with a dry sense of humor. We all loved him and will miss him terribly. Donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. www.pdf.org.

McKAY--Renee, a very talented artist and generous lady, passed away peacefully in New York City on April 16, 2011. Raised in Montreal and a graduate of McGill University with a major in French, she studied drawing and painting throughout her early years. In 1942 she married Kenneth McKay and moved to Summit, NJ where together they raised two children, Margo and Kip. During those years and after their move to NYC, Renee received numerous awards for her art work and was President of Audubon Artists in NYC and Director of Artists Equity in NYC. Her paintings were in traveling shows throughout Europe, Japan, Canada and the US and are now in permanent museum collections in Connecticut, Virginia, Massachusetts and Ohio. Renee was also a longtime and enthusiastic member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She and her husband were married for 68 years until his death in March 2010. Renee is survived by her son Kenneth McKay Jr., daughter Margo Mulligan and husband David Pasko, grandchildren Chris Mulligan and Lisa Brisini and husband Sean, great grandson Riley, and niece Joan Findlay Dunham and family. Services at St James' Church, Madison Ave. and 71st St., NYC, May 28, 2011 at 11am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to NY Artists Equity.

The Eat column on Page 46, about a ragú made by Dave Pasternack, the chef of Esca in New York, misidentifies a body of water that is a source for ingredients used by Venetian chefs. It is the Gulf of Venice, not the Gulf of Naples.

SOME people get ready for swimsuit season with Pilates. Others do it by lying down on a comfy bed while a highly trained French aesthetician gives them a soothing ''miracle'' treatment. Isabelle Bellis's two-hour detox session ($310) uses a French machine that simulates cupping, an ancient Chinese technique that purports to help rid the blood of toxins. ''But there's no bruising, like with traditional cupping,'' said Ms. Bellis (at right), a celebrity facialist. ''It's ideal for people who retain water.'' Clients notice increased suppleness and feel lighter after only one session, she said. So who needs bikini boot camp? (212) 966-3262. SANDRA BALLENTINE

We extend our deepest sympathies to her children Sara Binder Hamilton, Ellen Dubner and her husband Stephen, her four grandchildren Ethan, Annie, Solomon and Anya and the rest of her family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Thomas S. Kaplan, President Fredric Mack, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

THE former adult film star Sasha Grey has made a career out of creatively and willfully exploiting her body while nodding at an assortment of weighty topics: performance art, philosophy and girl power among them. Her latest project is a book of art photos, ''Neü Sex'' (Vice, $30), which collects all her meta-porn personas: the exhibitionist (in the book, she's pictured on the toilet), the performer (we see her outlandish costumes) and the bookworm (she name-drops Sartre). ''If you are a fan of photography, and you got your pile of Taschen books, this goes with it,'' Ms. Grey said of the book, which is padded with racy self-portraits. ''But if that's not your thing, and you're just a fan of me, maybe it doesn't go on your coffee table, you know what I mean?'' STEPHEN HEYMAN

WRIGHT--Ben Hickman, the late Dr. Nathan Wright Jr's twin, transitioned April 12 in Miami/Career diplomat; Clairol executive; Ebony Senior Vice President. His company, Black Resources Inc., conceived and administratively financed the 90+black national organizations and newspapers literacy coalition-AOIP. Survived by wife J. Jason, children, D. Igiehon (Nigeria), P. Wright (NV) Rev. D. Wright (VA). Services pending. Family requests in lieu of flowers to honor Ben's life's work by giving to your charity choice; community cause.

THE book ''American Fashion Travel'' (Assouline, $45) collects detailed questionnaires, personal photos and anecdotes from established and up-and-coming designers who live and work in America but whose wanderlust isn't confined to the United States. We discover, among other things, that Alexander Wang prefers the George V in Paris. Francisco Costa considers Havaianas sandals the perfect souvenir (not entirely unexpected from a bona fide Brazilian). Tommy Hilfiger loves to dine at Bukhara in New Delhi. Cynthia Rowley's favorite travel book is ''Local Color'' by Truman Capote. And Phillip Lim swears by Shiseido eye patches to cure jet lag. YURI CHONG

We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Movsas family. Aaron Seligson, President Glorie Isakower, Secretary

PIZZITOLA--Elizabeth B.,of New York, died on April 21 at the age of 86. Born Elizabeth Edna Bailey on August 11, 1924 in Springfield, MA. Cherished daughter of Charles A. Bailey, Jr. and Frances E. (Moore) Bailey, and dear sister of Charles A., III. Adoring wife and companion of 61 years to Frank J. Pizzitola. Beloved mother of Linda (Edward H.) Ruby; Gregory M.; Stephen F. (Colleen M.); and Paul B., who predeceased her. Doting grandmother of seven. Betty made a warm and loving home for her family and friends. She was involved in numerous charitable endeavors: a long-time volunteer and member of the Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital, she was also deeply involved in the Family Counseling Service of Westhampton Beach, and served as Chair of both organizations. She also served on the Board of Trustees of Green Mountain College. Betty had an enduring love of travel, but also took great joy in the quiet comforts of home and such interests as design, gardening and playing bridge with her friends. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and East 84th Street, on Tuesday, April 26 at 10:00am. May perpetual light shine upon her.

DALIS--Mandell. Founder of PACS Industries, a Great Neck, NY based manufacturer of switchgear for electric power supply, died on April 19. He was 84. Mr. Dalis founded PACS in 1972 with General Electric as his first customer, and grew it into a multimillion-dollar company that builds electrical switchgear and substations across the United States and the world. The company's most significant projects have included Citifield, The New York Times, La Guardia Airport, South East Pennsylvania Transit Authority, and Metro North Railroad. In 2007, Mr. Dalis was awarded a patent for the development of a new type of arc-resistant switchgear to increase worker safety and recently licensed it to Point Eight Power of New Orleans. Earlier this month, PACS, which also maintains a factory in Mount Vernon, Ohio, received an investment from Delta Point Capital Partners for a controlling interest in the company. The investment will enable Mr. Dalis' legacy to grow into the future. Born in Brooklyn on October 31, 1926, Mr. Dalis built his first radio at age nine. He later attended high school during daytime hours for academics while simultaneously attending vocational school at night to study radio and television repair. At 17, he enlisted in the United States Army. Because he was under age, his mother, a Russian immigrant, had to sign for him, which she did because of her gratitude to the United States and all of its opportunities. Mr. Dalis was among the first troops to occupy Japan following World War II. After the war, Mr. Dalis worked as a television and radio repairman, and met and married Juliet Meyer in 1951. He subsequently attended Pratt Institute under the GI Bill and received a degree in electrical engineering. Proud of his Jewish heritage, he served as president of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck for four years. He is survived by Juliet and three children: Bruce Dalis of Bayville, NY; Beth Manners of Westport, CT; Leslie Watnik of Sands Point, NY; and nine grandchildren.
Pop Jon Caramanica

RODGERS--Allan, Emeritus Professor of Geography at The Pennsylvania State University died on Tuesday, April 19, 2011. He is survived by his wife, Audrey, his son, Peter, his two grandchildren, Adam and Emma. A Memorial service in Dr. Rodgers' honor will be held on May 1, 2011 at the Eisenhower Chapel on the Penn State campus at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations will be gratefully received for the planned Allan Rodgers Graduate Fellowship, Department of Geography; Pennsylvania State University.

As the mother of four school-age children, I make countless trips to the local supermarket. Whether I shop for breakfast, school lunches, snacks, or dinner for six, the place is practically my second home. So I am very well attuned to rearranged aisles, new cashiers and the latest innovations. Recently, though, I've noticed a trend that has nothing to do with selling groceries. On a single shopping trip, I spotted three of the five cashiers texting while working, their cellphones strategically placed next to the registers so that they could quickly glance at incoming messages. Weigh a head of broccoli, eyeball the cell. Scan the chicken cutlets, check a text. Onion, text. Milk, text. Cheerios, text, text, text. I wanted to blurt out, ''Excuse me, feel free to text your friend that the customer at register three says, 'Hello.' ''
2011 New York International Auto Show Twitter updates, slide shows, critiques and other highlights of everything new and on wheels. nytimes.com

LOEWENSTEIN--Liselotte S. (Sternberg), died April 16, 2011. Born in 1922 in Germany, "Lilo" was the daughter of Frances Gochsheimer Sternberg and Emil Sternberg. She was predeceased by her husband of more than 50 years, Werner Loewenstein in 1999. She immigrated to the United States in 1939 and became a naturalized citizen. For many years she was co-proprietor with Joan Gellert of Joan and Lilo's, a women's apparel shop on Manhattan's east side. Liselotte is survived by her sons and their spouses, William and Mary Ann Loewenstein, Hudson, NY and Steven and Sharon Loewenstein, Peckville, PA; five grandchildren, Frances Loewenstein Brandt, Jason, Jeanne, Samara and Kristin Loewenstein; and three great-grandchildren, Emily and Abby Brandt and Ethan Nigel Loewenstein. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Metropolitan Opera Company, New York, NY; Channel 13 located on West 33rd St., New York, NY; AARP Andrus Foundation; The Jimmy Carter Habitat for Humanity; or the United Jewish Appeal.

ALBANESE--John P.,M.D. July 22, 1923 - April 24, 2010. You are missed and loved by your family every day .

THE NEWSBud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, will appoint someone to oversee the Los Angeles Dodgers because of his ''deep concern'' about the franchise, once home to legends like Jackie Robinson, Duke Snider and Sandy Koufax. BEHIND THE NEWS The team's owner, Frank McCourt, a Boston real estate developer, has burdened the Dodgers with more than $400 million in debt since taking control in 2004 and is embroiled in an ugly divorce. Sources close to Mr. Selig said he believed that Mr. McCourt mismanaged the team while enriching himself. Mr. Selig can terminate a franchise and push to force its sale under his ''best interests of baseball'' powers.

KAPELMAN--Leonard, 90, died April 21. Beloved husband and best friend of Helen for almost 65 years. Cherished father of Barbara (Larry) and David (Aggie). Adored grandfather of Adam (Jessica), Alex and Scott. Devoted son of the late Felix and Ray and loving brother of the late William. Brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and friend who was loved and respected by all who knew him. We were blessed to have had him for so many years. Services were held on April 22. Shiva at his home at 575 Bronx River Road, Yonkers, New York, Apartment 6H, after Passover from Tuesday evening April 26, 8:30pm to Sunday night May 1. Donations to the Young Israel of Mosholu Parkway or Fleetwood Synagogue.

SILVERMAN--Sandra, died on March 17. Please join us for a celebration of Sandy's life on Monday, May 2, at 5:30pm at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th St. at Madison.

Nearly 10 years after the Taliban were driven from power in Afghanistan, the capital city of Kabul is a patchwork of the old and the remade. New construction, fueled by billions in U.S. dollars, takes place amid rampant unemployment, growing poverty, an influx of people from outside the city, political corruption and a failed banking system. ''It's a kind of Wild West scenario,'' says the photographer Simon Norfolk, whose pictures of Afghanistan, taken late in 2010, will be exhibited at the Tate Modern in London from May 6 to July 10. ''The whole city has become a mad dash to build.'' Norfolk sees the building boom as part of the U.S. exit strategy. ''It's like throwing money out of the back of helicopters in an effort to leave,'' he says. YEAR KABUL BECAME CAPITAL OF AFGHANISTAN: 1773

An article on April 15 on homeowners facing foreclosure because of delinquent payments to their homeowners associations incorrectly stated the position of David Swedelson at the law firm Swedelson & Gottlieb, as well as the firm's relationship with Association Lien Services. He is a partner, not the managing partner of the firm; and Swedelson & Gottlieb is an affiliate of Association Lien Services; it does not operate the collection agency.

RUBINSTEIN--Amy Beilin, 66, of Great Neck, New York, and Warren, Vermont, died April 22, 2011, surrounded by her family. She was born October 30th, 1944 in Bronx, NY. She was the daughter of the late Joseph and Ruth Beilin. Amy was a tremendous track and field star who was discovered by Parry O'Brien, an American Olympic champion. She met the love of her life, Kenneth Rubenstein, in High School, and they were together 49 years and married for 46 years. Amy graduated Queens College and was a teacher in her younger years. She raised five children, while devoting all her spare time to charitable organizations, especially Hadassah, where she also appeared in many of their theatrical productions. Amy had a passion for life and enjoyed being a Mima to her ten grandchildren. She loved the mountains of Vermont, the beaches of Florida and Bermuda, and being home with her family. Judaism was an important part of her being. Amy was a member of Temple Israel in Great Neck, Jewish Community of Greater Stowe in Stowe, Vermont, and most recently she enjoyed being a member of Temple Emanu-El in Palm Beach, Florida. Amy was known by her friends as "Saint Amy" due to her selfless nature and giving ways. She was always smiling and encouraging, eager to make another person feel better. She saw only the good in everyone and was a true humanitarian in every sense of the word. She is survived by her husband Kenneth, her children, Kim, Jon, Keith, Lauren, Andrew, her ten grandchildren, Rex, Marley, Bo, Jed, Roscoe, Josey, Rio, Felix, Eloise and River, and her brothers Peter and George. A service will be held Sunday at Lake Success Jewish Center. Amy will be loved today, tomorrow, and always.

DEGENER--John Michael, died Sunday, March 20 on the Caribbean Island of Mustique of a heart attack. Born in New York City, he was the son of the late Nouche Lucien-Robert and George L Degener Jr. He attended Trinity School, boarded at Riverdale School for Boys, and graduated from Millbrook School in Millbrook, NY. He was a 1956 graduate of Williams College and received an MBA from NYU in 1972. He is survived by his wife of 38 years Helen MacDonald Zottoli Degener and two children from his first marriage, Carol Marie-Laure Degener of New York City, and J. Michael Degener, Jr., his wife Henriette Kets de Vries, and a granddaughter Belen Degener of Southampton, MA. A Memorial Service is to be held on Saturday, May 28, 2011 at Christ Episcopal Church in Sharon, CT at 11am. Memorial contributions may be made to the Sharon Audubon Society in Sharon, CT 06069.

DONATI--Robert, age 79, on April 17 after a short illness. He is survived by his beloved wife, Georgia Donati, of Scarsdale New York; his daughters, Sylvia Donati and Ellen Lyford; his grandchildren, Raffa and Amalia Motomura; his sons-in-law, Chikara Motomura and Tad Lyford; and his brother, Arthur Donati. He was predeceased by his daughter, Grace Donati. Born in San Francisco, California, he was a graduate of University of California, Berkeley, 1953. He worked at Lockheed Missiles & Space Co./DIALOG Information Systems. A memorial service will be at 3pm on Saturday, May 21 at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, 6 Greenacres Avenue, Scarsdale, New York.

RORY FINN, 28: It was the Monday after gay-pride weekend, and I was thinking that I was going to see my doctor later that afternoon and that there was a really good chance, like a 99 percent chance, that I would leave with a prescription for testosterone in my hand to begin my physical transition from female to male. So I was thinking that it was probably the last photo taken of me prior to that. I'm holding pictures of my two uncles because there's a strong naval tradition in my family. And I like to dress up as a sailor whenever I go out, because there's this whole connotation about gay sailors. Everyone knows me as the sailor boy. Now I definitely feel more comfortable within my own skin. I am more secure, and it's kind of weird, because when I walk around town with my girlfriend, everyone thinks that we're some straight couple. Which we are.
Art Holland Cotter

COLTON--Joel, born August 23, 1918, New York City passed away on April 17 in Durham, NC. Specializing in modern and contemporary European history, he taught at Duke University from 1947-1989, chairing the History Department from 1967-1974. The author of numerous articles and books on French history, he became known to generations of students as co-author of the college textbook, A History of the Modern World. Used in over 1000 high schools, colleges and universities, it has been translated into 10 languages. From 1974-1982, he served as Director for Humanities at the Rockefeller Foundation and returned to Duke in 1982 where he taught until his retirement in 1989. He graduated from City College of New York in 1937, receiving his B.A. magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa. He earned his M.A. in history in 1940 and his Ph.D. in 1950, both from Columbia University. During WWII, he was commissioned a military intelligence officer and served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1946. He published his first book in 1951, Compulsory Labor Arbitration in France, 1936-1939, followed by Leon Blum: Humanist in Politics in 1966. For Time-Life, he wrote The Twentieth Century in 1968. His articles and book reviews appeared in the American Historical Review, Journal of Modern History, Yale Review, and New York Times Book Review. His awards include fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, Rockefeller Foundation and National Endowment for the Humanities. In 1979, he was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Other awards included a Townsend Harris Medal as a distinguished alumnus of City College of New York; elected to the Fellows of the Phi Beta Kappa Society; a distinguished teaching award from Duke; honored by the Western Society of French History; and the Enno Kraehe Distinguished Service award from the Southern Historical Association. He taught as a visiting professor at numerous universities around the world and was fluent in 5 languages. He was married in 1942 to Shirley (Baron). She died in 2003. His daughter, Valerie Woodbury of Durham, his son, Kenneth of Montclair, NJ and five grandchildren survive him. The Joel and Shirley Colton Fund for European History has been established in his memory. Please send contributions to: Duke Library, P.O. Box 90197, Durham, N.C. 27708.

FLEISS--Susan Nelson an architect living in Santa Monica, CA, passed away at the Santa Monica UCLA Medical Center on April 18th. She died after a three month fight with colon cancer. She was 35 years old. Born to James and Mary Nelson in 1975, Susan was raised in Mequon, WI and Lake Forest, IL. She graduated from Lake Forest High School in 1994, and went on to attend the University of Virginia, where she received a Bachelors, of Science degree in Architecture in 1998. After graduation, Susan worked for the Beau Clowney Design firm in Charleston, SC, and Richard Meier & Partners Architects in Los Angeles, CA. She then received her MArch in Architecture from Princeton University in 2003, earning the Henry Adams AIA medal, awarded to the valedictorian of the class. Susan returned to the Los Angeles area, where she worked for Nicholas Budd Design, taught architecture courses at the University of Southern California and ultimately established her own private practice as a licensed architect in the state of California. In August 2004, Susan married Eric Fleiss, the love of her life. The couple had three children (Teddy, born in April 2007, and twins, Benjamin and Caroline, born in March 2010). As a mother, Susan brought her creativity and imagination into every aspect of parenthood. She was an incredible playmate to her children, and taught them to see the beautiful in the every day. Susan's most significant accomplishment was her unwavering dedication and love for her family. She was a loving wife to her husband of seven years, Eric, a caring and compassionate mother to her three children, a dedicated daughter to her parents, James and Mary Nelson (Sanibel, FL and Fish Creek, WI), and a beloved sister to Jane Saccaro and Ann Mittelstadt. Susan was a devoted daughter-in-law to Eric's parents, Dr. David and Karen Fleiss (New York, NY), and a treasured sister-in-law to Jay Saccaro, Matt Mittelstadt, Andrew and Jenny Fleiss, Peter and Sara Fleiss, and Alex Fleiss. Finally, Susan was a creative, fun-loving and adventurous aunt to Jack, Kate and Sam Saccaro, Zachary and Andrew Mittelstadt, and Solomon Fleiss. A memorial service is planned for Thursday, April 28th at 4:00pm at the Jonathan Club, 850 Palisades Beach Road, Santa Monica, CA. An additional memorial service will take place in June at the home of James and Mary Nelson in Fish Creek, WI. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made in Susan's memory to Camp Kesem, a summer camp for children whose parents have or had cancer. Gifts may be made online at www.campkesem.org by selecting "Donate-> In Honoremory Of," or via checks sent to Camp Kesem, In Memory of Susan Fleiss, P.O. Box 1113, Lafayette, CA 94549.
SLONE--Rita Krause. Extraordinary wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend. The love of our lives. Services were on April 17, 2011.

By the morning of April 25, 1861, residents of Washington had been expecting a Confederate attack for almost two weeks; for the last five days, the city had been completely cut off from the rest of the nation. No trains. No traffic into the city. No telegraph. No mail. Only the morning before at the White House, a despondent President Lincoln had greeted the wounded soldiers of the Sixth Massachusetts — the last reinforcements to arrive since April 19 — telling them, “I don’t believe there is any North. The Seventh Regiment is a myth.”

At one point in “The Wizard Of Oz,” Dorothy (Judy Garland) picks an apple and the tree she picks it off protests: “Well, how would you like to have someone come along and pick something off of you?” Dorothy is abashed and she says, “Oh, dear — I keep forgetting I’m not in Kansas,” by which she means she’s now entered an alternate universe where the usual distinctions between persons and objects, animate and inanimate, human beings and the natural world that is theirs to exploit do not hold. In Kansas and, she once assumed, everywhere else, trees are things you pick things off (even limbs) and persons are not. Persons have an autonomy and integrity of body that are to be respected; trees do not. A person who is maimed has a legal cause of action. A tree that has been cut down has no legal recourse, although there may be a cause of action (not, however, on behalf of the tree) if it was cut down by someone other than the owner of the property it stood on.

The documentary “Semper Fi: Always Faithful” follows Jerry Ensminger, a retired Marine who served in the military for 25 years. After his daughter died of a rare leukemia at the age of 9, Mr. Ensminger sought to learn the disease’s cause, eventually discovering that there were contaminants in the water at Camp Lejeune, the military base in North Carolina where he lived when his daughter was born. His research found that the water had been contaminated for a 30-year period between 1957-1987. The documentary, being shown at the Tribeca Film Festival, tells his story as as he works to gather more details about the water contamination and to reveal the issue to those affected, to Congress and to the public at large. In this video, Mr. Ensminger discusses how he found out about the incident, what some of its effects have been and his struggle with the Marine Corps to get a resolution.

British ornithologists record dramatic declines in the population of songbirds migrating from Africa. Since 1995, the number of turtle doves arriving in spring has dropped by 71 percent, while nightingales have declined by 53 percent. The reason for the losses is unknown, but scientists suspect that land-use changes could play a leading role. “The real problem is that there are so many different possible causes for these losses, which makes it difficult to tease out the factors involved in their decline and to prepare plans to put things right,” a scientist says. Indie record shops generally look like Championship Vinyl, the music-geek hangout owned by John Cusack in “High Fidelity,” which is to say the closest they get to décor is the album covers on the wall. “Everyone asks why we don’t have records on the wall,” says Ian Marshall, the co-owner, along with his wife, Jade Gordon, of L.A.’s Wombleton Records. “It’s like it’s some sort of requirement. But when we opened the store we knew we’d be spending a lot of time here and that’s not really the kind of environment we wanted to be in.” Instead, the couple has created a used-record shop that resembles a Victorian parlor, right down to the embossed wallpaper and potted plants. Marshall, a self-described Anglophile who grew up outside of Toronto but spent his school holidays visiting family in Britain, wanted the Highland Park store to have an English feel, a conceit that extends to its name, a play on the popular British children’s books (and later a BBC series) about the Wombles. To get Wombleton’s 19th-century ambience just right, the couple spent hours trawling eBay for vintage furniture and prevailed upon friends like David Donohue, a graphic designer and surf board builder who made the harpsichord-shaped record bins, and Nic Taylor and Jennifer Brandt-Taylor of Thunderwing Press, who created the store’s logo, a stagecoach on LP wheels. “Which is very apt,” Marshall says. “We spend a lot of time in foreign countries, driving around in rental cars looking for records.” But perhaps the most refreshing quality about Wombleton is its lack of snobbery. Unlike Barry and Dick (Jack Black and Todd Louima), “the musical moron twins” who staffed Championship Vinyl, Marshall and Gordon, who stock an eclectic mix of British pop from the ’60s, ’70s and ’80s, won’t deride your taste. “I’m a bottom feeder,” Marshall says, laughing. “I like crap. I’m not afraid to buy the 50-cent disco album that nobody wants.”

Love may come in many forms, but it has never quite taken the shape seen in Marie Losier‘s documentary “The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye,” which makes its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival on Monday. This film chronicles the lives of Genesis P-Orridge, the experimental artist and musician from the bands Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, and her partner, Lady Jaye, who expressed their unity by becoming near-duplicates of each other. The art experiment, in which the couple underwent plastic surgery to create a single, androgynous sexual identity, began in 2003, and continued even after Lady Jaye died in 2007.

In a package of articles called The Guantánamo Files, a team of my colleagues reports today on the release of more than 700 classified military documents that provide new and detailed accounts of the men who have done time at the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba, and offer new insight into the evidence against the 172 men still locked up there. The Guantánamo files were part of a huge trove of documents leaked last year to the anti-secrecy organization WikiLeaks. They were made available to The New York Times by another source on the condition of anonymity. For years, Robert Scholes,  a professor in the department of modern culture and media at Brown University, has led a project to put Modernist journals online,  which means you can have access to many of the period’s wonderful journals without being a student at a university with great archival holdings. So far, Scholes and his team (which includes Sean Latham at the University of Tulsa) have digitized 18 magazines: all 47 issues of The Freewoman and all 13 of The New Freewoman, an early feminist journal that espoused free love; the first nine volumes of the Little Review, which published 13 episodes of Joyce’s “Ulysses,” before being forced to stop due to obscenity charges, and, under the aegis of Pound as “foreign editor,” such writers as Djuna Barnes, Gertrude Stein and T.S. Eliot; the two issues of  Wyndham Lewis’s vorticist zine Blast;  the more visual Rhythm, which published several designs for the Ballets Russes, among them “L’après-midi d’un faune”; as well as such well-known journals as Scribner’s Magazine. Currently, the MJP is working on digitizing  The Crisis, the journal founded by W.E. B. Dubois for the then fledgling N.A.A.C.P. It ran from 1910 to 1924, with many hiatuses, but had an unusually wide audience for a little magazine: its circulation peaked at 100,000.

If returning to the golf course in sun and warmth is the greatest joy of a new golf season, then an attendant delight is welcoming the latest contributions to the legacy of elegant, instructive, engaging books on golf. With ''America's Gift to Golf: Herbert Warren Wind on the Masters'' (The American Golfer), the editor and historian Martin Davis has given us a hybrid book as valuable and precious as a hybrid club in the modern golf bag. This beautifully presented collection of articles written by Wind from 1954 to 1989 allows the reader to sample his work from various times in his long career at The New Yorker (along with two articles he wrote for a nascent Sports Illustrated). No passage is ever abbreviated or fleeting, but perhaps because it is a compilation and not a traditional narrative, it is more like a journey, with flowing missives from a familiar place.

ORGELFINGER--Louis, III, 95, of Waynesville, NC, died on April 8 at home, of chronic vascular disease. He was born in Farmingdale on December 11, 1915. Following his education in New York City public schools, he graduated from Grove City College (PA) in 1932 and St. John's University School of Law. He served in the European Theatre during WWII. In 1947 he joined the law firm of Mendes and Mount in New York City, retiring in 1982. On April 3, 1948 he married Caroline Mary Iannone. After residing in Richmond Hill and Munsey Park, the couple moved to Waynesville in 1983. Surviving are his wife; daughters, Gail Orgelfinger of Severna Park, MD and Joan Jarrard of Flora, IN; a grandson and great- granddaughter.

WASHINGTON - The Obama administration is preparing to inject an unpredictable new variable into its economic policy clash with Republicans: a plan to overhaul corporate taxes. Economic advisers have nearly completed the process initiated in January by the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, at President Obama's behest. That process, intended to make the United States more competitive internationally, has explored the willingness of business leaders to sacrifice loopholes in return for lowering the top corporate tax rate, currently 35 percent.

Eric E. Schmidt's new job as executive chairman of Google came with a very nice raise. Mr. Schmidt, who as chief executive of Google had been earning just $1 a year since 2005 (though his ownership stake in the company is worth several billion dollars), will now earn $1.25 million a year with a potential $6 million annual bonus, according to a regulatory filing Tuesday by Google.

The ramblin' man I wrote about on Tuesday managed to ramble off the island of Manhattan and back out to the wide open spaces. Seems he's headed north, according to a City Room reader named Al Barclay, a 54-year-old financial researcher from Beekman, N.Y. He said he spotted our rambler on Wednesday walking along a country road near Poughkeepsie, a 90-minute drive from the city.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who once harbored presidential aspirations himself, had some advice on Sunday for another billionaire considering national office: Stay away from the ''birther'' issue. Mr. Bloomberg, appearing on ''Fox News Sunday,'' declared flatly that ''the President was born here,'' and suggested that Donald Trump, the real estate tycoon now exploring a presidential run, is not helping his prospective candidacy by affiliating with those who argue that President Obama was not born in the United States.

RAE--Thomas Newton Whiteside, 81, died peacefully on April 24, 2011 following a long illness. He was the beloved son of the late Izard Newton Whiteside Rae and Harrie Rae (nee Parfitt). A graduate of Exeter Academy and Yale University, he served in the US Navy from 1956-1962. Following a career in banking, he devoted himself to the Church of the Resurrection, where he served as a vestryman and usher for many years. He is mourned by Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Mammana, Jr. of New Haven, Conn., Miss Ruth Wiltshire of Bryn Mawr, PA., and his fellow parishioners. A requiem mass will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, 74th Street, on April 26 at 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Living Church Foundation, Milwaukee.

Last week, I received a slender brown parcel in the mail. It contained a bottle of slate-colored nail polish, a tiny tub of facial scrub, rose-scented lotion, Italian herbal tea and a petite vial of perfume, among other things. But it wasn't a care package from my sister or a former college roommate. It was my monthly shipment from Birchbox, a start-up based in New York that mails out a package of beauty samples and products to its subscribers.

11 P.M. (Sundance) MY SO-CALLED LIFE Angela Chase (Claire Danes), Jordan Catalano (Jared Leto) and their angst-ridden classmates at Liberty High School return in reruns of this groundbreaking ABC series, which appeared from August 1994 to January 1995. Created by Winnie Holzman, with Marshall Herskovitz and Edward Zwick as executive producers -- part of the team behind ''Thirtysomething'' -- the show earned critical acclaim for addressing topics like child abuse, homophobia, teenage alcoholism and bullying. Reviewing the series in The New York Times, Bruce Weber wrote that Ms. Danes ''is refreshingly playing her age, and, unlike most youthful television stars, is far less adorable than skilled.'' Her Angela is ''confused, all right: about sex, about her parents, about what it means to have an identity,'' he said. ''But she's smart enough to sulk over these things, often with a pungent, self-deprecating wit.'' Still, with others in the cast to pick up the slack, ''she isn't overburdened carrying the drama,'' he added. ''So even when her so-called life isn't compelling, her world generally is.'' From left above, Devon Gummersall, A. J. Langer, Ms. Danes, Wilson Cruz and Devon Odessa. 8 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) THE BLUE BIRD (1976) Two peasant children (Todd Lookinland and Patsy Kensit) are instructed by the Queen of Light (Elizabeth Taylor, in head-to-toe jewels) to seek the Blue Bird of Happiness in this adaptation of Maurice Maeterlinck's fairy tale, directed by George Cukor. The international cast includes Ava Gardner (Luxury), Jane Fonda (Night), George Cole (Dog), Cicely Tyson (Cat) and members of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet. Writing in The Times, Vincent Canby said that while ''The Blue Bird'' was one movie, audiences couldn't help but see two films: ''One of these films is blandly American, like the sort of processed cheese sold in jars that can later be used as water glasses. The other is dimly Russian but without any real Russian character, except for the sets, which aren't great. They look like stuff left over from the Bolshoi Opera's last road tour.'' Then there was the problem of the birds. ''Some look like black birds and some are simply pigeons dyed blue.'' He added, ''No New Yorker in his right mind would cross a street to look for a pigeon.''

McWorld, a Web site for children sponsored by McDonald's, offers visitors the chance to create characters, decorate digital treehouses and go on a quest in a virtual world. French fries, hamburgers and apple pies are nowhere to be seen. This is the latest in online marketing, where the hope is that a site's visitor will naturally associate the brand with a pleasurable activity. It is a type of advertising that has less in common with a 30-second television spot than with a product placement in a movie. It is also a glimpse of the future, said Mark Smale, a senior vice president with Creata, the Australian company that created the site for McDonald's. Mr. Smale said in an interview that companies are realizing that, when going online, the best strategy is to forgo immediate sales in order to build lasting emotional relationships with children. In that sense, McWorld is a more sophisticated version of the sites that Matt Richtel discusses in an article about the online marketing of food to children.

Alec Baldwin is set to appear in August at one of the theater world's leading events, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, playing the ghost of Hamlet's father. But he won't be there to deliver his performances. With a busy summer that includes filming the movie version of the Broadway show ''Rock of Ages'' and preparing for a sixth season of ''30 Rock,'' Mr. Baldwin, above, will tape his scenes as Old Hamlet's ghost for the New York-based Fundamental Theater Project's fringe production ''3D Hamlet: A Lost Generation,'' said Fundamental's artistic director, Sam Underwood. Mr. Baldwin and Mr. Underwood starred in a production of ''Equus'' last summer in East Hampton, N.Y. Mr. Underwood, who will alternate in the role of Hamlet with Anthony Rapp (''Rent''), said in an interview that ''3D Hamlet'' would blend multimedia elements with Shakespeare's text ''to create an interactive perspective for the audience and a feeling that they are part of the action.'' Mr. Underwood said he was looking into using a 3-D camera to record Mr. Baldwin's scenes, which audience members would watch through special glasses. Kate Mulgrew (''Star Trek: Voyager'') will also star in the production as Hamlet's mother, Gertrude. Mr. Underwood, who said he was directing and producing the work with fellow Fundamental members, said the play would have a short run in New York in July.

This week, Ms. Couric is planning to acknowledge one of the worst-kept secrets in television: that she is leaving the ''CBS Evening News'' after five years. Then, as soon as she returns from London, where she will be anchoring the network's coverage of the royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday, CBS will announce her successor during the first week of May. The meticulously arranged exit plan was described by four people with knowledge of it, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because it was not supposed to be revealed before the formal announcement.

If you have a sore throat and runny nose because of allergies, chances are you do not want to spend a lot of time beside a gas pump. But if you find yourself there, a new digital advertising campaign for Halls aims to convince you - with the aid of real-time forecasts - that you should buy its cough drops. Part of the Halls campaign will include using video screens at gas station pumps, where consumers will see an ad for cough drops followed by the day's pollen count.

The top-selling movies this year have a fair number of children's releases, but those for adults predominate. Among the top 25, for example, ''The Fighter'' and ''Black Swan'' rank 14th and 15th, respectively. Of the top 25 movies, 17 cater to grown-up tastes, a figure which rises to 18 counting ''Bambi,'' above, a movie that premiered in August 1942. ''Bambi'' was last in theaters in 1988 and was released on VHS in 1989. Disney has five other films in the top 15: ''Tangled,'' ''Secretariat'' and ''Beverly Hills Chihuahua 2,'' as well as ''Tron Legacy'' at No. 12 and ''Toy Story 3'' at No. 13. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Last week, members of the press and others got an invitation to a Washington cocktails and hors d'oeuvres reception from the Motion Picture Association of America, of which Mr. Dodd is now chairman, to honor what it called ''our member company White House correspondents.'' Strictly speaking, the six studios in the movie trade association - Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures Entertainment, 20th Century Fox, Universal Studios, Warner Brothers and Walt Disney Studios - don't have much in the way of White House correspondents.

Throughout Raj Rajaratnam's trial, which could go to the jury as soon as Monday, there has been an elephant in the courtroom: Rajat K. Gupta. Mr. Gupta, once one of the world's most respected businessmen, is not being tried here nor has he been charged criminally. Yet hardly a day has passed when the jury in Mr. Rajaratnam's trial - the government's biggest insider trading case in a generation - does not hear about Mr. Gupta, the former head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company.

SCHLAFLY--Hubert J. ("Hub"), Jr.,91, of Stamford, Connecticut, died peacefully on April 20, 2011, at Stamford Hospital, after a brief illness. Born on August 14, 1919, in St. Louis, Missouri, he was the only child of Hubert, Sr. and Mary Rose Parker Schlafly. He was predeceased by his parents and his wife of 59 years, Leona Martin Schlafly, who died in 2003. He is survived by many relatives. An electrical engineering graduate of the University of Notre Dame (1941), Hub is best known for developing the teleprompter in collaboration with Irving Berlin Kahn and Fred Barton, Jr., and for co-founding the TelePrompTer Corporation. The teleprompter made its debut in 1950 on a soap opera called, "The First Hundred Years." In 1952, Herbert Hoover became the first politician to use it when he gave the keynote address to the Republican National Convention. Hub helped shape the modern television industry. He developed the first pay TV system that permitted subscribers to order programs delivered by cable. He executed the first satellite transmission of a cable program from Washington, D.C., to a convention of 3,000 cable operators in Anaheim, Calif. (June 1973). It was the first time a satellite was used to transmit cable programming and allowed one to go up to satellites from anywhere and transmit everywhere and transformed the industry. He engineered the HBO satellite transmission of the "Thrilla in Manila" boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier. Hub received an Emmy Award for the teleprompter and another for his outstanding engineering achievement for cable television technology. He was named a "Cable Television Pioneer" by the National Cable Television Association. He received the Sarnoff Citation for his contributions to cable television and the Vanguard Award for Science and Technology from the National Cable and Telecommunications Association. He was inducted into the Cable Television Hall of Fame. He held 16 patents. At WNET, New York City's public media provider, the convergence lab was named in Hub's honor. He supported numerous charities, including a scholarship program for minority students in engineering and the Schlafly Electronic Circuits Laboratory at Notre Dame. A Digital Media Lab at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, CT, was dedicated in his honor. Hub funded the Chapel of the Nativity at that university to honor his wife. Hub was a member of the Order of Malta and was a Knight of Saint Gregory the Great. Friends may call at Saint Mary Parish, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830, from 4-8pm on Monday, April 25, 2011. A Mass of Christian burial will take place at 10am on Tuesday, April 26, 2011, at Saint Mary Parish. Hub will be laid to rest next to his beloved wife, Lee, on April 28, 2011, in Louisville, NY.

LIBYA Rebel leaders said they had consolidated their control of the western city of Misurata, taking over the last two government outposts there. Overview | Does the abundance of Holocaust analogies in contemporary society affect the way that we remember the Holocaust? How can we both foster understanding of the Holocaust and encourage young people to draw personal connections? With 270 comments and counting, New York Times readers reacted to my article in Tuesday’s paper about roster management with passion, insight and numerous personal stories about how Title IX had affected their lives, whether good or bad. Many readers questioned why so much attention is paid to female athletes and argued that the fact that 57 percent of college students are now female is proof of discrimination against men by colleges and universities. Others asserted that Title IX overlooks the fact that men and women have different interests, and raised the question of whether fewer women want to play sports. Still others said the examples cited in the article showed that, 40 years after it was passed, Title IX needs to be rewritten.

If artistic achievement can be measured by the number of shows one has on TBS, Tyler Perry leads Spike Lee in that category, 3-0. On Tuesday that network announced that it was picking up a third television series from Mr. Perry, the actor-writer-director, mini-mogul and sometime nemesis of Mr. Lee, to be adapted from his “Why Did I Get Married?” movies. The new series, to be called “For Better or Worse,” will be a comedy-drama produced by Tyler Perry Studios and will star Michael Jai White (“The Dark Knight”) and Tasha Smith (“Couples Retreat”) as the husband-and-wife couple they have portrayed in the “Married” films. The new series, which will start with a 10-episode order and does not yet have a premiere date, joins Mr. Perry’s TBS comedies “Meet the Browns” and “House of Payne,” which is coming to the end of its run. In a statement, Mr. Perry said: “Working on ‘House of Payne’ taught me a lot about what it takes to make a successful television series and I’m looking forward to applying that experience to ‘For Better or Worse.’ ”

With mostly reruns on CBS and Fox, “Dancing With the Stars” dominated Monday night in the ratings, attracting 21.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That ABC reality competition easily led its 90-minute time slot from 8 to 9:30 p.m. while boosting ABC’s sitcom “Better With You” at 9:30 (11.6 million). CBS ranked second for the night with repeats of its sitcoms, including “How I Met Your Mother” at 8 (5.3 million), “The Big Bang Theory” at 9 (7.7 million), and “Mike & Molly” at 9:30 (7.8 million). A new installment of “Mad Love” garnered 5.6 million viewers at 8:30. Fox edged past NBC for third place, earning 4.8 million for a rerun of “House” at 8 followed by a repeat of “The Chicago Code” (4.1 million). NBC finished in fourth despite broadcasting new episodes of “The Event” at 9 (4.4 million) and “Law & Order: Los Angeles” at 10 (5.8 million), which trailed behind repeats of CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (7 million) and ABC’s “Castle” (7.6 million) in its time slot.

The Paris fashion house announced on Tuesday that Olivier Rousteing will succeed Christophe Decarnin. Springtime in my New York doesn’t begin on the equinox. And it has little to do with forsythia. It is instead that moment when the subway is suddenly, discernibly cooler than the sidewalks above; when descending into a station feels like a pleasant immersion in a sturdy old cellar whose masonry walls are still infused with winter.

This afternoon my son will head to the DMV to trade in his junior driver’s license for an unrestricted senior one. This evening we will go out to dinner to celebrate his 17th birthday. We’re planning to take two cars, and we will stay at the restaurant past 9. Then he will drive himself home — the first time the State of New York has allowed him to do so at that hour without an adult in the passenger seat.

The new era at Paris’s sex-charged fashion house Balmain is beginning to take shape, with 25-year-old Olivier Rousteing being tapped as the label’s new designer. Rousteing, who joined Balmain in 2009 and is currently in charge of women’s wear, replaces Christophe Decarnin, who left earlier this month due to strategic disputes with chairman Alain Hivelin. Before joining Balmain, Rousteing worked for five years at Roberto Cavalli, which should serve him well in delivering the decadent rock-inflected glamour that became the label’s trademark under Decarnin.

So Haley Barbour, who seemed like a near-lock to join the Republican field in 2012, has decided to join the ranks of Republican Mario Cuomos instead. It’s an understandable decision: Barbour’s strengths as a politician notwithstanding, his personal profile — a corpulent ex-lobbyist and quintessential Washington insider who’s also the governor of a deep-red state identified with secession and segregation — made him perhaps the least electable of the various would-be establishment candidates, and his famous political acumen was apparently acute enough to recognize that thick rolodexes alone do not a credible candidacy make. (See Gramm, Phil and Connally, John, among others.) Still, his departure leaves a thin G.O.P. field looking thinner (no pun intended), and it removes a candidate who had the wisdom to greet our Libyan intervention with a blunt: “What are we doing in Libya?” For that alone, he will be missed.

Last September, Laszlo Jakab Orsos, 46, assumed the directorship of the PEN World Voices Festival, New York’s first literary festival, now in its seventh year. Started by Salman Rushdie, the festival regularly features readings and conversations with more than 100 writers from more than 40 countries. Local literary heroes like Jonathan Franzen and Ben Greenman share billing with Nobel Prize winners like Wole Soyinka, of Nigeria, and newcomers like Rula Jebreal, author of “Miral.” This year’s festival opens today with a party at the Standard Hotel and will continue throughout the week with unusual events at unusual sites: poetry readings on the Highline, dance performances in the laundry room of Westbeth and a discussion of David Foster Wallace’s “The Pale King” by Rick Moody and others in the grungy St. Patrick’s gym on Mulberry Street.

Ricardo Morales and the New York Philharmonic have finally closed the deal. The orchestra back in October offered Mr. Morales — one of the stars of the Philadelphia Orchestra – the job of principal clarinetist, a key position that had been open since the end of the 2008-9 season. A spokesman said today that Mr. Morales had signed a contract and would officially start in New York in September 2012 once his obligations end in Philadelphia. The orchestra hopes to have Mr. Morales play some weeks on an ad hoc basis next season and possibly as early as this summer. The loss of Mr. Morales will be another blow to the Philadelphia Orchestra, which this month filed under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. New York operagoers may be familiar with his sound. He was a principal in the Metropolitan Opera before going to Philadelphia.
