Though Ozzy Osbourne was a reality-television fixture for three years — and, oh yeah, a pioneer of heavy-metal music for some four decades — there is more to be said about rock ‘n’ roll’s Prince of Darkness in “God Bless Ozzy Osbourne,” a documentary making its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival. The movie, directed by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli, chronicles Mr. Osbourne’s life — 62 years, if you can believe it, and counting — from his upbringing in Birmingham, England, through his years with Black Sabbath and as a solo performer, through his grieving for the accidental death of his guitarist Randy Rhoads, to the aftermath of his reality show, while a cloud of alcohol and drug abuse hangs over him. In addition to interviews with Mr. Osbourne and his band mates past and present, the film offers candid testimonials from his wife, Sharon, and children Jack and Kelly, as well as his little-seen daughter Aimee (who declined to be part of the reality series) and children Louis and Jessica (from a previous marriage).

It’s the most intimate class divide in human civilization, or at least in such relatively civilized places as Manhattan and Park Slope, Brooklyn. On the one side, there is the professional couple bringing in six figures a year; on the other, the nanny or maid without whom the couple wouldn’t be able to practice their professions. Conditions of employment are as variable as the individual employers are — from respectful and considerate all the way to criminally abusive. On average, a domestic worker is likely to get less than $15 an hour, no benefits and none of the credit or glory. To my knowledge anyway, there has never been a successful career woman — or man, for that matter — who’s responded to being praised for “doing it all” by saying, “Actually, Manuela (or Angelica or Harriet) does most of it.”

Here’s a simple rule of thumb for determining if a particular band is probably on the lineup for the 20th anniversary edition of Lollapalooza: does it play music? If the answer to that question is yes, there’s a good chance that it is. Artists who fit that description, including Eminem, Foo Fighters, Coldplay, Muse and My Morning Jacket, are among the 130 acts who are scheduled to perform at that long-lived festival, which runs from Aug. 5 through 7 at Grant Park in Chicago. Also on the bill this year are deadmau5, A Perfect Circle, Cee Lo Green, Damian “Jr. Gong” Marley & Nas, the Cars and Ween, as well as (deep breath) Bright Eyes, Arctic Monkeys, Big Audio Dynamite, Deftones, Beirut, Explosions in the Sky, Death From Above 1979, Ratatat and Crystal Castles, the festival’s organizers announced on Tuesday.

RAND--Madelon L.,Kekst and Company Inc. mourns with great sadness the passing of Madelon Leventhal Rand, beloved wife of our chief executive officer Lawrence A. Rand. Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about election-related violence in Nigeria characterized incorrectly the victory of the incumbent, Goodluck Jonathan. He was elected, not re-elected. (He became president in 2010 after President Umaru Yar'Adua died, and Mr. Jonathan, who was vice president, succeeded him.) The article also misstated the name of a village where a human rights researcher said he saw a mosque that had been burned down. It is Maraba Rido, not Maraba Rio.

The Chicago White Sox edged the Yankees, 2-0, behind a sterling start by Phil Humber, who allowed his only hit with one out in the seventh inning.

10 P.M. (National Geographic) THE ANGEL EFFECT Near death as he and two companions trekked for 36 hours over the mountains and glaciers of the sub-Antarctic South Georgia Island, the explorer Ernest Shackleton later wrote, ''It seemed to me often that we were four, not three.'' Years later a 9/11 survivor, an astronaut and a scuba diver would each tell a strikingly similar story about a mysterious presence that guided them to safety in their time of peril. A phantom? An angel? Or a trick of the mind? This ''Explorer'' edition uses recent neurological research -- on subjects like this student, above -- to investigate the phenomenon called ''the third-man factor,'' experienced by hundreds of people. The documentary is based on the book ''The Third Man Factor: Surviving the Impossible,'' by John Geiger, who is an author, with Owen Beattie, of ''Frozen in Time: The Fate of the Franklin Expedition'' and the president of the Royal Canadian Geographical Society. 8 P.M. RIZK--Khalil. On the 10th anniversary of his passing, the family of Khalil Rizk wishes to remember his life in this city where he lived and worked. Khalil founded and ran the Chinese Porcelain Company, an antiques store where he shared his love of objects and his considerable scholarly knowledge of Asian art with many. He was also a founder of the Asian Art Fair, the founding President of the non-profit Venetian Heritage, on the board of directors of the Chamber Music Society, and a member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, just to name a few of the organizations he contributed to. Khalil touched many people's lives with his kindness, generosity and grace. We miss his laughter, his wisdom, and his ability to transform an ordinary moment into a celebration of beauty. May he rest in peace and joy.

NEW YORK A brief report on Monday in some editions about parking regulations misstated the days this week that alternate-side street cleaning regulations are suspended. It is Monday and Tuesday, not Tuesday and Wednesday. The report also misstated the reason for the suspension. It is the seventh and eighth days of Passover, not the sixth and seventh days.

He worked for Curtis-Wright, Republic Aviation and Supermarkets General Corporation. He is survived by his wife Carolyn Widerman, his children Steven and Susan all of Huntington, and Paul of Accord, NY, and his grandchildren Laurie Beth, Samson, Marc, Chloe, and Zachary. Please make contributions to Temple Beth El, 660 Park Ave., Huntington, NY 11743.

Phil Hughes is a baseball player with an insightful mind, quick with an answer for everything, from hockey trivia to episodes of ''The Office'' to his own pitching motion. But now, Hughes is stumped, and so are the Yankees. All the progress he made rebuilding his arm strength over the last 10 days stagnated Monday, when he cut short a bullpen session because his shoulder felt too dead to continue. It was his final test before he was to begin a minor league rehabilitation assignment Thursday, but those plans have been canceled, replaced by a visit Monday night with the team doctor Chris Ahmad.

O'NEILL--Rev. Joseph J.,M.M., 91 of Brooklyn, Maryknoll missioner 61 years, died March 22. He served in Rome, South America and the U.S. Survived by sisters Margaret Barrett, Kings Park, NY; Veronica Glennon, Naples, FL; and many nieces and nephews. Wake: April 26, at 4:30 and 7:30pm at Maryknoll, Ossining, NY. Funeral Mass: April 27, 11:00am, Maryknoll Mission Center. Memorial donations in Father O'Neill's name to Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers, PO Box 302, Maryknoll, NY 10545.

DONALDSON--Edward Eames (Ted), The "Long Goodbye" ended peacefully for Ted in the comfort of his home on April 19, 2011 attended by his loving family. Ted is survived by his wife Stephanie, and sons John (Karen), Stephen (Sarah), Geoffrey (Mollie) and Peter (Laurie), seven grandchildren, and a brother William (Jane) of New York City and cousins Georgia Cummings, Suzanne Rice, and Sandy Marx. Born in Buffalo, NY in 1927, Ted graduated from The Nichols Preparatory School first in his class (highest in school). Following graduation he enlisted in the U.S. Navy. After World War II, Ted enrolled at Yale University earning two undergraduate degrees. Ted went on to earn a MBA from the University of Michigan and a Masters of Engineering from the Chrysler Institute of Engineering. With the start of the Korean Was Ted joined the US Air Force as a First Lieutenant. He spent his entire professional career with Chrysler including time in England in the 60's and 70's. Upon retirement Ted perfected his golf game, traveled extensively and spent many happy hours with his family on the Canadian shore of Lake Huron. A celebration of Ted's life will take place at Christ Episcopal Church, Grosse Pointe Farms, MI., at 11:00am on Wednesday, April 27, 2011 with The Very Reverend Father Dr. Davis Deiter Celebrant, and The Reverend Father Grayhame Bowcott, Homilist. A private inurnment will follow at Christ Church Columbarium. A second celebration of Ted's life will take place at St. John's By-The-Lake Anglican Church, Grand Bend, Ontario this summer. Memorial donations to the Gross Pointe Academy and the Alzheimer Society of Huron County, Ontario would be greatly appreciated by the family.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Saturday about Hazel Dickens, the bluegrass singer and songwriter, misstated the title of one of her songs. It is ''They'll Never Keep Us Down,'' not ''They Never Keep Us Down.'' The obituary also misstated the name of an award Ms. Dickens received and the year she received it. It is the National Heritage Fellowship, not the National Heritage Award; the year was in 2001, not 2008.

BANNER--Gerson, peacefully joined his beloved wife, Helaine, on April 24th. Adored father of Jon (Barbara), Patricia and Elizabeth. Grandfather of David, Alissa and Sydney, great-grandfather of Jake. Tough, smart, successful businessman, loyal friend. He will be greatly missed.

The New York Stock Exchange, that bastion and soundstage of capitalism, has always held itself up as a model of good corporate governance. It has strict governance rules for companies whose shares trade on its exchange. Even through years of weathering Enron and other corporate scandals, not to mention the outcry over the pay package for its own former chief executive, Richard A. Grasso, the exchange has marketed a Big Board listing as a Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval. So it has been somewhat surprising to watch the board of the exchange's parent company as it defends its planned merger with Deutsche Borse and fights off a rival bid from Nasdaq OMX Group and IntercontinentalExchange, or ICE.

ADAMS--George Bell, 80, of Manhattan and Old Field, NY, died on April 24, 2011 at home in Manhattan after a valiant battle with cancer. He will be profoundly missed by his beloved family, friends and former colleagues. Survived by his devoted wife of 58 years, Lucy. Loving father of Lisa (Jim Rowe), Marea, George Jr. (Jean) and Alison (Peter Collery) and adored "PopPop" of Chris and Lucia Rowe; Eliza, Mimi, and Alison Butler; George and Kate Adams; and Claire, Ned, and Elizabeth (Bip) Collery. Born and raised in New York City, he graduated from Yale University in 1952 and from Harvard Law School in 1957. He served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Army (Artillery) 1952 1954. He worked his entire legal career at Debevoise & Plimpton. Chairman of the firm's corporate department 1988 1993 and managing partner of its London office 1993 1996. He served as an arbitrator for the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission; a director of the Lawyers Alliance for World Security and a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York; Chairman of the Board of Sarah Lawrence College; President of The Greater New York Fund (United Way of New York City); trustee and executive committee member of the American Trust for the British Library; fellow of the Pierpont Morgan Library; member of the Yale University Council; and member of the Board of Visitors of the CUNY Law School. In retirement, he co-founded Gray Matters, an advisory group of retired professionals offering services to community based organizations. The funeral service will be held at 12:00pm, on Friday, April 29, 2011 at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to either the American Trust for the British Library, c/o Seana Anderson, rev@seanaanderson.com, or to Broadway Housing Communities, c/o Ellen Baxter, ebaxter@broadwayhousing. org.

BODENHEIMER--Arthur, of Philadelphia, PA, formerly of River Edge and Hackensack, NJ, passed away on Saturday, April 23, 2011 at the age of 90. Born in Frankfurt (M) Germany in 1921. Arthur escaped the Holocaust and came to the US in 1938. He was a publishing executive for 48 years, starting at Scholastic Magazines, and moved on to the Saturday Review of Literature, Pocket Books (Simon & Schuster), and retired in 1989 from the Benjamin Company, publishers of promotional books. He served in the US Army from 1942-1945 and participated in the Aleutian Campaign (Attu) and Marianas (Saipan). He received the Bronze Star and served in the US Air Force Reserve. He was a master of The New York Times crossword puzzles. His generosity and optimism were boundless. Husband of Suzanne (nee Ottenheimer), and adoring father of Peter (deceased), and Joan Borowsky, son-in-law Ted, and granddaughters Lisa, Julie and Alison, all of Lafayette Hill, PA. Funeral services at 1pm at Temple Avodat Shalom, 385 Howland Avenue in River Edge, NJ with burial at Cedar Park and Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Shiva at 7:30pm on Tuesday, April 26 and Wednesday, April 27 in the Presser Lounge at Cathedral Village, 600 East Cathedral Road, Philadelphia, PA. In lieu, consider a donation to the charity of your choice, Temple Shalom, or the Peter Bodenheimer Memorial Fund at Brown University, Providence, RI, 02912.

In one of the least welcome signs of the success that the musical ''The Book of Mormon'' is enjoying on Broadway, representatives said on Monday that counterfeit tickets had been sold to and presented by theatergoers on at least five different occasions in recent weeks. Adam Miller, the company manager for ''The Book of Mormon,'' said in a telephone interview that counterfeit tickets were first identified at the Eugene O'Neill Theater about two weeks ago; a group entered with eight tickets for orchestra seats, but when each ticket was scanned by an usher it came up as an invalid seat in the theater's mezzanine. Mr. Miller said similar incidents occurred as recently as the show's Friday and Saturday matinee performances, and each time, the fraudulent tickets showed the same mezzanine seat when they were scanned.

Wanna buy a bridge? You're too late. The 110-year-old Willis Avenue Bridge was floated to a Jersey City junkyard last week where it is being dismantled to be sold for scrap. You could have bought it for $1 - cash and carry. But when there were no takers five years ago, city officials required the contractor for the new Willis Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River to dispose of the old one.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. - Donnie Walsh and Mike D'Antoni stayed behind closed doors Monday and might remain there for some time, at least until questions about Walsh's future are settled. Walsh's contract as the Knicks' president expires June 30 unless the team picks up his option by Saturday. James L. Dolan, the Madison Square Garden chairman, has given no hint about his intentions. He could conceivably let the option deadline pass and offer an extension later.

Richard G. Ketchum is plotting Finra 2.0. The chairman and chief executive of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has ambitious plans to expand the influence of Wall Street's self-regulatory agency. At Mr. Ketchum's urging, Finra is vying to replace the Securities and Exchange Commission as the top enforcer overseeing tens of thousands of investment advisers. Finra, a private nonprofit, already monitors 600,000-plus stockbrokers.

An obituary on April 18 about Pietro Ferrero, an executive of the Italian food company Ferrero, misstated the location of Alba, the city where the company is based. It is in northwestern Italy, not northeastern Italy.

The Suzanne Farrell Ballet and Houston Ballet, troupes not often seen in New York, are among the companies scheduled to appear at the Joyce Theater in 2011-12. In addition to regulars like Garth Fagan Dance, Momix and Complexions Contemporary Ballet, and flamenco and tango performances, the season will feature a Martha Clarke work, ''Angel Reapers,'' created in collaboration with the playwright Alfred Uhry (Nov. 29-Dec. 11), and the return of a Christopher Wheeldon-less Morphoses, with the premiere of ''Bacchae,'' from the company's new resident artistic director, Luca Veggetti (Oct. 25-30). The Houston dancers will bring a new work by Jorma Elo (Oct. 11-16), while the Washington-based Farrell company will be dancing an all-Balanchine program (Oct. 19-23). More information is available at joyce.org. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

RAND--Madelon. The Brooklyn College Foundation and Brooklyn College mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, secretary of the foundation board, Madelon Rand. Deeply admired for her warmth and engagement, Rand extended her energies to teaching in the Department of English Language and Literature for more than a decade. Upon retirement in 2009, Rand's commitment to the college and its mission was honored by her husband Lawrence through the establishment of the Madelon L. Rand Chair in Literature. We celebrate how much of herself she gave to the college and are grateful for her spirit and generosity that will continue to inspire us.

Last week's school vacations were a boon for Broadway, with an unusually high numbers of musicals - 11 - each earning more than $1 million in ticket sales, according to box-office data released by the productions on Monday. Over all, Broadway shows grossed $28.9 million, up from $23.9 million the week before. ''The Lion King'' edged out the usual No. 1 show, ''Wicked,'' though both family-oriented productions grossed almost $2 million apiece, in part by charging premium ticket prices of $250 and $300, respectively, for many seats. Adult fare also proved lucrative: The critically acclaimed ''Book of Mormon'' set a house record for the Eugene O'Neill Theater last week, grossing $1,014,228 - a significant achievement for a theater with just 1,066 seats. (The previous record was set in 2007 by ''Spring Awakening.'') The 10 other shows in the million-dollar club had far more seats for sale; ''Jersey Boys'' grossed $1.17 million in the next-largest theater in the club, the August Wilson, with 1,228 seats.

SYRIA The army stormed the restive city of Dara'a with tanks and soldiers and helped arrest dozens of people in towns across the country in an escalation of a widening crackdown on Syria's five-week-old uprising, according to human rights activists, residents and accounts posted on social networking sites. They said at least 25 people were killed in Dara'a, with reports of bodies strewn in the streets. LIBYA NATO warplanes struck Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's compound in Tripoli, the capital, and bombed a state television complex in an escalation of the air campaign to aid the rebels. The attack on the compound was the third since air raids began in mid-March, but the strike at the television complex was the most significant broadening yet of the NATO air campaign to a nonmilitary target.

''Are you the playwright?'' the young woman asked the bearded, bespectacled older man who was handing out fliers on Sunday night under the marquee of Broadway's Golden Theater. Indeed he was: At age 75, after decades trying to find a bigger platform than Off Broadway for his messages, Larry Kramer is making his Broadway debut with ''The Normal Heart,'' his autobiographical work from 1985 about the AIDS crisis in New York City. Mr. Kramer had just given one of his fliers, headlined ''A Letter from Larry Kramer,'' to the woman, Kelly Richards, a tourist from Sydney, Australia. He had been handing them out since preview performances of ''The Normal Heart'' began on Tuesday night - an unusual role for a Broadway playwright, but classic Kramer.

MCGREAL--Joseph A.,of Spring Lake Heights, New Jersey on the 23rd of April at 76 years of age after battling complications from a stroke. Born March 6th, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY to the late Joseph and Aresta. Joe resided in Manhasset, NY for 33 years and retired to Spring Lake, NJ in 2000. He received a BBA in Business from St. Francis College in Brooklyn, NY. Joe served in the United States Army from 1955-1957, including active duty in Korea. Joe's early career began with Pfizer Pharmaceuticals where he served in several roles, including Vice President of Marketing for Roerig. In later years, Joe published several medical journals including Cardiovascular Medicine. He later launched his own company, Med/Pharm Publishing, developing educational programs for residents and physicians. In Spring Lake, Joe retired to an active life of playing golf, enjoying his grandchildren, and attending St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church. A warm, generous and witty man, Joe delighted in his family and grandchildren who lovingly called him "Big Joe". Joe is survived by his wife of 52 years, Peggie and their three children: Patrick (wife Kathleen) of Albany, NY, Pegeen Whalen (husband Jerome) of Lincroft, NJ and Joseph (wife Caroline) of Bethesda, MD and five grandchildren Margaret, Colleen, Patrick, Joseph, and Erin. Joe is also mourned by his sisters Anne Canavan (husband Edward), Mary McGreal, and sister-in-law Maureen McGreal, wife of his brother Thomas (predeceased) and their families. In addition, Joe will be deeply mourned by his many nephews and nieces, extended family and many dear friends. Visiting will be Wednesday, from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy. 35 at New Bedford Rd., Wall. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Thursday, 9:30am at St. Catharine's Church, Spring Lake. Entombment will follow in St. Catharine's Cemetery, Wall. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Carmelite Monastery, 341 Highland Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11207. For more information or to send condolences please visit: OBrienFuneralHome.com

MESSINGER--Joan. Passed away on April 25, 2011. Beloved matriarch of a loving family. Joan was married to her devoted husband, Martin Messinger, for over 54 years. Joan's daughters, sons in-law and grandchildren; Daryl Messinger and Jim Heeger, Adam and Robert; Rabbi Sarah Messinger and Rabbi Jeffrey Eisenstat, Ari, Miriam and Rachel; Alice Messinger, Sophie, Jesse and William; Lisa Messinger and Rabbi Aaron Panken, Eli and Samantha; all were blessed to have her as part of their lives. She had a career in Early Childhood education. Her charitable interests included Jewish Camps, education, art, and Westchester Reform Temple. Joan's humor, insight, cooking, and energy were a gift to all who knew and loved her. Services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY on Wednesday, April 27 at 12:30pm. Family requests private burial. Contributions in Joan's memory may be sent to WRT Education Fund or the URJ Eisner Camp Scholarship Fund.

Hundreds of thousands of Northerners were mobilizing for war in April 1861, but few with the speed and initiative of Dorothea Dix. When news of President Lincoln’s call for three-month volunteers reached her home in Trenton, the middle-aged reformer set out immediately for Washington. She arrived in Philadelphia just in time to catch the last train through Baltimore before the bridges north of the city were burned, cutting off Washington and temporarily suspending travel to the capital from points north. Undeterred by what must certainly have been a harrowing ride, Dix arrived in Washington on April 19th and headed straight for the White House.

If the Memphis Grizzlies defeat the San Antonio Spurs tonight in Game 5 of their first-round playoff series, it will be only the second time that a No. 8 seed has defeated a No. 1 seed in a best-of-seven-games N.B.A. series. That means a few things are likely. First, we’ll hear a lot about what a huge upset this is, given that the Spurs, who had the second-best record in the league this year, have won four championships in the last dozen years and the Grizzlies have never won a playoff game before this series began. Second, we’ll get lots of analysis about how the Spurs let things get away from them. And third, what attention is given to the Grizzlies and what they did right won’t include much about the contributions of their player Shane Battier.

Think Billie Holiday singing “Strange Fruit”; the Plastic Ono Band and “Give Peace a Chance”; or Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young and “Ohio.” These are songs that send chills down your spine.

Don’t expect to find baguettes and pastries at Grand Street Bakery. Come May, the space will be transformed into a shop for delicious goods of the vintage variety: heritage butcher stripe shirts will hang from the baking racks, a scattering of leather purses will reside on the wooden tables, and bangles and beaded necklaces will be displayed on bagel holders. The idea for the space was cooked up by Neal Mello, the former buyer for What Goes Around Comes Around and Urban Outfitters, who hounded the previous owner every day for two months before it finally became his. Mello artfully retrofitted the décor to its new use: the large metal ovens now double as changing rooms for cool garb like neon swimsuits, and the flour silos provide spacious storage. He’s also added furniture, art books and records to sell alongside his finely selected apparel collection. There are plans to have a lounge and espresso bar on the back patio and host art shows in the basement. But one thing remains the same: “I am going to keep the name The Grand Street Bakery here. It’s been here 25 years, and I told the landlady I was going to leave this sign.”

During the health care debate, it was fair to argue that the Democratic Party was more serious than the Republican Party about the underlying policy questions. By this I don’t mean that the Democrats necessarily had the correct approach to our dysfunctional health care system, or that the final legislation deserved to pass. (I don’t think it did.) But the proposals that eventually became the Affordable Care Act/Obamacare at least took the the system’s pathologies seriously, drew on some of the smartest liberal health care wonkery, and tried to grapple with the scale of the problems they were confronting. The Republicans, on the other hand, never coalesced around a substantial alternative, declined to embrace the best proposals from conservative policy thinkers, and generally made a purely negative (and sometimes cynical) case against the Democratic bill, rather than setting out a convincing and rigorous alternative.

The diplomat and strategist George F. Kennan was a marvelous connoisseur of his own bitterness, and some of the funniest passages in his “Memoirs: 1925-1950″ concern just how little interest the State Department had in his various cables and memorandums. On one sad occasion he was in Washington helping to sort backlogs and pulled out some of his own unread dispatches, confronting him with the choice of trashing them forever or saving them for the files. Kennan was a great writer and knew it; he kept them, unopened, for the files, marked “of interest.”

I was oddly excited to read that a couple of scientists at the Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, Calif., had published a huge study of the relationship between age and body temperature. Here at last, I thought, might be the answer to one of life’s most enduring mysteries: Why do assisted living facilities and nursing homes always feel like Phoenix in August? Do old people really prefer, or need, such relentlessly toasty temperatures?

On May 4 the Icelandic capital will celebrate the opening of the Harpa-Reykjavik Concert Hall and Conference Center, a stunning monolith whose shimmering glass facade was designed by the artist Olafur Eliasson. The building will be the new home of the Icelandic Opera and the Iceland Symphony Orchestra (which previously had to make do with performing in movie theaters), and for the opening celebration there will be concerts by local bands like Mammút and Agent Fresco as well as screenings of nature movies and documentaries. Many Icelanders hope the building, conceived of as a new cultural hot spot for the city, will also be a tourist draw during the long, dark winters — a fact of life that was central to the design. “In Iceland, 30 percent of the day is twilight. One third of people’s lives are lived in this transitional zone,” says Eliasson, whose facade reflects the low northern light in bewitching variation, as though it is lit from within. “The relationship people in Iceland have to the landscape is like the relationship you have to a close family member. It has to do with the way the light gives the landscape a constantly changing personality. It speaks to you with such finesse.”

NEW YORK An article on Monday about the Fifth Avenue Easter Parade and Easter services at St. Patrick's Cathedral described incompletely the subjects of pictures held by protesters outside the cathedral who were demonstrating against a recent spate of hate crimes and the Roman Catholic Church's position on same-sex marriage. They were members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered community who had committed suicide recently or had been killed in hate crimes, not just suicide victims.

With our hearts still broken in a hundred thousand flaws following the cancellation of ''Law & Order'' last year, fans of the series' longtime star, Sam Waterston, will see the actor trade his district attorney's suit for the royal garb of King Lear in a new production at the Public Theater as part of a coming season that includes works by Mike Daisey, Nathan Englander, David Henry Hwang, Richard Nelson, and Stew and Heidi Rodewald. The Public, which announced its 2011-12 season on Tuesday, will open on Oct. 11 with ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs'', written and performed by Mr. Daisey, the ''21 Dog Years'' monologist, about America's obsession with Apple and its chief executive. Its production of ''King Lear,'' starring Mr. Waterston as that tragic Shakespearean monarch and directed by James Macdonald, will begin performances on Oct. 18. Other planned productions include ''The Twenty-Seventh Man,'' Mr. Englander's play (adapted from his short story) about a Yiddish writer in a Soviet prison, to begin on Feb. 21; and David Henry Hwang's ''Chinglish,'' about an American businessman traveling in China.

LAWA, THAILAND -- The villagers in this poverty-stricken farming community are passionate about their food, especially the traditional varieties of fermented fish that one aficionado describes as tasting like heaven but smelling like hell. It can be a fatal attraction, medical researchers say. The raw fish that is so avidly consumed in the stilt houses that sit among rice paddies and wetlands of the country's northern provinces contain parasites that can accumulate in the liver and lead to a deadly cancer. Known as bile duct cancer, it is relatively uncommon in most parts of the world but represents the majority of the 70 liver cancer deaths a day in Thailand, according to Dr. Banchob Sripa, the head of the tropical disease research laboratory at nearby Khon Kaen University.

The modernization of Archie Andrews, that lovable redhead from Riverdale, continues. Archie Comics announced that the company would start offering some of its titles available for digital download in Spanish, The Associated Press reported. ''I've been thinking about it for quite a while,'' said Jon Goldwater, the co-chief executive of Archie Comics. ''When you talk about globalizing through digital, you can't really do that if you're only in English.'' In January the company announced that it would offer digital versions of its comics on the same day that the print editions arrive on newsstands. Digital copies of Archie comics are $1.99, one dollar less than their print counterparts. The company is beginning its Spanish digital offerings with 30 titles that will be priced at 99 cents each, the same price as some of the older comics that Archie offers online. ''I wanted to make these as accessible and available as possible,'' Mr. Goldwater said.

If Rebecca Federman and Ben Vershbow of the New York Public Library get their wish, they will have thrown an epic party for tens of thousands of people who visited, enjoyed the food and then, like perfect guests, did all the dishes. For Mr. Vershbow, the manager of the library's digital labs, and Ms. Federman, its culinary librarian, ''doing the dishes'' involves neither soap nor water. But it does require a little elbow grease: It is the process of transcribing the 10,000 menus in the library's online gallery to turn it into a fully searchable database that can be browsed by dish, beverage or price as well as name and date.

Standard & Poor's lowered its outlook for Japan to negative on Wednesday, citing the damage from the devastating earthquake and tsunami in March and estimating that reconstruction costs were likely to reach as high as 50 trillion yen, or $612 billion. S.& P. kept its long-term rating for the Japanese economy unchanged at AA-, but its decision to lower the outlook is a signal of a possible downgrade further down the line. It reflects the damage and disruption caused by the disaster and the nuclear crisis after it.

Here's a simple rule of thumb for determining if a particular band is probably on the lineup for the 20th anniversary edition of Lollapalooza: does it play music? If the answer to that question is yes, there's a good chance that it is. Artists who fit that description, including Eminem, Foo Fighters, Coldplay, Muse and My Morning Jacket, are among the 130 acts who are scheduled to perform at that long-lived festival, which runs from Aug. 5 through 7 at Grant Park in Chicago. Also on the bill this year are deadmau5, A Perfect Circle, Cee Lo Green, Damian ''Jr. Gong'' Marley & Nas, the Cars and Ween, as well as (deep breath) Bright Eyes, Arctic Monkeys, Big Audio Dynamite, Deftones, Beirut, Explosions in the Sky, Death From Above 1979, Ratatat and Crystal Castles, the festival's organizers announced on Tuesday. Lollapalooza's electronic and dance music stage, called Perry's, will feature performances by Girl Talk and Kid Cudi, as well as the festival founder (and the stage's namesake) Perry Farrell, who for some reason is performing under the name PerryEtty vs. Chris Cox. A complete lineup and more information can be found online at lollapalooza.com. If you like trivia or just want to feel old, the inaugural Lollapalooza featured artists like Jane's Addiction, Living Colour, Ice-T & Body Count, Violent Femmes and Fishbone when it toured nationally from July 18 through Aug. 28, 1991.

ADAMS--Kenneth Gaither. York College/CUNY mourns the passing of Professor Kenneth G. Adams, Chair and Professor of the Performing and Fine Arts Department, who died at home in Queens on Wednesday, April 20th after a brief illness. A native of Baltimore, with a Bachelor of Music Education (Howard University) and a Master of Music (Manhattan School of Music), he was considered a master of the flute, piccolo, clarinet and saxophone. His Broadway credits started with Guys and Dolls in the 1970s and concluded with Finian's Rainbow in 2010. He played with the New York City Ballet, the Brooklyn Philharmonic, the New York Virtuosi, the Dance Theatre of Harlem and the Black Repertory Ensemble of Chicago and recorded with Luther Vandross and Mary J. Blige. York College students have benefited from Prof. Adams' extraordinary experience in performance, conducting, and musicianship since 1971. We deeply appreciate his contributions; his qualities of calm, discipline and balance will be missed. A memorial service will be held on May 21, 2011 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, New York 11375. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Velma, son Mark and granddaughter Marleigh. President Marcia V. Keizs and the York College Community

Ricardo Morales and the New York Philharmonic have finally closed the deal. The orchestra back in October offered Mr. Morales -- one of the stars of the Philadelphia Orchestra -- the job of principal clarinetist, a key position that had been open since the end of the 2008-9 season. A spokesman said today that Mr. Morales had signed a contract and would officially start in New York in September 2012 once his obligations end in Philadelphia. The orchestra hopes to have Mr. Morales play some weeks on an ad hoc basis next season and possibly as early as this summer. The loss of Mr. Morales will be another blow to the Philadelphia Orchestra, which this month filed under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. New York operagoers may be familiar with his sound. He was a principal in the Metropolitan Opera before going to Philadelphia. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

NATIONAL An article on Monday about the choice of Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida to lead the Democratic National Committee erroneously attributed a distinction, provided by the D.N.C., to Ms. Wasserman Schultz. She will be the second woman elected to the position, not the first. The first was Jean Westwood, who was elected in 1972. The error also appeared in a report in the National Briefing column on April 6.

MIRSKY--Stanley, M.D. The trustees, faculty and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Dr. Stanley Mirsky, who died at age 81. Dr. Mirsky completed his residency at The Mount Sinai Hospital in 1959, and joined as an attending physician in 1962. He served as Clinical Professor in the Department of Medicine, Division of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Bone Disease. A preeminent diabetologist, Dr. Mirsky dedicated his career to teaching the importance of proper blood sugar control through diet, exercise, and appropriate treatment. He was recognized for his pioneering research, dedication to patient care, and the success of his books aimed at teaching diabetic care to a lay audience. In 2007, Mount Sinai honored Dr. Mirsky by establishing the Annual Stanley Mirsky, MD, Lectureship Award, given to distinguished endocrinologists from around the world. The Mount Sinai community extends its condolences to Dr. Mirsky's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

Lederman (Mark), her son Peter Grayson (Josephine) and the grandsons that she adored, Bradley and Eric. She was a very private person in life and final arrangements will be in keeping with that spirit. The family will receive friends at Nancy's home between 4:30pm and 7:30pm on Thursday April 28, 2011. Memorial donations can be sent to The Manhattan School of Music, "Nana's Way fund", 120 Claremont Avenue, NY, NY 10027.

PEYSER--Joan. We extend our deepest condolences to Kami, Tony and Monica on the passing of their mother. Music writer extraordinaire, she was smart and witty. The room was always filled with laughter when she was around. She is missed already. Our thoughts are with you. David and Fran Alexander

FRONT PAGE An article on Friday about military setbacks suffered a day earlier by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya misidentified the United Nations official who had described a flood of Libyan refugees into Tunisia. He is Firas Kayal, not Faras Kaya. The article also misstated the United Nations organization for which Mr. Kayal is the spokesman. It is the High Commissioner for Refugees, not the Human Rights Commission, an organization that no longer exists. (The Human Rights Council replaced the Human Rights Commission in 2006.)

STEPHENSON--J. Clayton, 78, of Greenwich, CT and Nantucket, MA died peacefully at home on April 24, 2011. He graduated from Yale in 1954 and began a career with Union Carbide from which he retired after 35 years in 1989 as CFO and Vice Chairman. He was the principal sponsor of the Human Origins Exhibit at Yale's Peabody Museum and at his 50th Reunion endowed a Professorial Chair in Anthropology. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Sarah Stephenson, daughter L. Parker Stephenson, son Robert Willard Stephenson and two grandchildren.

MIRSKY--Stanley. The Department of Medicine of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Stanley Mirsky, M.D. Dr. Mirsky was one of Mount Sinai's pre-eminent diabetologists. He was a devoted diabetes supporter and advocate for decades, teaching the importance of proper blood sugar control through diet, exercise and appropriate treatment, giving his patients the possibility of living a long life of high quality free from complications. To further the principles that have guided his life and service, Dr. Mirsky and Mount Sinai established the Stanley Mirsky, MD Diabetes Education Unit in 2007. Dr. Mirsky was a Clinical Professor of Medicine, having joined Mount Sinai in 1962. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and friends. Mark Babyatsky, M.D., Chair of Medicine Derek LeRoith, M.D., Ph.D, Chief of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Bone Disease

Madame Nhu, who as the glamorous official hostess in South Vietnam's presidential palace became a politically powerful and often harshly outspoken figure in the early years of the Vietnam War, died on Sunday in Rome, where she had been living. She was 86. Her death was confirmed by her sister, Lechi Oggeri.

WENZELL--Alan T. With a profound sense of sadness we honor Alan T. Wenzell and all that he contributed to the Milbank Memorial Fund. Tom served on the Board of Directors from 1987 until 2001 when he became the Fund's first Trustee Emeritus, a position he held until his death. He chaired the Finance Committee from 1990 to 1999, served on the Executive Committee from 1990 to 2001, and was a founding and continuing member of the Committees on Programs, Evaluation, and Staff Compensation. He was an effective leader in investing the moral, intellectual, and financial resources of the Fund and played an essential role in redirecting the Fund's sense of purpose in the early 1990s. Members of the board and staff relished Tom's wit, his incisive analyses, and his mastery of the art of conversation. We basked in his enthusiasm for the work of the Fund. Tom was a beloved friend. Samuel L. "Tony" Milbank, Chairman & Carmen Hooker Odom, President Milbank Memorial Fund
A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about ''War Horse,'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, misidentified the war that is the setting for the play. It is World War I, not World War II.

MIRSKY--Stanley, MD. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our colleague, teacher, and friend. Dr. Mirsky came to Mount Sinai as a Resident in Medicine in 1958 and has devoted more than 50 years of service to the institution. Specializing in the field of Diabetes, The Stanley Mirsky, MD Diabetes Education Unit was established with philanthropic donations and is dedicated to multidisciplinary screening, counseling and diabetes prevention. He was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients and was a compassionate practitioner of medicine. He was loyal to his patients and his patients were loyal to him. Dr. Mirsky will be remembered for his outstanding contributions in teaching, patient care and patient education. The AAS salutes his legacy in the fight against Diabetes. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD President Gila Leiter, MD Vice President Amy J. Weinstein Administrator

HADARY--Gideon, April 3, 2011. Diplomat and international entrepreneur. Facilitated immigration of middle eastern Jews to Israel in 1940's. Survived by wife Eunice; children Sharon, Susan, Joel, Tamara; six grandchildren; four great-grandchildren.

LILIENFELD--Sylvia M. Gettinger. 5/20/1910 4/27/2001 We remember our beloved aunt and friend for her grace, her courage in the face of many grievous losses, for her constant love, encouragement, advice, and support. Diana and Jason Gettinger, Karen Fisher.

MESSINGER--Joan. The Board of Directors and Staff of Bronx House mourn the passing of Joan Messinger, beloved wife of our longtime Board Member, past President and friend, Martin E. Messinger. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Marty and his entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. John Usdan, President Howard Martin, Executive Director

REGAN--James F.,81, of Staten Island, NY, died on April 25, 2011. A passionate educator who served four terms as president of the NYC Board of Education. Retired USNR captain. Loving husband of the late Mary F., devoted father of Claire and Cara.

If Rebecca Federman and Ben Vershbow of the New York Public Library get their wish, they will have thrown an epic party for tens of thousands of people who visited, enjoyed the food and then, like perfect guests, did all the dishes. For Mr. Vershbow, the manager of the library's digital labs, and Ms. Federman, its culinary librarian, ''doing the dishes'' involves neither soap nor water. But it does require a little elbow grease: It is the process of transcribing the 10,000 menus in the library's online gallery to turn it into a fully searchable database that can be browsed by dish, beverage or price as well as name and date.

A new poll from the Pew Research Center reports that nearly half of Americans identify states’ rights as the primary cause of the Civil War. This is a remarkable finding, because virtually all American textbooks and prominent historians emphasize slavery, as they have for decades. Even more striking, the poll shows young people put more stock in the states’ rights explanation than older people. The 38 percent of Americans who believe slavery was mainly to blame find themselves losing ground.

Well, for better or worse, Locationgate is over. On Wednesday, Apple responded with a statement explaining the presence of a file in the hard-drive backup of every iPhone and cellular iPad. “Apple is not tracking the location of your iPhone,” it said. “Apple has never done so and has no plans to ever do so.” So basically, Apple is saying that the researchers were wrong on both counts. First, the “secret file” contains information about nearby Wi-Fi hot spots and cell towers, not your exact location. And second, your device is sending information to Apple, although in an anonymous, encrypted form. One part of Apple’s response is a little unconvincing, says David Pogue. Read the rest of post at Pogue’s Posts.

Adele’s second album, “21,” will return to the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s Top 200 next week, for the sixth nonconsecutive week. I appreciate the small-r republican ardor with which Mark Oppenheimer assails America’s royal wedding obsessives, but he’s fighting a losing battle. “Americans are supposed to loathe and reject monarchs,” he writes, but it’s telling that all his examples of that loathing (“In the earliest years of English settlement, this land was a proud haven for king killers … [we] fought a bloody war for the privilege to ignore the king of England … Anti-monarchism was then written into our Constitution …”) are centuries old, dating from a time when republicanism was an exciting cause rather than a somewhat-ossified assumption. Since those days, we’ve regressed to the (very human) mean: We’re fascinated by the royal family that we once overthrew, we have our own hereditary dynasties (and the slobbering coverage to match), and we’ve gradually turned our presidency into a quasi-imperial office, complete with coronations and cultic devotions and all the rest. True, by the standards of modern history, with its parade of strongmen and caudillos and presidents-for-life, our republican institutions have been impressively resilient. But even the American experience suggests that the anti-monarchical temper Oppenheimer invokes is ultimately artificial and unnatural, a triumph of theory over instinct and idealism over human nature. In their hearts, most people want a king and queen.

April 29, 10:18 a.m. | Vote Results After two hours of debate, the Stanford faculty senate voted to bring ROTC back on campus: 28 members voted for its return, 9 voted against it and 3 abstained. During the faculty senate meeting, Former Secretary of Defense William Perry discussed how bringing ROTC back to Stanford could help the military by providing better trained and educated leaders. Much of the debate was centered on the military's posture toward transgendered people and also on whether academic credit would be granted to ROTC courses. An amendment to the resolution of bringing ROTC back to campus was added that stated the faculty senate's objection concerning the military's treatment towards transgender people.

NEWMAN--Nadine Fribourg, beloved wife of Jerrold Newman, mother to Daniel, Jason and Scott, passed away on April 25th after a long and brave struggle with cancer. She graduated from the Nightingale-Bamford School, Mount Holyoke College and Columbia Business School. In addition to her husband and three sons, Nadine is survived by her mother, Mary Ann Fribourg, and her siblings -- Robert, Paul, Charlie and Caroline. Nadine will be deeply mourned by her many nephews and nieces, extended family and many dear friends. Services will be held Thursday, April 28, 12:30pm at Temple Emanu-El, Lowenstein Sanctuary, 10 E. 66th Street entrance. A private burial service will follow. The family will sit shiva at the home of Mary Ann Fribourg, from 6-9pm on Thursday, April 28 and from 4-6pm Friday, April 29. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Nadine Fribourg Newman's name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087, directed for Dr. Ephraim Casper's research programs.

GAZA AND WEST BANK The two main Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, announced that they were putting aside years of bitter rivalry to create an interim unity government and hold elections within a year, a surprise move that promised to reshape the diplomatic landscape of the Middle East. It was the first tangible sign that the upheaval across the Arab world was having an impact on the Palestinians. YEMEN Although President Ali Abdullah Saleh and the political opposition appear to be in the final stages of negotiating a mediated settlement in which Mr. Saleh would cede power, protesters continued to engage in civil disobedience and to stage demonstrations. At least 10 protesters were killed by gunfire from government supporters in Sana, the capital, according to local doctors. And in Aden, a protester and a soldier were killed during fighting between demonstrators and the security forces.

Marianne Elliot-Said, who as Poly Styrene, the pioneering, braces-wearing frontwoman of the 1970s British band X-Ray Spex, made a place for feminine brashness in punk, died on Monday in East Sussex, England. She had been treated for cancer at a hospice in East Sussex, near her home in St. Leonards-on-Sea, in the south of England.

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about a vision experiment that indicated that the neurological connection between sight and touch is learned rather than innate misstated the role of Pawan Sinha of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Dr. Sinha was the senior author of a study published in Nature Neuroscience describing the experiment, not the lead author. (Richard Held, also of M.I.T., was the lead author.)

An obituary on April 19 about Evelyn Einstein, Albert Einstein's granddaughter, misidentified the writer of an unpublished manuscript she had in her possession, which led to the discovery of letters written by Einstein in 1986. The manuscript was written by her mother, Frieda -- not by her grandfather.

For the second time since they began deliberations Monday, the jurors in the trial of Raj Rajaratnam were able to listen to secretly recorded phone calls between Mr. Rajaratnam and his supposed associates. The calls are at the center of the government's case against Mr. Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group co-founder, who is accused of gaining $63 million trading on illegal stock tips. Of the more than 40 wiretaps played during the trial, jurors have so far asked to rehear 15.

ELLIS--Michael, was a giant among men. Beloved husband. Inspiring father. Adoring grandfather. Cherished brother and uncle. Born December 20, 1927 in Lvov, Poland. "Mike" survived WWII in heroic fashion, caught several times by the Nazis, he helped his family survive. His remarkable energy, wisdom, luck, and precocious glint of his blue eyes allowed Mike to survive unimaginable circumstances. These traits served him well until the day he passed. In 1947, Mike and his family immigrated to New York where he continued to use his natural gifts and love of life to build an enormously successful career in the diamond industry. Mike and his brother-in-law, Sidney Gluck (of blessed memory) took a small diamond business, T. Gluck and Company, and built it into an international industry leader. Mike was loved by everyone he met. He saw beauty in every human being and showed respect to all. He was a restaurant connoisseur, a major sports fan, and an avid skier. He loved a good party, beautiful music, a game of gin, and his family. He will be sorely missed. His gifts will live on. Funeral is Thursday, April 28, 11am at Temple Beth Shalom in Roslyn Heights, NY.

With sardonic resignation, President Obama, an eminently rational man, stared directly into political irrationality on Wednesday and released his birth certificate to history. More than halfway through his term, the president felt obliged to prove that he was a legitimate occupant of the Oval Office. It was a profoundly low and debasing moment in American political life. The disbelief fairly dripped from Mr. Obama as he stood at the West Wing lectern. People are out of work, American soldiers are dying overseas and here were cameras to record him stating that he was born in a Hawaii hospital. It was particularly galling to us that it was in answer to a baseless attack with heavy racial undertones.

VANNEMAN--William Henry Moore. After 102 years of an active, fulfilling life, William Henry Moore Vanneman, Sr., died gracefully, April 26. He enjoyed people and was the most giving person his family and friends ever knew. As a boy, he attended Camp Dudley and throughout his life he lived the Camp Dudley motto, "The other fellow first." When awarded Cornell's Frank H.T. Rhodes Award for Exemplary Alumni Service, Hunter Rawlings, then President of Cornell, stated, "A man's success in life isn't what he gains, it is what he gives." This described Bill's life. He and his precious wife Rosamond were married for 52 years before her passing in 1990. He was born to Charles Reeve and Mercy Moore Vanneman on April 6, 1909 in Albany, New York. He graduated from the Albany Academy, Cornell University, and Harvard Business School. He served in the Navy during WWII, completing his service as a Lieutenant Commander. After the war, he spent the remainder of his work life with Matthew Bender Company, a law book publisher in New York, retiring as senior vice president. He and Rosamond lived and raised their children, Bill and Reeve, in Old Greenwich Connecticut, where he served as Senior Deacon of the First Congregational Church. He is survived by his two sons, William Henry Moore Vanneman Jr. and his wife Irene and Reeve Doering Vanneman and his wife Jane; by two grandsons Matt Vanneman and James Vanneman and their mother Jill Jacovitz; three granddaughters Kara Klein and her husband Ken Klein, Michelle Vanneman and her husband Chad Yoder, and Julie Vanneman and her husband Scott Kiesling; and by the lights of his later life, his eight great-grandchildren ages 2-14, all of whom adored him dearly. Services will be held on Tuesday, May 3 at 1:30pm at the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Camp Dudley YMCA or Cornell University.

ON the music festival circuit, now in full swing, head-to-toe fringe is encouraged (along with crochet and lace and teeny shorts, if the photos from Coachella are any indication). But despite all of the extravagant fringe on the runways -- Roberto Cavalli showed more fringe than a Cher concert -- frolickers in the city are advised to keep the boho look in check. Lauren Manoogian, a jewelry designer in Brooklyn, pairs her adjustable hand-knotted raffia and leather necklace with classics. ''I wear it with a silk shirt or T-shirt and summer blazer,'' she said. ''It adds a strange and unexpected texture underneath, like another shirt.'' Lauren Manoogian necklace, $196 at Maryam Nassir Zadeh, 123 Norfolk Street (Rivington Street); (212) 673-6405.

FIELDS--Arthur, beloved husband of Jane Fields, passed away Tuesday morning April 26 after a long illness. Arthur was a graduate of City College, enjoyed a career of many years in the NYC Dept. of Social Services, and was an enthusiastic volunteer at the Museum of Natural History. A memorial service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th St and Amsterdam on Friday, April 29, at 11:30 am.

ALBANY - Vincent L. Leibell III, a former state senator who pleaded guilty in December to corruption charges, is to be sentenced in two weeks. Prosecutors are seeking two years in prison. But Mr. Leibell, a Republican from Putnam County, has an alternate proposal: a tour of duty as a diplomat in some unsteady corner of the globe - perhaps Iraq or Libya.

THOMASSIAN--Thomas. (June 25, 1926-April 19, 2011). Loving father, grandfather, friend and mentor. Proud Korean War vet, artist, poet, playwright, TV talk show host. Jennifer, Tommy, Jeremy, Maida, Linda mourn him.

For most of its 45-year existence, the Oakland Alameda-County Coliseum had no corporate name. But in 1998, the stadium was renamed for Network Associates, a computer software company. Then, from 2004 to 2008, it became McAfee Coliseum, when Network Associates returned to a previous name.

An article on April 7 about substance abuse treatment centers in Brooklyn misstated the type of treatment offered by the branch of the Hazelden rehabilitation center in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. It is outpatient, not residential.

Nadine passed away on Monday, April 25, 2011 after a long illness. Our thoughts and prayers go out to their families.

BUSINESS An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about the federal government's difficulty in divesting some of its real estate holdings misspelled the name of a deputy director in the Office of Management and Budget. He is Jeffrey D. Zients, not Jeffrey D. Zeints.

ORADELL, N.J. -- Nancy and Eric Olsen could not pinpoint exactly when it happened or how. All they knew was one moment they had a pastoral view of a soccer field and the woods from their 1920s colonial-style house; the next all they could see were three solar panels. ''I hate them,'' Mr. Olsen, 40, said of the row of panels attached to electrical poles across the street. ''It's just an eyesore.''

MIRSKY--Stanley, MD. Lenox Hill Hospital expresses deep sorrow on the death of Dr. Stanley Mirsky, a distinguished member of our staff since 1975. Dr. Mirsky was a respected clinician adored by his patients, and an author and educator who dedicated his career to teaching patients and professionals about the prevention and treatment of diabetes. We honor his memory and extend our sincere sympathies to his family. William O. Hiltz, Chairman, Exec Comm, Bd of Trustees Philip P. Rosenthal, Executive Director Anthony Antonacci, MD, Medical Director Jack Ansell, MD, Chairman, Department of Medicine

Q.Yesterday I received e-mail from a friend in North Carolina discussing the effects of a recent tornado. On the side (not in actual message) were sites for some cities near my friend. Is Google snooping in my messages? I am not pleased. A.Like other free Web-mail services, Google uses advertising to help support the cost of Gmail. To make the ad links more enticing, Gmail uses targeted ads that are often related to the places or topics mentioned within your messages.

For years, advertisers have known that ''hitting the fear button,'' as they would put it, is a good way to drive sales. Judging by the number of pitches you see for products that claim to protect your data, it must still be true. The latest is from DIFRwear, a company that makes wallets for about $23 that are meant to block RFID signals given off by some credit cards, ID cards and passports.

An article on March 17 about wearing stretch yoga pants at work misspelled part of the name of a woman who frequently wears them. She is Lisa Berlenbach Dixon, not Bierlenbach. Ms. Dixon pointed out the error in an e-mail received by The Times on April 13.

SCHMID--James D.,born August 8, 1950 in Queens NY, passed peacefully on Saturday April 23, 2011. Jim enjoyed success in his career at Chase Manhattan Bank, NY. Family and friends are invited to his viewing on Thursday April 28, 2011 from 6pm-8pm at James McGee, Funeral Home 690 Belmont Ave. 2nd St. Pike, Southampton, PA.

When the major choreographer Alexei Ratmansky signed on as artist in residence at American Ballet Theater in 2008, it was considered a coup for a company that had sometimes been criticized for conservative repertory. So the news that Mr. Ratmansky has extended his contract all the way to 2023 can be considered a major vote of confidence. Ballet Theater announced Wednesday that Mr. Ratmansky, who had been committed to the troupe through 2013, agreed to the extension two years before his previous contract was up. The terms remain unchanged: he is to spend 20 weeks a season with the company and choreograph at least one new work a year or restage one of his older dances.
The Scene City column last Thursday misspelled the surname of a guest at the 30th anniversary party for the art magazine Bomb. She is A. M. Homes, not Holmes.

NEWS of a collaboration between a designer and his publicist is not something you hear about every day, but neither is a publicist who moonlights as an arbiter of men's style. Nonetheless, the tie designer Alexander Olch, who doubles as a filmmaker, and Michael Williams, the creator of the style blog A Continuous Lean and a partner in Paul + Williams, teamed up to tweak the traditional rep tie for spring. The ties, inspired by vintage patterns in a men's store catalog from the 1960s, are hand-sewn at Mr. Olch's Brooklyn factory from fabric specially woven in England. ''The regimental stripes are engineered with a white warp silk thread to make crisper colors and whiter whites,'' he said. You don't even need all-temperature Cheer! Alexander Olch for ACL & Co. neckties, $140, and bow ties, $110, from acontinuouslean.com.

The Washington Nationals' Livan Hernandez, who is scheduled to pitch against the Mets on Thursday night, has been linked to a convicted drug dealer in Puerto Rico, a connection that is being studied by officials in Major League Baseball. The 36-year-old Hernandez, who pitched for the Mets in 2009, was named in the evidence presented in the trial of Ángel Ayala Vázquez, who was convicted on Tuesday of conspiracy to distribute cocaine, heroin and other drugs in Puerto Rico. Prosecutors said Vazquez had expensive cars and a warehouse registered in Hernandez's name.

MIRSKY--Stanley. Boys and Girls Harbor, Inc.,its Trustees, staff, alumni, alumnae and youth deeply mourn the loss of their much loved Board Member, friend and Harbor supporter of many decades, Dr. Stanley Mirsky. Our deepest heartfelt condolences to Stanley's wife Sue and children Jonathon and Jennifer. We will forever miss you Stan.

WENZELL--Alan T. The Board of Directors and Administration of the Mountain Top Arboretum mourn the loss of its long time member and Director Emeritus, Alan T. ("Tom") Wenzell. We extend our sympathy and condolences to his family. Tom gave over thirty years of wise counsel, support and dedicated service to the Arboretum. His love of trees and knowledge of horticulture, practiced fervently on his near-by farm, brought a practical perspective to our deliberations. More importantly, Tom was a strong advocate for the Arboretum's educational mission to the general public. We will greatly miss Tom's deep intellect, ready humor and collegial participation which enabled us to grow and prosper.

BUSH--Flora Wilhelm, died on Saturday, April 23, 2011 at 80 years of age. Loving wife to Dr. George Bush. Devoted mother to Dr. Jared W. Bush and Dr. Rachel W. Bush. Beloved grandmother to Maxwell, Zachary and Jacob. Services were held on Sunday, April 24 at Riverside. She will be deeply missed.

BEHRMAN--Nancy Terner, (77), passed away Thursday April 21, 2011 at her home in Manhattan, after a more than 10 year fight against lung cancer. She was born in Brooklyn and lived most of her life in Manhattan but found her peace and inner self when she was at her house in Sagaponack, NY. She was a longtime Trustee of The Manhattan School of Music and a patron of the arts for many of the New York and Sagaponack area institutions. She was predeceased by her former husband Dr. Stanley J. Behrman, her parents Emanuel and Mathilda Terner, and her sister Elaine T. Cooper. She is survived by her sister Carol T. Lederman (Mark), her son Peter Grayson (Josephine) and the grandsons that she adored, Bradley and Eric. She was a very private person in life and final arrangements will be in keeping with that spirit. The family will receive friends at Nancy's home between 4:30pm and 7:30pm on Thursday April 28, 2011. Memorial donations can be sent to The Manhattan School of Music, "Nana's Way fund", 120 Claremont Avenue, NY, NY 10027.

PATTERSON--Bevin Daly, 84 years old, died on April 25, 2011 after a long courageous battle with Alzheimer's disease. Bevin was the beloved wife of 54 years of Robert P. Patterson Jr. She was the dearly loved mother of six children: Anne Patterson Finn, Robert P. III, Margaret, Paul, Katherine, and Bevin C. Patterson who died as a child in 1961. Bevin grew up in Fairfield Connecticut, the fourth child of eight born to Madeleine and Paul Daly: Madeleine D. Potter, Paul, Michael, Daniel, T.F. Gilroy, Dermot Daly and Alison Gerard, who survives her. Since the age of four, when she taught herself to read, she was an avid reader and excelled at school, skipping several grade levels. She graduated from Barnard College; and, before marrying, worked as a secretary and as a model. Though very beautiful, her most striking qualities were her kindness and compassion. In addition to being a devoted mother and wife, Bevin volunteered to teach children reading in Harlem and religious education in the Bronx. She also did volunteer work for the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society and the Central Park Conservancy. She served as secretary of the Board of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York City. Much of her spare time, she spent gardening at her home in Cold Spring on Hudson, N.Y., where she was involved in a variety of organizations such as the Putnam County Garden Club and Historical Society. After her children were raised, she worked as a real estate agent at the Douglas Elliman firm. Bevin's amazing grace, beauty, and kindness endured through her long struggle. She will be remembered for her compassion, thoughtfulness, and insight. She faced her difficult last years courageously, without a complaint, and always unselfishly. All who knew her felt blessed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis Tennessee 38105 (donors@stjude.org). A wake will be held on Friday, April 29, from 4:00 to 7:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, N.Y.C. A service will be held on Saturday, April 30, 2011, at 11:00am at Our Lady of Loretto, Fair Street, Cold Spring on Hudson, New York, 10516.

The small screen rules the pop charts this week, with big-selling new entries from the ''Glee'' franchise and Disney's latest teen-pop confection. ''Glee Presents the Warblers'' (Columbia), the 10th album from the Fox series, opened at No. 2 with 86,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It's the latest big showing for ''Glee,'' which has already surpassed Elvis Presley's record for the most songs that have placed in Billboard's singles chart. (As of February, that number was 113 songs, compared to Presley's 108.)

Sonos, the heralded music system that allows users to send music tracks to units placed throughout the house, has long had a soft spot for Apple. Apps developed for both the iPhone and iPad allow Sonos owners to choose which music they'd like to have streamed from their PC or the Internet, and control the volume of that music on each device independently. In a bow to the importance of the Android platform, the company announced last week that it had created an Android app that does the same, as well as a few more tricks not available on Apple's devices.

9 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE Michael (Steve Carell, above) bids a teary farewell to his Dunder Mifflin colleagues before leaving for Colorado, and taking his ineptitude with him, in his final appearance in the series. Meanwhile Deangelo (Will Ferrell) and Andy (Ed Helms) work overtime to hold on to Michael's biggest clients. The Thursday-night comedy block begins at 8 with ''Community,'' in which Shirley (Yvette Nicole Brown) goes into labor just as the anthropology class gathers for its final exam. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 10, Jerry (Jim O'Heir) stirs up trouble with his entry in the community art show. And in ''30 Rock,'' at 10:30, Liz (Tina Fey) decides to assume control of her personal life by fixing up her dream apartment. Jack (Alec Baldwin) has his own problems when Avery (Elizabeth Banks) is held hostage. And Tracy (Tracy Morgan) is stunned to learn that Kenneth (Jack McBrayer), Dot Com (Kevin Brown) and Grizz (Grizz Chapman) have bonded in his absence. 8 P.M. (Showtime) BUD GREENSPAN PRESENTS: VANCOUVER 2010 STORIES OF OLYMPIC GLORY In his final documentary, Mr. Greenspan, who died on Dec. 25 at 84, follows the athletes of the Winter Games in Vancouver, British Columbia.
PRESSNER--Victoria, loving wife, mother, mother-in-law, and devoted friend. She will live on in our hearts. Donations may be made in her honor: Temple Shalom, Greenwich, CT.

ADAMS--George Bell, 80, of Manhattan and Old Field, NY, died on April 24, 2011 at home in Manhattan after a valiant battle with cancer. He will be profoundly missed by his beloved family, friends and former colleagues. Survived by his devoted wife of 58 years, Lucy. Loving father of Lisa (Jim Rowe), Marea, George Jr. (Jean) and Alison (Peter Collery) and adored "PopPop" of Chris and Lucia Rowe; Eliza, Mimi, and Alison Butler; George and Kate Adams; and Claire, Ned, and Elizabeth (Bip) Collery. Born and raised in New York City, he graduated from Yale University in 1952 and from Harvard Law School in 1957. He served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Army (Artillery) 1952 1954. He worked his entire legal career at Debevoise & Plimpton. Chairman of the firm's corporate department 1988 1993 and managing partner of its London office 1993 1996. He served as an arbitrator for the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission; a director of the Lawyers Alliance for World Security and a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York; Chairman of the Board of Sarah Lawrence College; President of The Greater New York Fund (United Way of New York City); trustee and executive committee member of the American Trust for the British Library; fellow of the Pierpont Morgan Library; member of the Yale University Council; and member of the Board of Visitors of the CUNY Law School. In retirement, he co-founded Gray Matters, an advisory group of retired professionals offering services to community based organizations. The funeral service will be held at 12:00pm, on Friday, April 29, 2011 at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to either the American Trust for the British Library, c/o Seana Anderson, rev@seanaanderson.com, or to Broadway Housing Communities, c/o Ellen Baxter, ebaxter@broadwayhousing. org.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Wednesday about the singer-songwriter Phoebe Snow misidentified the producers of her first album, ''Phoebe Snow,'' on Shelter Records. They were Dino Airali and Phil Ramone, not Denny Cordell. (Mr. Cordell, the president of the label, produced earlier versions of some songs on the album, but nothing on the album itself. The tracks he produced were included on a later CD reissue of the album.) The obituary also misidentified the Shelter executive who discovered Ms. Snow at the Bitter End in Greenwich Village. It was Mr. Airali, not Mr. Cordell.

SPORTS An article on April 14 about the recruitment of a New York City high school basketball player, Marquis Barnett, misstated his former Bronx neighborhood. It was Crotona Park, not Katonah, which is in Westchester County.
STONE--Allen. Happy 75th Birthday Dearest Brother. Loved and Remembered Forever and a Day. Cynthia

NATIONAL A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the relationship between the Microsoft founders Paul Allen and Bill Gates and their impact on Seattle misstated the name of Mr. Allen's museum of rock 'n' roll there. As the article and accompanying chart said, it is the Experience Music Project, not the Music Experience Project.

AT Tess Giberson's whitewashed little shop in SoHo, you can browse this designer's minimalist spring Shift collection and learn firsthand why she is a favorite in the fashion and art worlds. The shop, which opens officially on May 5, showcases her functional modern basics and assorted accessories made specifically for the store, like Ninh Wysocan's cable necklaces, as well as a collection of limited-edition art books and music selected by Ms. Giberson (at right) and her husband, the artist Jon Widman. A peacock-feather wall piece by the artist Carol Bove, a spot-on complement to the mostly black and white garments, is not for sale, but it's yet another reason to pay a visit. Tess Giberson, 97 Crosby Street (near Prince Street); (212) 226-1932.

CULTURE The Books of The Times review on April 15, about ''The Dead Yard'' by Ian Thomson, a look at modern Jamaica, misidentified the event described by Mr. Thomson at which people wore ''spiffy'' tracksuits and ''glittery'' jewelry. It was a funeral, not a concert.

Comcast said Wednesday that it had become the first cable or satellite provider to have TV shows from each of the four major networks on its video-on-demand service. While the selection is still incomplete - hit shows like ''Modern Family'' and ''The Big Bang Theory'' are missing - the deals represent progress for the television industry. Both network owners and cable providers know that they have to provide more shows on demand to keep consumers happy. Making more programming available on the cable platform could be perceived as an alternative to online streaming and digital video recording.

Their pieces were not based on work by Jean-Michel Frank. (Only the furniture designed by RDAI Studio was based on Mr. Frank's work.)
