The letters that Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. wrote over a career of nearly seven decades in public life, including correspondence with John F. Kennedy, Henry A. Kissinger, Katharine Graham and Reinhold Niebuhr will be collected in a new book that Random House has acquired. And while it will contain documents like Schlesinger's critique of Kennedy's manuscript for ''Profiles in Courage,'' it will not include the donkey that William F. Buckley Jr. sent to Schlesinger. ''I signed for it,'' Stephen Schlesinger said of the donkey, which arrived at the family home in Cambridge, Mass., when he was 10 years old, ''and I put it out in our backyard, so it grazed. And then my mother had the foresight to realize that I was under age to sign, so she called up and they took the donkey back.''

9:02 p.m. | Updated Berkshire Hathaway directors have accused David L. Sokol, once considered a possible successor to Warren E. Buffett, of misleading the company about his personal stake in a lubricant manufacturer that Berkshire recently agreed to acquire.

The CNBC anchor Erin Burnett is poised to sign a long-term contract with CNN, according to three people with knowledge of her plans. The signing will represent a shift to general news anchoring for Ms. Burnett, who has shown interest in branching out beyond business news, CNBC's specialty. It is unclear what time slot she will occupy at CNN.

A report on April 14 in the Browsing column misidentified the new creative director for the fashion label Project Alabama. She is Charlotte Greenough, not Morgane Le Fay. (Morgane Le Fay is the company Ms. Greenough used to work for.)

DeMOTT--Margaret Aldrich, on April 24, at the age of 100, in Montecito, California. Maddie was the daughter of Richard Aldrich, the eminent New York Times music critic, and Margaret Chanler Aldrich, and sister of the late Richard Chanler Aldrich. Survivors include her sons Christopher Rand, Richard Rand, Peter Rand, her daughter Diana Rand Fairclough, eight grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. She is predeceased by her daughter Mary Rand Johnson. Maddie spent her childhood on West 74th Street in New York City, and at Rokeby, the family farm on the Hudson in Dutchess County. A graduate of Vassar College, pianist and Francophile, she was also an accomplished equestrienne who rode to hounds with the Chatham Hunt, where she met her first husband, Christopher Rand, a Yale undergraduate at the time, who later earned renown as a journalist and New Yorker correspondent. Maddie DeMott was a woman who attracted a great many loving friends and admirers all through her life wherever she made her home, on the West Coast, in San Francisco and Santa Barbara, and abroad, in Paris and Nairobi, Kenya. Maddie was an avid tennis player. For over a decade she was happily married to Byron DeMott, a beloved Santa Barbara tennis pro, with whom Maddie played an active role in the Southern California tennis world of the 1950s and early 1960s. She was a self-styled adventurer. In the years following Byron's premature death in 1963, Maddie traveled to Africa, where she lived and worked for twenty years as the founder of the Flying Doctor's Society, a fundraising arm of the African Medical Research Foundation. She was a woman of sparkling wit and modesty who took delight in the name bestowed upon her by a British television documentary titled "The Angel of Africa." Maddie will be missed by her extended family and all those who knew and worked with her, including the staff of the Casa Dorinda, where she spent the last years of her eventful, adventurous life. Donations in Maddie's memory can be made to AMREF.

RAND--Madelon. USTA Serves, the national charitable foundation of the United States Tennis Association mourns the passing of Madelon, our friend and wife of our devoted board member and Vice President Larry Rand. Madelon has been a shining light and role model to her family, friends and colleagues. Her commitment to education and her unselfish work to fight ALS has been remarkable. She will continue to be an inspiration to all of us as we continue our work in changing lives through tennis and education.

DUBAI, United Arab Emirates - Arif Naqvi isn't spooked by turmoil. Abraaj Capital, his Dubai-based private equity firm, made one of its first buyouts in the aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, acquiring Aramex, a Jordanian express mail company that traded in New York.

The Broadway musical ''Baby It's You!'', about the pop and doo-wop music company Scepter Records, has quickly yielded a disharmonious reunion of several artists from that label. On Tuesday - the day before the show formally opens - lawyers representing Dionne Warwick, Chuck Jackson and Beverly Lee, a founding member of the girl group the Shirelles, as well as the estates of Doris Coley Jackson and Addie Harris McFadden, both founding members of that group, filed suit against the producers of ''Baby It's You!,'' saying their names, likenesses and life stories are being depicted without their consent. A complaint filed in New York State Supreme Court says the plaintiffs were ''cheated out of their royalties when they were young and popular'' and ''are now victimized again.'' The complaint seeks a jury trial and damages from the musical's producers, including Warner Brothers Theater Ventures and Warner Brothers Entertainment. The show was previously presented at the Pasadena Playhouse and workshopped at the Coast Playhouse in Los Angeles, and has run in previews at the Broadhurst Theater since March 27; it is scheduled to open on Wednesday night. A press representative for the Broadway production referred inquiries to Warner Brothers, where a spokesman said he had not yet seen the lawsuit and could not comment.

EUSTICE--James. We mourn the passing of James Eustice, our retired partner and dear friend. As Counsel Jim founded the tax practice at Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman (predecessor to the present firm, Cooley LLP) in 1970 while a full professor at NYU School of Law. From that time and since he was universally regarded as one of the nation's foremost tax scholars and lawyers. We benefited from his superb judgment, acumen, warmth and good humor. We will forever be grateful for his friendship and for his mentoring of generations of lawyers in our firm. Cooley LLP

Q.I've had an E-Z Pass to use with bridge and tunnel tolls around New York for years, but am wondering how long the battery lasts. Can I replace it myself if the battery dies?A.Those small E-Z Pass tags - which are typically stuck to the car's windshield to electronically transmit payment information to a sensor on the toll booth- are powered by small lithium batteries that are permanently sealed into the device. These batteries are meant to last for nine or 10 years, but the Metropolitan Transit Authority's Bridges and Tunnels department has a tag-replacement program in place. When your tag's battery is deemed to old, the M.T.A. sends out a letter and then a replacement kit with a new tag and a post-paid envelope to return the old one. You do need to return the old tag to avoid the $23 lost-tag fee. More information on the replacement program can be found here.

Like other e-book readers, the iBooks app for the iPad (and iPhone or iPod Touch) allows you to make margin notes inside digital books. To make a note in an open iBooks file, press down on the iPad's screen to select the word or phrase you want to annotate. In the menu bar that appears above your selected text, tap the Note button to create a digital sticky note and use the iPad keyboard to type in your thoughts. When you tap the text behind the note, the note file shrinks to a small square on the edge of the book's page, near the highlighted text you originally selected. Tap the shrunken note to expand it so you can review your annotations.

Andrew Morton, who has written biographies of Diana, Princess of Wales, Monica Lewinsky and Tom Cruise, has turned to a familiar subject for his next book: the newly wedded royal couple Prince William and the former Kate Middleton. St. Martin’s Press said on Friday that it would publish “William & Catherine: Their Story” on May 17, promising that Mr. Morton will tell “the full story” of the couple, including their time at university together, the prince’s proposal in Kenya and the wedding itself, with all its pomp and circumstance. “I have drawn on 30 years of experience covering the royal family to bring perspective and insight into the life of a young man I have watched develop from a toddler and schoolboy into a soldier — just as I have tried to discover more about his bride,” Mr. Morton said in a statement. The book is not an authorized biography, however, and Mr. Morton did not interview William or the Duchess of Cambridge, as she is now known.

It was surely one of the great scientific adventures of the modern age. For several years in the middle of the last decade, a group of eminent climate scientists fell under the patronage of a billionaire philanthropist named Gary Comer, who turned his luxury yacht into a scientific platform for exploring the Arctic. Spending Mr. Comer’s money and riding in planes and helicopters that he procured, the researchers managed in just a few years to turn up intriguing new evidence about the potential for abrupt climate change.

Building a first-class art collection takes a lot of time and a lot of money, but the latest show at the Berlin gallery Arratia Beer, “As Long As It Lasts…,” demands a whole other level of commitment from its prospective buyers. The curators, Josée Lepage and Aric Chen (who has written for The Times), and the gallery have created a pop-up tattoo parlor, engaging one of the city’s best tattoo artists, Sarah Bolen from AKA Berlin, and offering designs from a diverse group of artists and designers, including heavyweights like Lawrence Weiner and Wim Delvoye, as well as fashion favorites like the architect Peter Marino and the German conceptual pranksters Bless. One of the most compelling designs comes courtesy of Olaf Nicolai, who suggests that collectors mark the initials of someone they love or hate using his codified variation on the alphabet. In designing his alphabet, Nicolai says that he “found [a] minimalistic style more interesting,” which didn’t function “like a billboard.” (In other words, you’re out of luck if you’re looking for hearts pierced by daggers or busty mermaids.) His design emphasizes “not just information, but also communication. You have to ask the person [what the tattoo means] if you want to understand it.”

Though the animated Fox comedies “Family Guy,” “The Cleveland Show” and “American Dad” are occasionally known for courting controversy, the network has decided to hold off on broadcasting episodes of those shows that were too close to current events for comfort. Fox was planning on Sunday to show new installments of those series with an interconnected story line about a hurricane on the Eastern Seaboard. These episodes were planned several months ago, before the recent storms that have killed nearly 300 people in the South. But on Friday, Fox said in a brief statement, “In light of the recent storms that have affected the nation, Fox has decided to postpone the crossover episodes of ‘Family Guy,’ ‘American Dad’ and ‘The Cleveland Show’ that were originally scheduled to air this Sunday.” A spokeswoman for the network said these episodes will instead be shown next season.

Of the many bizarre plot lines running through last night’s episode of “30 Rock,” Condoleezza Rice’s sly cameo as the ex-girlfriend of Alec Baldwin’s character, Jack Donaghy, was by far the highlight. In the scene, shown above, Ms. Rice, a former secretary of state and classically trained pianist, challenged Mr. Baldwin, a Lincoln Center regular himself, to a musical face-off. (Mr. Baldwin does not actually perform in the episode.) We asked Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The Times, who interviewed Ms. Rice about her chamber music experience in a profile in 2005, to identify the pieces. “They are all by Mozart,” he said. “The first is the opening of the third movement, the Rondo, from the Piano Quartet in G minor. The second is the opening of the first movement, the Allegro, of that same Piano Quartet in G minor. The third, and this gets complicated, is the slow movement, the Romanze, of the Piano Concerto No. 20 in D minor, not the opening of the movement, but the beginning of the fast middle section of that movement. Whew.” For insiders, Mr. Tommasini said, “the joke is the snippets of pieces played are not at all pieces for flute.” He added, “He tried to match her playing this music on the solo flute, an unfair match.”

As Michael Scott (Steve Carell) said goodbye on “The Office” on Thursday, the NBC sitcom delivered Thursday night’s second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, falling behind “American Idol” on Fox. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Office” drew approximately 8.3 million viewers from 9 to 9:53 p.m., ending just short of the hour and the start of an extended version of “Parks and Recreation” (4.6 million). Although ratings for “The Office” were the highest since January, NBC still lagged behind the other networks. It was a distant fourth place for the night in total viewers, garnering just 4 million for “30 Rock” at 10:30 p.m. and 3.6 million for “Community” at 8.

"Rhapsody," Jennifer Bartlett's epic polymorphous post-painting painting in nearly 1,000 parts is once again on view at the Museum of Modern Art, wrapped around three long walls and looking tailor-made for the museum's giant atrium. The work was first shown here five years ago, as part of an exhibition of works given to the Modern by the collector Edward R. Broida. At that time, the piece's appearance was an early indication that the atrium might serve as something other than a large, alienating event space.

The single most common question I got on my book tour was the following: Do you think Facebook is destroying friendship and deep personal connections? I generally gave a positive answer (Facebook supplements friendship, it doesn’t supplant it) while adding that what matters are the qualities the user brings to Facebook, not the technology itself.

I was listening to a podcast of Tina Fey talking to Terry Gross on "Fresh Air" recently about her book, "Bossypants," and Fey mentioned something in passing that gave me insight into an enduring political mystery. Gross asked Fey about her time writing for "Saturday Night Live" and which guest hosts she particularly liked. Fey talked about how much she enjoyed John McCain when he was on the show in the early 2000s. In 2004, Life magazine photographed the two of them together in Washington for a get-out-the-vote cover.

The young designer Marco Dessí, who was born in Italy and who is based in Vienna, has a knack for clarity. A recent case in point is his Basket chandelier for the venerable Viennese manufacturer Lobmeyr. Dessí took as its starting point the glass-tube arms of an 18th-century chandelier but employed them in a new way, bending them into hexagons, stacking them in a shape inspired by mosque lanterns and the glass-tube windows of Frank Lloyd Wright’s S. C. Johnson Administration Building, and weaving them together with jewel-toned silk cords. The result is an alluring combination of the industrial and the glamorous. Go to lobmeyr.at.

It is not certain that CBS's hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men'' will return next season, but the show's studio, Warner Brothers, confirmed Thursday that it was trying to bring the show back without its original star, Charlie Sheen. A senior Warner Brothers executive, speaking on condition of anonymity because no deal has been set yet for the new version, confirmed Thursday that Chuck Lorre, the creator of the series, has set to work on a reconstruction of the show's format.

He is survived by Shirley, his beloved wife of 66 years, his children Leslie, David, Deborah, and Jonathan, his grandchildren Georgia, Maggie, Emily, Rachel, Robin and Emma, and ten great-grandchildren. A decades-long relationship between Boston's Huntington Theater Company and Stanford and Norma Jean Calderwood has yielded a $10 million gift to the endowment of the theater, its leaders announced on Thursday. The gift from the Calderwood Charitable Foundation, by far the largest in the theater's 29-year history, doubles the size of the Huntington's endowment. The financial boost comes as private support for the nation's major regional theaters is decidedly mixed. Arena Stage in Washington has undertaken more ambitious programming after a $135 million expansion financed by private and public dollars, including a $35 million private gift, while the Intiman Theater in Seattle announced this month that it was canceling the rest of its 2011 season and laying off its staff because of weak revenue projections after a period of significant cost overruns.

Alan Champion, a sign-language interpreter who opened up hundreds of Broadway and regional theater productions to deaf and hard-of-hearing audience members over the last three decades, died on April 22 in Ramona, Okla. He was 55. His death was confirmed by his sister, Alice Burnett. Ms. Burnett, who lives in Ramona, said Mr. Champion had moved there this month to stay with her after lengthy treatment for appendix cancer. Mr. Champion had commuted between his home in Bensalem, Pa., and Manhattan a few days a week in recent years.

(HLN) THE WEDDING OF PRINCE WILLIAM AND KATE MIDDLETON Royals watchers will need to rise and shine extra early to catch the nuptials of William and Kate at Westminster Abbey, above, scheduled for 11 a.m. local time (6 a.m. in New York), after celebrities like David and Victoria Beckham and foreign royalty including the sultans of Oman and Brunei have filed into the pews. The service will be led by the Rev. Dr. John Hall, the dean of Westminster; the couple will be married by the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury. The Right Rev. Richard Chartres, the bishop of London, will present the address; music will be provided by the Chapel Royal Choir and the Choir of Westminster Abbey, the London Chamber Orchestra and the fanfare trumpets from the Central Band of the Royal Air Force, in honor of William's service as a pilot. After the ceremony the newlyweds will travel to Buckingham Palace for the traditional kiss on the balcony in the 1902 State Landau coach (rain gear: the Glass Coach), accompanied by nine gray horses. ROYAL WEDDING PRIME-TIME ROUNDUP Let the analysis and the backbiting begin! Joan Collins, Lisa Rinna, Lisa Vanderpump, Nate Berkus, Jay Manuel and Colin Quinn dish on the details in ''Joy Behar's Royal Wedding After Party,'' at 7 p.m. on HLN. London is the setting for ''The Fox Report With Shepard Smith'' at 7 and''The Royal Wedding,'' a recap of the day's high points at 9, both on Fox News Channel. Perez Hilton and NeNe Leakes let the snark flow with highlights from the wedding in ''Will + Kate Forever,'' at 7 on the Wedding Channel and at 9 on WE. Katie Couric examines the significance of the wedding and the future of the British monarchy in ''The Royal Wedding: Modern Majesty'' at 8 on CBS. You can be sure that no stone will be left unturned, and possibly unflung, in ''Kathy Griffin's Insightful and Hilarious Take on the Royal Wedding,'' at 8 on TV Guide. Ann Curry ventures backstage to find out what happens after the pomp and circumstance in a two-hour version of ''Dateline NBC'' at 9. Barbara Walters reminisces about the events of the day, and no doubt evokes a tear or two, in ''A Special Edition of 20/20: A Modern Fairytale'' at 9 on ABC. And on E! Ryan Seacrest traces the footsteps of the bride and groom in ''Will and Kate: Road to the Altar'' at 9, while Joan Rivers, Kelly Osbourne, George Kotsiopoulos, Giuliana Rancic and Tori Spelling dissect the guests' attire, the headpieces and the gown to end all gowns in a special edition of ''Fashion Police Royal Wedding'' at 10.

NEW YORK A picture credit on Thursday with an article about a Connecticut woman who was arrested for sending her son to a school outside her district misidentified the photographer and for whom the picture was intended. THE ARTS An art review on Wednesday about ''Blinky Palermo: Retrospective 1964-1977'' at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, which includes a painting, ''Composition With 8 Red Rectangles,'' that pays homage to the Russian Modernist Kazimir Malevich, misspelled part of a similarly titled Malevich work. It is ''Suprematism With Eight Red Rectangles,'' not ''Suprametism.''

IMJINGAK, SOUTH KOREA -- On a pleasant spring day, with the wind breezing up from the south, the quirky little tourist outpost of Imjingak -- with its Peace Land amusement park, some souvenir sheds and a Popeye's chicken stand -- hardly seemed like a possible flash point for violent hostilities between North and South Korea. Imjingak, the site of a ferocious battle during the Korean War, has become a favored launching site for some of the South Korean activists who send propaganda balloons northward. The balloon campaign has so angered North Korea that its military has threatened -- as recently as last Friday -- to ''mercilessly'' shell Imjingak and other border towns if the launchings continue. North Korean artillery units are dug in a few kilometers away, just across the world's most heavily militarized border.

Generally regarded as the greatest leadoff hitter ever, Rickey Henderson thrilled baseball fans for a quarter century by stealing a major league-record 1,406 bases. Along the way, his feats on the base paths fueled the stereotype that speed is the leadoff man's defining tool. But it wasn't his base stealing that made him so effective in the leadoff spot; rather, it was his ability to get on base to begin with. From a sabermetric perspective, the cardinal rule of leadoff hitting is to avoid making an out. The No. 1 spot in the order comes to the plate on average 4.8 times a game, nearly a full plate appearance more than the No. 9 hitter at 3.9, according to ''The Book: Playing the Percentages in Baseball,'' a baseball research reference by Tom Tango, Mitchel Lichtman and Andrew Dolphin. A table-setter like Henderson must be able to consistently provide run-scoring opportunities to the players batting behind him. He cannot score, let alone steal, if he is not on base.

Each raised more money -- not less.

After Warren E. Buffett disclosed last month that David L. Sokol was resigning from Berkshire Hathaway amid the revelation that he had bought a $10 million personal stake in Lubrizol while promoting a takeover of the company, Berkshire was quiet for weeks. Now, on the eve of Berkshire's annual shareholders meeting, the company has come out fighting. The company's directors on Wednesday issued a scathing report that accused Mr. Sokol, once a star manager and potential candidate to replace Mr. Buffett atop the Berkshire empire, of violating the company's ethics and insider trading policies.

BENITEZ--Nancy Shannon Critchlow, of Easton, MD, died Tuesday, April 26, 2011. She was 88. Born in Detroit, Michigan September 11, 1922, she was the daughter of the late John and Margaret Evans Critchlow. She was a 1941 graduate of the Baldwin School, Bryn Mawr, PA and attended Wheaton College, MA. She is survived by her: children, Cristina Benitez, Peg Evans and John Benitez; three grandsons; and brother, Roger Critchlow. She was preceded in death by her husband, R. Adm. Rafael Benitez, USN, Ret., her brother, John N. Critchlow, Jr. and sister, Jean Beatty. Memorial contributions may be made to Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers, Christ Church Easton, MD or the Talbot Hospice Foundation.

MOROCCO A powerful bomb exploded at lunchtime in a crowded cafe in Marrakesh, killing 14 people and wounding dozens. The bombing was timed to maximize fatalities in one of North Africa's most popular tourist destinations. While the attack appeared to be the work of a suicide bomber, there was no immediate claim of responsibility. Al Arabiya television reported that at least 11 foreigners were among those killed. BAHRAIN A military court sentenced four Shiite Muslim protesters to death in the killing of two police officers last month during demonstrations against the Sunni-ruled government, Bahrain's national news agency reported. Three other activists who were also on trial in the same case received sentences of life in prison.

An article on Monday about American television networks competing for on-air commentators for the British royal wedding misidentified, using information provided by the agent for Katie Nicholl, the author of ''William and Harry,'' one outlet that has hired Ms. Nicholl. In addition to ABC News and ''Piers Morgan Tonight'' on CNN, she will appear on ''Entertainment Tonight;'' she is not working for the entertainment news magazine ''Extra.''

With a third round of bidding for the Warner Music Group coming to an end this week, another suitor for the music company has emerged, just as some of the leading bidders are considering withdrawing because of worries over Warner's finances. D.M.I., or Digital Music Industries, a consortium led by Bernhard Fritsch, a German-born technology entrepreneur, has made an offer for the company, according to a person involved in the private negotiations who spoke on the condition of anonymity. D.M.I. is made up of managers from GMI, Mr. Fritsch's merchant bank, along with other private equity and banking investors. The size of D.M.I.'s bid was not known.At the same time, concerns about Warner's financial health, and about the outlook for the music business in general, have led Bank of America to consider withdrawing its financing from several companies' bids, according to two people involved in the talks who asked not to be identified because the bidding process was not over. In addition, the Yucaipa Companies, which has been considered one of the top bidders, may pull out of the auction for the same reason, those people said.

PAISNER--David, 87, passed away in Riverdale on April 24, 2011. Dave was a loving husband, devoted father, adoring grandfather and dear father-in-law. Dave will be remembered as a dedicated teacher. His kindness and counsel will be greatly missed by family throughout the country.

OBITUARIES A picture caption with an obituary on March 14 about Joe Morello, the drummer with the Dave Brubeck Quartet, misidentified the bassist in the photograph. It was Joe Benjamin, who worked briefly with the Brubeck quartet; it was not Eugene Wright, who was the bassist for most of the quartet's existence, from 1958 to 1967. A caller alerted The Times to the error on April 22.

DeMOTT--Margaret Aldrich, on April 25, at the age of 100, in Montecito, California. Maddie was the daughter of Richard Aldrich, the eminent New York Times music critic, and Margaret Chanler Aldrich, and sister of the late Richard Chanler Aldrich. Survivors include her sons Christopher Rand, Richard Rand, Peter Rand, her daughter Diana Rand Fairclough, eight grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. She is predeceased by her daughter Mary Rand Johnson. Maddie spent her childhood on West 74th Street in New York City, and at Rokeby, the family farm on the Hudson in Dutchess County. A graduate of Vassar College, pianist and Francophile, she was also an accomplished equestrienne who rode to hounds with the Chatham Hunt, where she met her first husband, Christopher Rand, a Yale undergraduate at the time, who later earned renown as a journalist and New Yorker correspondent. Maddie DeMott was a woman who attracted a great many loving friends and admirers all through her life wherever she made her home, on the West Coast, in San Francisco and Santa Barbara, and abroad, in Paris and Nairobi, Kenya. Maddie was an avid tennis player. For over a decade she was happily married to Byron DeMott, a beloved Santa Barbara tennis pro, with whom Maddie played an active role in the Southern California tennis world of the 1950s and early 1960s. She was a self-styled adventurer. In the years following Byron's premature death in 1963, Maddie traveled to Africa, where she lived and worked for twenty years as the founder of the Flying Doctor's Society, a fundraising arm of the African Medical Research Foundation. She was a woman of sparkling wit and modesty who took delight in the name bestowed upon her by a British television documentary titled "The Angel of Africa." Maddie will be missed by her extended family and all those who knew and worked with her, including the staff of the Casa Dorinda, where she spent the last years of her eventful, adventurous life. Donations in Maddie's memory can be made to AMREF.

She was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, and friend, and a distinguished professor at Fordham University. She will be laid to rest at the Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Sleepy Hollow, NY.

Bill Cook's first business venture -- selling shot glasses with pictures of nude women on the bottom -- flopped. But that did not stop him from developing a sprawling company that has made thousands of medical devices, including heart stents, urological equipment and living-tissue transplants. Along the way he amassed a $3.1 billion fortune, making him the 101st richest American in 2011, according to Forbes magazine. And yet he lived a modest life. He and his wife, Gayle, continued to live in the three-bedroom home they bought in 1967, having moved there from an apartment where they had used a spare bedroom to make a new sort of catheter.

INTERNATIONAL A picture in some copies on April 9 with an article about dozens of protests across Syria was published in error. The picture, which was also published with a separate article, for which it was taken, showed a boat filled with migrants in a port of the Italian island of Lampedusa. It was not a television image of protesters near a barricade in Dara'a, Syria.

CHERRY BLOSSOM FESTIVALS (Saturday and Sunday) Their blossoms have colorful but fleeting lives, so the time is now to see the city's cherry trees in all their splendor. Many of the celebrations, always annual displays of rebirth, are especially so this year; they are helping earthquake relief efforts in Japan. The grande dame of celebrations, the Sakura Matsuri at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, is in its 30th year and will offer sounds, sights and tastes of Japan on Saturday and Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Visitors can make paper cranes that will be matched by charitable donations from a philanthropic organization, or write their thoughts on tea-stained sacks that will be pinned together to make a tea quilt. On Roosevelt Island, above, a cherry blossom festival with Japanese-theme entertainment and food is planned for Saturday, from 1 to 3 p.m., on the West Promenade, with a grove of trees dedicated to the people of Japan. On Sunday a walking tour of the blooming trees on Roosevelt Island -- with a look at the island's history as well -- will meet at 11 a.m. at the Visitor Center Kiosk at the Tram Plaza; a $5 donation is suggested. Roosevelt Island is reachable by tram, bus, car and subway; rioc.com; rihs.us. Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; (718) 623-7200; bbg.org.; $15; $10 for students, 65+ and children 12 and older; free for children under 12 and members. Not to rush you, but one good windstorm, and the show will be all over. (Anne Mancuso)

FRONT PAGE Because of a computer software error, two articles and a chart on Monday about classified documents assessing Guantánamo detainees misstated several numbers. The first article, which reported the government's conclusions about the prisoners misstated the number of prisoners for whom no assessments were available. It is 15, not about 75. The article also misstated the number of detainees about whom the documents offered the first public look because they had been transferred from Guantánamo without going through a hearing process instituted in 2004. It was 193, not 158. The second article, about the process of rating the risks posed by the release of prisoners, misstated the total number of detainee assessments. It was 766, not 704. The chart misstated the number of Russian detainees who were determined to pose a high threat in 2003. It was one, not none.

SENOR--Beatrice (Auslander), Loving mother of Flori Rosenthal, Pamela Glass and Eliot. Survived by brother Herman. Devoted wife of the late Gabriel. Cherished grandmother of Bianca, Geoffrey, Erica, Zachary, Cameron, Gabriel and Harrison and great-grandmother to Jacob.

The Tribeca Film Festival announced its winners Thursday night, with films from Sweden, South Korea, Rwanda and Norway among those taking prizes. The Founders Award for best narrative feature went to ''She Monkeys,'' directed by Lisa Aschan, which looks at the friendship between two girls on an equestrian acrobatics team. The best documentary prize went to ''Bombay Beach,'' a film by Alma Har'el film that looks at a small community on the Salton Sea in California. Both of these awards came with a $25,000 prize.

BUSINESS Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the continuation of an article on Thursday about Renesas Electronics' Naka factory in Japan misstated, in some editions, that factory's contribution to global supplies of a certain automotive computer chip. Renesas as a company supplies about 40 percent of the world market for that chip; that is not the amount supplied by its Naka factory.

Orlando Bosch, a Cuban-American pediatrician and militant Cuban exile leader who was accused, and then acquitted, of masterminding the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner in which 73 people were killed, died Wednesday in Miami. He was 84. His family announced the death. He had been hospitalized with a number of illnesses.

A New York artist well known for capturing street culture and people in cool clothing -- as seen through the lens of a documentarian who knows a thing or two about those topics -- will be the subject of ''Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer,'' a new feature from the ''Wild Style'' director Charlie Ahearn that will have its premiere at this year's BAMcinemaFest, the festival's organizers said on Thursday. Mr. Ahearn's new film chronicles Mr. Shabazz, the Brooklyn photographer whose work (above, a sample) is collected in the book ''Back in the Days,'' with help from Fred Brathwaite, a k a Fab 5 Freddy, and KRS-One, rappers who have figured prominently in Mr. Ahearn's previous work. The full BAMcinemaFest, which is presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music's BAMcinématek program, runs from June 16 through June 26, and opens with Andrew Haigh's ''Weekend,'' about a gay romance that unfolds over 48 hours. Other films include ''Terri,'' a comic feature starring John C. Reilly and directed by Azazel Jacobs; ''Separado!,'' directed by the Super Furry Animals frontman, Gruff Rhys, and Dylan Goch, and described as a hybrid documentary-costume drama about Mr. Rhys's search for his flamenco-singing uncle; ''Magic Trip,'' from the prolific documentary filmmaker Alex Gibney (''Taxi to the Dark Side''), about Ken Kesey and his Merry Pranksters; and ''Last Days Here,'' a documentary about Bobby Liebling and his heavy-metal band, Pentagram. The closing-night film is ''Tournée'' (''On Tour''), directed by and starring Mathieu Amalric (of ''The Diving Bell and the Butterfly'').

Proud great-grandfather to Noah and Logan, Julia and Sam. Private burial in East Hampton near his beloved daughter Nancy. Family and friends will miss "Bobby" very much.

GREEN--Samuel (Sam) Adams. Born May 20, 1940 Died March 4, 2011. Green was a doyen of the New York art scene and in the forefront of the Pop Art movement. As Director of the Institute of Contemporary Art, he organized the first museum exhibition for Andy Warhol. Later in life, he founded Landmarks Foundation to protect "sacred sites" globally. Memorial service May 3. For details contact: samgreen@landmarks foundation.org

Starting in December, Michael Jackson will have a second life in Las Vegas. Jackson's estate has revealed details of the two collaborations with Cirque du Soleil that it announced last fall, with side attractions including a display of memorabilia from Neverland, Jackson's fantastically decorated ranch home in California, and a high-tech exhibition that promises ''a journey to the next level'' of fandom.

This is how it is, these are our customs. If there is something to eat, we will eat it together. If there is nothing to eat, we will have nothing together. ABDALLAH AWAYE, a Tunisian who has taken in Libyan refugees. [A13]

PATTERSON--Bevin Daly, 84 years old, died on April 25, 2011 after a long courageous battle with Alzheimer's disease. Bevin was the beloved wife of 54 years of Robert P. Patterson Jr. She was the dearly loved mother of six children: Anne Patterson Finn, Robert P. III, Margaret, Paul, Katherine, and Bevin C. Patterson who died as a child in 1961. Bevin grew up in Fairfield Connecticut, the fourth child of eight born to Madeleine and Paul Daly: Madeleine D. Potter, Paul, Michael, Daniel, T.F. Gilroy, Dermot Daly and Alison Gerard, who survives her. Since the age of four, when she taught herself to read, she was an avid reader and excelled at school, skipping several grade levels. She graduated from Barnard College; and, before marrying, worked as a secretary and as a model. Though very beautiful, her most striking qualities were her kindness and compassion. In addition to being a devoted mother and wife, Bevin volunteered to teach children reading in Harlem and religious education in the Bronx. She also did volunteer work for the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society and the Central Park Conservancy. She served as secretary of the Board of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York City. Much of her spare time, she spent gardening at her home in Cold Spring on Hudson, N.Y., where she was involved in a variety of organizations such as the Putnam County Garden Club and Historical Society. After her children were raised, she worked as a real estate agent at the Douglas Elliman firm. Bevin's amazing grace, beauty, and kindness endured through her long struggle. She will be remembered for her compassion, thoughtfulness, and insight. She faced her difficult last years courageously, without a complaint, and always unselfishly. All who knew her felt blessed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis Tennessee 38105 (donors@stjude.org). A wake will be held on Friday, April 29, from 4:00 to 7:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, N.Y.C. A service will be held on Saturday, April 30, 2011, at 11:00am at Our Lady of Loretto, Fair Street, Cold Spring on Hudson, New York, 10516.

SWEENEY--James M.,of New York City and Long Beach Island, NJ died suddenly on April 26, 2011 after a brief illness. He was born on June 3, 1938 in the Bronx, New York and attended Cardinal Hayes High School and Iona College. He served in the United States Marine Corps Reserve. Jim had a successful 33-year management career with IBM. His fondest memory at IBM was his expatriate assignment in Nice, France with his family where he was able to explore his love of international business, travel, culture and cuisine. He stepped out of retirement to work for the AFL-CIO for 10 years where he would utilize his talents to serve the working men and women of America. His most joyous and important times were spent with his loving family. He was married to Elizabeth Sweeney for 30 years and they had four children together. Jim is predeceased by his parents, James and Kate Agnes. Survivors include his four children, Carolyn (Bill) Murnane, of Wayzata, MN, Margaret Cooney (David), of Manhattan, Christine (Gavin) Rees, of Manhattan, and James (Jennifer) Sweeney, of West Nyack; his ten loving grandchildren; his brother John (Maureen) Sweeney, and his sisters Cathy (Greg) Hammill and Peggy (Ted) King. Visitation will be held Friday April 29, 2011, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main Street, New City, NY 10956. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered 10:00am, Saturday, April 30, 2011 at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church, West Nyack, NY. Burial will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of James M. Sweeney to the Central Park Conservancy-Adopt a Bench.

Among the questions nagging at investors making the pilgrimage to Omaha this weekend to attend the annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway will be this: Will the outcry over David L. Sokol affect Warren E. Buffett's deal machine? Only two months ago, Berkshire appeared to be riding high. The conglomerate posted a 61 percent gain in annual profit for last year. HANCOCK--George Wade, 92. Known to his friends as Wade, died suddenly April 21, 2011 in an auto accident in Amherst, MA. Veteran of WWII, Wade had a long career as an art director for New York advertising agencies before joining Time Inc. He retired from Norwalk, CT to Mount Desert Island, ME where he was known for his beautiful moss garden. At the time of his death, he and his wife Marianne were residents of the Lathrop Community in Easthampton, MA. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, three grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

HELM--Robert (Bob), beloved minister of Trinity Presbyterian Church, died on April 25. Rev. Helm, a graduate of Princeton University and Union Theological Seminary, celebrated his 50th anniversary of pastoral service in 2010. He spent his life helping those in need; under his leadership, Trinity became known as "the little church with the big heart." Condolences to his family, friends, and members of his congregation. INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, an article on April 21 about the Taliban's rush to take responsibility for attacks on allied forces in Afghanistan, fanning fears of infiltration in the country's military and police, misstated, in one instance, the role of an Afghan border police officer in the April 4 killing of two American soldiers. He was the assailant; he was not one of the victims.

Score another one for big business, it seems. The Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that companies can use contracts that prevent consumers claiming fraud from banding together to file group arbitration claims and, possibly, class-action lawsuits. The case has broad implications for consumers because all sorts of companies, like banks, builders and even nursing homes, use contracts that require disputes to be settled through arbitration and forbid class actions. Banks and credit card companies, in particular, have come under scrutiny recently for their use of such binding arbitration clauses in customer contracts.

11:05 a.m. | Updated European Union antitrust regulators announced on Friday two sweeping antitrust investigations into the world's largest banks and their roles in a market for derivatives where a small number of companies control trillions of dollars of financial instruments. The European officials are looking at whether banks, including Barclays and Goldman Sachs, have harmed rival organizations that could compete in markets for providing information and clearing a form of transaction that had become critical to the smooth functioning of the entire economy.

LIBYA Fighting between rebels and troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi spilled into Tunisia when government forces routed opposition fighters at a crucial border crossing in the southwest and pursued them to a nearby town. Outraged Tunisian officials summoned a Libyan envoy to complain about the incursion, the third in less than a week, Tunisia's deputy foreign minister, Radhouane Nouicer, told the Arabic news channel Al Jazeera. In Misurata, Libya, meanwhile, fighting erupted across a broad front in the city's southern and western areas. SYRIA Soldiers fired on demonstrators carrying olive branches and seeking to break the military's siege of the rebellious town of Dara'a, killing at least 16 people, as thousands took to the streets to protest the government's crackdown of the six-week-old uprising. The violence in Dara'a was the worst on a day in which at least 40 protesters were killed across the country. After noon prayers on Fridays, demonstrators poured into the streets, only to face the determination of the government to disperse them, often with live ammunition.

Ramit Sethi runs the Web site I Will Teach You to Be Rich. Think of the last 10 pieces of personal finance advice you've read. Do any of these sound familiar?-Cut back on lattes!-The world's top 10 coupons-Don't go on vacation this year!If you boil all the advice down, there are just two ways to improve your financial situation: earn more or cut costs. So why don't more personal finance experts talk about earning more? Because most of them don't know how.

The painting is beautiful. Does it really matter if it is by Titian or Giorgione? It did to Joseph Duveen, the art dealer, whose efforts in the 1930s to persuade the art historian Bernard Berenson to change the attribution from one to the other are the subject of Simon Gray's play ''The Old Masters,'' which recently ended a run at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. And it matters to museums like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which will host two staged readings of the play, on June 20 and 27. The readings will feature the Long Wharf cast, with Sam Waterston playing Berenson and Brian Murray playing Duveen. The Met's spokesman, Harold Holzer, said the museum had a long connection with Duveen, owning more than 120 European paintings that at some point passed through his galleries, and acquiring the galleries' archives in 1968. (The Met gave the archives to the Getty Research Institute in 1994, though it has since acquired a microfilm copy.) Mr. Holzer said that Mr. Waterston, who has done readings at the Met before, was instrumental in making this one happen. KATE TAYLOR

EUSTICE--James S.,of New York City, died on Tuesday April 26, 2011 of congestive heart failure. He was 78. He devoted much of his life to his tremendous career teaching, writing about and practicing corporate tax law, but in his free hours he was a marathon runner, balloon traveller, golfer, opera lover, crossword puzzler and beloved father and husband. His zesty humor and twinkling eyes will be missed. He is predeceased by his first wife, LaVaun S. Eustice to whom he was married for 38 years. He is survived by his second wife Carol Fonda Eustice, children from his first marriage Cynthia LaPier of Sheffield, MA and James M. of Pacific Palisades, CA, their spouses, Jim LaPier and Jennifer Avant Eustice and grandchildren Hannah LaPier and Alexander James Eustice. A memorial service will be held at 2:00pm on Monday, May 9th at the First Presbyterian Church of the City of New York on Fifth Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets. PATTERSON--Bevin Daly, 84 years old, died on April 25, 2011 after a long courageous battle with Alzheimer's disease. Bevin was the beloved wife of 54 years of Robert P. Patterson Jr. She was the dearly loved mother of six children: Anne Patterson Finn, Robert P. III, Margaret, Paul, Katherine, and Bevin C. Patterson who died as a child in 1961. Bevin grew up in Fairfield Connecticut, the fourth child of eight born to Madeleine and Paul Daly: Madeleine D. Potter, Paul, Michael, Daniel, T.F. Gilroy, Dermot Daly and Alison Gerard, who survives her. Since the age of four, when she taught herself to read, she was an avid reader and excelled at school, skipping several grade levels. She graduated from Barnard College; and, before marrying, worked as a secretary and as a model. Though very beautiful, her most striking qualities were her kindness and compassion. In addition to being a devoted mother and wife, Bevin volunteered to teach children reading in Harlem and religious education in the Bronx. She also did volunteer work for the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society and the Central Park Conservancy. She served as secretary of the Board of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York City. Much of her spare time, she spent gardening at her home in Cold Spring on Hudson, N.Y., where she was involved in a variety of organizations such as the Putnam County Garden Club and Historical Society. After her children were raised, she worked as a real estate agent at the Douglas Elliman firm. Bevin's amazing grace, beauty, and kindness endured through her long struggle. She will be remembered for her compassion, thoughtfulness, and insight. She faced her difficult last years courageously, without a complaint, and always unselfishly. All who knew her felt blessed. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis Tennessee 38105 (donors@stjude.org). A wake will be held on Friday, April 29, from 4:00 to 7:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, N.Y.C. A service will be held on Saturday, April 30, 2011, at 11:00am at Our Lady of Loretto, Fair Street, Cold Spring on Hudson, New York, 10516.

CARL--Paul R.,Naples, FL. Paul R. Carl was born in Manila, Philippine Islands, the son of a West Point Army officer. He returned to the USA shortly after his birth. He received his Bachelor of Science degree in Chemical Engineering at Lehigh University at the age of 20. He immediately enlisted in the United States Navy. He served as an engineering officer aboard the heavy cruiser "Pensacola" and participated in six major naval battles in the Pacific World War II theatre. Mr. Carl's entire 43 year professional career began at Mobil Oil research and development lab. His many accomplishments included many patents in the catalytic cracking feed preparation techniques and other related areas. He received an award from Mobil I founding fathers for his personal and professional contribution in launching Mobil I and making it America's best known motor oil. He retired in 1984. He enjoyed hunting, fishing, bridge, golf and belonged to Woodway Country Club in Darien, CT. Royal Poinciana, and Mooring Country Clubs in Naples, FL. He is survived by his loving wife of 66 years, Betty (Daubenspeck) Carl, two sons, Robert Carl and John Carl (and wife Stephanie). He is also survived by three grandchildren, Matthew Carl, Sean Carl, and Whitney Carl. A service will be held Sunday, May 1st at 2pm at United Church of Christ, 5200 Crayton Road, Naples, FL. Commital services will be held at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to: The Glenview Employee Scholarship Fund 2400 Tamiami Trail North, suite 300, Naples, FL 34104.

Though the animated Fox comedies ''Family Guy,'' ''The Cleveland Show'' and ''American Dad'' are occasionally known for courtingcontroversy, the network has decided to hold off on broadcasting episodes of those shows that were too close to current events for comfort. Fox was planning on Sunday to show new installments of those series with an interconnected story line about a hurricane on the Eastern Seaboard. These episodes were planned several months ago, before the recent storms that have killed nearly 300 people in the South. But on Friday, Fox said in a brief statement, ''In light of the recent storms that have affected the nation, Fox has decided to postpone the crossover episodes of 'Family Guy,' 'American Dad' and 'The Cleveland Show' that were originally scheduled to air this Sunday.'' A spokeswoman for the network said these episodes will instead be shown next season. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

While this year's Tony Award nominees won't be announced until Tuesday, a Tony oversight panel announced an unusually long list of decisions on Friday about the eligibility of several Broadway actors, Edie Falco, Joel Grey, Jennifer Jason Leigh, and Joe Mantello among them. It's news that might tide over theater junkies through the weekend. The panel, known as the Tony Awards Administration Committee, considers requests from Broadway producers who want their actors and artists to be eligible for Tony nominations in specific categories. Without committee action, for instance, performers who are listed above the title of a show would be eligible for the lead acting categories, while those listed below the title would have a shot at featured (or supporting) categories. Producers can engage in gamesmanship here, requesting eligibility changes for their actors in hopes of receiving more Tony nominations. (Tony Awards can influence ticket sales and national touring prospects of some shows.)

Andrew Morton, who has written biographies of Diana, Princess of Wales, Monica Lewinsky and Tom Cruise, has turned to a familiar subject for his next book: the newly wedded royal couple Prince William and the former Kate Middleton. St. Martin's Press said on Friday that it would publish ''William & Catherine: Their Story'' on May 17, promising that Mr. Morton will tell ''the full story'' of the couple, including their time at university together, the prince's proposal in Kenya and the wedding itself, with all its pomp and circumstance. ''I have drawn on 30 years of experience covering the royal family to bring perspective and insight into the life of a young man I have watched develop from a toddler and schoolboy into a soldier - just as I have tried to discover more about his bride,'' Mr. Morton said in a statement. The book is not an authorized biography, however, and Mr. Morton did not interview William or the Duchess of Cambridge, as she is now known. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

For much of his career, Superman has fought for truth, justice and the American way. In the landmark Action Comics No. 900, which was released on Wednesday, Superman decides he has to stand for something bigger and he renounces his United States citizenship. The Man of Steel's declaration, ''I'm tired of having my actions construed as instruments of U.S. policy,'' follows accusations that he caused an international incident in Tehran. Superman flew to the country during a huge protest, where he stood silent for one day, to show his support for the demonstrators. The 24 hours pass with a mix of appreciation (flowers and flags) and fear (hurled Molotov cocktails). But the government of Iran sees Superman as an agent of the United States and feels his action is an act of war. ''Truth, justice and the American way - it's not enough anymore,'' Superman tells the president's national security adviser. ''The world's too small. Too connected.'' He then makes the decision to go before the United Nations and renounce his American citizenship.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE KIDS ARE ALL RIGHT (2010) The teenage children (Mia Wasikowska and Josh Hutcherson) conceived by a lesbian couple (above, from left, Annette Bening in her Oscar-nominated role and Julianne Moore), with the help of an anonymous sperm donor search for -- and find -- their biological father (Mark Ruffalo). And suddenly life is a little less normal. Lisa Cholodenko's take on the American family, which starts from the premise that gay marriage is an established social fact, ''is so canny in its insights and so agile in its negotiation of complex emotions that it deserves to stand on its own,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is outrageously funny without ever exaggerating for comic effect, and heartbreaking with only minimal melodramatic embellishment.'' But ''its originality -- the thrilling, vertiginous sense of never having seen anything quite like it before -- also arises from the particular circumstances of the family at its heart,'' he added. Ms. Cholodenko and Stuart Blumberg, with whom she wrote the screenplay, ''have discovered in this very modern arrangement a way of refreshing the ancient and durable wellsprings of comedy.'' 7 P.M. (Animal Planet) GENESIS AWARDS 2011 This 25th annual ceremony, sponsored by the Humane Society of the United States and taped on March 19 in Los Angeles, honors those in entertainment who have made significant contributions to the advancement of animal welfare. Nominees include the DreamWorks animated film ''How to Train Your Dragon,'' the documentaries ''My Child Is a Monkey'' and ''The Elephant in the Living Room,'' HBO's ''True Blood'' and ''The Oprah Winfrey Show.'' Kristin Davis (''Sex and the City'') was honored with the Wyler Award, named after Gretchen Wyler, the founder of the Genesis Awards, in recognition of her work to bring attention to the plight of African elephants increasingly poached for their ivory tusks. At 10, ''Too Cute! Kittens'' counts down the cuddliest balls of fur to be seen on the Web.

I've been staying out of the truly stupid debate about whether Keynes advocated central planning; folks, this is not an issue to be settled by trawling his works for gotcha quotes. Keynes had a model, laid out at length in his General Theory; it was a model of how an otherwise workable market economy can suffer from inadequate demand, and how government can play a useful role by pumping up demand to achieve full employment. This model is, as Keynes himself said, moderately conservative in its implications.

BARBRA EHRENREICH Asked what she'll tackle in her next book, the award-winning activist-journalist Barbara Ehrenreich chuckles: ''All I can say is that it deals with religion.'' Ehrenreich made a splash with her 2001 best seller, ''Nickel and Dimed,'' in which she went undercover to see what it was like to live on entry-level wages. Here, she profiles the labor crusader Ai-jen Poo of the National Domestic Workers Alliance in ''The Nannies' Norma Rae'' (Page 49).
The Designers Andrea Trimarchi, left, and Simone Farresin are Studio Formafantasma's Netherlands-based partners.

A report in the Video column on April 17, about the release of ''The Bob Hope Collection, Vol. 2,'' misstated the name of a 1972 movie in one instance. It is ''Cancel My Reservation,'' as noted elsewhere in the column, not ''Pardon My Reservation.''

THUY PHAM and Miho Aoki are big believers in going au naturel. The duo behind the United Bamboo label recently set out to create an eco-friendly line that would give green garments a bit of boudoir appeal. ''There are many companies putting out clothes labeled as organic, but the fabrics might have been dyed or finished with harsh chemicals,'' Mr. Pham said. Bamboo By, a new collection of camisoles, dresses and smocks inspired by Victorian undergarments, definitely delivers on the sexy front. But as far as organic goes, there is still work to be done, Mr. Pham said candidly, ''It's a long process, and we'll probably never be 100 percent.'' But props for trying. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

COLTRERA--Margaret Cullen, died April 15, 2011, age 88, her lively, inquiring mind, warmth, and wry humor blazing. A strong appreciation for art and the motherland Brooklyn drove years of volunteer work at the Brooklyn Museum and an undying loyalty for "Dem Bums". Iconoclastic and opinionated with a love of books and her grandchildren: Kate, Emma, Colin, Erin, Martina, and Tyrone. Deeply loved wife of Joseph (deceased), mother of Francesca, Marc, and Deirdre, and mother-in-law to Andrew, Anne, and Jonathan. For those who wish, donations may be sent to the Brooklyn Museum or Hospice of the Good Shepherd in Newton, MA.

THE nails really came out at the fall shows, with cutting-edge manicures being the order of the day. At Mugler, Lady Gaga sported a matte-black cat claw from Minx. Cushnie et Ochs introduced us to textured ''caviar nails'' made out of black seed beads. And rainforest-inspired and gold-tipped nails emerged on Jen Kao's catwalk. For a toned-down, off-the-runway take on the trends, show a bit of bare nail this summer and choose a classic red lacquer to highlight a nude half-moon (left). Or, if Jason Wu's gold-and-burgundy take on the classic French manicure is not exactly your speed, a black-and-white reverse French with Japanese calligraphy on a nail or two. KATHRYN BRANCH

He earned an MBA from NYU and worked over the years for Banker's Trust, REA Express, Diversified Mortgage Investors, Interway and Transamerica. Mr. Norris is survived by his wife, Sue Darling Norris, his sons, Andrew and Anthony, his grandchildren, Mara and Jonah, and a sister, Julia Kilmer. Bookshelf Justin Martin's ''Genius of Place'' (Da Capo, $28) is about Frederick Law Olmsted -- yes, the Central Park landscape designer, but also the abolitionist, early-adopter environmentalist and roving journalist. The filmmaker Albert Brooks's first novel, ''2030'' (St. Martin's Press, $26), imagines a cancer-free future in which parents live longer than ever and children resent them for it. ''Beaten, Seared and Sauced'' (Clarkson Potter, $24) is Jonathan Dixon's memoir of learning to cook at the Culinary Institute of America.'' This is useless!'' one instructor screams about a failed spaetzle before throwing it on the ground and stomping on it. ''Joan Mitchell, Lady Painter: A Life'' (Knopf, $40), by Patricia Albers, is the first biography of the stellar Abstract Expressionist, a steel heiress who made herself into a bohemian exemplar. In Simon Van Booy's ''Everything Beautiful Began After'' (Harper Perennial, $15), an artist, an archeologist and a prep-schooled philology enthusiast sweat through a fictional summer in Athens -- ''a world of despair and sudden beauty.'' And then, a real-life love triangle in Victorian England: Suzanne Fagence Cooper's ''Effie'' (St. Martin's Press, $27) is about the socialite Effie Gray, who left her (unconsummated) marriage to the art critic John Ruskin after falling for the Pre-Raphaelite artist John Everett Millais. STEPHEN HEYMAN This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The best place to get your fashion fix this season is not on Madison Avenue but at a museum near you. From London to New York, Yohji to Yves, the 1930s to 2011, these exhibitions spotlight solo designers and give new meaning to the words ''just looking.'' ''Balenciaga and Spain'' at the de Young Museum, San Francisco (through July 4) This look at the work of the master, curated by Hamish Bowles, Vogue's European editor at large, digs deep into the designer's Spanish roots - particularly religion, bullfighting and dance.

ONE of the most talked about Broadway shows of the current season is ''The Book of Mormon,'' a foul-mouthed musical about AIDS, atheism and unusual sex acts, from the creators of ''South Park.'' But it's not the only show to go to dark places with tap shoes in hand. Below is a sampling of musicals in development, some with their eyes on Broadway, that aren't afraid to make audiences squirm. Based on song titles, online clips and early critical reports, it's a guide to shows that might knock 'em dead or leave 'em cold. ERIK PIEPENBURG

VANNEMAN--William Henry Moore. After 102 years of an active, fulfilling life, William Henry Moore Vanneman, Sr., died gracefully, April 26. He enjoyed people and was the most giving person his family and friends ever knew. As a boy, he attended Camp Dudley and throughout his life he lived the Camp Dudley motto, "The other fellow first." When awarded Cornell's Frank H.T. Rhodes Award for Exemplary Alumni Service, Hunter Rawlings, then President of Cornell, stated, "A man's success in life isn't what he gains, it is what he gives." This described Bill's life. He and his precious wife Rosamond were married for 52 years before her passing in 1990. He was born to Charles Reeve and Mercy Moore Vanneman on April 6, 1909 in Albany, New York. He graduated from the Albany Academy, Cornell University, and Harvard Business School. He served in the Navy during WWII, completing his service as a Lieutenant Commander. After the war, he spent the remainder of his work life with Matthew Bender Company, a law book publisher in New York, retiring as senior vice president. He and Rosamond lived and raised their children, Bill and Reeve, in Old Greenwich Connecticut, where he served as Senior Deacon of the First Congregational Church. He is survived by his two sons, William Henry Moore Vanneman Jr. and his wife Irene and Reeve Doering Vanneman and his wife Jane; by two grandsons Matt Vanneman and James Vanneman and their mother Jill Jacovitz; three granddaughters Kara Klein and her husband Ken Klein, Michelle Vanneman and her husband Chad Yoder, and Julie Vanneman and her husband Scott Kiesling; and by the lights of his later life, his eight great-grandchildren ages 2-14, all of whom adored him dearly. Services will be held on Tuesday, May 3 at 1:30pm at the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Camp Dudley YMCA or Cornell University.

For centuries, Seville, Spain, has been known for its striking architecture -- particularly its Moorish Alcázar and huge Gothic cathedral. The Metropol Parasol, a large, multipurpose structure that made its debut late last month in the city, looks both backward and forward in its unusual design. The project was initiated in 2004 after Roman ruins were discovered in a parking lot. An ensuing competition for a surrounding structure was won by Jüergen Mayer H., an architect based in Berlin. Seven years and about 110 million euros (about $162 million) later, Seville has a structure, over 450 feet long and seven stories high, that incorporates those ruins into a museum on its lowest level. The upper levels house an indoor food market, plazas with panoramic views, and a restaurant. But most notable is the undulating, honeycombed roof of the structure, made from polyurethane-covered wood and held together by a new type of glue.

Tissamaharama, Sri Lanka, Feb. 17, 2011 With the Sri Lankan civil war finally over, Yala National Park is once again safe to visit. While on vacation, I went there -- essentially on safari -- and I caught a beautifully serene moment with a huge buffalo enjoying a refreshing dip and a tiny frog sunbathing on its back. SZABOLCS MOSONYI, Budapest

Steve Stone wears a ring to commemorate his magical season of 1980, when he captured the American League Cy Young Award and set a Baltimore Orioles record for victories in a season, with 25. But that performance was the exception over 11 workmanlike years. ''I wasn't a great pitcher most of my career, so I had to be more observant,'' Stone said. ''I was routinely facing guys who were better than I was, guys who were going to the Hall of Fame, and I had to learn how to get them out.''

Unable to start writing, I look out past the veranda shadow. From my house on Australia's Bruny Island -- named in Year 1 of the French Revolution by a French royalist after himself -- I can see Tasmania, home to a human civilization for 10,000 years before modern man arrived in France. Just out of view on the left is a cove. There, in a remote outstation, less than 60 years after the visit by Bruni d'Entrecasteaux, that civilization's 47 spirit-shocked survivors were dumped by the colonial authorities and left to die. After hearing of their story -- he called it a ''war of extermination waged by European immigrants'' -- H. G. Wells wrote ''The War of the Worlds,'' in which Martian immigrants exterminate Europeans.

The new Web site DesignersAndBooks.com collects reading lists from esteemed architects, critics and designers. Some picks make sense: Norman Foster chooses four books by Le Corbusier, while Milton Glaser has a thing for John Berger. Others are more personal: ''Old Yeller'' was the first book to make Michael Sorkin cry. Assembled here are annotated titles from the legendary adman and art director George Lois, culled from his collection of 7,000 books. STEPHEN HEYMAN

Naming a baseball bat is not a new phenomenon. Shoeless Joe Jackson's beloved Black Betsy sold for $577,610 in 2001, and the fictional Wonder Boy made Roy Hobbs famous. But leave it to a pitcher, the Mets' R. A. Dickey, to come up with the most creative names of all. In the Mets' bat rack at Citi Field, almost every bat includes a sticker with the player's number on the knob. Not Dickey's.

Pick up a book about a young New York artist these days, and you're likely to spot Brendan Dugan's name in the fine print. As the founder of the graphics firm and indie publishing imprint An Art Service, Dugan has become a go-to designer for galleries like Gagosian and Hauser & Wirth, or for virtually anyone in Dan Colen's crowd. Now he's slowly making his presence known with Karma (21 Downing Street; open Thursday-Sunday from noon to 7 p.m. or by appointment), a tiny shop in the front of his office where he sells his own catalog of gritty pop-minimalist art books and posters alongside books and objects that inspire him. Dugan started the publishing arm of his business in 2009 as an additional platform for the artists whose Web sites, books and ephemera he was already designing. ''Allan Kaprow, Ed Ruscha and a lot of the Fluxus artists were designing all these amazing objects to help support their projects,'' he says. ''I guess I think of us as trying to help continue that lineage.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

GARDEZ, Afghanistan -- When construction crews faced attacks while working on a major American-financed highway here in southeastern Afghanistan, Western contractors turned to a powerful local figure named simply Arafat, who was suspected to have links to Afghanistan's insurgents. Subcontractors, flush with American money, paid Mr. Arafat at least $1 million a year to keep them safe, according to people involved in the project and Mr. Arafat himself.

It's the most intimate class divide in human civilization, or at least in such relatively civilized places as Manhattan and Park Slope, Brooklyn. On the one side, there is the professional couple bringing in six figures a year; on the other, the nanny or maid without whom the couple wouldn't be able to practice their professions. Conditions of employment are as variable as the individual employers are - from respectful and considerate all the way to criminally abusive. On average, a domestic worker is likely to get less than $15 an hour, no benefits and none of the credit or glory. To my knowledge anyway, there has never been a successful career woman - or man, for that matter - who's responded to being praised for ''doing it all'' by saying, ''Actually, Manuela (or Angelica or Harriet) does most of it.'' You don't have to be down on your knees scraping congealed creme fraiche off marble tiles to see that there's something not quite right about this picture. Ai-jen Poo was a recent Columbia University graduate in 1998 when she got incensed about the status of New York's domestic workers and started organizing them into something resembling a union. It's not that easy to organize domestic workers, even the ones who are fluent in English, because their workplaces are scattered among thousands of individual apartments and town houses and no one keeps a list of their names.

FRONT PAGE A picture caption on April 17 with the continuation of an article about John Tanton, who helped start all three major national groups that are fighting to reduce immigration to the United States, misstated the mission of Numbers USA, a group founded by Roy Beck. It seeks to reduce legal and illegal immigration alike, not ''to give voice to anger about illegal immigration.''

NATIONAL An article last Sunday about the arrest of a pastor in the ''international parental kidnapping'' of a child in a same-sex custody battle misstated the relationship between Liberty University and a businessman who has denied accusations that he provided a house in Nicaragua for the fleeing biological mother and child. The businessman, Philip Zodhiates, does not have ''close ties'' or any formal relationship with Liberty University, according to university officials.

It is fairly safe to assume that Sofia Sanchez Barrenechea's apartment is the only one in the West Village with a floor-to-ceiling view of Patagonia. Sanchez Barrenechea, a 25-year-old graphic designer who grew up in Buenos Aires, decorated an entire wall with a mural she created from a photo of the lake where her family spent their summers. ''It's the first thing I see when I wake up,'' she says. The rest of the apartment is best described as urban eclectic - furnished with things scavenged from flea markets or, in the case of a favorite chair, found on the street. An art director at Lloyd & Company working with beauty and fashion brands, Sanchez Barrenechea nearly had a career as a model, but she's more content to operate behind the scenes. ''Friday nights when I'm bored, I play with Photoshop,'' she says. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on April 17 about the amount of sleep people need misstated the time frame of a sleep study done by David Dinges and Hans Van Dongen. It took place from 1998 to 2002, not in 2003, which was when the results were published.

SYRIA The military seized a landmark mosque that had become a center of protests in the besieged southern town of Dara'a, killing at least six people as the Syrian government intensified its crackdown. Tanks and armored personnel carriers led the assault, and the army later stationed snipers on top of the mosque to cover a paratrooper landing in the area. YEMEN President Ali Abdullah Saleh appeared reluctant to sign an agreement under which he would step down in return for immunity, complicating the Yemeni opposition's efforts to complete the deal at a meeting in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, scheduled for Sunday.

I'd been on the road for barely an hour, but when you've got to go, you've got to go. To the beach, I mean. As I drove down the eastern Florida coast, the view had gone from high-rise ocean-view condos to luxe waterfront homes to just a narrow strip of grass and shrubs, with Atlantic waves breaking on the other side. Spotting a footpath through the shrubs, with a lone car parked nearby, I swung the wheel of my rental Ford Focus and parked.

Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset like to build things up just to knock them down, as in the last Venice Biennale, where they dolled up a pavilion as a house - and then put it up for sale. For ''The One and the Many,'' a new installation at the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen's Submarine Wharf in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, they created a boulevard of broken dreams, with an apartment block inspired by East German socialist housing. Visitors will peek into the building's windows from a Ferris wheel and gawk at the humanity therein, including a middle-aged man watching soccer on TV in a room decorated with trophies, or a teenage boy logged onto a gay-chat Web site. ''It's like building a Disneyland with less of that feel-good effect and slightly more complex content,'' they said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MORE dancing queen than demure, the Times Square, Oscar de la Renta's new metallic-print lamé, crystal-studded double platform sandal ($1,595), marks a revamp of the designer's footwear business. While Mr. de la Renta hasn't abandoned the ladylike kitten heels and pretty pumps his mature customers have come to expect, his latest collection is peppered with the kind of sky-high satin stilettos and sexy platforms his younger fans have been clamoring for. Another sign of the youthquake at the atelier: the designer has just reintroduced his classic fragrance, Esprit d'Oscar, with fresh, zingy notes that are sure to seduce his ladies in waiting. Go to oscardelatrenta.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

It sometimes feels as if no aspect of American midcentury modern design has been left unconsidered, unexhibited, unreissued. But there is undiscovered territory. You're sitting on it. ''Knoll Textiles, 1945-2010,'' at the Bard Graduate Center in Manhattan from May 18 to July 31, flips the story line on the brand's famous chairs (Womb, Tulip, Diamond, Platner) by focusing on the fabrics rather than the frames. ''One of the major goals of this project was to shift the attention,'' said Earl Martin, a curator of the exhibition. ''People might save a Saarinen Womb chair but have it recovered because we don't yet have a sensibility about the textiles being that important.'' Among the vintage chairs on display with their original upholstery will be a 1945 Ralph Rapson rocker with a woven webbing seat and back, and a 1965 Eero Saarinen side chair covered in still-brilliant red Cato fabric by Paul Maute. Some of the reasons for textiles' also-ran status are mundane: fabrics are ephemeral, faded by sunlight, dirtied by use. ''We needed the conservators at the Museum of Modern Art to rescue some of these pieces and preserve the upholstery,'' Martin explained. Because Knoll's program was frequently experimental, a few early fabrics that incorporated fiberglass or rayon disintegrated within the first years of production and had to be discontinued or reformulated. Moreover, much of the company's business was contract work, and office drones hardly paid attention to the provenance of their swivel chairs or curtains.

From the day 200 years ago when the street grid was imposed on Manhattan, New York was destined to be a rectilinear city. But from the day 130 years ago when the architect Rafael Guastavino y Moreno arrived here from Catalonia, curves entered into the equation. In a big way. Guastavino domes and vaults are everywhere, but they are not always easy to see. Some of the best work by Guastavino and his son, Rafael Guastavino y Esposito, like the stairwell of Washington Memorial Arch or the passenger platform of the abandoned City Hall subway station, is out of the public eye.

THE auctioneers are calling it ''the Most Famous Car in the World.'' In truth, there are multiple Chitty Chitty Bang Bangs, beginning with racecars with aircraft engines that inspired the Ian Fleming children's book and subsequent 1968 movie. Profiles in History, the Los Angeles auction house, this month is set to sell what it calls the only drivable example of the Chitty cars built for the movie. The car was assembled in England to mimic a prewar classic, but with a Ford V-6 engine and automatic transmission. According to Nancy Seltzer, a company spokeswoman, the car is expected to sell for $1 million to $2 million.
