Max van der Stoel, a career Dutch diplomat who used his appointment as the United Nations' official watchdog on Iraqi human rights abuses in the 1990s to paint searing portraits of Saddam Hussein's murderous government, died on April 23 at his home in The Hague. He was 86. The government of the Netherlands announced the death. No cause was given.

Ten years ago James Freeman was roasting his own coffee beans on a baking pan in his Oakland, Calif., kitchen. Today the former clarinet player and owner of Blue Bottle outposts in the Bay Area and Brooklyn (Williamsburg, naturally) is the leader of the artisanal Japanese-style, slow-drip brewing movement. Using organic, shade-grown beans that are sold within 48 hours of roasting, Freeman and his wife, Caitlin, a pastry chef, are converting customers one perfectly brewed cup of joe at a time. About his cult status among the caffeinated, he maintains an aw-shucks attitude. ''I got burned out on the music playing,'' he said. ''This was my wacky plan B.''

FOR decades now auction houses have sold challenging works of art. There have been arcane, ancient sculptures, canvases by little-known artists and bizarre objects like glass cabinets filled with medical supplies or cigarette butts. But at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips de Pury, the art for sale at the big auctions this season, beginning Tuesday, requires little thought. Even those without much knowledge of art history will recognize Andy Warhol's haunting self-portrait with his spiky fright wig or Jeff Koons's lovable sculpture of a Pink Panther being hugged by a buxom blonde or the classic pink-and-red abstract canvas that shrieks Mark Rothko. These instantly recognizable images spell ''wall power,'' a well-worn art-world phrase that describes an artwork that telegraphs its owner's wealth. Often these trophy purchases are flaunted in the entrance of a McMansion or over a living-room fireplace or in an office-building lobby. Sometimes, however, prized art will disappear into private collections where their superrich owners show them off to only their superrich friends.
Television Ginia Bellafante

TICK--Sally, on April 28, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Tick. Loving mother of Carole Gluck and her husband Sanford and daughter-in-law Sheila and the late Donald Tick. Cherished grandmother of Mitchell, Leslie, Stacy, Jeffrey, Pamela and Jonathan, their spouses and great-grandmother of 13. She was a very elegant and vibrant lady who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. She lived her life of 101 years with dignity. Service Monday, May 2, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street.
Film Mike Hale

In León, a city of modest scale in the volcanic lowlands of northwest Nicaragua, within sight of one of the largest cathedrals in Central America, La Catedral de León, you'll find its zona rosa, or entertainment zone. Hardware stores and motorcycle repair shops housed in cavernous, decaying, centuries-old homes have given way to restaurants, bars and improvised discotecas. The conversion happened organically over the last couple of years, without any planning or support from the city; this unofficial status -- not to mention a notable lack of parking or even addresses -- lends a chaotic, uniquely Nicaraguan spirit to the scene. Extending from the southwest corner of the Parque Central, the zona rosa is clustered on a single block. Even during the week, tranquilo crowds of revelers eat, drink and dance their way past midnight, mixing on the sidewalk as they move from place to place. JOSHUA BERMAN

IN contrast to the sleek manufactured furniture that was on display during Milan's design week last month, the work of younger designers often took a narrative tack. One intriguing example was the Heartpot porcelain teapot by Maria Volokhova, who was born in Ukraine and now lives in Berlin. The teapot, with its heart shape, aorta-like handles and charmingly incongruous human legs, typifies Ms. Volokhova's preoccupation with making things that are neither ''functional'' nor ''art,'' and with exploring our perceptions of the human body. Another of her teapots, Jejenum, is a web of porcelain tubes that look like intestines. PILAR VILADAS

KLEIN--Allan B.,on April 29, 2011. Beloved husband of Karyn for 42 years, devoted father of Gregg and wife Julie, Kerry and husband Matt, and Brett and wife Dena - his love was unconditional and always apparent; Adoring grandfather to Samantha, Sydney, Alex, Zach, Russell, and Max - his grandchildren were his life and made him smile; Dear brother of Jill Gidseg and the late Gary Klein. Allan was a dedicated and accomplished oral and maxillofacial surgeon for 38 years. He had a passion for tropical fish, gardening and animals and enjoyed sports cars and playing golf with his friends. He was a loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend who will be deeply missed but never forgotten. Memorial donations may be made to the St. Barnabas Hospital Cancer Center in Livingston, NJ.

KLEIN--Allan. He was our beloved friend for 45 years. We will miss his charm, wit, and respect he gave to all who knew him. Our love goes to our dear friend, Karyn, his wife, and their entire family. We will miss him always. Love, Meryl & Steve Gassman

ZELUCK--Kevin. Our hearts are broken. Our lives will never be the same. You are our best friend and you have the gift of making everyone around you feel so loved. We will always miss your joy, laughter, and pure love of life. You will always be in our hearts. Sandy, Jaime and Lauren, you are our family and we love you more than you will ever know. We will miss you, Kev, forever. Amy and Corey, Felicia and Perry, Teress and Allan, Sunny and Arthur, and Cathy
THE TRAGEDY OF ARTHUR By Arthur Phillips

SPORTS An article on Tuesday about Manny Ramirez's youth in Washington Heights misstated the name of the bridge over the Harlem River that his friends crossed to watch his Yankee Stadium debut in 1993. It was the Macombs Dam Bridge, not the Harlem River Bridge.

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to Alessandra Stanley's column about advance television coverage of the marriage of Prince William and Kate Middleton. ''I told them. I said, 'Look, just cut all the nonsense, go to Vegas, get married by an Elvis impersonator, and be done with it!' But would they listen? Of course not!''
An obituary in some editions last Sunday about the composer Peter Lieberson misstated the year the Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition was given to his ''Neruda Songs.'' It was 2008, not 2007.
Art Carol Vogel

EUSTICE--James S.,of New York City, died on Tuesday April 26, 2011 of congestive heart failure. He was 78. He devoted much of his life to his tremendous career teaching, writing about and practicing corporate tax law, but in his free hours he was a marathon runner, balloon traveller, golfer, opera lover, crossword puzzler and beloved father and husband. His zesty humor and twinkling eyes will be missed. He is predeceased by his first wife, LaVaun S. Eustice to whom he was married for 38 years. He is survived by his second wife Carol Fonda Eustice, children from his first marriage Cynthia LaPier of Sheffield, MA and James M. of Pacific Palisades, CA, their spouses, Jim LaPier and Jennifer Avant Eustice and grandchildren Hannah LaPier and Alexander James Eustice. A memorial service will be held at 2:00pm on Monday, May 9th at the First Presbyterian Church of the City of New York on Fifth Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets. Donations in Jim's memory may be made to Hospice through www.mjhsfoundation.org

''For 10 years I was dreaming about it, for five years I was looking for a spot for it, for two years working on it, for another two years building it, and finally here it is,'' says Alexandre de Betak, luxuriating in the master bedroom of the house he has created, inside and out, in a small coastal village in the Tramuntana region of Majorca. Like virtually every other room, this one has devastating views of the Mediterranean Sea, oddly curvaceous white plaster walls and a surfeit of unpretentious, quirky design gestures. Consider a pair of shutters set in a rounded expanse - painted olive gray-green, a shade approved by the village's strict building code - that open to reveal a view of, no, not the orange grove that forms a part of the property, nor the ancient terraces laid out by the Moors a thousand years ago, but a wide-screen TV. But ask de Betak if the undulating surfaces - there's hardly a right angle in the place - are meant to evoke the spirit of Antoni Gaudi, and he laughs and concedes that the influence is more like Barbapapa, the shape-shifting cartoon character from the 1970s. ''I love '70s organic architecture,'' he says. ''I am very influenced by the time when I grew up.''

HIRSCHENFANG--Seymour. Born 1920. Decorated WWII veteran. BA/Brooklyn College. MA/NYU. Teacher of Speech and Jewish Studies. Loving husband to Phyllis, brother to Jay Hershey and father to Gail and seven stepchildren. His son, Nathan, died in 1992. He had five grandchildren. Sy will be remembered for his immense kindness, passion for justice and gentle spirit.

No strangers to mouthwatering gems, the youngest members of the venerable German jewelry house Hemmerle have taken the concept a step further with ''Delicious Jewels,'' a cookbook they created with the chef Tamasin Day-Lewis to accompany their latest collection -- a bounty of exquisite vegetable brooches and earrings. ''We like to entertain,'' says Christian Hemmerle. ''But we don't want to stand in the kitchen for 10 hours. The book is full of good, honest food that people can actually cook.'' SANDRA BALLENTINE Strain the yogurt through a muslin or cheesecloth into a bowl for an hour to rid it of its watery whey.

For a high-powered money manager, being the wife of the American ambassador to France is gilt-edged. The residence of the American ambassador to France is not the kind of place you'd expect to find young, scantily clad models - not on the record, anyway. But there they were in droves one evening in March, when Ambassador Charles Rivkin and his wife, Susan Tolson, welcomed the fashion crowd into their home to celebrate Michael Kors's 30th anniversary and his new store on the Rue St.-Honore. An enormous tent erected in the garden set the scene for a seated dinner for 200 that culminated in a performance by Mary J. Blige, who belted out ''Stairway to Heaven,'' ''One Love'' and ''Happy Birthday'' in honor of Tolson's 49th.

SANTARELLI--Vincent A.,Ph.D., 80 of Manhattan passed away on April 29, 2011. In addition to being a loving father and husband, he proudly taught at Rutgers University from 1958 to 1996 while holding the department chair from 1980 to 1986 where he fulfilled his life's passion as an educator and mentor. He is survived by his beloved wife, Marie (Nee Cicchelli); son, James and daughter-in-law, Jacqueline; daughter, Annie and son-in-law, Jason Languasco; and four grandchildren. Reposing Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St., NYC on Sunday 1:00 to 5:00pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10:00am Our Lady of Guadalupe at St. Bernard's Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

Delta Airlines has begun a system that allows its passengers to track their bags after they've been checked in, its blog reported recently. The bag tracking system works in a similar fashion to that of a delivery company: users simply enter a last name and the baggage tracking number and then are told whether their luggage has been loaded on the aircraft, is in a claim area or is in a different location. Delta is the first major domestic carrier to offer such a service. The tracking system was touted on the blog along with other enhancements meant to minimize the hassle of baggage delays, including notification via text or e-mail if your bags do not make your flight, an online baggage claim form and a rebate for which you can apply online if your bag has been delayed for more than 12 hours.

THE 40,000 commuters who pass through the University of Naples metro stop each day had a nice surprise recently, when the American designer Karim Rashid unveiled his psychedelic redo of their station. As part of a dozen stops being renovated by MetroNapoli along the city's No. 1 and No. 6 lines, he joins the likes of Alessandro Mendini and Sol LeWitt, who used their art to decorate the depots. Mr. Rashid turned the station's entire 36,000 square feet into a signature piece, with hologram flooring, tiled epigrams, silver sculptures and shifting ''muta-blob'' walls. ''So much of the world is gray or beige,'' he said with a sigh. ''If this kind of passion and attention'' was lavished on New York's subways, he added, ''I would ride them again.'' SHONQUIS MORENO
THEY say you never forget how to ride a bike. Tell that to Delsa Jacqueline Lopez.

COTTONDALE, Ala. As the flight to Birmingham began its descent, the passenger in 8B, a barrel of a man wearing a camouflage baseball cap, peered out the window at the disfigured sprawl of Tuscaloosa below. There, he said, pointing: that light brown scar marks the tornado's path.
The race needs more responsible adults who can actually do the job. FERGUS CULLEN, a Republican seeking broader presidential field. [1]

T MAGAZINE An article on Page 54 about a Brooklyn couple, Tarajia Morrell and Sebastian Sergeant, and their key ingredients for an ideal dinner party misstates the Web site of Ms. Morrell's new food blog. It is thelovage.com, not spoon-struck.com. (Ms. Morrell changed the blog's domain after the article went to press.)

GORDON--Judith Arenstein, daughter of Emilie and Murray Arenstein passed away in New York City where she had resided for fifty years. She was a graduate of Brandeis University ('61) and New York University School of Law ('68). Judy was an Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York; an Assistant Corporation Counsel of the City of New York and an adjunct professor at the Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University. As an Assistant Attorney General, she was a senior member of the Litigation Bureau representing the state and its citizens at all levels of the judicial system including appearances in front of the Supreme Court of the United States. Judy is survived by her children Alicia and Anthony. Her passion for family and friends was matched by her passion for the law and an unending quest for higher civic purpose. A stalwart champion for good, she will be remembered for her intellect, wit and fighting spirit. A memorial service will take place on Sunday, May 22, 2011 at 4:30pm at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York. If you plan on attending, please reply through the online New York Times guestbook. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in her name to the NYU School of Law Public Interest Law Center, c/o NYU School of Law Office of Development, 110 West 3rd Street, 2nd Fl., New York, NY 10012. Gifts may also be made via www.law.nyu.edu/giving Please indicate IMO J.A. Gordon.

Steven Guarnaccia's twists on ''Goldilocks and the Three Bears'' and ''The Three Little Pigs'' (Abrams, $19) recast the fairy tales as only a design dork could. So Papa Bear's chair has a ladder back (by Charles Rennie Mackintosh). Goldilocks eats out of an Eva Zeisel bowl. The Three Little Pigs are (above, from left) Philip Johnson, Frank Gehry and Frank Lloyd Wright. And the house before which the Big Bad Wolf hopelessly huffs and puffs is none other than Fallingwater. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FISCHER--Thomas Ray, 1943-2011. Thomas grew up in the west end of Louisville, KY, attending Holy Cross Elementary School and Flaget High School where he first met the Xaverian Brothers. After high school Thomas joined the Brothers studying at The Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C., where he majored in English concentrating on Shakespeare. After graduating in 1967, Thomas went on to teach English, religion, and cinema at Xaverian High School in Brooklyn, NY where he monitored the yearbook and began developing lifelong friendships with students and faculty members. In the early days of his career, Brother Thomas was known as Brother Xavier, taking the name in honor of the Jesuit missionary who traveled to India and the Far East. He adopted the 70s spirit donning bell-bottomed pants, wearing his hair long, and even sporting a beard. During this time he studied at night to earn a master's degree in cinema from New York University. During his summers he studied at Wesleyan University in Middletown, CT, earning a master's degree in English. In the mid-70s Thomas withdrew from the brotherhood and left his beloved New York, relocating to Lynchburg, VA where he directed Campbell County's ongoing education program for teachers of social studies and English. Thomas earned a Ph.D. in education from the University of Virginia launching a career of educational leadership which took him to Chicago, IL, and Ankara and Istanbul, Turkey. While in Wheaton, IL he taught at West Chicago Community High School and later retiring from Lyons Township High School in La Grange, IL. Thomas traveled to Ankara, Turkey on a Fulbright Scholarship. After retiring he chaired the English Department of a Turkish/American school in Istanbul. Having overcome polio at an early age, Thomas was eager to stay fit through regular exercise and yoga. Being an avid swimmer, Thomas also enjoyed scuba diving which took him to destinations yet to be discovered. While in Chicago he joined the Smelts, a competitive swim team, and participated and won several medals in the International Gay Olympics Games. Thomas' passion for learning was matched only by his love for travel, developing and nurturing lasting friendships along the way. He visited and studied in dozens of countries during his career, bringing back memories and experiences he shared with his students in the classroom. Thomas' apartment was filled with those memories, treasures he had collected while exploring the world. In all his traveling and exploring this great world of ours, Thomas never met a stranger. Students and friends have described Thomas as gifted, intelligent and hip, a friend and mentor, having a zest for life with a constant quest for knowledge. He loved the arts from jazz to opera and was drawn to big city life for what it had to offer. Thomas is predeceased by his parents Firmin Casimir and Dorothy Louise of Louisville, KY and his brother Robert Joseph of Eagle Rock, CA. He is survived by his siblings, Judith Ann Ventrella of Punta Gorda, FL, Linda Marie Finn of Naples, FL, Anthony Edward of Alta Loma, CA, James Gregory of Zephyrhills, FL, Martin Christopher of Sanford, FL and Kenneth Eugene of Apopka, FL. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, May 21, 2011 at the home of James Markey, 950 West Berwyn Avenue, Unit 3, Chicago, IL 60640. Please RSVP to: jrmarkey@hotmail.com Thomas appreciated the Newberry Library in Chicago. Donations can be made in his name at www.newberry.org. "Carpe diem."

What New Yorker doesn't dream of a bigger apartment? You know - a place with more storage space, more walls for books and the elusive ''one more room.'' But there's a difference between a bigger apartment and a perfect apartment. Ronald Bentley and Salvatore LaRosa, who are partners in the New York design firm B Five Studio as well as in life, understand that difference, and their recently completed apartment on the Brooklyn waterfront offers numerous lessons in how to have both. The two are no strangers to the quest for perfection (or space): in addition to the houses and apartments that they've designed for their clients, they've designed homes for themselves, including a one-bedroom apartment on lower Fifth Avenue and a 3,400-square-foot weekend house in Bucks County, Penn. And when they decided that the apartment wasn't big enough and the 16-acre country property was too big to maintain, they searched for a place that offered both more space and a connection to the outside world.

WECHSLER--Miriam Pullan, on April 26, 2011. Dear cousin of Irving and Paula, Dana and Joanna Frisch. Beloved friend of Nicole F. Blumensztein and Deborah Baber. Will also be missed by many friends and her caregiver Margaret Mark. Service Tuesday 11:30am, "The Riverside," 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

The key ingredients to a Brooklyn couple's groovy gatherings? A stellar guest list and a seating plan. Tarajia Morrell and Sebastian Sergeant live in a Boerum Hill carriage house, the ideal setting for their groovier-than-thou dinner parties. The interior is the vision of Sergeant, 34, a set and furniture designer. In their living room, simple Milo Baughman sofas surround an ornate 18th-century mantel topped with one of Sergeant's creations, a mercury mirror in a torched frame. When it comes to the food, Morrell -- the 31-year-old daughter of Cathy and Peter Morrell of the Morrell & Company wine shop and restaurant -- takes over. She is currently enrolled in the French Culinary Institute and will chronicle her passion for food on the new blog thelovage.com. ''Our culture has become obsessed with everything being available in one place, but carrying my straw basket around to neighborhood specialty shops is essential to entertaining,'' says Morrell, who is known to work the kitchen in a vintage Yves Saint Laurent top and a polka-dot apron. ''There are few things I find more rewarding than cooking for and eating with friends.''

IN the first independent crash tests of mainstream electric vehicles conducted in the United States, the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf have been named Top Safety Picks by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. That is good news for early adopters and bodes well for these vehicles as they fight for broader acceptance in the marketplace.

Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, faces a crisis of confidence. He is excoriated on the right for debasing the currency, and blasted on the left for failing to stimulate more than he has. It has gotten so bad that last week Mr. Bernanke, who prefers to discuss monetary policy with erudite professors like himself, submitted to the indignity of a news conference. Among the uninvited was Representative Ron Paul, who is flirting with a presidential run, and who, if he took office in 2013, would like nothing more than to celebrate the Fed's centennial by ... abolishing it. And that got me to thinking: What if there were no Fed? Don't laugh; it has happened before. The United States had a primitive central bank, conceived by Alexander Hamilton, but President James Madison let its charter lapse in 1811. A second such bank became the target of President Andrew Jackson, who viewed it as a ''hydra'' and a ''curse'' upon the nation. Jackson sought to decertify the bank and, in 1836, succeeded. Never mind that the following year, the United States was plunged into a serious financial panic. The curse had been lifted, not to reappear for nearly a century.

David Lynch is best known as a director, but it was the paintings he made in Philadelphia as a young art student that gave him the idea to make his first film. The work he is showing nearly 50 years later at the William Griffin Gallery in Santa Monica, Calif., straddles both genres - illuminated light bulbs protrude from the canvases, and abstract figures dance across them. The installation includes eerie watercolors and a number of lamplike sculptures. Lynch's proclivity for ''shape and light'' drew him to another project, Silencio, a nightclub set to open this summer at 142 rue Montmartre in Paris, for which he designed the interiors and the furniture. ''I enjoy how architecture and design create mood,'' he says. The club was named for the spooky theater in ''Mulholland Drive,'' so no telling what that mood will be. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
An article on April 17 about the Niles Canyon railway stated incorrectly the type of oil the Niles Canyon train runs on. It is Bunker C oil, not bunker seed oil.

LEON--Sophia Vourna, D.D.S.,of New York City, passed away March 25, 2011, at age 92. Predeceased by her dear husband James Leon, she is survived by two daughters, Elena Madonia and husband John; Rania Kelly and husband Brian; and four grandchildren, Sophia Madonia, Alexandra, James and Jenna Kelly. A true lady and a remarkable person, she will be missed.

9 P.M. (13, 49) SOUTH RIDING Anna Maxwell Martin, right, plays Sarah Burton, a feisty teacher who returns to her hometown in 1930s Yorkshire, England, to shake up the local girls' high school and is drawn to Robert Carne (David Morrissey), a tradition-bound landowner and war veteran -- and just about the last fellow Sarah would normally find herself falling for. This ''Masterpiece Classic'' period drama, adapted by Andrew Davies from the novel by Winifred Holtby, might just be what viewers need on the heels of the royal wedding: ''a mild astringent for those suffering from an excess of pomp,'' Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. And, he added, ''there's not one abominable Philip Treacy hat in sight.'' 4 A.M. (CNN, Fox News, MSNBC, Telemundo, Univision) THE BEATIFICATION OF POPE JOHN PAUL II Live reports from St. Peter's Square in Vatican City.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the enjoyment of spring in New York misidentified the location of a brownstone owned by the actor Matthew Broderick where teenagers once gathered on the front stoop. It was Charlton Street, not Charles Street.

Several best-seller entries on April 10 misstated the number of weeks that eight books had spent on various lists as of that date: ''The Dressmaker of Khair Khana'' had been on the hardcover nonfiction list for 1 week, not 2; ''I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell'' had been on the paperback nonfiction list for 167 weeks, not 168; ''Half Broke Horses'' had been on the paperback trade fiction list for 28 weeks, not 29; ''One Thousand Gifts'' had been on the hardcover advice list for 2 weeks, not 3; ''Radical'' had been on the paperback advice list for 41 weeks, not 42; ''Wild Bill Donovan'' had been on the e-book nonfiction list for 4 weeks, not 5; ''Townie'' had been on the e-book nonfiction list for 2 weeks, not 3; and ''Eat, Pray, Love'' had been on the e-book nonfiction list for 8 weeks, not 9 (on April 24, that book had been on the list for 9 weeks, not 10). (In all these cases, the figures were inflated by a computer program's erroneous inclusion of a week spent on one of The Times's extended best-seller lists.) Five recent entries for ''The Lincoln Lawyer'' misstated the number of weeks it had been on the e-book fiction list. On March 27, it had been on the list for 3 weeks, not 1; on April 3, 4 weeks, not 3; on April 10, 5 weeks, not 4; on April 17, 6 weeks, not 5; and on April 24, 7 weeks, not 6.

FRANK--William A. Died April 26th, Pompton Plains, NJ, age 88, beloved husband of Barbara Wiener Frank since 1946, father of Margaret Sanfilippo and John Frank, father-in-law of Alice Curtis and Charles Sanfilippo, grandfather of Lisa, Diane, Katherine. Interment: May 3rd, 2011, 1:30-2:30pm. St. James Chapel at Cathedral St. John the Divine, New York City.

''Buffett was on an unrealistically high pedestal to begin with.'' Alice Schroeder, author of a biography of Warren E. Buffett, on fallout from the activities of David Sokol, who recently resigned from Mr. Buffett's company, Berkshire Hathaway. A Berkshire audit committee said Mr. Sokol's actions had violated the company's insider stock-trading policy. ''We haven't been tracking anybody. Never have. Never will.'' Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, who said that while Apple had made mistakes in how it handled location data on its mobile devices, it had not used iPhones and iPads to keep tabs on the whereabouts of customers.

THE NEWSPrince William and Kate Middleton appeared on the balcony of Buckingham Palace after their wedding for the traditional first public kiss as husband and wife -- and then, to roars from the crowd, kissed again. BEHIND THE NEWS The newly minted Duchess of Cambridge won plaudits for wearing a wedding dress that was respectful and restrained yet flawlessly modern. But much of the style chatter on the day focused instead on a fashion feature that is nowadays seldom seen in less-rarefied social circles: women's hats. The prince appeared in the scarlet uniform of the Irish Guards regiment.
Classical Allan Kozinn

PAISNER--David, 87, passed away in Riverdale on April 24, 2011. Dave was a loving husband, devoted father, adoring grandfather and dear father-in-law. Dave will be remembered as a dedicated teacher. His kindness and counsel will be greatly missed by family throughout the country.

The acrostic answers on April 17, for the acrostic puzzle of April 10, omitted the final two solutions. For letter V, with the clue ''Distinctive features of the primitive reptilian archaeopteryx,'' the answer was ''Feathers.'' For letter W, with the clue ''Admit to being wrong,'' the answer was ''Eat crow.''

GREENBERG--Charles Chase. on April 27 2011, at the age of 44 years. Lived fully and fought courageously. Husband of Daimara. Cherished son of J. Michael and Barbara Greenberg. Brother of Kimberly and Dr. Marc Schechter and James and Janice Greenberg. Cousin of Aaron Lamstein and Charles N. Greenberg. Uncle of Jordan, Ariana, Jonathan, and Sean. Funeral service Sunday 12:30pm at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

Franco Noero, Art Dealer: Who said a blind date can't turn out to be the love of your life? That's how the art dealer Franco Noero hooked up with Casa Scaccabarozzi (known as La Fetta di Polenta, or ''the slice of polenta''), snatching it up at auction without so much as taking a tour. Designed by Alessandro Antonelli, the impossibly slender 19th-century building has been home to Noero's eponymous gallery since 2008. ''We conceived the space as a laboratory of ideas,'' says Noero, whose roster includes space invaders like Francesco Vezzoli, Jim Lambie and Mike Nelson. Book your visit soon: once all of the artists have had their way with the building, Noero plans to move on. Via Giulia di Barolo, 16/D; 011-39-011-882-208; franconoero.com.

METROPOLITAN An article in some editions last Sunday about an exhibition at ArtsWestchester's Arts Exchange comprising works that address the current economic climate, misstated, from a description by the exhibition's curator, the meaning of the title of a mixed-media installation by Kambui Olujimi. ''The O'Woof Woof'' is not ''Southern black vernacular meaning 'something you ain't gonna get.''' It is a reference to the phrase ''selling wolf tickets,'' which means making grand and threatening proclamations, none of which come to fruition.
Sip a tall drink, and sleep with the windows open.

CAMPISI--Louise, on April 30. Beloved wife of the late Mario J. Campisi. Loving mother of Manny and his wife Terri, Marianne and her husband John. Cherished grandmother of Christina and Michael. Loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. She will always be remembered as a gracious loving lady with a heart of gold. Family will receive Monday 6 to 9pm and Tuesday 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 11am at St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

Rafael de Cardenas might be the hippest thing going in interior design, and there's certainly nothing square about his first collection of furniture, on display starting May 13 at Johnson Trading Gallery in New York. His angular benches, cabinets and tables (above) were inspired by the architects Frank Lloyd Wright and Bruce Goff. De Cardenas says the cabinets in particular turn the concept of creature comfort on its ear: ''I see them as anthropomorphic features - friendly beasts.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Turin, Italy: Locals might scoff at the idea of Turin being convenient to Milan, but a fairly efficient recent high-speed railway link from Milano Centrale to Torino Porta Nuova has brought the two Italian cities within an hour's reach. Which means that should you find yourself in Milan, it's entirely possible to pop over for a leisurely lunch, stroll Turin's elegant city center and even take in some art -- and still make it back by curtain time at La Scala. MARCO VELARDI 1. Cristiani Art & Design: If your appetite for Italian design is as big as it is for Italian food, come here, where the owner Giancarlo Cristiani stocks iconic pieces by the likes of Giò Ponti, Franco Albini and Gae Aulenti. An original Carlo Mollino Polaroid makes a nice souvenir. Via Porta Palatina 13; 011-39-011-436-2092; cristiani.net.

ANNA MEDVEDEVA, 24: The photo was taken the night before my breast-augmentation, chin- and neck-liposuction surgeries, and I was very confused and was thinking, What are you doing with yourself, girl? I spent all that day at home preparing for surgery. I was alone with my fear that night, and I was thinking that I wanted to change my decision. So I tried on the bandage that I would have to wear on my face after the surgery.

The young designer Marco Dessi, who was born in Italy and who is based in Vienna, has a knack for clarity. A recent case in point is his Basket chandelier for the venerable Viennese manufacturer Lobmeyr. Dessi took as its starting point the glass-tube arms of an 18th-century chandelier but employed them in a new way, bending them into hexagons, stacking them in a shape inspired by mosque lanterns and the glass-tube windows of Frank Lloyd Wright's S. C. Johnson Administration Building, and weaving them together with jewel-toned silk cords. The result is an alluring combination of the industrial and the glamorous. Go to lobmeyr.at. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Unlike most New Yorkers, who pull up to the flower stand at a deli in search of something to pump up the swell factor at their Tuesday-night dinner parties, Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen don't find the choice pathetic or even depressing. And they don't agonize. Of course, it helps that they are wizardly professionals. Both run boutique floral design studios in Brooklyn, Saipua (Ryhanen) and Nicolette Camille (Owen). As a team (and as friends who would take a bullet for each other), they also operate the Little Flower School. ''There isn't a fiftieth here of what we see at the wholesale flower market in Manhattan,'' Ryhanen said the other morning, scanning the 24/7 sidewalk stand glued to the blank side-street facade of a Key Food in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn. ''The material is, of course, much older -- not crispy but not wonderfully hydrated, either. Bodega flowers have been cut for 10 days by the time you buy them. Still, there's a lot here. Look at these nice quince branches. Let's go to the studio and see what we can do.'' ELABORATE BOUQUETS NEED THREE TIERS.

Jim Brown has played many roles in his 60 years in the public spotlight: football star, lacrosse legend (some consider him the best lacrosse player ever), actor, social activist and more. He has added plaintiff, in a lawsuit against Electronic Arts for portraying him - not by name or face, but by weight, height, years in the league, skill rating and skin color - on the 1965 Cleveland Browns team in the Madden video-game series. The suit was dismissed in district court but is being considered by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Brown, 75, spoke by phone about the case, the lockout and his wearing yet another hat: pole-vaulter. Q. It seems that most football lawsuits these days deal with the lockout, but what is yours about?
Theater Jason Zinoman
The nick of time.

This issue is dedicated to the (wrongly) clichéd question of how one makes a house a home. We all know, of course, that the answer lies in love and friendship and commitments of a deep and complex character; but we also know that those precious bonds can be sorely tested by aggravating, inhospitable, bank-busting environs. To live beautifully requires a commitment to comfort and joy -- an amazing and rare quality. I hope you will find it here in small, instructive gestures: the folks from Blue Bottle's method for roasting coffee beans at home; a tutorial in how to transform supermarket flowers into an offhand, gorgeous bouquet; a seating plan for a Saturday supper; an idiosyncratic family reading list from the legendary George Lois.

FUTTERMAN--Alvin Jerome, died on April 30 at age 83 after a brave struggle against heart and kidney disease. He was a stalwart internationalist, leading several textile export and trading firms. He loved his wife, children, family and friends as well as travel and shared his love of world cultures with all. He was a profound optimist and gained much pleasure and respect from his interactions with people from every walk of life. Among his greatest achievements were is memoirs, "I wouldn't change a minute" which summarized his amazing and successful life spanning eight decades and including travel to six of seven continents. He proudly served in the US Army and graduated from City College at age 19. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Muriel, and his loving and devoted children, Donna Futterman, MD and Richard Futterman and their respective spouses, Virginia Casper and Ellen Futterman. He is also survived by his adoring grandchildren, Evan Casper-Futterman and Matthew and Lauren Futterman as well as his loving siblings, Honey, Stanley, and Janie and their spouses and many nieces and nephews. Donations in his honor can be made to an educational charity, or adolescentaids.org. The Funeral will be held on Sunday, May 1, at the Community Synagogue. Alvin, dad, grandpa will be missed and loved always.

GOLDSMITH--Dolores. May 2, 2009. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain, When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die.

SALTZMAN--Howard B.,86, died peacefully at home in NYC on April 26, 2011. Son of Sophie and Davis. Brother of Pearl, Joe, Blanche. Survived by Harriett, his wife of 62 years, his three daughters, Donna, Robin, Jane, sons-in-law Larry, Bob and grandson Jason. A true New Yorker. Born, raised, educated in New York City. Graduated from NYU. Served in U.S. Army. Built a successful, lifelong career in business. A real people person, he will be remembered for his sense of humor and because he made everyone smile. In Howard's memory, donations to: VNS of NY Hospice Care.

OBITUARIES An obituary last Sunday about the computer-music pioneer Max Mathews omitted the name of a survivor. A MEDIUM-SIZE seaport teetering on the edge of what we recognize as Italy, Trieste is a mysterious and puzzling place. Its iconic central square, the Piazza dell'Unità d'Italia, bounded on three sides by comically pompous 18th- and 19th-century buildings, most of them decorated like big, boxy wedding cakes, is wide open to the Adriatic, as though the ever-changing seascape were an entertainment staged for the city's benefit. This vast, glorious piazza promises all sorts of civic delights, but in fact it's one of the few immediately gratifying spots in Trieste. The rest takes time -- exactly what most of us are unwilling to give up. With a convoluted history of serial conquest, culminating in a century-long tug-of-war between Italy and Austria, a melting-pot population, a street plan that ranges from serenely rational to bewilderingly crooked and steep, and a forbidding limestone plateau crowding it down to the waterfront, Trieste is like a modernist novel -- complex, layered, ambiguous. It makes you dig for significance. But don't worry, the story has a happy ending: the patient visitor will go away well satisfied (and wonderfully well fed), rewarded by an experience unavailable to those looking for a quick and easy foreign fix.

OMAHA -- The billionaire Warren E. Buffett offered on Saturday his sharpest criticism yet of a former top lieutenant at his investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, saying that David L. Sokol had violated company trading policy and calling Mr. Sokol's actions ''inexplicable and inexcusable.'' Addressing a gathering of thousands of investors at Berkshire's annual shareholders meeting here, Mr. Buffett spoke at length publicly for the first time about the a controversy involving Mr. Sokol, who resigned from Berkshire a month ago after it was revealed that had bought shares in the chemical maker Lubrizol before pitching that company to Mr. Buffett as a potential takeover target.

CARR--James Owen "Sonny," died on April 24 at home in NYC surrounded by family and friends. He is survived by his beloved wife Joanne Howell, sister Laura Southerland and sister-in-law Sarah Carr of North Carolina, two nieces, three nephews, nine great-nieces and nephews and many loving cousins. Born June 11, 1935 in Dunn, NC. Sonny earned a BA in English from the University of North Carolina and Master's Degree from Hunter College, NYC. After moving to New York in 1958, he was a renowned jazz drummer for 20 years playing in New York clubs recording with Stan Getz, Joao Gilberto, Bobby Cole and others. He entertained servicemen on two USO world tours and accompanied the Louis Falco and Jennifer Muller dance companies. Sonny later worked as a technical writer for Reuters, Citi Bank and SIAC, retiring in 2000. A crossword puzzle fanatic and ardent Yankee fan, Sonny was devoted to his family and many friends and will be greatly missed.

MIRSKY--Stanley, MD. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our colleague, teacher, and friend. Dr. Mirsky came to Mount Sinai as a Resident in Medicine in 1958 and has devoted more than 50 years of service to the institution. Specializing in the field of Diabetes, The Stanley Mirsky, MD Diabetes Education Unit was established with philanthropic donations and is dedicated to multidisciplinary screening, counseling and diabetes prevention. He was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients and was a compassionate practitioner of medicine. He was loyal to his patients and his patients were loyal to him. Dr. Mirsky will be remembered for his outstanding contributions in teaching, patient care and patient education. The AAS salutes his legacy in the fight against Diabetes. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Steven B. Weinfeld, MD President Gila Leiter, MD Vice President Amy J. Weinstein Administrator

KELLY--George P. (Phil), a highly regarded retail executive for more than 40 years who lived most recently in Guayaquil, Ecuador and Panama City, Panama, died in Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, Florida on April 5. He was 74. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Marilyn, and a brother, C. Robert Kelly and his wife, Lynn, of Barrington, R.I. He was a graduate of Amherst College and Columbia School of Business. He began a 17-year career at Bloomingdale's in New York while a graduate student. Phil became chairman of Marshall Field's Chicago Division, president and CEO of J.W. Robinson's, in California, and president and CEO of Garfinckel's, Washington, D.C. As an international consultant, he was president of privately held Almacenes De Prati, headquartered in Guayaquil. An enthusiastic patron of the arts, he served on the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago. A memorial service is being planned for later this spring, in Providence.

Andy Phillips was on a recruiting trip Wednesday when tornadoes ravaged his hometown, Tuscaloosa, Ala. Phillips, a former Yankees infielder who is the hitting coach at the University of Alabama, said his family and his players were accounted for. But some players lost everything, he said, and friends told him the campus had been devastated. ''There's almost a milewide path the tornado went through,'' Phillips said by telephone. ''They said you could literally stand a mile and a half away from the Coliseum, where there used to be homes and buildings in between, and now there's nothing.''

FLINSCH--Margaret, of West Harrison, NY, died on April 16, 2011. She was the widow of Walter Flinsch of Frankfurt am Main, Germany. Mrs. Flinsch was born in Glendale, OH, the fifth child of Paul Matthews, later the Bishop of New Jersey, and Elsie Procter. From the age of 19 until her death at the age of 103, she was a pupil of G.I. Gurdjieff and was one of the founding members of the Gurdjieff Foundation in New York City. Her life interest in education led to the founding of the Princeton Nursery School in Princeton, NJ, when she was young, as well as later, to the founding of the Blue Rock School, now in West Nyack, NY. Both schools continue to this day. She is survived by her two daughters, Angela Laignel-Lavastine and Josephine Thatcher, and by seven grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Donations in her memory can be made to Blue Rock School, 110 Demarest Mill Rd. W. Nyack, NY 10994.

KOHLER--Lotte (Grimm), 91, Professor Emerita of City College, died March 24th after a brief illness. A Rostock, Germany native with a Ph.D. in German Literature from the University of Munster, she became a close friend of Hannah Arendt after emigrating to the United States in 1955. Succeeding Mary McCarthy as Literary Executor of the Hannah Arendt Bluecher Literary Trust, she edited the Arendt-Karl Jaspers and Arendt-Bluecher correspondences. She is survived by a sister Johanna Burgdahl, and predeceased by husbands Wilhelm Kohler (1943) and Hans Joachim Schrimpf (2003) and sister Rosemarie Grimm (2010). Lotte's boundless curiosity, keen mind and passion for friendship will be missed by her many close friends.

''Home Show, Revisited,'' opening this month at the Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum in California, puts a new spin on the expression ''mi casa, su casa.'' Now in its third iteration, the site-specific exhibition pairs 10 Los Angeles artists with 9 area residences, inviting the artists to explore the notion of home. Some of the work, like the circular swimming pool that Piero Golia built in the yard of an updated Spanish-style gem or Jennifer West's experimental surf films, which will screen at sundown at a Carpinteria surf shack, makes direct references to life in Southern California. Other installations play with personal space: the sculptor Ry Rocklen's tiled floor piece speaks to the work of the mosaic artist who is hosting him, and Bettina Hubby (above) has created curtains - depicting her ''living'' inside a Montecito Tudor - that will hang outside the windows, ''providing privacy for the owners but exposing me,'' she says. For info on self-guided tours, go to sbcaf.org. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A ceremony in celebration of her life will be held on Monday at l'Eglise Saint Laurent of Tavernay, France. If you would like to contact the family, they can be reached at: famille.rotival@gmail.com

The Web site for the Israeli publication Haaretz led its coverage with a map of the compound where Osama bin Laden was found, with the headline: "U.S. Had No Choice but to Kill Bin Laden, Says U.S. Defense Official." Other content on the home page included a slide show of Americans celebrating the killing and an article featuring the results of a survey conducted by the Pew Research Center Global Attitudes Project. According to the article, the data found that support for Bin Laden had declined among Muslims worldwide. While the publication's lead editorial focused on the commemoration of Holocaust Martyrs and Heroes Day, an editorial titled "The Road to Bin Laden Ran Through Guantánamo Bay," by Yossi Melman, extolled the merits of the United States' war on terror, including the cost to American taxpayers. "It turned out that it was worth every cent."

Three hearses, flag-draped and drawn by horses, rolled through the colonial streets of Boston on May 1. The men of the Sixth Massachusetts - the "noble sons who have given their life's blood in defense of the laws and maintenance of their country's honor," in the words of the next morning's newspaper - had come home. The cortège, accompanied by Gov. John A. Andrew and by militia cadets marching with their muskets reversed, drew up at last before the staid 18th-century portico of King's Chapel on Tremont Street. Slowly, the chapel's great bell, cast long ago in bronze by Paul Revere himself, tolled a dirge.

The last of the 200 comments to my previous column declaring the political impotence of the everything-is-socially-constructed thesis accuses me of assuming that "ideas have no consequences." Nothing could be further from the truth. "Women have long been marginalized and suppressed by a dominant male culture" is an idea. "Gays have been denied the rights that are theirs as citizens" is an idea. Each of these ideas has been enormously consequential; and each has been the basis of concerted action that altered our political and cultural landscape.

Mr. Haj also responded to speculation that the killing was a hoax. "None of us believe that Obama would dare go out on a limb and declare a victory such as this" if it were a hoax, he said.

What did we say about Osama bin Laden? The magazine exhaustively covered 9/11 and the wars that followed - the wars, especially, with in-depth reports from Iraq and Afghanistan as well as coverage of policy debates in Washington and leading trends in South Asia and what the State Department calls MENA (Middle East/North Africa). But Bin Laden only occasionally wafted into view. In the first few months after 9/11, he was omnipresent - Andrew Sullivan, for example, filed an article late that month that talked about how it was a mistake to deny that the conflict we were in was "about religion." His main evidence was the statements of Osama bin laden, which were then forthcoming in abundance.

One pleasure of the sixth floor — right now I mean the offices, not the blog — is getting to walk past the prints of some of the photos we’ve published in the magazine over the years. They’re big, and they’re full of fun or beauty or mystery or some mix of all these and other qualities. I’m no art critic — I know, shocking, right? — but one in particular has struck me as subtler than the rest, harder to “read” at a glance, easier to pass by on a daily basis without fully seeing what’s going on. That’s how it has been for me, anyway. The photo is a black-and-white camera obscura image of Times Square by Abelardo Morell. It ran in the magazine in 1997, and is reproduced above.

Will “Catch Me If You Can” be nominated for the best musical Tony Award, after being left out of that category by the Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle award nominators last week? Which of these five Broadway plays — “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” “Good People,” “Jerusalem,” “The —————— with the Hat,” or “War Horse” — will not be in the running for best play when all of the Tony nominees are announced Tuesday morning? Will the two male stars of “Catch Me” and the two in “The Book of Mormon” take up four of the five nominations for best actor in a musical? And who will make the cut for the five spots in another competitive performance category this year, best actor in a play? Broadway veterans like Brian Bedford (“The Importance of Being Earnest”) and Joe Mantello (“The Normal Heart”); movies stars like James Earl Jones (“Driving Miss Daisy”), Al Pacino (“The Merchant of Venice”), and Robin Williams (“Bengal Tiger”); and widely admired actors Bobby Cannavale (“Hat”) and Mark Rylance (“Jerusalem,” “La Bête”) are all more-than-plausible as nominees. Did you grow up with the notion that you should never cheer at the death of a person, even a tyrant? I did. I suppose it has to do with that very subtle business of distinguishing yourself from your enemies. So I felt some slight ambivalence when a force that was much stronger than my ambivalence took me into my daughter's bedroom this morning to wake her and show her the local newspaper, then on the same errand into my son's room, waiting while he rubbed the sleep out of his eyes and focused on the Page 1 headline in great, black type: BIN LADEN DEAD. I exult in the death of my enemy.

When the 1941 Quonset hut that housed Hoorsenbuhs’s Santa Monica atelier was scheduled for demolition, the first reaction of the fine jewelry line’s founders, Robert Keith and Kether Parker, was resistance; after all, the iron structure’s rustic feel was the perfect complement to Keith’s opulent industrial designs, favored by style savvy celebs like David Beckham, Katie Holmes, Mary Kate Olsen and Rihanna. But soon the two men, who became fast friends on a Malibu beach 20 years ago and started Hoorsenbuhs in 2005, decided that an upgrade was in order. The new private showroom opened this week in a former bungalow on Santa Monica’s Main Street, with fittings from the old space, like dark wood sliding doors, industrial lamps and jewelry cases offset with heavy maritime chains. (The Hoorsenbuhs name comes from a Dutch trading ship sailed by Keith’s ancestors.). The new space is an airy, light-filled room that will soon open to an outdoor area with a fire pit.

When you entreat a conscientious bartender to make you a gimlet these days, he frequently does something that is at once resolutely incorrect and completely forgivable: he makes you a drink containing gin, simple syrup and fresh lime juice. I've done it many times myself. Depending on whom you talk to, that might be a type of sour or it might be a type of fix, but it almost certainly is not a gimlet. A proper gimlet is made with lime cordial. And what most of the world knows as lime cordial is Rose's, that dusty, fluorescent yellow-green bottle in the drinks section of your supermarket. I am willing to bet that at some point in its very long history Mr. Lauchlin Rose's Cordial Mixer Lime Juice may have been a bracing product, redolent of the fruit that it promises. Sadly, its current incarnation is to limes as Spam is to steak. It tastes of the high-fructose corn syrup, stabilizers and various chemicals that give it its cesium-like shelf life, which is all fine for Cadbury, which has owned the brand since 1981, but is bitter gruel for someone trying to tap into the sublimity of a true gimlet. For that, as for many such rich rewards, you've got to make your own.

There was a nice piece by Asef Bayat in Foreign Affairs last week on "The Post-Islamist Revolutions." Bayat -- born and raised in Iran, educated in Britain, professor at Leiden then the University of Illinois -- makes the first convincing (rather than wishful) argument I've seen that the Arab Spring is likely to usher in relatively liberal, though religiously inflected, societies. The article makes a nice pairing with another recent Foreign Affairs piece by Michael Scott Doran, which takes Iran and Syria seriously as a kind of "anticolonialist" bloc single-mindedly focused on undermining the United States. It is perhaps a slightly paranoid or excited piece, but it is paranoid about something that the United States, as a noncolonial and indeed anticolonial power, habitually underestimates in its foreign policy, namely the enduring political power of anticolonial feeling in a post-colonial world.

Back in 2006, "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip" made its debut on NBC, and the show was intriguing for several reasons. One, it was created by arguably TV's most revered auteur at the time, Aaron Sorkin, who was more-or-less fresh off "The West Wing," a paragon of snappy-pattered, makes-you-feel-smart-just-for-watching television. Two, "Studio 60" was about comedy: specifically, late-night comedy and, presumably, "Saturday Night Live." ("Studio 60" was the name of a fictional, live, late-night sketch-comedy show produced out of Los Angeles.) Third, in a weird coincidence, "Studio 60" premiered the same year, on the same network, as the similarly numerically titled "30 Rock," which is also sort-of about "Saturday Night Live" and is written by the ex-"S.N.L." head writer Tina Fey.

OMAHA - At the annual gathering of Berkshire Hathaway's investors here this weekend, Warren E. Buffett made it clear that, as far as he is concerned, it's back to business as usual. But a former top manager for him, David L. Sokol, may make that a difficult goal to accomplish. Mr. Buffett said at a news conference on Sunday that while he viewed the controversy caused by Mr. Sokol's abrupt departure a month ago as sad, he saw little reason to dwell on the matter for very long.

NASH--Judith H. Our beloved mother Judith Hartley Nash from Armonk, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, died peacefully, on April 28, 2011. She was the granddaughter of Governor Roland H. Hartley, the two term Governor of Washington and the 10th Governor of that state. She was predeceased by Robert L. Nash, her loving husband of more than 60 years. Daughters Jennifer, Kathy, and Marcia will remember and admire her strength as she fought Alzheimer's disease for too many years. Her surviving sisters Marcia and Jeanne, her grandchildren Cooper and Andrea, and son-in-law Bill Hesse are deeply saddened by their loss. Mom, a special and wonderful person, loved her life, her family and friends, tennis games, and all the animals she saved over many years. She will be missed by all who were fortunate to know her. A special thanks to Detla, Fareeza, and Mathilda for the love and care they provided to all of us. We appreciate any contribution to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. We are deeply grateful to them.

The makers of the Samsung SH100 digital camera are taking a literal approach to product placement in a marketing campaign that starts on Monday. The campaign, called the Samsung Coast to Coast Photo Post, will put a single SH100 into the hands of people in 25 cities across the country so they can use it to post photos on various social media sites like Facebook, YouTube and Picasa. The campaign is intended to highlight the camera's ability to instantly upload photos to the Web, something that an increasing number of cellphone cameras already do.

OBITUARIES An obituary on April 17 about the violinist Billy Bang omitted the name of a survivor. In addition to two daughters, two sons, a granddaughter and his companion, Maria Arias, Mr. Bang is survived by his wife, I Ting, from whom he was separated.

OTTAWA -- Shortly before the start of Canada's current federal election campaign, which concludes on Monday, the governing Conservatives had something they believed would seriously undermine the credibility of Michael Ignatieff, leader of the Liberal Party. They came across a photograph on the Internet that showed six men wearing Santa Claus hats and American battle gear posing with weapons in front of an American military helicopter in Kuwait prior to the Iraq war. One of the men resembles Mr. Ignatieff, who directed a human rights center at Harvard before returning to his native Canada to take up political life.

KOBLENTZ--Charles, 93, died on April 30. Born in Chicago, he married his college sweetheart, Evelyn Dunn, in 1939 and soon moved with her to Washington, DC. There, his career advanced quickly as he conducted personnel management studies for various federal government agencies. During World War II, he served his country in the Office of Statistical Control at the Pentagon with the rank of Chief Warrant Officer, USAAF. Post-War, he returned to the federal government, where he planned and conducted a reorganization of the FCC. His challenging and fulfilling government career was cut short, however, when he was investigated in the late 1940's by the House Un-American Activities Committee on grounds of "guilt by association." At the ensuing hearing, he was exonerated of all charges. In 1950, Charles joined a prominent management consulting firm but was dismissed when the firm learned he had once been investigated by HUAC. Throughout much of the 1950's and 1960's, Charles, determined to provide for his family, which by then included four young children, worked at jobs dictated not by choice but by the constraints imposed by blacklisting. Rising above the trauma inflicted by the McCarthy years, in 1966 he joined American Trading and Production Company, where he rose to Executive Vice President for the Industrial Group and served on the Board of Directors. After retiring from ATAPCO in 1993 at age 75, he moved to Longboat Key, Florida, where he enjoyed his life-long enthusiasm for long walks that began as a boy in Chicago. He continued to maintain a home in Baltimore, Maryland, and later in White Plains, New York. In addition to foreign travels with Evelyn, he took lively trips in his 9th decade and the beginning of his 10th with sons Joel and Gerald. He wore them out walking over the bridges of Venice, up and down the hills of Montmartre and through the temples at Ramses II. A keen intellect with a strong interest in the social, economic, and political forces that shape history, Charles read widely and wrote a chronicle that set the events of his own life within the context of the times in which he lived. The saddest experience of his life was the loss of his son Paul in 1982. The people who knew Charles, whether for decades or in the brief interactions of day-to-day encounters, recognized a charismatic person of evident goodwill towards them in how he treated them, listened, and spoke. The memory of Charles, particularly his strength of character, intelligence, moral integrity, and devotion, will be cherished by friends, relatives, and former colleagues, as well as by those in his immediate family, whom he loved so much: Evelyn, his devoted wife of 71 years; children Joel, Suzanne Goodman (Jordan), and Gerald; grandsons Gregory Koblentz (Linda Fu) and Jason Goodman; and great-grandsons Kai and Evan Koblentz. Funeral services will be held at noon on May 3, Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to MAZON: A Jewish Response to Hunger, Charles' most favored charity.

Fans of Delicious, an online bookmarking service, raised a ruckus after word leaked four months ago that its owner, Yahoo, might shutter it as part of a streamlining plan. To deflect criticism, Yahoo quickly reassured users that it was trying to find Delicious a new home rather than kill it.

LEVY--Helen Friedman, in her 99th year. Beloved wife of the late Edward for over 68 years. Her life revolved around her children Jim and Leslie Levy and Jane and Andrew Dolkart, grandchildren, Caren and Jonathan Greenhouse, Laurie Levy, Judith Dolkart and Peter Dolkart and her great-granddaughters, Sophie and Caroline Greenhouse. Her cultural interests included art, music and literature. She loved to garden. Her charitable interests as a volunteer included Brandeis University, Camp NYDA, and Sloane Kettering Memorial Hospital among others. She will be remembered with love by all who knew her. Private graveside service.

Very few golf strokes scare touring pros, quite a few scare the rest of us, and one scares everyone. The frightening stroke in question would be the slice putt, the dreaded slider, the one that is forced by the contours of the green to move from left to right for right-handers and from right to left for lefties. The slippery slope of putting, the slider comes in different lengths, rolls uphill or down, goes by several names and has been called many unprintable things.

ZELUCK--Kevin. "Dude, Uncle Kuzzy, Uncle Kev. You were like a father to us all. There is a hole in our hearts that can never be filled. We could always come to you to make us laugh, turn to you for advice, and count on you to be the best dressed guy in the room. We cannot imagine our lives without your smiling face in it. We will always remember your endless generosity and we can only aspire to touch the lives of others half as much as you have touched each of ours. We will forever love and miss you, Blake, Stanley, Elyse and Ben, Justin, Lauren and David, Danielle, Morgan, Samantha, Erica and Joe Farryn, Amanda and Austyn

INTERNATIONAL A report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about a proposal by the Turkish government to build a canal connecting the Black Sea to the Marmara misstated the relative size of the canal. The proposed canal, which would be 28 to 30 miles long, would not be longer than the Panama Canal, which is about 50 miles long, or the Suez, which is about 101 miles long.

NATIONAL An article on Tuesday about a decision by the Atlanta law firm King & Spalding to withdraw from an effort by Republicans in Congress to defend the constitutionality of the federal Defense of Marriage Act misstated the position at the firm to which two former United States senators, Connie Mack of Florida, and Dan Coats of Indiana, were appointed in 2005. It was co-chairman of the government practice group, not partner. (Mr. Coats was re-elected to the Senate in 2010. )

SCHILLER--Harvey M, 90 passed away peacefully at home on Saturday, April 16, beloved by his wife of 61 years Martha Berstein Schiller, who helped run their business the Schiller Printery, by his daughter Kathi, his son Robert, his grandchildren Zak, Mina, and Sahm, brother Roland, and daughter-in-law Niloufar Gidfar. He was a decorated veteran of WW II, and was awarded the Bronze Star. Revered as generous, committed, compassionate, he remained active after his retirement in local community organizations: his synagogue, Rotary Club, environmental groups, and taught ecology to the local elementary school, while continuing his passion for painting. He will be greatly missed by his friends, family, and community. Contributions can be made in honor of Harvey Schiller for a tree planting fund to the Friends of Rye Brook, Attn: Treasurer, 938 King St, Rye Brook, NY 10573.

PHILADELPHIA - Just before ducking into the indoor batting cage Sunday afternoon, Jose Reyes spotted an old mentor he had not seen in five years, one who had a big impact on his career, he said. The man was Bobby Valentine, the former Mets manager who was at Citizens Bank Park in his role as a broadcaster for ESPN. He was in the clubhouse to talk to Terry Collins, the current Mets manager, before the game, when Reyes saw him. Valentine went over and greeted Reyes, kissing the back of his hand, and came away with a huge smile, saying, ''And by the way, in case anyone asks, I made him into a switch-hitter.''

Zite, a news aggregator for the iPad whose app has irked major news publishers, said Monday that Mark Johnson, a longtime adviser to the company, would become its new chief executive. But the announcement those news publishers were likely to focus on was Zite's release of a new version of its app, which it calls a ''personalized magazine.'' It said it was intended to quell the criticism from publishers.

NEW YORK An article on Friday about the last elevator operators at New York City subway stations misstated the access to the 191st Street station in Upper Manhattan. It can be accessed by elevator from St. Nicholas Avenue and by a pedestrian tunnel from Broadway; the elevator is not the only access.

8 P.M. (TCM) A SALUTE TO EBERTFEST In a festival held each spring (this year's ran from Wedesday to Sunday) in Champaign, Ill., Roger Ebert, the Pulitzer Prize-winning film critic, presents movies he believes have been overlooked by the public or film distributors. The lineup here begins with ''Gates of Heaven'' (1978), Errol Morris's documentary about the pet cemetery business in California -- a film that Mr. Ebert had seen perhaps 30 times when he wrote, in 1997, that he was ''still not anywhere near the bottom of it.'' The screenings continue at 9:45 with Tia Lessin and Carl Deal's ''Trouble the Water'' (2008), in which Kimberly Rivers Roberts, a resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans, records Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath with her video camera; at 11:30, ''Playtime'' (above, 1967), directed by and stars Jacques Tati as his unflappable alter ego, Monsieur Hulot, who is sent on a comic errand through the newfangled architecture of Paris; Jeff Nichols's ''Shotgun Stories'' (2007), about half brothers (including Michael Shannon, Douglas Ligon, Barlow Jacobs and Travis Smith) who initiate a feud after the death of their father in rural Arkansas, at 1:45 a.m.; and, at 3:30, Paul Cox's ''Innocence'' (2000), starring Julia Blake and Charles Tingwell as former lovers who rekindle their affair 40 years later. 9:30 A.M. WASHINGTON - Republicans, with justification, shouted ''hypocrisy'' last week after former White House aides opened a campaign organization using the sort of anonymous donors condemned by President Obama. But they also understood it as a compliment. That's because, in another springtime full of political disappointment, Democratic strategists have begun concluding that Mr. Obama faces a tougher-than-anticipated re-election fight.

Sidney Michaels, a playwright who was nominated for Tony Awards in three consecutive seasons in the 1960s, died on April 22 in Westport, Conn. He was 83. His daughter-in-law, Jennifer Jennings, confirmed his death. Mr. Michaels had Alzheimer's disease.

SPORTS The On Soccer column on Thursday, about Real Madrid's 2-0 victory over Barcelona, misspelled the surname of Lionel Messi's teammate who assisted on one of his two goals. It is Ibrahim Afellay, not Affelay.

It is not often you see a couple of characters dashing around the Bronx dressed in Kiplingesque explorers' outfits. But last summer, two actors named Joey Rizzolo and Christopher Borg pulled on their aviator goggles and straightened their bow ties and set off on an expedition. The two explorers looked as if they were bound for Cairo or Casablanca to unearth some ancient tomb. In fact, they set their course for Storage Deluxe in Co-op City, which charges a monthly fee for a walk-in storage space about the size of a large elevator.

PERLOWIN--Paul R. Born February 4, 1918 died April 6, 2011. After he had been ill since November, he was an exceptional husband for Hilda, and a wonder father for Lane Nemeth and Beth Weissman. He was a successful salesman in the photography industry. He had cameras imported from Japan and sold them here; namely Minolta. He worked with them in the 60s through the 90s when he retired.

LEAHY--Francis J. "Buddy", on April 30, 2011, of Spring Lake, NJ, age 72. Buddy was born in New York City and was a self-employed construction consultant. He was a member of the Metallic Lathers Local 46 who later became a leader in the construction industry for over 50 years. He was also a Marine Veteran of the Korean War. Beloved husband to Anne J. (nee) Dillon. Devoted father to Francis, the late Joseph, Susan Hagen and her husband Drew, and Linda Sassone and her husband Brian. Loving brother to Marie Cahill and her husband Jimmy and the late William Leahy and his wife Barbara. Adored grandfather to William J. Leahy, Daniel and Brian Hagen. Funeral Service will be held at the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home 495 Anderson Ave., Cliffside Park, NJ on Wednesday May 4, 2011 at 10:00am. Interment to follow at St. Joseph Cemetery, Hackensack, NJ. Visiting hours Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Buddy's memory to The Lustgarten Foundation 1111 Stewart Avenue Bethpage, NY 11714 or online at: www.curePC.org. www.akmacagnafuneralhome.com
MELNICK--Gisele. 10/27/1935 - 05/02/2006. The world is diminished without her.

Teams of scholars have spent nearly 30 years tracking down, researching and editing the more than 15,000 letters written by or to Charles Darwin. Now, thanks to $8.2 million in grants from the Evolution Education Trust, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and the Isaac Newton Trust, the entire collection will be published in full by 2022. Texts of some 6,000 letters and information on 9,000 more are already available here.

So, driven to a rustic frenzy by the Northeast's oxen craze, you've just bought a pair of brawny bovines and are ready to put them to work in your garden. But you have no idea how to do that. For $29.95 you can buy the DVD "Training Oxen," made in 2003 by Drew Conroy, a professor at the University of New Hampshire who is known in draft-power circles as "the ox guru." Or, to get started, you can take a look at this clip from the DVD with Tim Huppe of BerryBrook Ox Supply, in Farmington, N.H.

I reviewed two new restaurants this week, one declaring itself British and the other French-Italian - but oddly similar in their devotion to bread, salt, fat and wine. At Jones Wood Foundry, toast with potted shrimp, or crumpets with lemon curd; at Buvette, pork rillettes, local cheese, or hazelnut pesto on crunchy baguette. Buvette calls itself a "gastroteque"; Jones Wood Foundry is a model gastropub. Both are places where, theoretically at least, New Yorkers might drop in any time for a glass and a bite. Where do you like best for that kind of meal?

Where is Ai Weiwei? It's a good question, and one posed by the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija on a banner created to accompany Ai's exhibition at Berlin's Neugerriemschneider gallery, the opening of which Ai was regrettably unable to attend this past weekend because of a previous engagement with Chinese authorities. Despite his absence, his show was a big crowd pleaser during Berlin's Gallery Weekend. The 44 participating galleries and numerous off-calendar spaces presented a thoughtful program that celebrated Berlin's low-key ethos, and where the work, rather than celebrity-stocked private dinners and A-list parties, was the main attraction.

The No. 23 city bus running along the cobblestones is still known as the “trolley,”and you can take it to visit the house where a young Benjamin Franklin stopped for advice on books or to other homes where Revolutionary War battles left powder marks and bloodstains. George Washington slept here, a lot, and decades later so did runaway slaves at a well-preserved stop on the Underground Railroad. There’s also a homey lunch spot known for its veggie burger.

After disappointing performances by the Williams Formula One car in the first three races, the team announced on Tuesday that its technical director, Sam Michael, and its chief aerodynamicist, Jon Tomlinson, had resigned, effective at the end of the season. The team also announced that Mike Coughlan, the race car designer behind a spying scandal four years ago, would join the team in June as chief engineer.

After reading Frank Bruni's article on Torrisi Italian Specialties and the future of Italian-American food, I was curious - and hungry. Even more so after the two chefs agreed to let us post several of their recipes online. As a general rule, I'm not into polyglot food. Curry on pasta? Even pineapple on "Hawaiian" pizza? Not for me. As Bruni points out, fusion has become a bit of a naughty word. But I was intrigued by the chefs' Lower East Side mash-ups. Centuries ago, Leicester Square was a genteel patch, but now it is brash and loud, bordered by an all-night Chinatown and ringed by West End theaters, carousels and street stalls. On weekend evenings, gaggles of young women soused on Magners or caffeinated tonic wine don dangerously short skirts (even in frigid temperatures) and stumble around the hucksters, buskers and neophyte tourists who've been sucked in, mothlike, by all that neon. There are good movie theaters here, great soup dumplings, and the square is convenient to just about everything in London. But it is not a traditionally desirable neighborhood for a hotel.

Now that Osama bin Laden is dead, I imagine many historians will be taking out their chisels and stones in an attempt to capture the moment within the historical record. Most military histories hyphenate years of conflict and inscribe them on a tombstone formed by parentheses. When we walk through history’s graveyard, for example, we find: World War I (1914-1918) and World War II (1939-1945) among the many rows of markers annotating warfare.

Popelini, the pastry shop Lauren Koumetz opened this month in Paris's Marais neighborhood, is devoted exclusively to choux à la crème, or cream puffs, the bite-size flavor shots that offer a sugar lover an alternative to France's superstar macaron. On any given day, the choux are lined up in a half dozen flavors including dark chocolate, lemon praline, salted butter caramel, Madagascar vanilla and rose; some have an additional confit filling of passion fruit or raspberry. And then there's the choux du jour, dreamed up by the pastry chef Alice Barday, which might be strawberry-litchi, Earl Grey tea, pear, or tiramisu, inspired by the Italian dessert with whipped cream, almonds and crunchy chocolate sprinkles.

The United Nations projects that the population of the world may hit 10.1 billion by the year 2100, Justin Gillis and Celia W. Dugger report. Less than 48 hours after Osama bin Laden's death, the book deals have begun. Peter Bergen will write the "definitive" book on the hunt for Bin Laden, his publisher said on Tuesday. Charles Fishman, a longtime writer for Fast Company magazine, is the author of "The Big Thirst," a new book on water. He previously wrote "The Wal-Mart Effect," which was an Economist "book of the year" in 2006 and a finalist in The Financial Times's awards for best business book. Our conversation follows.

This week, A. O. Scott looks at a film from Corneliu Porumboiu, one of the directors who has emerged out of the new wave of Romanian cinema. His film, "12:08 East of Bucharest," looks back at the Romanian revolution of 1989 and asks what the revolution meant to the country and how such a dynamic moment could quickly fade into history. In the film, three characters gather in a drab television studio to commemorate the revolution and to also question whether or not it really happened. Mr. Scott says that one of the elements that makes the film stand out is its "sly, deadpan, understated wit." Have you seen "12:08 East of Bucharest" or other films from the Romanian new wave? Please share your thoughts.
