Our cover story on Sunday was about the American soldiers accused of murdering Afghan civilians. Some reports have depicted them as a rogue unit, but our story goes deeper into the psyche of the American soldier and questions whether the killings are symptoms of a much larger issue. Being a weekly, time was a factor, so we executed some staff-produced, alternate versions of the magazine's cover, two days before it had to ship. We started with a graphic approach, experimenting with every font in our arsenal. We did more than can be featured in this blog post, but the following is a curated depiction of our process for developing a cover.

What’s this? A full slate of real, original plays – and I mean plays, like mom and dad used to dress up for and would talk about over martinis afterward. Though the Tony nominations announced Tuesday morning didn’t offer many surprises (the hearty, 12-nomination celebration of “Scottsboro Boys” was the only mild shocker), it did confirm some good news. Legitimate dramas are still being written, and they’re being written well.

Last week, we published a case study that explored whether Big D Custom Screen Printing could become profitable by specializing in small T-shirt orders. After a year in business, the company had sales of $325,000 on which it suffered a nominal loss. Big D’s co-founder, Darren Robbins, and his partner disagreed as to the best way to turn things around. His partner wanted to focus on large corporate accounts. Mr. Robbins believed Big D could thrive by targeting customers with small orders — as small as one T-shirt. The partners split (amicably) over the issue.

Somewhere, Lord Voldemort is surely smiling while “Harry Potter” fans are heartbroken: Daniel Radcliffe leveraged his years as the star of that boy-wizard franchise to play J. Pierrepont Finch in the current Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” and spent months in vocal and dance training to get up to speed for the role. Yet he couldn’t conjure up enough magic to secure a Tony nomination on Tuesday for a performance that excited many theatergoers and critics, making him one of the most glaring snubs of the morning. Did Tony nominators agree with Ben Brantley, who wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Radcliffe “is clearly not to the musical manner born.” Or was Mr. Radcliffe simply the victim of an evil spell cast by Severus Snape? The quest for the perfect cup of organic fair-trade Sumatran coffee can take you far afield (or at least off the island of Manhattan). But why travel when Melissa Knott of Grounded Coffee Catering will bring her coffee bar to you? Knott will journey anywhere in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania where there's a dedicated electrical outlet and "four clear feet of space" for her folding table and portable Pasquini espresso machine. Along with filter coffee and espresso drinks - including a fantastic decaf - Knott offers loose-leaf black and herbal teas, hot chocolate (made with dairy, soy or coconut milk) and Italian sodas, all organic and fair-trade. She works with a local roaster to create custom blends and has them specially roasted for each event she caters. Since founding her business three and a half years ago, Knott has pulled shots and poured cups everywhere from suburban pool parties to the set of a slasher film on Governors Island. Her dedication to coffee - she wrote her thesis on it - is such that she even checks the water quality of an area before heading out. "I actually prefer to bring my own," she says. "If the water's too hard or too soft it really affects the taste of the coffee." For more on Grounded Coffee Catering, including information on the farmers' markets where Knott sells her custom roasted beans, go to groundedcatering.com.

I’ve periodically recommended that high school students take a “gap year” after graduation, by deferring college entrance for one year. Most colleges encourage students to take a gap year, partly because students then arrive a little more mature, a little more ready to study, a little more worldly. It’s becoming a bit more common, and Princeton now pays for some kids to travel during their gap year, but most people are still wary of the idea. In fact, almost every kid I’ve talked to who has taken a gap year raves about the idea, so I thought I’d commission a guest column from my eldest son, Gregory, who is currently taking a gap year in China. He spent most of the year studying Chinese at Tsinghua University and then at a language school in Dalian, and soon he’s going to finish up the year studying Spanish in Peru. On the side, he worked and volunteered. Here’s his take:

Every spring art galleries in the Saint-Germain-des-Pres neighborhood, long famed as home to artists, writers and musicians, open their doors to the public, in a block party called Art Saint-Germain-des-Pres. With what might be the highest concentration of galleries in the world, it's an ideal area to find a variety of art, from primitive to contemporary and sculpture and painting to photography, jewelry and antiques. This year's event, from May 19 to 22, will include at least 60 galleries. As an example of the event's breadth, La Galerie Artco-France will show works by the Surrealist René Magritte and La Galerie Frédéric Got Fine Art photographs by Elliott Erwitt.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- In Afghanistan, where Osama bin Laden was based for many years and where Al Qaeda helped to train and pay insurgents, there was relief and uncertainty about how his death would play out in the fraught regional power politics now shaping the war. While senior political figures welcomed the news of his death, they cautioned that it did not necessarily translate into an immediate military victory over the Taliban, and urged the United States and NATO not to use it as a reason to withdraw. ''The killing of Osama should not be seen as mission accomplished,'' said Hanif Atmar, a former interior minister who has been a strong opponent of the Taliban. ''Al Qaeda is much more than just Osama bin Laden.''

Rabia Mehmood, a Pakistani journalist working with The New York Times, wrote the following after watching Urdu-language news broadcasts on Pakistani television from New York: I have watched the prime-time transmissions of the leading news networks. The most extreme opinions were given during a talk show on Geo TV, a leading Urdu channel. On the prime-time talk show ''Capital Talk,'' Ansar Abbasi, a senior journalist, said, ''Osama bin Laden was not a terrorist,'' adding that the Taliban and Al Qaeda ''have never been enemies of Pakistan.'' He also said the American raid on Bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad ''breached Pakistan's sovereignty.''

SYRIA Security forces have escalated an arrest campaign in the country's most rebellious regions, activists said. Although the authorities have arrested protesters across the country since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad began six weeks ago, they have engaged in a broader campaign of intimidation in recent days. Insan, a Syrian human rights group, said it had documented more than 500 arrests in the besieged city of Dara'a since Thursday, and more than 300 in towns on the outskirts of Damascus, the capital. LIBYA Turkey closed its embassy in Tripoli, apparently frightened by the angry crowds that have threatened the embassies of NATO countries after the NATO airstrike that the government said killed a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and three of his grandchildren. Since the airstrike on Saturday night, Qaddafi supporters have vandalized or set ablaze the Italian, British and American Embassies, which were already closed, and ransacked United Nations buildings, forcing officials there to withdraw.

For Eisenstein, you can go to Netflix and stream ''Battleship Potemkin'' or ''Ivan the Terrible.'' For Dovzhenko, you can stream ''Earth'' at Netflix or ''Arsenal'' at Amazon. For Pudovkin, ''Mother'' is at Amazon. But what if you're looking for a more recent, if less familiar, brand of Russian cinema? Like, say, Vitali Moskalenko's 2002 Volga river-boat comedy, ''The Chinese Tea-Set.'' Or Emil Loteanu's 1979 adaptation of the Chekhov novella ''The Shooting Party'' (original title ''My Tender and Affectionate Beast'').

NASH--Judith H. Our beloved mother Judith Hartley Nash from Armonk, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, died peacefully, on April 28, 2011. She was the granddaughter of Governor Roland H. We appreciate any contribution to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. We are deeply grateful to them.

ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan -- The sprawling compound where Osama bin Laden sheltered before his death stood out in its middle-class neighborhood on the edges of this scenic city, home to a large Pakistani military base and a military academy. The compound is about eight times the size of most homes in the area and was surrounded by high walls topped with barbed wire. Nearby residents noticed that few people ever ventured out of the house, and although a senior Obama administration official said the property was valued at about $1 million, no telephone lines ran into the compound.

The Public Theater production of ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson'' won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding musical on Sunday night, while Kristoffer Diaz's ''The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity'' was named best play in the 26th annual competition recognizing Off Broadway work. ''Bloody Bloody'' was a hit at the Public last spring but had trouble finding an audience when commercial producers moved it to Broadway in the fall; ''Chad Deity,'' meanwhile, had a critically acclaimed production at Second Stage Theater. Signature Theater Company's production of ''Angels in America'' won for best revival, while ''Mike Birbiglia's My Girlfriend's Boyfriend'' won for solo show.

The New York Times and WNYC are collaborating to create an interactive map of bird-watching spots throughout the five boroughs as part Bird Week, a celebration of avian life in the city. Text BIRD to 30644 from your cellphone and follow the instructions to submit the location you would like to share and your most recent bird sighting. We will present the map with highlights of your contributions by the end of the week. For more articles, photos and multimedia on Bird Week, go to nytimes.com/cityroom or listen to ''The Brian Lehrer Show'' on WNYC and wnyc.org.

Since 9/11, there has been an outpouring of books about Osama bin Laden, Al Qaeda, the Sept. 11 attacks and the war in Afghanistan. Below is an annotated list of some of the more useful ones.Some of these books are primarily concerned with giving the reader a bildungsroman-like account of Bin Laden's transformation into a charismatic leader from a callow young man who ''couldn't lead eight ducks across the street,'' as Prince Bandar, the former Saudi ambassador in Washington, once said. They underscore the unresolved Oedipal problems (not unlike those of George W. Bush) that he had with his powerful and wealthy father, while exploring the role that older mentors played in his growing radicalization. ''The Bin Ladens,'' by Steve Coll, also adds new details to our understanding of how the young Bin Laden evolved from a loyal family adjutant into an angry black sheep lashing out at some of the very connections his father and brothers had cultivated in their business dealings for years.

6:40 p.m. | Updated Arch Coal said on Monday that it would buy the International Coal Group for $3.4 billion in cash, creating one of the world's largest coal producers. The deal is largely a bet on steel: the combined company would be the second-biggest producer of metallurgical coal in the United States at a time when prices for such steel-making coal are rising thanks to demand from China and India. The biggest producer of steel-making coal is Alpha Natural Resources, which outbid Arch Coal earlier this year to acquire Massey Energy for $7.1 billion in cash and stock.

Osama bin Laden, who was killed in Pakistan early Monday, was a son of the Saudi elite whose radical, violent campaign to recreate a seventh-century Muslim empire redefined the threat of terrorism for the 21st century. With the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001, Bin Laden was elevated to the realm of evil in the American imagination once reserved for dictators like Hitler and Stalin. He was a new national enemy, his face on wanted posters. He gloated on videotapes, taunting the United States and Western civilization.

SIRKIN--Sidney of Dedham, MA formerly of New York died April 29, 2011. He was 95 years old. Born in Sydney, Nova Scotia and raised in Waterbury, Connecticut, he graduated from CCNY in 1938. He founded Kornbluh, Sirkin & Ritter, an accounting firm, in 1948 in New York City where for more than 50 years he practiced international accounting. He advised an ever-widening circle of European companies that came to do business in the United States, Foods from France, Petrossian, Hermes and others. He was awarded the Order of Merit by the French Government and was a member of Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. He loved his work, growing roses, French wines, food and culture, international travel and most of all his beloved wife of 67 years Marion. He was witty, charming and kind. Sidney is survived by his wife, two sons, Elliott and Joel, and two grandsons, Alex and Jake. Donations in his memory may be made to 21st Century Foundation, City College Development Office, 160 Convent Avenue, New York, NY 10031.

Kid Rock received an award from the Detroit branch of the N.A.A.C.P. on Sunday night despite the protests of picketers outside the ceremony who said he should not be using the Confederate flag during his performances. The Associated Press reported that about 50 protesters assembled outside the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual Fight for Freedom Fund dinner at the Cobo Center in Detroit, where Kid Rock was presented with the organization's Great Expectations Award, honoring him for his advocacy of the city. A replica of a Confederate flag, seen by some as an enduring symbol of slavery and racism, was burned during the protest.

Steve Riedner of Schaumberg, Ill., was a 55-year-old tool-and-die maker, a job that involves difficult mental calculations, and a frequent speaker at community meetings when he found himself increasingly at a loss for words and unable to remember numbers. He even began to have difficulty reading his own written comments. The neurologist he consulted thought Mr. Riedner had suffered a stroke and for three years treated him with cholesterol-lowering medication. But instead of his language ability stabilizing or improving, as should happen following a stroke, it got worse.

Just when you thought that serotonin was passé, and you'd tossed all your half-used bottles of S.S.R.I.-type antidepressants because the ones that didn't give you nausea or smother your libido left you wondering whether you were in the placebo arm of a clinical trial, here comes a raft of new discoveries that sweeps the small, evolutionarily ancient and slyly powerful signaling molecule back on to center stage. Researchers lately have learned that serotonin plays an impressive number of critical roles throughout the body, both below the neck and above it, and from the earliest days of prenatal pre-sentience. One team has found that serotonin starts seeping into the embryonic forebrain during the first trimester of pregnancy, helping to shape the basic neural circuitry that later in life will be applied to learning, emoting and consulting a psychiatrist.
International FORMER LEADER'S RETURN

There exists a large and soothing body of scientific literature suggesting that regular exercise can improve someone's mood and fight anxiety. And then there is this experiment from Germany, in which researchers placed running wheels in the cages of a group of laboratory mice and let them exercise at will. Mice generally love to run, and these rodents spent almost every waking hour on their wheels, skittering through more miles than most animals are allowed to complete during exercise studies, averaging about seven miles per mouse per day. The scientists, from the Central Institute of Mental Health Mannheim, then placed these avid runners in unfamiliar situations. What they found was surprising, in part because it contradicted earlier experiments by other researchers. The mice froze or quickly fled to dark corners, behaviors considered by some researchers to signify anxiety. It was as if the marathon runners in this experiment had become more anxious and neurotic than the nonrunners, presumably because of the volume of their running.

McKENNA--William E. August 9, 1919 April 29, 2011. William E. McKenna, a 45-year resident of Beverly Hills, passed away April 29th, 2011 at age 91. He was a World War II hero, having won an Air Medal, an Air Combat Insignia, and a Presidential Personal Citation. He also was a well-known corporate director and business leader. Bill was born in 1919 in Boston, Massachusetts. He graduated with honors from The College of the Holy Cross in 1947 and later earned his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1949. Bill served in executive positions at a number of companies, including as a senior executive at Litton Industries and Chairman and Chief Executive of Norton Simon, Technicolor and Sambos. In addition, he served as a director on the board of numerous public and private companies, including Drexler Technology, Midway Games and WMS Industries. Bill was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his third wife Marcela; sister Kathleen; sons William P. (Mary Jo), Daniel J., and Paul V. (Karen); daughters Kathleen (John Wander) and Eileen (Martin Neumeier); grandsons William E. McKenna II, John P. Wander, William E. Wander, Paul J. McKenna, and Robert McKenna; granddaughters Sara Neumeier, Jennifer A. McKenna, Megan E. McKenna and Ann Marie Wander; and great grandson Zachary M. Wander. Bill was predeceased by wives Eileen McKenna (Sullivan) and Mary McKenna (Smith); sister Mary McKenna (Ostrowski); daughter Mary-Ellen McKenna; and granddaughter Heather K. Wander. As a philanthropist, Bill generously donated to St. John's Hospital, The College of the Holy Cross, St. Victor's Catholic Church, and the Institute for Advance Catholic Studies. In addition, he frequently contributed to scholarship programs at numerous local schools. Bill enjoyed playing golf, bridge and gin at Bel Air Country Club where he was chair of the infamous Garbage Group, gardening and participating in family activities. In particular, he enjoyed the time spent with his grandchildren. Known to some as the Owl and to others as the Chairman, Bill's loving heart and playful style left a legacy to his family and friends of endearing memories of times shared together. He will be missed so much. A rosary service will be held on Friday, May 6th, 2011 at 7:00pm at St. Victor's Catholic Church. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, May 7th, 2011 at 10:00am at St. Victor's Catholic Church, which will be followed by an interment at Holy Cross Cemetery. The address for St. Victor's Church is: 8634 Holloway Drive, West Hollywood, CA 90069. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to St. John's Health Center Foundation. The address is: 2121 Santa Monica Blvd., Santa Monica, CA 90404.

There were, of course, the joyous celebrations, the honking horns, cheering crowds and waving flags, as if war had been won and tyranny ended. But word that Osama bin Laden had at last been killed brought out other voices on Monday as well: sober, reflective, wounded still and vengeful, but also articulate in hope. As Americans streamed to the World Trade Center site and spontaneous gatherings across the New York region, there were countless more subdued scenes that captured the day's emotion: a woman at St. Patrick's Cathedral, praying amid flickering votive candles, her face strangely powerful in its stillness.

Abbottabad, Pakistan, where Osama bin Laden was hiding, bears the name of Sir James Abbott, a British Army officer, who founded it during British colonial rule over India, almost a century before the creation of the state of Pakistan. A portrait of Sir James, painted in 1841, resides in the National Portrait Gallery in London.

OMAHA -- In Warren E. Buffett's view, he was as ruthless as ever. The chairman of Berkshire Hathaway - who has faced scrutiny for weeks after revelations that a top lieutenant, David L. Sokol, bought $10 million of shares of Lubrizol while orchestrating an acquisition of the company - has been criticized for his initial response to the situation. In a press release, Mr. Buffett provided a detailed account of the questionable trades and declared that he did not believe the purchases ''were in any way unlawful.''

LANDE--Mildred Bronfman, passed away peacefully on April 29. Milly was an esteemed pillar of the Montreal community who trailblazed leadership positions for women in countless organizations. In her selflessness, humility, genuine convictions, respect for all, capacity for friendship, and love for family, she leaves a great legacy. Our condolences go to our Founder/ President, Ruth Lande Shuman, her sons, David and Michael, daughter-in-law, Alex, and grandson, Nate, along with all the other members of Milly's entire family. STEWART--William Bernard, 87, son of the late Isadore and Minette Steinberg. He adored his family, his country, the Yankees and chocolate. Beloved husband for over 58 years of Bernice (nee Friedman), father of Michael Stewart (Vicki) and April Stewart Klausner (Paul), and grandpa of Gabe and Jonah Klausner and Robbie Stewart. Adored and adoring twin brother of Hilda Sachs. Born and raised in The Bronx, he enlisted in 1942 at the age of 18 in the Army Corps of Engineers and served until the end of 1945 in North Africa, Italy, France, Germany, Austria, and England. Though he showed great potential as a shortstop playing in the Pirates' organization, he kept a promise to his mother that he would go to college if he survived the war. He graduated Parsons School of Design on the GI Bill, where he fell in love with a beautiful and funny fellow student who became his wife, and went on to a long career as a graphic designer and art director. All who were fortunate enough to know him will miss his quiet, steady presence and unwavering love. He led a principled, honest and dignified life. He was a true mensch. Funeral on Wednesday, May 3rd, at 11:45am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (630 Amsterdam Avenue). Donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

To start with, a confession: I want to root for the Oklahoma City Thunder. I like the players. I like the team. I like the way it plays. The Thunder is easily one of the most likable teams in pro basketball. I get that. But I cannot root for the Oklahoma City Thunder. I refuse. That feels wrong, feels like cheating, feels like taking 20-plus years of rooting for the Seattle SuperSonics and pretending they never happened.

Will ''Catch Me If You Can'' be nominated for the best musical Tony Award, after being left out of that category by the Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle award nominators last week? Which of these five Broadway plays - ''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,'' ''Good People,'' ''Jerusalem,'' ''The ------ with the Hat,'' or ''War Horse'' - will not be in the running for best play when all of the Tony nominees are announced Tuesday morning? Will the two male stars of ''Catch Me'' and the two in ''The Book of Mormon'' take up four of the five nominations for best actor in a musical? And who will make the cut for the five spots in another competitive performance category this year, best actor in a play? Broadway veterans like Brian Bedford (''The Importance of Being Earnest'') and Joe Mantello (''The Normal Heart''); movies stars like James Earl Jones (''Driving Miss Daisy''), Al Pacino (''The Merchant of Venice''), and Robin Williams (''Bengal Tiger''); and widely admired actors Bobby Cannavale (''Hat'') and Mark Rylance (''Jerusalem,'' ''La Bete'') are all more-than-plausible as nominees. To that end, will Mr. Rylance be competing against himself at the Tonys ceremony? And which shows were blanked among the nominees? Who wuz robbed? We'll be live-blogging the Tony nominations here starting at 8:30 a.m. Tuesday. Also, be sure to cast your vote on our interactive Tony Awards ballot, which will be available on ArtsBeat later Tuesday.

MESTICE--Bishop Anthony F. Bishop Anthony F. Mestice passed away on April 30, 2011, was born in NYC on December 6, 1923. He was ordained into the Priesthood on June 4, 1949 and consecrated as a Bishop on April 27, 1973. His ministry took him to the Church of St. Anthony, Bronx, NY, Church of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, Poughkeepsie, NY, Church of St. Dominic, Bronx, NY, Church of the Holy Trinity, Poughkeepsie, NY and Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY as Pastor and Vicar of Central Westchester. Bishop Mestice served on many Boards of Trustees: St. Francis Hospitals (Poughkeepsie and Beacon), Ferncliff and Astor Home in Rhinebeck, St. Joseph Seminary, and Operating Services of the Archdiocese of New York. He founded the Commission of Health and Human Services of Dutchess County. He served as Vicar for Vocations in the Archdiocese of New York from 1973-1985. He was elected Chairman of the Vocations Committee of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops in 1980 and served the three year term in that capacity. He taught at Manhattan College, served on the Board of Visitors for the City College of New York and received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Marist College. He is survived by his nieces Patricia J. DeGregorio and Rosalie M. Mislowsky and was great-uncle to Michael A.A. DeGregorio, Christiana D. DeGregorie and Angela M. Mislowsky. He was predeceased by two brothers: P. Francis Mestice MD and G. Michael Mestice JD, CPA. A wake will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY on Wednesday May 4 from 5 PM until 7PM when the Mass of the Holy Eucharist will be celebrated. The mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Please contact Graham Funeral Home, 914-967-0129, for time of mass. Internment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mt. Pleasant, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Priest Relief Fund of the Archdiocese of NY.

Community bankers, on the other hand, need not fear the new regulatory regime, the administration says. Wolin, above, said in a speech on Monday to the Independent Community Bankers of America, a powerful lobbying group in Washington. BEN PROTESS

The nation's No. 1 television judge, Judy Sheindlin, has decided to continue settling disputes for at least the next four years. Ms. Sheindlin, who has headed up ''Judge Judy'' for the last 15 years, has signed a new contract that will keep her on the show through 2015, her distributor, CBS Television Distribution, said Monday. Ms. Sheindlin, who is one of the highest-paid stars on television, had suggested publicly that her prior contract, which has her on the show until 2013, could have been her last, The Associated Press reported. But she evidently decided to sign up for two more years.

"Thoroughbred" premieres in the New York area at 10 p.m. Wednesday on WNET/Thirteen and nationally on PBS on Thursday at 9 p.m. Eastern.

In the past few years, there have been a number of documentaries about iconic fashion designers, from the critically acclaimed “Valentino: The Last Emperor” to the wayward “Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston.” But none seems as delicately composed and poignant as Pierre Thoretton’s “L’Amour Fou,” which had its United States premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival last month and will be out in theaters on May 13. Thoretton hangs the film on the spectacular $480 million art collection that the French-Algerian couturier Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Bergé, amassed during their 50 years together and its symbolism for the love they had for one another. Still it’s hard not to wonder if it was Bergé, as much as Thoretton, who called the shots in the film much as he did in Saint Laurent’s life and image. Here, the 43-year-old French director discusses the crazy love between the two men and the filmmaking techniques he chose to tell the story.

Osama bin Laden is dead. The news was announced in tickers, as I entered my office at Bagram Airfield in Afghanistan on Monday morning. Everyone was gathered around the television, intently sitting on the edge of their black swivel chairs. "All right, let's pack up now -- it's time to go home," one of the sergeants in the room said. "I want to see a death certificate," our chiseled former infantry first sergeant said. "We all know Donald Trump is going to demand to see one." The blond newscaster described how Bin Laden had been hiding in a luxurious compound 60 miles outside of Islamabad. She exclaimed, "Who would have thought he would be hiding in Pakistan all along?" One sergeant jumped up, muttering, "I would have thought that." We all laughed.

Last weekend, when I wasn't delivering meals to the homebound, I was "researching" Beatles bootlegs. And I discovered the so-called "Commonwealth Song." It's not so much a song as it is an extended improvisation during the interminable "Get Back" studio sessions in 1969 (in fact, some theorize that "The Commonwealth Song" is a prototype for "Get Back"). "Commonwealth" name-checks Enoch Powell (the Tom Tancredo of his day, or Thilo Sarazin, if you prefer a German reference), who had delivered his anti-immigrant "Rivers of Blood" speech the previous year. "Commonwealth" was Paul McCartney's mocking response. All of which shows that the sun never sets on some issues. It's also nice to know that as late as 1969, Lennon and McCartney could still crack each other up, especially when John interjects his high-pitched "Yes!"

Sugar is getting a bad reputation. A cover article in The New York Times Magazine several weeks ago persuasively reported that our national overindulgence in fructose and other sugars is driving the epidemics of obesity, diabetes and other illnesses. But that much-discussed article, by the writer Gary Taubes, focused on how sugars like fructose affect the body in general. It had little opportunity to examine the related issue of how sugar affects the body in motion. Do sweeteners like fructose — the sweetest of the simple sugars, found abundantly in fruits and honey — have the same effect on active people as on the slothful?

WINOPOL KLEIN--Frances. In memory of our beloved mother, who passed away peacefully with her family by her side in Riverdale, April 4, 2011, at 92. Born in Toronto to Lily Gula and Philip Winopol, during WWII she worked for the British Food Mission in Washington, where she met our father, the late Irwin Klein. She graduated at 62 from New York University with a BA in art history and was an active member of Beth El Synagogue New Rochelle. A loving mother, grandmother and sister, she will be deeply missed by her daughter, Phyllis Prussin, and son-in-law, Adam Prussin, both of Purchase; son, Jeff Z. Klein of New York; grandchildren David and Laura Prussin and Asher and Grace Klein; and brother, Manny Winopol of Toronto.

Peter Galassi, the chief curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, will retire in July, the museum announced. Mr. Galassi, 60, who first worked for the museum as a curatorial intern in 1974, will leave to devote time to other projects, including writing, according to a statement from the museum. He joined MoMA's photography department as a staff member in 1981 and was made chief curator 10 years later. Under his direction the museum expanded its exhibition style to include not just documentary but also post-modern works. Mr. Galassi organized or helped to organize more than 40 exhibitions, including two major retrospectives of Henri Cartier-Bresson. Among the most notable acquisitions during his tenure were a collection of more than 1,000 photographs by Lee Friedlander and the complete series of Cindy Sherman's ''Untitled Film Stills.''

NATIONAL A headline on Tuesday with a report in the National Briefing column about a ruling by Nevada's secretary of state to open a special election there to all candidates, not just those selected by the two major political parties, misidentified the race. As the report correctly noted, it is a for the United States House, not the Senate.

Dancers with the New York City Ballet voted 63-1 on Tuesday to accept a contract after contentious negotiations over issues like overtime and salary. ''I'm pretty excited,'' said Devin Alberda, a member of the company's corps de ballet who serves on the dancers' six-member negotiating committee. ''I don't think we got everything we wanted, but we made a lot of progress in terms of our work conditions.'' The dancers will receive a 2.5 percent pay increase for the year beginning in August and no increase for the current year. (They had asked for a 3 percent raise for both years; the company had proposed no increase for the current year and a 1.5 percent increase for 2011-12.) The troupe, which is facing a $6 million deficit on an operating budget of $62 million, unsuccessfully tried to reduce overtime pay.

Less than 48 hours after Osama bin Laden's death, the book deals have begun. Peter Bergen will write the ''definitive'' book on the hunt for Bin Laden, his publisher said on Tuesday. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said it had acquired a new book by Mr. Bergen that it described as ''an immersive, definitive account of the operation that killed the world's most wanted man.'' Mr. Bergen is the author of three books about terrorism and Al Qaeda: ''The Longest War,'' ''Holy War, Inc.'' and ''The Osama bin Laden I Know.'' He is now a national security analyst for CNN and the director of the National Security Studies program at the New America Foundation, a public policy institute in Washington. When Mr. Bergen was a producer for CNN in 1997, he produced Bin Laden's first television interview, which has been widely replayed ever since.

McKENNA--William E. August 9, 1919 April 29, 2011. William E. McKenna, a 45-year resident of Beverly Hills, passed away April 29th, 2011 at age 91. He was a World War II hero, having won an Air Medal, an Air Combat Insignia, and a Presidential Personal Citation. He also was a well-known corporate director and business leader. Bill was born in 1919 in Boston, Massachusetts. He graduated with honors from The College of the Holy Cross in 1947 and later earned his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1949. Bill served in executive positions at a number of companies, including as a senior executive at Litton Industries and Chairman and Chief Executive of Norton Simon, Technicolor and Sambos. In addition, he served as a director on the board of numerous public and private companies, including Drexler Technology, Midway Games and WMS Industries. Bill was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his third wife Marcela; sister Kathleen; sons William P. (Mary Jo), Daniel J., and Paul V. (Karen); daughters Kathleen (John Wander) and Eileen (Martin Neumeier); grandsons William E. McKenna II, John P. Wander, William E. Wander, Paul J. McKenna, and Robert McKenna; granddaughters Sara Neumeier, Jennifer A. McKenna, Megan E. McKenna and Ann Marie Wander; and great grandson Zachary M. Wander. Bill was predeceased by wives Eileen McKenna (Sullivan) and Mary McKenna (Smith); sister Mary McKenna (Ostrowski); daughter Mary-Ellen McKenna; and granddaughter Heather K. Wander. As a philanthropist, Bill generously donated to St. John's Hospital, The College of the Holy Cross, St. Victor's Catholic Church, and the Institute for Advance Catholic Studies. In addition, he frequently contributed to scholarship programs at numerous local schools. Bill enjoyed playing golf, bridge and gin at Bel Air Country Club where he was chair of the infamous Garbage Group, gardening and participating in family activities. In particular, he enjoyed the time spent with his grandchildren. Known to some as the Owl and to others as the Chairman, Bill's loving heart and playful style left a legacy to his family and friends of endearing memories of times shared together. He will be missed so much. A rosary service will be held on Friday, May 6th, 2011 at 7:00pm at St. Victor's Catholic Church. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, May 7th, 2011 at 10:00am at St. Victor's Catholic Church, which will be followed by an interment at Holy Cross Cemetery. The address for St. Victor's Church is: 8634 Holloway Drive, West Hollywood, CA 90069. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to St. John's Health Center Foundation. The address is: 2121 Santa Monica Blvd., Santa Monica, CA 90404.

GRAPEK--Marilyn, on Monday, May 2, 2011. Cherished daughter of the late Max and Gertrude Elkind. Loving mother of Susan, Louis and William Miron. Loving grandmother of Joshua Fine. Information call Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (800) 938-6372.
KAUDERS--Henry P. Passed away, April 29, 2011. Loving Husband, Father, Brother, Grandfather. Memorial Service, May 5 at Noon, Parkside Chapel, Brooklyn, NY.

The Board of Medical Examiners in New Jersey, which is responsible for licensing doctors practicing in the state, said on Tuesday that it had disciplined three orthopedic surgeons because they did not disclose their personal financial interests in the success of an artificial spinal disk they were studying in clinical trials that were used by federal regulators to approve the disk. The state agency reprimanded Drs. Richard A. Balderston, Thomas J. Errico and Jeffrey A. Goldstein for failing to tell their respective research institutions about their financial ties in ProDisc, the artificial disk, while they participated in research on the devices. These surgeons were among a group of doctors who stood to profit financially from the disk's success. The device was the subject of a front-page article in The New York Times in early 2008 that examined concerns over the doctors' potential conflicts of interest.

A California appeals court has turned down an appeal by Phil Spector to have his murder conviction overturned and rejected the argument that other women who said he had threatened them with guns should not have been allowed to testify in the case, The Associated Press reported. In 2009 Mr. Spector, the music producer noted for his ''Wall of Sound'' recording technique, was convicted of second-degree murder for the shooting death of the actress Lana Clarkson at his mansion in 2003. He was sentenced to 19 years to life in prison.

MEGLINO--Jerry, on April 30, 2011, also know as John Meglino, son of Antonio Meglino and Pasqualina Lava, born in Italy, founders of Jayem Notion Co., in New York City with longtime partner Helen Sherman. Jerry, brother of Nicholas Meglino (deceased), born in Italy, founder of Jodee Plastic Co. and Patrician Products Co., in Hicksville, NY; brother of James Meglino (deceased); brother of Gus Meglino (deceased), long term employee of Lasser Garment Co.; brother of John Meglino (deceased), employee of IBM, Hornblower Weeks, Dean Witter, Wall Street Firm; brother of Mary J. Meglino (deceased), long term manager at AT&T. Uncle to James Meglino, Don Meglino, Patricia Meglino, Paula Meglino Schultz and David Jerry Meglino of Dallas, Texas. CHIARA--Marco, friend, father and grandfather passed away peacefully in Milan, Italy on May 1st, 2011 with many of his friends and family at his side. Marco, the son of Jula Scherb and Piero Chiara was born in Zurich Switzerland on July 7, 1937. He was predeceased by his ex-wife and best friend Judy Chiara. Marco's compassion and insight, love and acceptance were a source of great joy to both friends and family. In addition to his friends, his loss will be felt by his beloved companion Jaia, his children, Daniela, Charlie, and John, their siblings, Richard, Frances, Anne, Nancy, Susan, his grandchildren, Julian, Lucas, Sophie, Aliana, Karma and by all of the members of the vast family to which he belonged and to whose lives he brought a light that will be sorely missed.

BUSINESS The DealBook column on Tuesday, about Warren E. Buffett's handling of the resignation of a top lieutenant over questionable stock trading, misattributed a quotation. It was Mr. Buffett who said, ''We can have all the records in the world and if somebody wants to trade outside them or something, you know, they're not going to tell us they're trading in their cousin's name.'' It was not his partner Charlie Munger.

BALFUS--Roberta. The members, Board of Governors and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our longtime member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to her husband Laurence and the entire family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

What's this? A full slate of real, original plays - and I mean plays, like mom and dad used to dress up for and would talk about over martinis afterward. Though the Tony nominations announced Tuesday morning didn't offer many surprises (the hearty, 12-nomination celebration of ''Scottsboro Boys'' was the only mild shocker), it did confirm some good news. Legitimate dramas are still being written, and they're being written well. Of the four nominees for Best Play this year, I would say that three of them are among the best-written new works Broadway has seen in years. And though my pronounced personal favorite is the British import ''Jerusalem,'' Jez Butterworth's portrait of a mythic man in a myth-starved land, I wouldn't cry or even gnash my teeth if the prize went to David Lindsay-Abaire's ''Good People'' or Stephen Adly Guirgis's ''The ------------------------ With the Hat.''

James Capel, who had been a top adviser to Representative Charles B. Rangel for more than a decade, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to failing to file tax returns, months after Mr. Rangel was censured on the House floor over his own tax problems. Mr. Capel, 67, who rose from a community representative in Mr. Rangel's office to become his chief of staff, admitted in Manhattan Criminal Court that he did not file tax returns from 2003 through 2009. His failure to file resulted in about $25,000 in unpaid taxes.

ANDERSON--Robert Marshall (the Rt. Rev.). December 18, 1933 May 3, 2011. Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Minnesota from 1978 to 1993, a former assisting bishop in the Diocese of Los Angeles, and a former dean of St. Mark's Cathedral in Salt Lake City, died May 3 in Minneapolis of pancreatic cancer. He was 77 and a native of Staten Island, NY. Survivors include his wife of 50 years, Mary Artemis Evans Anderson, and three daughters; Martha Anderson (Paul Lehman), Elizabeth (Magnus) Kempe, Catherine (William) Gregg; son Thomas Robert (Lea) Anderson; grandchildren Quinn, Simon and Benjamin Lehman; William, Charlotte Mary and Jonathan Gregg; Olivia Kempe and Winter Rose Anderson; sister-in-law Susan C. Evans, and brother-in-law Tom (Lorraine) Evans, two nieces and a nephew. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 9, at 11am at St Mark's Cathedral, 519 Oak Grove Street, Minneapolis. The family has asked that clergy attend but not vest. A reception will follow at the Woman's Club, 410 Oak Grove Street, Minneapolis. Interment will be at the columbarium at the Cathedral Center of St. Paul in Los Angeles. The family has requested that memorial contributions be made to the Department of Indian Work with the Episcopal Church in Minnesota, 1730 Clifton Place, #

STEWART--William Bernard, 87, son of the late Isadore and Minette Steinberg. He adored his family, his country, the Yankees and chocolate. Beloved husband for over 58 years of Bernice (nee Friedman), father of Michael Stewart (Vicki) and April Stewart Klausner (Paul), and grandpa of Gabe and Jonah Klausner and Robbie Stewart. Adored and adoring twin brother of Hilda Sachs. Born and raised in The Bronx, he enlisted in 1942 at the age of 18 in the Army Corps of Engineers and served until the end of 1945 in North Africa, Italy, France, Germany, Austria, and England. Though he showed great potential as a shortstop playing in the Pirates' organization, he kept a promise to his mother that he would go to college if he survived the war. He graduated Parsons School of Design on the GI Bill, where he fell in love with a beautiful and funny fellow student who became his wife, and went on to a long career as a graphic designer and art director. All who were fortunate enough to know him will miss his quiet, steady presence and unwavering love. He led a principled, honest and dignified life. He was a true mensch. Funeral on Wednesday, May 4th, at 11:45am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (630 Amsterdam Avenue). Donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

An article last Wednesday about the New York Public Library's project to turn its online menu collection into a searchable database misstated how recently the library won a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. It was in April, not last fall. The article also quoted incorrectly from comments by Ben Vershbow, the manager of the library's digital labs. He said of an e-mail he received from a student in Portland, Ore., the day after the menu project was started, ''She wanted to host a transcription party,'' not, ''He wanted to host a transcription party.''

NIEDERMAN--Susan. Born in Czechoslovakia, she survived concentration camp to emigrate to the United States in 1946, at age 17. While raising three children she worked her way through a high school equivalency and both college and master's degrees to become a teacher extraordinaire at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, where she dedicated herself tirelessly for 21 years. Susan joins Leslie her beloved husband of 58 years (founding partner of Fischer Bros & Leslie), leaving behind heartbroken children Steven, Marcy and Mark and their spouses Carolyn, Paul and Gail. Adored grandmother of Talia, Zachary, Janine, Cory, Alexis, Lisa, and Jacob. Her nurturing, guidance, friendship and love will be missed by friends, family, and all the lives she touched with kindness throughout her 82 years of life well-lived. Contributions in Susan's memory may be made to World ORT, or charities benefiting the State of Israel or Holocaust Remembrance.

As the San Francisco-based Kronos Quartet prepared for a European tour, beginning on Thursday in Athens, its bags became a little heavier on Tuesday with two major awards. Kronos will receive the Avery Fisher Prize, awarded in New York to individuals or chamber ensembles for outstanding achievement and excellence in music, as well as the Polar Music Prize, awarded in Stockholm (not on the quartet's current itinerary), also intended to recognize exceptional achievement in music. This is the first time any individual or ensemble has won both awards, even apart from having done so in the same year. The Fisher award, which carries a cash grant of $75,000, will be presented after the tour, on June 8 at Lincoln Center. The Polar award, with a cash grant of about $166,000, will be given on Aug. 30, when a similar award will be given to the singer and songwriter Patti Smith. To make the ceremony really interesting, the Swedes should stipulate that the winners have to perform together. These particular artists would probably enjoy it.

Last week I visited RiverRun Books in Portsmouth, N.H., to talk about ''Lord of Misrule,'' my racetrack novel that won the National Book Award last November. It drizzled all day in the harbor town, but a good crowd showed. The conversation turned to the ways racing had changed, and hadn't. I said something about Pimlico, my hometown track, how times were tough, but still, jockey Rosie Napravnik had gotten her start there, riding for the trainer Dickie Small. (Dick Small had also helped me with my book.)

LEET--Mildred Robbins, co-founder of Trickle Up and an activist who devoted her life to improving the lives of people all over the world, passed away on May 3. Mrs. Leet is best known as the co-founder of Trickle Up, a global nonprofit that empowers some of the world's poorest and most vulnerable people. Trickle Up's chief executive for over 20 years and board chair until 2006, she continued as Board Chair Emerita until her death. A born entrepreneur, she dedicated her enormous energy and unwavering optimism to a wide range of organizations that she helped found or lead, including the U.S. Committee for the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM), United Cerebral Palsy, Metropolitan College of New York, and InterAction. Active in Democratic politics and civil rights, she was proud to have stood on the speaker's platform for Martin Luther King's "I Have A Dream" speech. Among many honors, Mrs. Leet received, along with Mother Theresa and Wangari Maathai, the Women of the World Award in 1989, presented by Princess Diana. Mrs. Leet was married to Louis J. Robbins from 1940 until his death in 1970 and to Glen Leet from 1974 until his death in 1998. She is survived by her daughters Jane Marla Robbins and Aileen Robbins; granddaughter Ariel Fantasia and a great-granddaughter, Sage Price Fantasia. A memorial will be held on Friday, May 6, at 11:45 am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Trickle Up (www.trickleup.org) and Metropolitan College of New York (www.mcny.edu). Memories and condolences can be posted at www.mildredrobbinsleet.org

KOENIG--Louis W.,94, of Garden City and Westport, NY, on April 27, 2011. Beloved husband of 66 years to Eleanor and father of Juliana. Born in Poughkeepsie, NY, to Casper and Pauline. Noted scholar of the presidency, he taught political science at New York University for 36 years until his retirement when he became a Visiting Distinguished Professor at Long Island University, where he taught until 2009. He earned his A.B. and an Honorary Degree from Bard College and his Ph.D. from Columbia University. He taught at Bard before joining NYU. He is the author of several major books and is best known by students of the presidency for his classic text, The Chief Executive.

An Op-Ed article on April 25, about ship registries, misstated the circumstances of the sinking of the oil tanker Erika in 1999. It broke apart in a storm off northwestern France; it did not run aground.

The police are questioning a 17-year-old in connection with the death of a baby who died on Tuesday while in the teenager's care, a law enforcement official said. The baby, 9 months old, had visible injuries to his torso, suggesting trauma, the official said. The 17-year-old is a friend of the family.

(13) THOROUGHBRED As the Kentucky Derby approaches on Saturday, Paul Wagner (who shared a best director Oscar with Marjorie Hunt for the documentary short ''The Stone Carvers'') explores the world of horse racing. He starts at the ''backside'' of Aqueduct in Queens, where grooms, jockeys, trainers, owners, breeders and gamblers converge to prepare for the races -- in this case the 2009 Wood Memorial Stakes. Mr. Wagner then travels to Three Chimneys Farm in the heart of Kentucky bluegrass country, where Arthur Hancock introduces a promising mare and discusses his family's history of breeding and racing thoroughbreds, including Sunday Silence, the 1989 Kentucky Derby winner. From there, Mr. Wagner visits Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the ruler of Dubai, who oversees the richest series of horse races in the world. (Above, his Godolphin training center in Dubai.) Mr. Wagner ends his journey at Churchill Downs in Louisville for the 2009 Kentucky Derby, where even the horses seem to revel in the spotlight. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) WITNESS: DC 9/11 After the killing of Osama bin Laden by United States special forces, the channel rebroadcasts this documentary, which reconstructs the Sept. 11 attack on the Pentagon and the response throughout the capital.

LESSER--Mary M. (Donna), passed away on May 2nd after an extended battle with cancer. She was 79 years old. Born on April 10th 1932, as Mary M. Maxwell, she grew up in Montclair NJ, went to College High School and attended the College of Mount St. Vincent in a program that included two years at the college and two years in nurses' training at St. Vincent Hospital in New York City. She graduated in 1954 with her RN and a Bachelor of Science degree. Donna married Edward Lesser of Pelham, NY in 1956 and the Lessers subsequently moved to Yorktown Heights, NY, to raise their family. In retirement they divided their time between homes in Bedford Hills, NY and Carefree, AZ. Donna is survived by her husband, Edward; her son, James; her daughters, Elizabeth Mandel and Carol Wood; three grandchildren and her brother, Michael Maxwell. The funeral will be private. The date for a memorial service will be announced. The family has established the Donna Lesser Fund with the Northern Westchester Hospital Foundation for the purpose of funding a new staff facility at the hospital which will be named in her honor. Contributions in Donna's memory will be gratefully accepted and should be sent to Northern Westchester Hospital Foundation, 400 E. Main St., Mount Kisco, N.Y. Attn. Annette Serrano Account Donna Lesser Fund.

William O. Taylor II, a former publisher of The Boston Globe and the fourth member of his family to run that newspaper, died on Sunday at his home in Boston. Mr. Taylor, who oversaw the sale of The Globe to The New York Times Company in 1993, was 78. The cause was a brain tumor, which had been diagnosed two years ago, The Globe said.

BLEWER--Sondra Gerdau, of NYC and Sugar Hill, NH, February 4, 1931-May 1, 2011. Education: Brearley, Westover '49; Smith '53. Married to John M. Blewer for 16 years with whom she had four daughters: Cecilia Blewer of NYC, Evelyn Blewer of Paris, Victoria Blewer of Lincoln, VT, Julia Cox of Boxford, MA. Retired Executive Director of the Mayflower Society of NYC of which she wrote the history; earlier worked at Wm. deRham Dancing School, Robert Louis Stevenson School, and Center for the Study of the Presidency. Memberships included Colony Club, Profile Club, Smith Club, and City Gardens Club. Active volunteer knitter for the Seamen's Institute and alumnae fundraiser for Smith. Frequently sighted on her bicycle or in Central Park on her ice skates. Prize-winning gardener in New Hampshire. Sixth-generation New Yorker and true amateur of the city whose cultural events she frequented. Enjoyed bridge, badminton, swimming, knitting, quilting, needlepoint, reading, travel, family life, and her cat. Mourned by her brother, The Rev. Carlson Gerdau; her daughters; and five grandchildren: Theodore Young, Catherine and Grace Blewer, Thomas and Myrna Cox; and her sons-in-law Clayton Young, Chris Bohjalian, and Robert Cox; cousins; niece; and many friends. Predeceased by her long-time companion, George Lee. Funeral 11am at Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st and Park. Burial Woodlawn. An Op-Ed essay on Sunday, about the health effects of radiation, imprecisely described the accomplishments of the Manhattan Project. In producing an atomic bomb, the project used fission, which splits the atom, not fusion, the process that occurs in the sun when atoms fuse together.

WEEKEND A film review on Friday about ''Fast Five,'' the fifth feature released in theaters in the ''Fast and Furious'' series, misstated the film's chronological order in the plot of the series. It is the fourth, not the third.

ALTCHEK--Dr. Albert. Dr. Albert Altchek, 85, passed away on May 2. He was a world-renowned professor and author of textbooks and articles on obstetrics, gynecology and reproductive science. He was a founding father of research in the field and Chief of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine attending there for over 50 years. Teaching medicine was the overwhelming passion of his life. He practiced medicine without regard for monetary reward, and often stated that for him the patient's well being was sufficient reward for his labors. He published nearly 200 research papers in various medical journals over his 63 years as a practicing physician. For the last ten years, he served as Editor in Chief, in collaboration with his dear friend and colleague Dr. Liane Deligdisch in authoring seven medical text books. Sweden recognized him as a groundbreaking thought leader in advancing the possibility of uterine transplant. Mexico elected him, in recognition of his groundbreaking research, as the Honorary President of the Mexican Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. He was a true renaissance man with interests that ran the gamut from pre-Columbian art to music and photography. He was a wealth of knowledge in all areas of history, science and current events, sharing his stories with all his family and friends. He was son of the late Solomon and Blanche Altchek, beloved husband of the late Miriam Altchek, loving brother of Rita Angel, the late Dr. Martin Altchek and Olga Karasik,. Loved as uncle to Nicole Wachter, Spencer Angel, Dr. David Altchek, Dr. Pamela Karasik and David Karasik and great uncle to Michael and Matthew Wachter, Sophia and Joshua Angel, Charles, Christopher, Chloe and Sophie Altchek. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York at 1pm on Wednesday, May 4. Donations to charity of your choice.

Earlier this week, I reported on the Myelin Repair Foundation (M.R.F.), an organization that is working to develop a novel treatment for multiple sclerosis, a degenerative disease that currently has no cure. Over the past four decades, despite extraordinary advances in bioscience, cures for many chronic diseases have remained elusive. As Norman from New York City (17) noted, the survival rates for many cancers have not changed much since the launch of the nation's war on cancer during the Nixon administration: "The death rate has only declined by 3.3 percent or less in colon cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and leukemia." In response, groups like the M.R.F. have begun exploring new models to accelerate research and hasten the development of new treatments for disease.

The secession crisis created tremendous turmoil in Virginia. The state initially considered leaving the Union in February, and then again in early April, but on both occasions the proposal was defeated. This was partly a matter of geography: slavery was relatively rare in the western counties, and as the crisis intensified residents there began to see secession as primarily driven by the interests of slaveholders. As easterners became more strident about their rights, those in the west began to see themselves as a separate group with fundamentally different interests.

A handful of nightclubs have achieved legendary status and are symbolic of the excesses and revelry of the decade. The 1970s had Studio 54, of course, and the '90s are synonymous with the club-kid shenanigans of the Limelight. Nothing exemplified the art boom of the go-go '80s and the cross-breeding of uptown and downtown like Area. Located on a quiet Hudson Street factory block, when TriBeCa was an out-of-the way ghost town, Area was equal parts conceptual installation, fun house and disco. Every six weeks or so, the outlandish theme would change - and we're not talking about using balloons instead of streamers. The indoor pool would morph from, say, "Sports" to "Bikers," featuring actual bikers and beyond. James Levine has withdrawn from Thursday night's performance of "Walküre" because of illness, the Metropolitan Opera said. Derrick Inouye was assigned to take his place. A Met spokeswoman said Mr. Levine's withdrawal was unrelated to the back problems that have caused him to miss performances in the past.

Global warming has depressed crop yields in some countries in recent years from what they would have been otherwise, Justin Gillis reports, citing a new study in the journal Science.

The deadly tornadoes that struck the South last month were historic in their intensity and destruction. In their wake,  makers of storm shelters say, they have been receiving a lot of requests for information from homeowners in tornado-prone areas.

The Alexander McQueen retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art set an attendance record for the opening day of a Costume Institute exhibition - and nearly for the entire museum. The show had 5,100 visitors on Wednesday, beating out popular shows like the Jacqueline Kennedy and Chanel exhibitions, though time will tell if the numbers hold up for the duration of the show. The crowd was so large that the Met had to temporarily suspend its guided tours, a spokeswoman said. The museum sold 600 catalogs that day in its gift shop.

Much of Thursday's news for the Kentucky Derby involves the repercussions of the post position draw. The happiest people seemed to be the connections of Dialed In who drew post position No. 8 in the 20-horse field and was named the morning-line favorite at 4-1.

Below, we pose five questions to ask about Friday's jobs report, much as we did a month ago. The big picture is that job growth has been picking up in recent months -- but the job market is still a long way from being healthy, and the last month or so has offered new reason for concern.

A presidential commission called on Congress to establish a Smithsonian American Latino Museum at the Capitol on Thursday morning during a news conference attended by proponents of the project. In a report submitted this week to President Obama and Congress, the commission said that it would cost $600 million to build and open the museum, adding that half of the money could be raised privately. In deference to current budget conditions, the commission said that no federal financing would be needed for six years. Congress established the panel, the National Museum of the American Latino Commission, in 2008.

The latest public service announcement warning against distracted driving has an interesting twist: it presupposes that people know about the dangers of multitasking behind the wheel. Instead, it illustrates the emotional toll for those who are affected by an accident caused by a person texting or talking on a phone.

Julie Taymor, the ousted director of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” will deliver a keynote speech at a major theater conference in Los Angeles on June 18, four days after the $70 million musical is scheduled to have its long-delayed opening night in New York. Ms. Taymor will also speak that Saturday at a panel session, titled “A Director’s Life,” during the annual conference of Theater Communications Group, a national organization of nearly 700 nonprofit theaters and affiliated groups.

"I wanted to create objects from a childhood that I never experienced firsthand," Lucien Smith says, explaining the background of "Imagined Nostalgia," which opens May 6 at 41 Cooper Gallery. The show is a collaboration between Smith, 22, and Jack Siegel, 24, who shared studio space at Cooper Union (where Smith is enrolled and set to graduate this month). The work is based on how our imaginations create false memories of what actually happened in the past -- how we remember something from the past and embellish it to make it seem worse or better, larger than life, different. Highlights include yearbook-style photographs from familiar New York faces like the filmmaker Austin Peters and the artist Brenden Lynch.

For Amanda Brooks, the new fashion director at Barneys, Mother's Day falls during the busiest time of the year. "There are two Arieses and four Tauruses in my immediate family so it's hard not to get celebration fatigue," she explains. Her idea of the perfect way to spend the day includes staying in bed until lunchtime reading the Duchess of Devonshire's memoir, "Wait for Me," and opening handmade cards from her husband and children. But in case anyone is asking, she also wouldn't mind an Armand Diradourian cashmere travel blanket, a gold Love Knot ring by Finn and two Jean Prouvé chairs for her office: "My mother always said, Dream big."

In our weekly "Poetry Pairing" series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem's themes. When Donald Judd died in 1994, he had a couple thousand dollars in the bank but was millions of dollars in debt. The task of sorting out his estate was left to his two children, Rainer and Flavin, who persevered against what many considered insurmountable odds, resulting in the creation of the now seemingly solid Judd Foundation. Judd's daughter, Rainer, is the president of the board of the foundation and the more public of the two while his son, Flavin, is vice president (but referred to himself as the "curatorial consultant"). Despite being very involved in the day-to-day running of the foundation, he remains relatively out of the public eye. T recently caught up with Flavin Judd, who was in town to oversee the installation of a major exhibit of his father's work at David Zwirner gallery. "Donald Judd," which opens on Friday, features nine aluminum boxes originally shown in a 1989 exhibition at Staatliche Kunsthalle Baden-Baden. It is the first time since that such a large number pieces from that show have been installed in one place.

The Brazilian pop band Cansei de Ser Sexy (CSS) kicked off its current American tour with a star turn at Coachella, then stepped off the stage and went straight to Pomona, Calif., and an all-ages show at the Glass House the following night. Fans mobbed the barricades to get a closer look at the lead singer, Lovefoxxx (pictured here). Dressed in a sequined bolero ensemble and Doc Martens boots, she turned cartwheels and surfed the crowd. The audience read like a throng of exultant misfits, gathered to hail their beloved leaders. Lovefoxxx gave a shout-out to someone watching that night, who had written the band an e-mail explaining how they had inspired him to come out and be honest about who he was with his family and friends, and later she brought several teenage girls to the stage to dance alongside her. CSS will perform three nights in New York City in May.

In this weekend’s magazine, the New York Times reporter Adam Nagourney writes about Gov. Jerry Brown as he wrestles with California’s budget. Linda Ronstadt makes a cameo appearance as Brown’s former girlfriend. But for me, Ronstadt is always the main event. Seeing her perform in her Cub Scouts uniform at Pine Knob outside Detroit in the late 1970s (or early ’80s; it’s a bit hazy) was a formative experience. With a few not-inconceivable twists of fate, it’s possible (at least to me) to imagine Brown as president and Ronstadt as first lady. That this didn’t happen might have marked the moment when things started to go wrong. Or maybe that was when Johnny Carson retired. Anyway, this clip of “My Boyfriend’s Back” (date uncertain but probably filmed sometime during the campaign for the 1980 Democratic nomination) gives a hint of what we missed.

TAGUE--Alicia Murtha, born February 1, 1927 in NYC. Educated at Dominican Academy and Fordham University. On August 6, 1949, Alicia married her life's love, Charles Tague, whom she met at age 16. Together they lived in Jackson Heights, NY, Colts Neck, NJ, Upper Saddle River, NJ, and Jackson, NJ, raising six children and sharing almost 62 years of memories. She was an elementary teacher, librarian and served in a number of community and church volunteer leadership roles, particularly at St. Mary's and Church of the Presentation parishes in Colts Neck and Upper Saddle River, NJ. Alicia died April 29th of complications of Alzheimer's. She is survived by her loving husband, Charles; sons Patrick, Charles, Thomas, James; daughters Mary Alicia Haberman, Elizabeth Anne Giuliano; their respective spouses Brenda, Gloria, Elise, Liza, Joseph, and Russell; 11 grandchildren and many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Dominican Academy, 44, E. 68th St, NYC, NY 10065.

SCHEUER--Lewis J.,Tarpon Springs, FL, died May 3, 2011. Born April 13, 1924. Worked on the Space Program's Redstone and Jupiter missile projects along side Wernher von Braun. Later, for Grumman Aerospace Corp., New York, he developed glare resistant guidance technology for the A6 Intruder and radar jamming technology for the EA6A Fighter. He became Program Manager for the Orbiting Astronomical Observatory, Subcontract Manager for the Apollo Spacecraft's Lunar Module, and Grumman's Director of Subcontract Management for over a decade. The immediate family members he is survived by are wife Josephine and sons Glenn and Ken.

ConAgra Foods' proposal to buy Ralcorp Holdings for $4.9 billion may be called a bear hug, but the deal is far from warm and fuzzy. After an earlier rejection by Ralcorp, ConAgra, whose lineup includes the Chef Boyardee, Orville Redenbacher's and Healthy Choice brands, sweetened its bid to $86 a share on Wednesday as it looks to fill its portfolio with generic goods. The price represents a 32 percent premium to Ralcorp's stock on March 21, the day before ConAgra made its first approach.
HELLER--Katherine Ann (Kelly), 80, died Easter Sunday. Memorial service, St. Patrick's Church, Bedford, NY, 12pm Thursday.

Having a great idea for a company is one thing. Getting the money to get it moving and growing is quite another -- especially when you've got an unconventional product or business model that your average investor isn't likely to recognize as an obvious winner. When we started TerraCycle as undergrads, my co-founder and I entered and won a number of business-plan competitions around America, effectively financing our business from the resulting prize money. The best thing about prize money is that it provides financing without diluting your ownership in the company; the challenge of relying on prize money is that it is relatively limited -- $5,000 to $100,000, generally, and you can't enter the same contest more than once, especially if you do well the first time.

HILLSBORO, Ore. -- Intel announced on Wednesday that it had again found a way to make computer chips that could process information more quickly and with less power in less space. The transistors on computer chips -- whether for PC's or smartphones -- have been designed in essentially the same way since 1959 when Robert Noyce, Intel's co-founder, and Jack Kilby of Texas Instruments independently invented the first integrated circuits that became the basic building block of electronic devices in the information age.

HIGHER EARNINGS Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Wednesday that its first-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, as private equity firms continued to benefit from the economic recovery. The company's $742.5 million profit, reported as economic net income after taxes because it excludes some charges related to its public stock offering, amounts to 96 cents a share, up from 93 cents a share in the period a year earlier. ''The first quarter represented a good start to 2011 for each of our businesses,'' the company's co-chief executives, Henry R. Kravis, above, and George R. Roberts, said in a statement. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

Q.I need to digitally repair tears and scratches in old photos that I have scanned into my computer. What software do I need? A. Most photo-editing programs include a basic tool for retouching images to fix small tears and scratches. You also get options for enhancing contrast and faded colors on scanned prints to improve them further.
