If the Royal Wedding hasn't yet made you aware of just how mundane wedding photos can be, June is coming soon with fresh opportunities for cliched group shots (''Smile! Smile, everybody! Smile!'') Denis Reggie, a wedding photographer, takes a different approach, with outstanding results. Over his 30-year career, his unobtrusive style, which he calls ''wedding photojournalism,'' has led him to shoot now-iconic images of the Kennedy-Bessette wedding, as well as the nuptials of Chelsea Clinton, Vera Wang, Emilio Estevez and many others.

BRUSSELS -- Organized crime groups in Europe have become more versatile in their efforts and more reliant on the Internet, according to a report released Wednesday by Europe's law enforcement agency, Europol. Crime syndicates are gathering ''diverse portfolios of criminal business interests,'' the report said, and they are using new technology, including voice services like Skype and social media Web sites like Facebook, both to defraud victims and to orchestrate other crimes.

A picture on Tuesday with an article about the response of New Yorkers to the death of Osama bin Laden was published in error. As the caption indicated, it showed a ceremony in Manhattan that included a reading of the names of Holocaust victims; the event was not connected to Bin Laden's death.

''Lombardi,'' the play that tried to draw men to Broadway with a story about the legendary Green Bay Packers coach, will close on May 22 after a total of 30 preview performances and 244 regular performances, its producers said on Tuesday night. Previously scheduled to run through June 19, ''Lombardi'' is leaving the field after receiving only one 2011 Tony Award nomination, announced Tuesday morning, for best featured actress in a play for Judith Light, who plays Vince Lombardi's wife, Marie. The production took in $155,898 for its eight performances through Sunday, just 21 percent of the maximum possible and the lowest dollar total earned by a Broadway show last week.

8 P.M. (TCM) ESTHER WILLIAMS: STAR OF THE MONTH Whether gliding through water ballets or performing her own daredevil stunts, Ms. Williams, a champion teenage swimmer and reluctant movie star, suggested a ''porpoise amused by its own sex appeal,'' the film critic James Agee said. This monthlong tribute begins with ''Bathing Beauty'' (1944, above), starring Ms. Williams in her first leading role for MGM as an aquatic instructor at a girls' school who is wooed by a songwriting pupil (Red Skelton). In ''Thrill of a Romance'' (1945), at 10, she plays a newlywed swimmer who inconveniently falls in love with an Army Air Corps hero (Van Johnson). Ms. Williams and Johnson team up with Lucille Ball in ''Easy to Wed'' (1946), at midnight, about a tough newspaper editor who hires a gigolo to compromise a woman suing his paper for libel. In ''Fiesta'' (1947), at 2 a.m., Ms. Williams trades a swimsuit for trousers as a Mexican beauty who replaces her toreador twin brother (Ricardo Montalban) in the bull ring. And in ''This Time for Keeps'' (1947), at 4, she portrays the object of desire of the son (Johnny Johnston) of an opera star (Lauritz Melchior). 6 P.M. (ABC Family) GREASE (1978) A John Travolta double bill begins with this adaptation of the Broadway musical about teenage angst in the 1950s. Olivia Newton-John is Sandy, the Australian good girl who ends up at Rydell High after her parents cancel plans to move back home; Mr. Travolta is the greaser Danny, Sandy's beach fling. Can their summer lovin' survive senior year? At 8:30 Mr. Travolta dons a dress to play Edna Turnblad in ''Hairspray'' (2007), another Broadway adaptation, based on John Waters's 1988 movie. Nikki Blonsky is Tracy Turnblad, Edna's daughter, a chunky high school student who lives to dance on ''The Corny Collins Show.'' Brittany Snow is Amber Von Tussle, the show's uppity star, who isn't about to let Tracy onto the set.

It was the producers of ''Desperate Housewives'' who decided to kill off Edie, the much-married Wisteria Lane resident whom Nicollette Sheridan had played on the prime-time ABC soap opera since its 2004 debut. But it is a California jury that will decide whether the character's death, in a car accident during the show's fifth season, was a fair exit for Ms. Sheridan, who has sued for damages for wrongful termination, among other matters. In a ruling on Tuesday Judge Elizabeth Allen White of Los Angeles County Superior Court said that Ms. Sheridan's lawsuit against ABC and the ''Desperate Housewives'' producer Marc Cherry can go to trial in June, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Sheridan filed suit last year, saying that in addition to pushing her character out of the series Mr. Cherry had hit her during a fight and sexually harassed her.

DINING A listing on Wednesday in the Calendar referred incorrectly to an outdoor dining event scheduled for Saturday and sponsored by the New Museum and its Festival of Ideas for the New City. The price, $80, covers the cost of the dinner; the event is not a benefit for the museum.

OPENINGS FREITAG, a Swiss line of bags made from recycled tarps, opens a New York shop today at 1 Prince Street (Bowery), (212) 334-0934; freitag.ch. It will carry messenger bags, totes, backpacks and other styles. ...ALICE + OLIVIA has opened a store at 755 Madison Avenue (66th Street); (646) 545-2895; aliceandolivia.com. Besides the house line, the store will carry a selection of vintage pieces, Philippe Audibert jewelry, and Abigail Aldridge hats and of-the-moment fascinators.

The new system upgrade for the Nook Color e-reader from Barnes & Noble does more than improve its usefulness as an electronic book - it adds new features that you'd normally associate with a tablet. That includes the addition of apps, new e-mail capabilities and improved the social features. Maybe the most significant change is the addition of apps. The store currently counts 137 apps (and the number is growing quickly). Some apps like ''The Art of the Slow Cooker'' are more like rehashed books, but there are also offerings like Angry Birds, solitaire, a PDF reader, Epicurious, and Flight View, a flight tracker. Prices range from free to $100 for an app especially for doctors, but most are in the $3 to $6 range.

LEROY GRANNIS began surfing in 1931, when he was a 14-year-old in Hermosa Beach, Calif. Photography was the hobby he took up as an adult to help him relax. Mr. Grannis, whose legendary images captured the surf culture of the 1960s and '70s, died in February, but Scott Sternberg, the designer of Band of Outsiders, the Los Angeles line known for its twisty take on schoolboy prep, is stoked on the photographs. Although Mr. Sternberg is no surfer, he used Mr. Grannis's images for a special series printed on his This Is Not a Polo Shirt collection. His interest, he said, stemmed from a love for his city. ''Its history and various subcultures represent much more than the endless clichés and stereotypes,'' he said. Still, don't feel guilty if you hear the Beach Boys in the background. Band of OutsidersLeRoy Grannis shirt, $340 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street (Broadway); openingceremony.us.

THE ARTS The Books of The Times review on Tuesday, about ''A Singular Woman: The Untold Story of Barack Obama's Mother,'' by Janny Scott, misstated the location of Mercer Island, where President Obama's mother, Ann Dunham, lived at one point. It is in Lake Washington, near Seattle, not ''off Washington State.''

7:12 p.m. | Updated Glencore, the world's largest trader of commodities, on Wednesday prepared the stage for a $10 billion initial public offering this month, setting a price range and placing nearly a third of the offering with sovereign wealth funds and hedge funds.

FOLEY--Eugene J, 92, of Huntington, NY. Born in New York City, September 12, 1918. Passed away April 18, 2011, in Denville, NJ. Predeceased by his loving wife of 55 years, Marie (Gilhooly) and one sister and two brothers (Katherine, William, John). Graduate of Townsend Harris and New York University. After service as an officer in the US Army Corps of Engineers during WWII, he co-founded Foley Hardware, Larchmont, NY, and was a sales executive for several industrial companies. Active throughout his life in his Church, Boy Scouts, local community and charities. Survived by one brother, Vincent (Denville, NJ), and four sons who will miss him dearly: Donald (Barbara), Greenwich, CT; Robert (Mary), Omaha, NB; John (Courtney), Montclair, NJ; Peter (Susan), Northport, NY, as well as 11 grandchildren, 10 nephews and nieces. A fabulous, caring father, uncle and friend. Often said "What a Life!" We believe he meant it! Viewing at Leo P. Gallagher's, Greenwich, CT, May 6, 6 to 8pm. Mass at St. Michael, North Street, Greenwich, CT May 7, 10am. Interment at Gate of Heaven, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Burke Foundation- Eugene and Marie Foley Memorial Fund, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605.

René Emilio Ponce, a Salvadoran military leader accused of ordering one of the most shocking atrocities of El Salvador's civil war, the killing of six Jesuit priests in 1989, died on Monday at a military hospital in San Salvador. He was 64. In a statement, El Salvador's Defense Ministry said he had been admitted to the hospital last week in critical condition with heart trouble.

FRONT PAGE A chart on Wednesday with the continuation of an article about global population projections by the United Nations misstated the year for which a breakdown of regional population estimates was given. It was 2100, not 2010.

Lloyd C. Blankfein has his share of critics, but perhaps none are more vocal than Evelyn Y. Davis, an outspoken gadfly with a long history of haranguing corporate executives at annual meetings. It turns out that Ms. Davis may have a new reason to dislike Mr. Blankfein: Goldman Sachs canceled its $7,200 subscription to her annual newsletter, Highlights and Lowlights, according to a person briefed on the matter but who was not authorized to speak on the record.

DESPITE being across the street from a mammoth Macy's, Mociun, a new pop-up collective in Brooklyn, feels anything but eclipsed. The designer Caitlin Mociun has filled the vast space, once the home of a furniture company, with an assortment of her hand-drawn print dresses, neon swimwear and delicate jewels. She has also brought some friends along: 18 local designers and artisans. There are breezy summer dresses from Bodkin, ceramics by Shino Takeda and, for the gentleman, outerwear from the indie line Highland. The furniture company, Nightwood, even left behind some of its hand-built reclaimed wood pieces to be sold. Mociun, until May 29 at 200 Livingston Street (between Hoyt and Smith Streets), Brooklyn; info@mociun.com.

Hours before Francisco Liriano completed a 123-pitch no-hitter for the Twins against the White Sox in Chicago on Tuesday night, another left-hander from that storied fraternity of major league pitchers stood in front of the visitors' dugout at Citi Field and recalled the fallout from his own unplanned appointment with fame. Now entrusted with some of baseball's most prized young arms as the pitching coach of the San Francisco Giants, Dave Righetti wished he had had someone like himself to come out of the Yankees dugout in the 1980s to demand his company more often on the return trip.

''Throwback'' is a word the Cue r1 clock radio brings to mind. For one thing, it's a clock radio, by which it has an AM/FM radio built in and which is tied to the clock's alarm timer. Then there is the appearance: With its white plastic rectangular case, minimalist three knobs and black-and-white display, the Cue r1 looks like it might have come from a Scandinavian furniture store circa 1968.

It's no secret that I love pigeons. They have been a fascination of mine since I was a young boy, and they continue to bring me great peace even now. People are curious as to why I have such great affection for them.

The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about allergies triggered by organic skincare products, misstated the relationship of Dr. Xiu-Min Li, a professor of pediatrics, allergy and immunobiology at Mount Sinai Medical Center, to a line of carefully blended herbal creams, tea and bath products. She created them; she does not sell them.

BLEWER--Sondra Gerdau, of NYC and Sugar Hill, NH, February 4, 1931-May 1, 2011. Education: Brearley, Westover '49; Smith '53. Married to John M. Blewer for 16 years with whom she had four daughters: Cecilia Blewer of NYC, Evelyn Blewer of Paris, Victoria Blewer of Lincoln, VT, Julia Cox of Boxford, MA. Retired Executive Director of the Mayflower Society of NYC of which she wrote the history; earlier worked at Wm. deRham Dancing School, Robert Louis Stevenson School, and Center for the Study of the Presidency. Memberships included Colony Club, Profile Club, Smith Club, and City Gardens Club. Active volunteer knitter for the Seamen's Institute and alumnae fundraiser for Smith. Frequently sighted on her bicycle or in Central Park on her ice skates. Prize-winning gardener in New Hampshire. Sixth-generation New Yorker and true amateur of the city whose cultural events she frequented. Enjoyed bridge, badminton, swimming, knitting, quilting, needlepoint, reading, travel, family life, and her cat. Mourned by her brother, The Rev. Carlson Gerdau; her daughters; and five grandchildren: Theodore Young, Catherine and Grace Blewer, Thomas and Myrna Cox; and her sons-in-law Clayton Young, Chris Bohjalian, and Robert Cox; cousins; niece; and many friends. Predeceased by her long-time companion, George Lee. Funeral on Friday, May 6, 11am at Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st and Park, reception following. Burial Woodlawn. In lieu of flowers, donations to her schools or to Addison County Humane Society, 236 Boardman Street, Middlebury, VT 05753.

Last week, we published a case study that explored whether Big D Custom Screen Printing could become profitable by specializing in small T-shirt orders. After a year in business, the company had sales of $325,000 on which it suffered a nominal loss. Big D's co-founder, Darren Robbins, and his partner disagreed as to the best way to turn things around. His partner wanted to focus on large corporate accounts. Mr. Robbins believed Big D could thrive by targeting customers with small orders - as small as one T-shirt. The partners split (amicably) over the issue. The April 2008 decision to take smaller orders, Mr. Robbins said, paid off almost immediately: ''My phone started ringing off the hook.'' In 2009, Big D's sales were $675,000, he said, and they hit $900,000 the following year. He also said the company, which has 12 employees in Austin, Tex., is now profitable. And about a year ago, it opened two-employee branches in Los Angeles, Chicago, and southwest Michigan. More recently, Big D expanded to Las Vegas as well. Meanwhile, Mr. Robbins said the economy forced many of his competitors to go out of business -- and to sell their equipment at a loss on Craigslist.

CAT-EYE sunglasses have been gathering steam since the fashion world latched onto Norma Kamali's retro tortoiseshell shades last spring. Taylor Tomasi Hill, the style and accessories director of Marie Claire and a self-proclaimed ''cat-eye queen,'' found her match in the shape. ''I have a very narrow face that can be swallowed up by a lot of frames,'' she said. ''Cat-eyes don't make me look like a kid playing dress up.'' Now, with a new crop of modified styles, the trend is moving full speed ahead. Oversize frames from Nicole Richie's House of Harlow; two-tone frames with sharper angles from Karen Walker; and an extra-pointy design, fittingly called Monroe, from Elizabeth and James are all more chic than quirky. From top: House of Harlow Chelsea sunglasses, $138 at singer22.com.

The Small Business Administration's special stimulus-funded loan program, known as America's Recovery Capital, may be gone, but the controversy surrounding it lingers. In March, the agency's independent Inspector General released a report estimating that of the 4,559 A.R.C. loans made through January 2010, nearly half ''were not originated and closed in compliance with S.B.A.'s policies and procedures, resulting in approximately $66.5 million in inappropriate loan approvals.'' If those loans default, the report warns, the banks that made them should not expect to be fully repaid by the S.B.A. The A.R.C. loan program was conceived as a lifeline for sound businesses navigating the ragged shoals of recession. Companies could borrow up to $35,000 to retire existing debt, defer payments on the new loan for a year, and then take five more years to repay the obligation - with no interest or fees charged to the borrower. (The government would pay those.) The S.B.A. estimated that it had enough money to fund about 10,000 loans, and some observers predicted the program would be fully subscribed within a few months.

Adele tops the Billboard album chart for a sixth time this week, easily taking the top slot in a down week for music sales. Her ''21'' (XL/Columbia) sold 124,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and it became only the fifth album by a woman in the last 10 years to be No. 1 for at least six weeks (either consecutively or in total). The others, according to Billboard, are Norah Jones's ''Feels Like Home''; Susan Boyle's ''I Dreamed a Dream''; and Taylor Swift's last two records, ''Speak Now'' and ''Fearless.'' At home in Britain, ''21'' racked up its 13th No. 1 this week; after spending 12 consecutive weeks on the top of the chart, it had been bumped to No. 2 for a week by the Foo Fighters' ''Wasting Light'' (Roswell/RCA).

Teams of scholars have spent nearly 30 years tracking down, researching and editing the more than 15,000 letters written by or to Charles Darwin. Now, thanks to $8.2 million in grants from the Evolution Education Trust, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and the Isaac Newton Trust, the entire collection will be published in full by 2022. Texts of some 6,000 letters and information on 9,000 more are already available here. The Darwin Correspondence Project, which is jointly administered by the Cambridge University Library and the American Council of Learned Societies, includes letters from Darwin's school days, his voyage on the H.M.S. Beagle and the controversies that followed the 1859 publication of ''On the Origin of Species.'' Dr. Jim Secord, the project director, said in a statement that ''Unlike his published works, Darwin's letters are vitally important in showing how science is done, with the constant gathering of new data, and the testing and questioning of theories and ideas.'' The letters between Darwin and his 2,000 or so correspondents are scattered among 200 institutions and private collections. Cambridge houses the largest haul of Darwin's manuscripts, his library of books and journals, and around 9,000 of the letters. In 2009 the Darwin project opened a satellite branch at Harvard.

SCIENCE TIMES The Basics column on Tuesday, about the many functions of the hormone serotonin, misstated the academic credentials of Kay Redfield Jamison. Though she is a professor of psychiatry at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Dr. Jamison is a psychologist, not a psychiatrist.

LEET--Mildred Robbins, co-founder of Trickle Up and an activist who devoted her life to improving the lives of people all over the world, passed away on May 3. Mrs. Leet is best known as the co-founder of Trickle Up, a global nonprofit that empowers some of the world's poorest and most vulnerable people. Trickle Up's chief executive for over 20 years and board chair until 2006, she continued as Board Chair Emerita until her death. A born entrepreneur, she dedicated her enormous energy and unwavering optimism to a wide range of organizations that she helped found or lead, including the U.S. Committee for the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM), United Cerebral Palsy, Metropolitan College of New York, and InterAction. Active in Democratic politics and civil rights, she was proud to have stood on the speaker's platform for Martin Luther King's "I Have A Dream" speech. Among many honors, Mrs. Leet received, along with Mother Theresa and Wangari Maathai, the Women of the World Award in 1989, presented by Princess Diana. Mrs. Leet was married to Louis J. Robbins from 1940 until his death in 1970 and to Glen Leet from 1974 until his death in 1998. She is survived by her daughters Jane Marla Robbins and Aileen Robbins; granddaughter Ariel Fantasia and a great-granddaughter, Sage Price Fantasia. A memorial will be held on Friday, May 6, at 11:45 am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Trickle Up (www.trickleup.org) and Metropolitan College of New York (www.mcny.edu). Memories and condolences can be posted at www.mildredrobbinsleet.org

In a previous post, I wrote about the Business Council for Peace, a nonprofit network of professionals who provide pro bono business services to mostly female entrepreneurs in countries affected by conflict, including Rwanda. Last month, three Rwandan owners, graduates of the three-year BPeace program, visited the United States during a trip that paired them with American businesses in their industries. The participants included Languida Nyirababeruka, who founded Pompe Funebre Twifatanye, a funeral home, after the 1994 genocide. Ms. Nyirababeruka, a former teacher who lost her job for political reasons, ran a tailoring business before 1994. The genocide claimed her husband and several family members, as well as her home and business. When it was over, she had to locate her three children, now in their 20s. ''After the genocide, I started from scratch,'' she said, speaking through an interpreter. A United Nations contact helped Ms. Nyirababeruka get a job as a cook, and she began to rebuild her life in Kigali.

Its courts were the site of the United States Open tennis championship for 62 years and they hosted the Beatles, Frank Sinatra and the Rolling Stones. But time may finally be running out for the now crumbling West Side Tennis Stadium in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, one of the world's most storied tennis arenas. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission notified supporters this week that it had decided not to grant landmark status to the stadium, a dilapidated 15,000-seat arena where, among other historic accomplishments, Arthur Ashe in 1968 won the Open, becoming the first black man to win a Grand Slam tournament.

SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — How long have you been doing late week puzzles? Except for the Sunday, I’m relatively new to them, because I used to believe that the Saturday puzzle, at least, was for the truly suicidal. It just goes to show that practice makes, if not perfect, a lot better. That’s a good thing, and I hope that people who are afraid to try them sit down and give them a chance. And then another and another, until they can crack them almost as easily as they do a midweek puzzle.

The two months following Lincoln’s inauguration found Frederick Douglass struggling to understand and bitterly demoralized by the president’s policies, but also exhilarated by the outbreak of war at Fort Sumter. He had no interest in the new president’s oratorical olive branches to the seceded South, his poetry about the “mystic chords of memory” or the “better angels of our nature.” Indeed, Douglass despised the olive branches, calling the speech “little better than our worst fears,” and a “double-tongued document, capable of two constructions,” concealing rather than declaring a “definite policy.”

In 1940, a Brooklyn woman named Jean Kay filed a suit with the State Supreme Court against the her city’s Board of Higher Education claiming that the renowned mathematician and philosopher Bertrand Russell was morally unfit to teach at the City College of New York, where he had been offered a professorship. Kay, supported by a host of others in the public scrum, including Bishop William Manning of the Episcopal Church, argued that Russell, who advocated sex before marriage and other heretical lifestyle choices, posed a threat to the virtue of her daughter — even though the impressionable youth was not actually a student at the college. A judge ruled in Kay’s favor. Russell, who was not allowed to speak in his own defense, was denied his appointment at the college, which was, and is, part of the publicly financed City University of New York system. Today, the now-notorious incident is chronicled in an exhibition on City College’s Web site, called “The Struggle for Free Speech at CCNY, 1931-1942,” as is a recounting of the subsequent firings, spurred by the McCarthy era Rapp-Coudert Committee, of faculty members accused of being Communist Party members.

Target is offering matching dresses for moms and babies from its new Calypso collaboration. Lucky magazine recently introduced a back-page feature called "My Mom, the Style Icon." But for most of us, there was a period, in between teetering in Mom's high heels and aching to steal her vintage blouses, during which we'd balk at anything - anything - she liked. Not so for Lily Mandelbaum, a student at N.Y.U. who has collaborated with her mother, the fashion editor and stylist Elisa Goodkind, on the style blog Stylelikeu since 2008. The popular site features closet tours, style mantras and video interviews with their fashion muses, both known (the fashion designer LaQuan Smith) and unknown (Virginie Sommet, who makes art out of Indian candy and fennel). Now, just in time for Mother's Day, they've released a book of the same name, full of beautiful images of sartorial inspiration, including collages of hands garnished with jaw-dropping gems, club kids posing in their bedrooms and little old ladies who refuse to hang up the toreador pants. As Tziporah Salamon, one such senior, happily explained: "Every single day you get a chance to invent yourself. How fun is that?" Happy Mother's Day!

First we considered having a photographer charter a plane and fly over the recovery ship, the Alucia, while it was still near the spot where its crew located the plane in early April.  We decided that option was too costly, so next we tried to take a satellite picture of the Alucia.  But on the chosen day, a combination of vague coordinates - French authorities refused to provide the precise location of the ship - and cloud cover prevented us from getting any usable image.

The New York Times daily newspaper is printed at multiple locations across the globe to ensure timely delivery. The entire run of The New York Times Magazine, however, is printed every week at RR Donnelly, a press in Lancaster, Pa. They have been printing our magazine for almost 30 years. The hole-in-the-wall at 2234 Mission Street in San Francisco looks more like a greasy spoon where General Tso's chicken is ordered by number than a cult outpost offering quirky, responsibly sourced Chinese food. Inside, it's both. Danny Bowien and Anthony Myint, who ran the pop-up Mission Street Food out of Lung Shan restaurant, are now cooking here permanently with Mission Chinese Food. Alongside Lung Shan's menu, you can now indulge in what Mr. Bowien calls "whimsical Chinese" - sizzling cumin lamb, ma po tofu, barbecued brisket braised with a Mexican/Coca-Cola gastrique. "It's not fusion," he said. "It's not fine dining. It's not authentic. It's not from one region. We're just trying to do everything backwards." Go to interactive feature >>

From St. Tropez to Porto Cervo, Capri to Cannes, few brands are as at home in the world's most glamorous settings as Eres - and come this weekend, the luxury swimwear house is setting up shop in America's playground of the rich and fabulous, the Hamptons. "In America, having stores in resort locations is a must," explains Eres's swim and lingerie designer, Valerie Delafoss. But unlike the Eres boutiques in Palm Beach and Los Angeles, this latest venture, at 55 Main Street in East Hampton, will feature more beachy attire - ocean-blue maillots with a flirty tassel belts, color-blocked boy-short bikinis and cotton jersey wide-leg cover-up pants - than delicate lingerie. Our opinion? Either way, it's a good excuse to go to the Hamptons!

Prospective students who are wondering whether to major in business or art in this harsh economic climate might want to take a look at a survey of arts graduates. The Strategic National Arts Alumni Project based at Indiana University, which tracks the lives and careers of arts graduates, has recently released one. The results of the 2010 online survey include responses from more than 13,500 students who were in fine arts, theater, dance, music, creative writing, media arts, film, design and architecture programs and graduated in the past 15 or so years from 154 arts high schools, undergraduate and graduate institutions.

His sinister voice and unnerving gaze have guaranteed Jeremy Irons a career playing nefarious characters, but does he dream of playing a hero – even a once-great medieval king who is ditched by his wife for a newer and better model of knight? If so, Mr. Irons, a star of the Showtime series “The Borgias” (not to mention films like “Reversal of Fortune” and “The Lion King”) will get to fulfill that goal in a one-night concert production of “Camelot” for the Irish Repertory Theater, in which he will play King Arthur. Press representatives for the production, which will be presented on June 6 at the Shubert Theater, said on Friday that Mr. Irons will play Arthur, the Excalibur-wielding monarch, in the Lerner and Loewe musical. James Barbour and Melissa Errico will play Lancelot and Guenevere, reprising the roles they played in a 2005 production at the Hollywood Bowl. The Irish Rep concert production, which will be directed by Charlotte Moore, with musical direction by Mark Hartman, will be presented as a benefit for the theater, so be prepared to dig up a little more coin of the realm for tickets. Prices for individual seats are $100 to $300.

In the last week I've been in the South of France for the Hyères Fashion Festival and in San Francisco to meet students at the Academy of Art University, with a stop in New York for the opening of the Alexander McQueen exhibition. What links these places is not just fashion, but the design process itself and how the ideas of designers evolve over time. That evolution is one of the pleasures of Andrew Bolton's selections for the McQueen show, especially in the tailoring choices. It was inspiring to see how his cutting methods changed over his career, yet how certain assumptions remained fixed. One of the most rewarding and maddening of these assumptions is that design is a learning process. And McQueen always wanted to learn.

In a city dominated by coq au vin and rillettes, authentic Mexican food - let alone a good margarita - has been hard to come by. Now there is Candelaria, Paris's first real taqueria, which recently opened in the Marais. The galley-size kitchen, helmed by the Mexican chef Luis Rendon, is buffered by a five-seat counter and a communal table. The seasonal menu, listed on a jagged blackboard, currently includes dishes like rajas con queso (tacos with sautéed green peppers, onions and melted cheese), totopos (chips) with zesty guacamole and longaniza (spicy pork) or pollo pibil (stewed chicken) tostados dressed with shredded red cabbage. The crisp tortillas are made in-house with meseca imported from Spain. Spicy sauces are on hand - and thankfully so are Mexican beers, bubbly fluorescent Jarritos sodas and hibiscus juice. There's no wine or coffee - positively heresy in Paris - but here "nothing has been compromised for a French palate," insists Carina Soto Velasquez, who founded the restaurant with Adam Tsou and Joshua Fontaine. And about those margaritas? Hidden behind a mural-covered door in the back is a cocktail bar whose alcoholic arsenal includes well-aged tequilas, organic mezcal, rare rums and a curated drink selection with contributions from international bartender aficionados. (One is from the provenance of the East Village's Death & Co.) Assorted young artists helped supply the décor, including Adrian Rubi-Dentzel, who repurposed the space's original floor into the bar, and Confetti System, whose shimmering pendant adds a nice flourish.

When Gully Wells left London for New York City in the mid-'80s, she was shocked to discover that New York women were uniformly dressed in short skirts and Manolo Blahniks. Wells, who is now the jet-setting features director of Condé Nast Traveler, is no stranger to the vagaries of style -- her mother was Dee Wells, the author and columnist whose home, located between Toulon and Marseille, France, was the scene of many salacious exploits (summer affairs, teeny bikini contests) often involving her fabulous friends (Christopher Hitchens and Antonia Fraser). Wells recounts these tales and fashionable lessons her mother taught her in her coming memoir, "The House in France," to be published in June by Knopf.

Since the time I took my very first cuts with a baseball bat, my father has been telling me about Stan Musial. Not just about the corkscrew batting stance but also about the gentleman. You may not be able to imitate the stance, I think was the lesson, but you could always emulate the man. Somehow Musial slipped from the pantheon of baseball's immortals among the general public; more fathers chose to tell their sons about DiMaggio and Mantle and Mays, and as their legends grew, Musial's kind of faded into some kind of runner-up, a tragic slight that culminated with him being left off the all-century team voted on by fans in 1999.

Simon Cowell's plan to turn the British singer Cheryl Cole into a global star is progressing just as he has hoped. Mr. Cowell has succeeded in signing up Ms. Cole as a judge on ''The X Factor,'' a singing competition that he is importing from Britain for the Fox network. Her long-rumored role on the judging panel was confirmed by Fox on Thursday in the latest of a series of announcements that are intended to build anticipation for the show, which is to be broadcast beginning in September.

A presidential commission called on Congress to establish a Smithsonian American Latino Museum at the Capitol on Thursday morning during a news conference attended by proponents of the project. In a report submitted this week to President Obama and Congress, the commission said that it would cost $600 million to build and open the museum, adding that half of the money could be raised privately. In deference to current budget conditions, the commission said that no federal financing would be needed for six years. Congress established the panel, the National Museum of the American Latino Commission, in 2008. The mood at the news conference was celebratory, with several speakers, including Interior Secretary Ken Salazar and Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California, making their remarks in both Spanish and English, and much attention going to the commission's two celebrity members, the ''Desperate Housewives'' actress Eva Longoria and the music producer Emilio Estefan. In a statement the Smithsonian's spokeswoman, Linda St. Thomas, said that if Congress passed legislation to establish and finance a national Latino museum, the Smithsonian ''would be prepared to welcome it to the Smithsonian family of museums.''

DENNIS--George William. October 23, 1923 - May 3, 2011. WWII navigator, 381st Bomb Group, 8th Army Air Force; shot down over occupied Europe with his pilot and lifelong friend (Dr.) Harold Blog, May 19, 1944, and held as POW until April 29, 1945. Commissioned in the USAF Reserves in 1951, he retired in the rank of major in 1970. Graduate, St. John's University (1949); Rutgers Univ. Stonier Graduate School of Banking (1965); Harvard Advanced Management Program (1975). CPA with Haskins & Sells (1947-590; Auditor and Senior Vice President of the Hanover Bank/ Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. (1959-80). Taught on faculty of AIB New York Chapter, and the Bank Administration Institute (BAI) School for Bank Administration. Chaired the BAI audit commission, and served in leadership positions that included BAI National President and Chairman of the Board (1975-76). CBA and CPA; member, NYSSCPA, AICPA (1953-2011). Treasurer, board member of organizations including his Harvard AMP Class; American Legion Post 144; Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery; St. Mary's Children & Family Services; Alzheimer's Association, LI; Child Abuse Prevention Services; American Ex-POWs Association. An active member of the Greater Long Island Running Club (GLIRC), he competed in 698 road races, including 10 NYC, LI and Philadelphia Marathons, the last at age 75. Preceded in death by his wife of 54 years, Catherine Ann Lillian (nee Mullen); they married on Memorial Day, 1949. Survived by sisters Edith Lott, Dorothy Germond and Marylin Rowe; brother-in-law William Lott; sisters-in-law Helen Adams, Faith Mullen, Barbara Mullen and Barbara Henrichs; children George, Raymond, Karen, Victoria and Donovan Dennis; daughters-in-law Kathleen, Rosemarie and Stephanie Dennis; son-in-law Brian Lehrer; grandchildren Kimberly, Courtney, Ryan, Kevin, Nathan, Colby, Simon, Noelle, and Gabriel; grandson-in-law Terry; many beloved nieces, nephews and their children; and innumerable dear friends. Burial at Cypress Hills National Cemetery, Monday, May 9, 11am. Visiting hours Saturday, 2-4, 7-9pm, Beney's Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Rd., Syosset, NY 11791, 516-921-2888. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to the V Foundation for Cancer Research, 106 Towerview Court, Cary, NC 27513, or online at www.jimmyv.org.

A Minnesota legislator who ridiculed the fantasy writer Neil Gaiman has apologized for his intemperate remarks, but is standing by his criticism of the author for receiving a speaking fee from the state that the lawmaker deems excessive, Minnesota Public Radio reported. Matt Dean, the Republican leader of the Minnesota House of Representatives, initiated the war of words with Mr. Gaiman, the best-selling author of ''The Graveyard Book'' and ''Coraline,'' amid a hearing this week over a bill that would reduce state financing for public radio and other cultural organizations.

LEET--Millie. The Metropolitan College of New York community is saddened by the loss of one of our cherished members and benefactors Millie Leet. Millie was a loyal, loving supporter of the College and was present at our founder Audrey Cohen's side from the very beginning. She was always an inspiration for faculty, staff and students. Always a natural leader, Millie will be sorely missed. Vinton Thompson, President Metropolitan College of NY

An article on Tuesday about the compound in Pakistan where Osama bin Laden was living before he was killed in an American raid omitted reporting credits in some copies. Ismail Khan contributed reporting from Peshawar, Pakistan, and Adam B. Ellick from New York.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about federal elections in Canada described incorrectly, in some copies, the political career of Michael Ignatieff of the Liberal Party. He was making his debut as party leader -- not as an elected politician. The article also misstated in some copies the previous record number of seats won by the New Democratic Party, which broke that record by winning 105 seats and finishing in second place. It was 43, not 45.

An article on Thursday about the disposition of the criminal cases of two former students from South Hadley, Mass., in the bullying of Phoebe Prince, who committed suicide in January 2010, misstated the plea of one student. Kayla Narey ''admitted to sufficient facts'' for a harassment charge; she did not plead guilty. (If she satisfies the conditions of probation, the charges will be dismissed.)

TAGUE--Alicia Murtha, born February 1, 1927 in NYC. Educated at Dominican Academy and Fordham University. On August 6, 1949, Alicia married her life's love, Charles Tague, whom she met at age 16. Together they lived in Jackson Heights, NY, Colts Neck, NJ, Upper Saddle River, NJ, and Jackson, NJ, raising six children and sharing almost 62 years of memories. She was an elementary teacher, librarian and served in a number of community and church volunteer leadership roles, particularly at St. Mary's and Church of the Presentation parishes in Colts Neck and Upper Saddle River, NJ. Alicia died April 29th of complications of Alzheimer's. She is survived by her loving husband, Charles; sons Patrick, Charles, Thomas, James; daughters Mary Alicia Haberman, Elizabeth Anne Giuliano; their respective spouses Brenda, Gloria, Elise, Liza, Joseph, and Russell; 11 grandchildren and many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Dominican Academy, 44, E. 68th St, NYC, NY 10065.

LEET--Mildred Robbins, co-founder of Trickle Up and an activist who devoted her life to improving the lives of people all over the world, passed away on May 3. Mrs. Leet is best known as the co-founder of Trickle Up, a global nonprofit that empowers some of the world's poorest and most vulnerable people. Trickle Up's chief executive for over 20 years and board chair until 2006, she continued as Board Chair Emerita until her death. A born entrepreneur, she dedicated her enormous energy and unwavering optimism to a wide range of organizations that she helped found or lead, including the U.S. Committee for the United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM), United Cerebral Palsy, Metropolitan College of New York, and InterAction. Active in Democratic politics and civil rights, she was proud to have stood on the speaker's platform for Martin Luther King's "I Have A Dream" speech. Among many honors, Mrs. Leet received, along with Mother Theresa and Wangari Maathai, the Women of the World Award in 1989, presented by Princess Diana. Mrs. Leet was married to Louis J. Robbins from 1940 until his death in 1970 and to Glen Leet from 1974 until his death in 1998. She is survived by her brother Lawrence Elow, daughters Jane Marla Robbins and Aileen Robbins; granddaughter Ariel Fantasia and a great-granddaughter, Sage Price Fantasia. A memorial will be held on Friday, May 6, at 11:45 am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Trickle Up (www.trickleup.org) and Metropolitan College of New York (www.mcny.edu). Memories and condolences can be posted at www.mildredrobbinsleet.org
The On Horse Racing column on Tuesday, about the writer's difficulties in picking a Kentucky Derby winner, misstated the year Barbaro won the race. It was 2006, not 2003.

LEET--Mildred Robbins. We mourn the passing and honor the extraordinary life of Mildred Robbins Leet, who co-founded Trickle Up in 1979 and created an organization that has touched the lives of over one million poor people around the world. She inspired us daily with her unending commitment and optimism. Her example will always be a beacon for us, as we go forward to help fulfill her vision of a world where no woman lacks the opportunity to create a better future for herself and her children. The board, staff and partners of Trickle Up

Since they began deliberations last week, jurors in the trial of Raj Rajaratnam have asked to listen to secretly recorded conversations between the money manager and suspected tipsters, the evidence that is at the center of the government's insider trading case. On Thursday, the jurors focused for the first time on Danielle Chiesi, a hedge fund consultant who pleaded guilty early this year to swapping confidential information with Mr. Rajaratnam, the head of the Galleon Group hedge fund.

An article on Saturday about the second day of the N.F.L. draft misstated the position played by the former San Francisco 49er Dwight Clark, who announced the team's second-round pick. He was a wide receiver, not a tight end.

A column last Friday on Stand for Children, an education reform group, listed an incorrect fund-raising total for the group's Illinois public action committee. It has raised $3.5 million, not $1.5 million.

The baseball roundup on Monday by The Associated Press erroneously attributed a distinction to the Boston Red Sox pitcher Tim Wakefield. In making his first start of the season on Sunday, Wakefield, 44, did not become the oldest pitcher to start a major league game since Roger Clemens started for the Yankees in 2007 at 45. Last season, Jamie Moyer of the Philadelphia Phillies started a game at 47.

On Thursday, Bill Clinton called on New York state lawmakers to pass a bill allowing gay couples to marry. ''For more than a century, our Statue of Liberty has welcomed all kinds of people from all over the world yearning to be free,'' Mr. Clinton said in a statement released by the Human Rights Campaign. ''In the 21st century, I believe New York's welcome must include marriage equality.'' Read more on City Room. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Through the first month of the season, baseball's new major leaguers have started off as the worst-hitting bunch ever. While offense is slightly off throughout baseball, the 42 players who made their debut in March or April have all failed to contribute to their teams at the plate. Through April, they had managed only 47 hits in 274 at-bats for a .172 batting average. That is the worst batting average through April for players making their debut since 1920. They also hit the trifecta with the worst slugging percentage (.212) and the worst on-base percentage (.248) of any set of players making their debut.

RATNER--Robert J. The officers and staff of AFCO Credit Corporation mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague, friend and General Counsel, Robert J. Ratner. We extend our deepest sympathy to Bob's wife, Valerie, his sons, Andrew and Michael, and all their loved ones.

Only weeks ago, top Democrats appeared to have all but written off a special election for a Congressional seat in the suburbs of Buffalo. After all, Republican voters vastly outnumber Democrats in the district, and the Republican candidate, Jane L. Corwin, a well-liked state assemblywoman, seemed to be a shoo-in. Then along came Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin. Mr. Ryan, a top House Republican, released a plan calling for the most extensive overhaul of Medicare since it was created.

WACHTEL--Ginette. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of Ginette Wachtel. Ginette passed away on Wednesday, May 4, 2011, after a prolonged illness, but not without a profoundly courageous fight. A beloved sister, aunt and devoted friend, Ginette will be deeply missed by everyone whose life she touched. Born in Metz, France in 1935 of Polish parents, she emigrated to Panama with her family where she spend much of her youth. She moved to the United States as a teenager, and was a proud graduate of Brooklyn College, earning a degree in mathematics. That led her to becoming a pioneer in the field of Information Technology, most recently as Senior Vice President of Application Development at Marsh & McClennan, Inc. She was also a Director of Cheyenne, and a Board Member of the American Society for Jewish Heritage in Poland and the Riverside Symphony. An inveterate New Yorker, she took advantage of all the culture that was right outside her front door, from the theater, movies and concerts to restaurants, museums and talks. Ever curious, she traveled extensively, zealously traced the roots of her family and was always eager to share her experiences. She is survived by her brothers Edmond, Edwin and Henry, seven nephews and nieces and countless dear friends. They will all miss her enthusiasm, her devotion and her easy-going warmth. A memorial service will be held Monday, May 9 at 11:00am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., at the corner of Amsterdam Ave.

BROWN--Patricia Anne Meegan, 82, beloved mother and grandmother, died after a brief illness on May 4 in Sarasota, FL. Born in the Bronx, educated at the Academy of Mt. St. Ursula and Our Lady of Good Counsel College, she married Walter J. Brown, Jr. in 1951 and they raised their four children in Westchester Co. She was predeceased by her one and only love in 1983 and since then divided her time between homes in Bronxville, NY and Siesta Key, FL. She had strong and lasting friendships in both places. In lieu of flowers, the family invites donations to Mt. St. Ursula, 330 Bedford Park Blvd, Bronx NY, 10458. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, May 9 at 11am at the Church of St. Joseph, 15 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY.

For his first Broadway role since his performance in the 2008 revival of ''A Man for All Seasons,''Frank Langella will return to star in another play with a masculine title: ''Man and Boy,'' the Terence Rattigan drama, which will be presented by Roundabout Theater Company, the company said on Thursday. In the play, which is being staged as part of a centenary celebration of Rattigan, the author of ''The Browning Version'' and ''The Winslow Boy,'' Mr. Langella, 73, will play Gregor Antonescu, a cut-throat financier of the 1930s who seeks the help of his estranged son when his business is threatened by the Depression. The Roundabout production will be directed by Maria Aitken (who directed the comedic stage version of Alfred Hitchcock's ''The 39 Steps'') and performed at the American Airlines Theater. It is scheduled to begin previews on Sept. 9 and open on Oct. 9, with a limited run that is planned to end on Nov. 27.

The On Soccer column on April 28, about a match between Real Madrid and Barcelona, misspelled the surname of Lionel Messi's teammate who assisted on one of his two goals. It is Ibrahim Afellay, not Affelay. A correction in this space on Monday misidentified the winner; Barcelona, not Real Madrid, won, 2-0.

HONSBERGER--Barbara, 84, of Williamstown, MA passed away on May 4, 2011. She was the last survivor of a family of 10. Barbara was a fashion executive and Vice President at Lord & Taylor and traveled extensively throughout her life. Barbara tirelessly pursued her passions of art, music, and learning. She attended daily Mass as a devoted Catholic. Her treasured brother and sister-in-law, cousins, dozens of nieces and nephews and many friends will dearly miss Barbara's enthusiasm, vitality, sparkling blue eyes and loving smile. An obituary on March 25 about the playwright Lanford Wilson misstated the name of the publication in which Mr. Wilson was quoted discussing his early days in New York. It is Current Biography, not Contemporary Biography. A reader alerted The Times to the error on Thursday.

An Associated Press article and headline on Wednesday about Pfizer's quarterly earnings report misstated the company's revenue forecast for 2011 and 2012. The company maintained a forecast that it had issued in April; it did not lower it.

REGAN--Robert James, beloved husband of Mary Regan and father of Kenneth, Andrew, the late David, and Audrey, passed away Wednesday morning after a brief illness. Regan was Non-Ferrous Editor of Iron Age Magazine, and also worked for the Journal of Commerce, UPI, the American Metal Market, and Purchasing Magazine. He wrote columns for the Magnesium Monthly Review right up to now. For further information: www.vanderplaat.com.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with the Reuters Breakingviews column, about the initial offering of Renren, a Chinese social network, and the bailout of Portugal, misidentified the person pictured in some copies. He is José Sócrates, the prime minister of Portugal, not Joseph Chen, the chief executive of Renren.

CHAMBERS--William L.,II, William L. Chambers II, 82 years old, died on May 4 in Palm Beach Gardens Hospital, in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. He died after being in a coma for 27 days following emergency heart surgery. A native New Yorker, he lived for the last seven years in Jupiter, FL. Bill, a longtime employee of the New York Times, spent many of his 46 years with the company as an editor on the news makeup desk. A skilled editor, he handled deadline pressure with a cool calmness yet possessed a warm sense of humor that endeared him to many. In a newsroom where rumpled shirts were the fashion norm, he always stood out in his impeccable jacket, shirt and tie. He once told a colleague that early in his career he was hired for a job in the publisher's office because he was the only one wearing a suit. He enjoyed life to the fullest and always looked forward to his next adventure. His friends and family will miss him deeply. Survivors include his son, Geoffrey C. Chambers, Sr. and daughter-in-law, Ellen, of Bluemont, VA; his son, Matthew C. Chambers and his partner, William E. Davis, of Jupiter; his grandson, Geoffrey C. Chambers, Jr. of Arlington, VA; and numerous cousins. He is also survived by Catherine Kelly Chambers, of Queens, NY and Flerida Orozco, of Jupiter. He was predeceased by his beloved son, William L. Chambers III; his mother, Margaret and sisters Dorothy and Gloria. A wake will be held Sunday, 2 to 5pm and 7 to 9pm and on Monday, 2 to 5pm at Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Queens; an evening service will be held at the funeral home on Monday from 7 to 9. Burial at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, Long Island, will follow a gravesite service on Tuesday at 11am.

RATNER--Robert, 60, of Westfield passed away on May 4th. Services will be held today, Friday May 6th at 11:30 at the J.L. Apter Memorial Chapel, 415 Morris Avenue in Springfield with interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery on Gill Lane in Iselin, NJ. Mr. Ratner leaves his devoted wife Valerie (nee Lohn), adored sons Andrew and Michael, dear mother Dorothy Scherzer, loving brothers Kenneth and David and close friend Steve Legum. An attorney with AFCO Financial for more than 25 years, Bob loved his career and his job. A graduate of NYU and St. John's Law School, he was a member of the New York Bar Association, M.E.N.S.A. and enjoyed gardening, as well as being a proficient writer and was an active, caring, civic minded individual. The family would appreciate donations to the Union County Torah Center or St. Jude's Children Hospital. For shiva details, please call the chapel at 973-376-2600.

WOOD--J. Austen Flint, born September 17, 1922 in Rotherham, England died on April 6 in Tryon, NC. During the Second World War, he was commissioned in the Royal Navy Fleet Air Arm and served as one of the youngest carrier-based fighter pilots and production test pilots. During his business career in marketing, he traveled throughout the world often to Japan, Russia and Europe. He is survived by daughters Rowena Wood of New York and Nicola Edwards of London, grandchildren Lindsey, Romaine and Lauren and great-grandchildren Laila and Rufus. Memorial Service to be held on June 9, 2011 at 11:00am, in New York at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue.

The ''Glee'' franchise isn't all about indulging the 1970s nostalgia of its creators and structuring entire episodes around ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' or Fleetwood Mac's ''Rumours'' album; that hit Fox musical comedy has a few modern-day tricks up its sleeve, too. For instance: its ''Glee Live! In Concert!'' series will be filmed this summer for a 3-D movie that will feature 14 members of the television series and utilize whatever remaining exclamation points Fox possesses. On Wednesday, Twentieth Century Fox's film and television divisions said that the ''Glee Live! 3D!'' movie will be released in theaters on Aug. 12 and run for two weeks. The film, directed by Kevin Tancharoen (director of the 2009 remake of ''Fame,'' and the online series ''Mortal Kombat: Legacy'') will feature ''Glee'' stars like Lea Michele, Chris Colfer, Heather Morris and Darren Criss performing numbers like ''I'm a Slave 4 U,'' ''Raise Your Glass'' and ''Teenage Dream.'' (No word about the ''Glee'' star Matthew Morrison, whose cleft chin would seem tailor-made for the 3-D format.) This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PETSCHEK--Alfred Edgar, 81 years old, died on May 2, 2011. Beloved son of the late Franziska and Walter Petschek, beloved brother of the late Stephen Petschek and of Susan Petschek, devoted uncle of Jennifer and Alexandra Petschek, and great-uncle of William Baskerville Robson. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Harvard University. His kindness, generosity and humor will be missed by his many relatives and friends. Services will be private.

Donilon, appears on “Fox News Sunday,” ABC’s “This Week,” NBC’s “Meet the Press” and CNN’s “State of the Union” to talk about the raid that brought down the 9/11 mastermind who has eluded capture for years.

My column this week looks at the extraordinary efforts of Times staffers as they responded to the news of Osama Bin Laden's death in a raid by Navy Seals. Because the news broke late on print deadlines, The Times took extraordinary measures to stop the presses, remake print pages and rush to get updated copies not only to New York readers but to many readers in major cities nationwide. On top of that, the Times mounted an intense global reporting effort aimed at delivering fresh stories through the night for publication on NYTimes.com, which became the key venue for breaking developments after the print edition closed at 12:45 a.m. Monday. The result was an outpouring of fresh copy that was published online-only and then superseded eventually by new stories on Monday, some of which ultimately fed a 10-page special print section titled "The Death of Bin Laden" that was delivered Tuesday.

Wildlife rehabilitators visited the president’s office at New York University on Saturday afternoon to check on Violet and her injured leg and whether she could be reached from the window. They determined that she could and should be captured, treated and returned immediately to the nest. The rehabilitators, Robert and Cathy Horvath, will return within a few days — the day has not yet been worked out — to do the job. Mr. Horvath said that the object on Violet’s leg, a wildlife band, has been stuck there for months and that another day or two should not matter. Click for the full story. >>

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - Some people just like to be difficult. You say day, I say night. Tomato, tomahto. You get the idea. In today's puzzle, however, Daniel Finan has decided to play both sides of the coin, and I think it works very well.

In 1963, Juan Marichal was making a name for himself, fresh off a no-hitter and on the way to a 25-win season for the San Francisco Giants. On July 2, his Milwaukee Braves opponent was Warren Spahn, 42 and nearing the end of his career. Marichal and Spahn pitched scoreless inning after scoreless inning until the 16th, when Willie Mays homered to win it for the Giants. The game is celebrated in Jim Kaplan’s book “The Greatest Game Ever Pitched.” Marichal, 73, now has a farm in the Dominican Republic and still remembers the game vividly.
Chutzpah, according to the traditional definition, is when you murder your mother and father, then plead for mercy from the court on the grounds that you're an orphan.

Animal Kingdom, who had never run a race on dirt, beat Nehro by two and three-quarter lengths to win the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday in his fifth career start. Trained by Graham Motion and owned by Team Valor International, Animal Kingdom had won twice and finished second twice in his previous four starts. Mucho Macho Man finished third.

The Pirates’ Charlie Morton was historically terrible in 2010. In 17 starts, he was 2-12 with a 7.57 earned run average . Only one other pitcher has made so many starts with an E.R.A. so high and a winning percentage so low: Ed Holley, who was 1-11 with an 8.12 E.R.A. for two teams in 1934.

Everybody knows that all the favorites in this year's Kentucky Derby have serious vulnerabilities and that lots of long-priced horses have hidden virtues. Everybody wants to go contrarian, but you got be different from everybody if you want to be contrarian. I can't add to what everybody already knows. Rather than look at the race comprehensively in a limited space, I will take this opportunity to explore a pure contrarian opportunity in this race that could produce value in a race screaming out for a contrarian approach.

If Midnight Interlude wins the Kentucky Derby, Bob Baffert should place his friend Philip Thomas on the payroll through the Belmont. In 2002, Baffert's Derby horse War Emblem bit his groom before winning the Derby. He bit the same groom before winning the Preakness. Word is that the groom disappeared before the Belmont which War Emblem lost. This week, Baffert's Derby horse Midnight Interlude bit Phillip Thomas twice on the arm. In the world of racetrack superstitions, Baffert views this as a very good sign.

We are covering the final season of "Friday Night Lights" according to the NBC schedule. We ask that readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section.Can this child be saved? That was the underlying theme of the latest episode of "Friday Night Lights,'' as we watched Epyck lash out, fight and get suspended and Buddy's son roll into town with his quasi-vegan-induced anger and disillusionment. Who among us wouldn't become cranky if subjected to a step-parent mandated diet of seitan? It seems to take Buddy Jr. about 10 seconds of being in Dillon to steal his father's credit card and break into the booze and another 20 for everyone to figure that the cure for what ails Buddy is going to be two-a-days. I'm already feeling too optimistic about Buddy's future, and I don't want to feel optimistic. I hope for more screeching engines and rebellion, a challenge to Buddy's narrowly circumscribed gridiron view of the world.

A music review on April 23 about Secret Mountains, at Cake Shop in Manhattan, misstated the titles of the songs that closed the group's show. They were ''High Horse'' and ''Golden Blue,'' not ''Kaddish'' and ''Gate/Gate/Paragate.''

His sinister voice and unnerving gaze have guaranteed Jeremy Irons a career playing nefarious characters, but does he dream of playing a hero - even a once-great medieval king who is ditched by his wife for a newer and better model of knight? If so, Mr. Irons, a star of the Showtime series ''The Borgias'' (not to mention films like ''Reversal of Fortune'' and ''The Lion King'') will get to fulfill that goal in a one-night concert production of ''Camelot'' for the Irish Repertory Theater, in which he will play King Arthur. Press representatives for the production, which will be presented on June 6 at the Shubert Theater, said on Friday that Mr. Irons will play Arthur, the Excalibur-wielding monarch, in the Lerner and Loewe musical. James Barbour and Melissa Errico will play Lancelot and Guenevere, reprising the roles they played in a 2005 production at the Hollywood Bowl. The Irish Rep concert production, which will be directed by Charlotte Moore, with musical direction by Mark Hartman, will be presented as a benefit for the theater, so be prepared to dig up a little more coin of the realm for tickets. Prices for individual seats are $100 to $300. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LAURENTS--Arthur, died May 5, 2011 after a brief illness in his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Born in Flatbush, Brooklyn on July 14, 1917, he graduated from Cornell University and was a resident of Greenwich Village, New York and Quogue, Long Island. He spent 52 extraordinary years with Tom Hatcher, his beloved companion, who died in 2006. A giant both on Broadway and in films, Laurents had written countless plays, musicals and screenplays. Among his Broadway credits are the books for the musicals "West Side Story," "Gypsy," "Anyone Can Whistle," "Do I Hear A Waltz?" and "Hallelujah, Baby!" He directed the original Broadway production of "La Cage Aux Folles" in 1983 and enormously successful revivals of "Gypsy" (three times) and "West Side Story." A partial list of his plays includes "Home of the Brave" (his 1945 Broadway debut), "The Time of the Cuckoo," "A Clearing In The Woods," "Invitation To A March," and "Jolson Sings Again." Highlights of his screenwriting career include "Rope," "The Turning Point," "Anastasia" and "The Way We Were." He received three Tony Awards (all for Best Direction of a Musical) for his work on Broadway as well as five Academy Award nominations. In 2000, Laurents published an acclaimed autobiography, "Original Story By Arthur Laurents: A Memoir of Broadway and Hollywood," and in 2009 republished Mainly On Directing: "Gypsy," "West Side Story" and Other Musicals. He will be remembered not only as having one of the most extraordinary careers in contemporary history, but for his fierce beliefs and fierce personal convictions. In 2010, he created the Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award to be given annually to a deserving young playwright. He is survived by a niece and nephew. Donations may be made to The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation 608 Northville Turnpike, Riverhead, New York 11901.

An essay this weekend on Page 11, about photographers who cover wars, refers imprecisely to Chris Hondros, a photographer who was killed last month while covering Libya's rebel militia. He was a senior staff photographer for the Getty Images agency, not a freelancer. The essay also misstates the year that Joao Silva was on assignment for The New York Times in Najaf, Iraq. It was 2004, not 2006.

William Campbell, an actor who was widely familiar to film and television audiences and who was also known as the first husband of Judith Campbell Exner, a mistress of President John F. Kennedy, died on April 28 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 87. His death, at the Motion Picture & Television Hospital, was confirmed by Jennifer Fagen, a spokeswoman for the Motion Picture & Television Fund, which administers the hospital.

CROSBY--Robert F.,of New York City, passed away May 4, 2011, at home, in his 85th year. A retired banker, Bob spent the last 17 years as an administrator of two non-profit arts organizations which support opera and young singers: Opera Index and the Martina Arroyo Foundation. Donations may be made to either organization. Bob, you will be missed for your devotion and wisdom.

Representative Ron Paul of Texas has none of the typical attributes of a successful presidential candidate, except one: he can raise money. According to Mr. Paul's Web site, his one-day ''money bomb'' aimed at collecting funds during Thursday's Republican debate netted his campaign more than $1 million.

The International Center of Photography in Manhattan is looking for a new home that can accommodate both its museum and its school, its director, Willis E. Hartshorn, said on Friday. The school and museum are across the street from each other on the Avenue of the Americas near 43rd Street. Mr. Hartshorn said the center was in the ''early phases'' of evaluating various sites below 26th Street, including buildings in Lower Manhattan and Chelsea. ''It's not clear when we will move or where,'' he said, adding that the center would like to increase its total space to about 100,000 square feet from its current 65,000. The center, which has occupied its site for 15 years without paying rent to the owner, the Durst Corporation, has three remaining years on its existing leases and the option to renew each for five years. ''So we're not really pressured,'' Mr. Hartshorn said.

RUBINOVICH--Yuri. With great sadness we learn the unexpected passing of Yuri Rubinovich, 49, on May 4th. Graduate of St. Petersburg Polytechnic University and Columbia Business School, Yuri was an accomplished professional, managing partner at Inter-Capital, Inc, highly regarded in international business community, loved and admired by many for his generosity and wit. He is mourned by his parents, Ninel and Anatoly and many friends and colleagues all around the world. The funeral service will be Sunday, May 8, at 9:00am in Kehila Funeral Chapel, 60 Brighton 11th Street, Brooklyn.

LEET--Mildred Robbins. We mourn the passing and honor the extraordinary life of Mildred Robbins Leet, who co-founded Trickle Up in 1979 and created an organization that has touched the lives of over one million poor people around the world. She inspired us daily with her unending commitment and optimism. Her example will always be a beacon for us, as we go forward to help fulfill her vision of a world where no woman lacks the opportunity to create a better future for herself and her children. The board, staff and partners of Trickle Up

The cover article this weekend, on Page 38, about the disappearance of Air France Flight 447 in 2009, makes several references to unrecovered data cylinders from the plane's black boxes. On May 1, after the article went to press, the cylinders were found on the floor of the South Atlantic Ocean and are expected to be analyzed in the coming week.

In the annals of Metropolitan Transportation Authority history, it has not been customary for transit officials to be caught up in a celebrity wedding. Their work has focused more on the construction of the No. 7 line extension, say, than on bridal gown designers, floral arrangement preferences or what the bridesmaids will wear. But that all changed for the agency on Friday when Sir Paul McCartney confirmed his engagement to a transportation authority board member, Nancy Shevell. They have been dating for four years, and both are divorced. Ms. Shevell will become Mr. McCartney's third wife.

An article on Tuesday about strained relations between Syria and Hamas, the Palestinian group based in Syria, over the neutrality of Hamas in the antigovernment uprising there, misstated the role in Hamas of a Syrian man, Abu Almajad, who was quoted as saying that Qatar would be happy if the group moved there. Mr. Almajad is a Hamas supporter, not a Hamas leader.

On Wednesday, he is scheduled to speak, before former President George W. Bush, at a prominent hedge fund conference in Las Vegas. Earlier this year, he made his first trip to Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum, where he could be seen dancing the night away at a private party.

Asmus, an early proponent of expanding the Atlantic alliance to include Eastern European nations and a key figure in the Clinton administration's realization of that vision, died April 30 in Belgium. LAURENTS--Arthur. The Dramatists Guild Council mourns the passing of Council member Arthur Laurents, who died at age 93 on May 5, 2011. A prolific playwright, screenwriter and director, Arthur's theatrical legacy is guaranteed by his books for two of the most influential and iconic musicals in American theater history, "West Side Story" and "Gypsy," as well as ground-breaking plays such as "Home of the Brave." Arthur was also an extraordinary mentor and supporter of young writers, and many including myself have been the grateful beneficiaries of his creative generosity. Elected to the Guild's Council in 1946, Arthur was a staunch and tireless advocate for the rights of writers everywhere. We will miss his uncompromising passion, and we celebrate his achievements that will live on forever. Stephen Schwartz, President Dramatists Guild of America

The executive director of the financially struggling American Folk Art Museum in Manhattan is stepping down in July, Bloomberg reported. In a statement on the museum's Web site, the director, Maria Ann Conelli, said that she was leaving the museum after six years to take a job in academia. A spokesman for the museum, Fred Schroeder, said he was not at liberty to name her future employer. The Folk Art Museum is in default on nearly $32 million worth of bonds that it issued to construct its building on West 53rd Street. Last summer the museum entered into a forbearance agreement with its bond insurer, ACA Financial Guaranty, which will expire on June 30. Unless the agreement is extended or the museum is able to resume payments on the debt, the museum will be subject to foreclosure. Mr. Schroeder said that the board did not yet have a formal plan to look for a successor and that after Ms. Conelli leaves in July the museum would be run into the interim by the deputy director, Linda Dunne.

8:52 p.m. | Updated The Warner Music Group agreed on Friday to sell itself to the Russian-born billionaire Len Blavatnik for a total of about $3.3 billion, ending a months-long auction of the music company that is the home of artists including Green Day, Red Hot Chili Peppers and Eric Clapton.

Julie Taymor, the ousted director of Broadway's ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' will deliver a keynote speech at a major theater conference in Los Angeles on June 18, four days after the $70 million musical is scheduled to have its long-delayed opening night in New York. Ms. Taymor will also speak that Saturday at a panel session, titled ''A Director's Life,'' during the annual conference of Theater Communications Group, a national organization of nearly 700 nonprofit theaters and affiliated groups. The Tony Award-winning best director of ''The Lion King,'' Ms. Taymor has been largely silent about her ''Spider-Man'' experience in the weeks since the show's producers announced on March 9 that she was leaving the production; privately, both sides said she was fired over creative clashes. Ms. Taymor has declined to give interviews to the media while her lawyers continue to negotiate with the producers over the terms of her artistic control on ''Spider-Man,'' which she created over the last decade with Bono and Edge, its composers, and wrote the script for with the playwright Glen Berger. (The three men remain with the show.)

EHRICH--Dorothy D.,(82), beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister, passed away peacefully on May 5, 2011 surrounded by her loving family. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 am on Sunday, May 8, 2011 at Temple Emanu-El, 756 E. Broad. St., Westfield, NJ. Burial will follow at Riverside Cemetery in Saddle Brook, NJ.

A $5 million lawsuit against Simon & Schuster over a book by former President Jimmy Carter was dropped by the plaintiffs on Thursday, three months after it was filed. The plaintiffs in the class-action suit had argued that Mr. Carter's ''Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid,'' about the Arab-Israeli conflict, was falsely marketed as ''absolute truth.'' When the suit was filed in February, Simon & Schuster immediately condemned it, calling it frivolous, without merit and a ''chilling attack on free speech.'' On Thursday, after the suit was dropped, Adam Rothberg, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, said in a statement: ''In the face of a powerful argument for the rights of free speech for authors and publishers, the plaintiffs wisely withdrew their action. We hope that they will consider this the end of the matter.

Beloved son of the late Franziska and Walter Petschek, beloved brother of the late Stephen Petschek and of Susan Petschek, devoted uncle of Jennifer and Alexandra Petschek, and great-uncle of William Baskerville Robson. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Harvard University. His kindness, generosity and humor will be missed by his many relatives and friends. Services will be private.

ALTCHEK--Albert, MD. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Albert Altchek, MD. For 65 years, Dr. Altchek was a physician and faculty member in the Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Science. He published and lectured widely, and was recognized for his expertise in adolescent and pediatric gynecology, as well as renal biopsies in patients with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. Dedicated to family, patients, and residents, Dr. Altchek is survived by several family members, including 11 fellow physicians. We will miss this educator, clinician, and gentleman. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Michael L. Brodman, MD, Professor and Chairman, The Ellen and Howard C. Katz Chairman's Chair, Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Science.

The About New York column on Friday about Jeffrey S. Weisenfeld, the CUNY trustee who pushed successfully to deny an honorary degree from John Jay College of Criminal Justice to the playwright Tony Kushner, misspelled in some editions the name of the president of the college. He is Jeremy Travis, not Travers. The column also misstated in some editions the year Mr. Weisenfeld was appointed to the board. It was 1999, not 1996.

Teach for America is the latest organization to ensure that its employees with same-sex partners get the same treatment as opposite-sex married couples when it comes to health care costs. Gay people who are fortunate enough to work for employers that extend health benefits to their same-sex partners are still at a disadvantage: they must pay an extra tax on the value of those benefits that heterosexual married couples do not pay.

An article on Friday about a special election for a Congressional seat in the suburbs of Buffalo that has been shaken up by a Republican plan to overhaul health care misidentified the federal program that would be turned into a grant program for states under one part of the plan. It is Medicaid, not Medicare.

I have neither the background nor the inclination to hold forth on Tony Kushner's political views on the Middle East. But I was deeply saddened to read of the City University of New York's initial decision, now being reconsidered, to rescind an honorary degree for Mr. Kushner, after a trustee at CUNY said the playwright had made disparaging remarks about the State of Israel, particularly in regard to Israel's policy toward Palestinians. One of our most high-reaching dramatists, Mr. Kushner is a writer of rare intellectual scope and reading in both art and politics. But these assets would mean very little without the extraordinary, active empathy that pervades every one of his plays, extended even to those who would not appear to be his allies.
