Walcott, schools chancellor, peacemaker and former kindergarten teacher. Mr. Walcott had just finished speaking with a group of reporters about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget when Rafael Martinez Alequin, a blogger, and Dave Evans, a political reporter for WABC-TV, began yelling at each other.
An obituary on Friday about the actress Sada Thompson misidentified the character she played in a 1977 television production of ''Our Town.'' It was Mrs. Gibbs, not Mrs. Webb.

DVOSKIN--Dr. Samuel, passed away on May 4 at the age of 94 after a brief illness. Sam carried a love of nature with him throughout his life and still had his well-worn, annotated botanical books near him when he died. He was born in New York City, graduated from City College and Columbia Medical School and became a medical researcher. He recalled barely surviving a bout of Rat Bite fever during those years. He served a stint as a Medical Doctor in the army. During that time he met and married his life-long partner, Leila Mitchell. After the Army he joined the Pack Medical Group as a Diagnostician. He retired from active medical practice in the 1970's but in later years worked for a time for the New York State Department of Health as an investigator. Throughout these years he engaged in what he might have considered his "real" career as a naturalist and botanist. His knowledge was deep and his excitement for the natural world never waned. He was closely involved with the New York Botanical Gardens, serving as a docent, giving tours and sharing his love of the plant world. A wonderful profile of Sam by Caroline Dworin appeared in The New York Times on August 15, 2008. It can be found here: http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/17/nyregion/thecity/17walk.html. Sam is survived by his sister Carolyn Banton Finfer of Commack, NY, his niece, Isabel Banton Clowe of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, and his nephews, Jon Banton and Drew Banton, both of Boston, MA. He is also survived by his brother-in-law, Howard Mitchell, of Arizona, and several great-nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the New York Botanical Gardens in the Bronx at a date to be determined.
WINTER--Marvin S. We remember you each day with love. Your Family

After a six-month process the Tribune Company has announced the appointment of a new president and chief executive. On Friday, the struggling media company, home to some of the country's biggest newspapers, announced that Eddy Hartenstein, the publisher and chief executive of The Los Angeles Times, had been appointed to the position. Mr. Hartenstein will continue to serve the Times as its chief executive and publisher and will be joined by Kathy Thomson, who was appointed to a new position of president and chief operating officer at the paper.

The National Education Association took a major step on Friday toward becoming the first labor union to formally endorse President Obama's re-election bid, announcing that its political action committee approved a recommendation for the union to back Mr. Obama and for its 3.2 million members to vote for him. The move by the nation's largest union will inevitably be followed by other unions endorsing Mr. Obama, whose campaign hopes that organized labor will be a crucial component in his re-election effort, especially in pivotal swing states like Ohio, Wisconsin, Missouri, Indiana and Pennsylvania.

9:17 p.m. | Updated | Dissatisfied by the first ratings report cards for OWN, Oprah Winfrey and her business partner, Discovery Communications, said on Friday that they had dismissed the four-month-old channel's chief executive, Christina Norman. Peter Liguori, the chief operating officer for Discovery Communications, will take over OWN through at least the end of the year. His assignment is formidable: to lure more viewers to a fledgling channel that most people cannot easily find on their cable systems and to manage the introduction for its two most anticipated programs, one featuring Ms. Winfrey and one featuring Rosie O'Donnell.Mr. Liguori indicated in an interview that he would try to amp up the entertainment value of OWN's programs without losing sight of Ms. Winfrey's live-your-best-life principles. ''I think you're going to see more joy on the network,'' he said. Ms. Winfrey and David Zaslav, the chief executive of Discovery, preached patience in the months preceding the Jan. 1 introduction of OWN: The Oprah Winfrey Network, which is built around the supremely valuable Oprah brand. But both have been disappointed by the low ratings for the channel's mix of feel-good reality shows, talk shows and films. On a total day basis, OWN is barely outperforming the channel it replaced, Discovery Health, despite hundreds of million of dollars of investment.

An obituary on Friday about the playwright, screenwriter and director Arthur Laurents misstated the year he won the first of his three Tony Awards, for ''Hallelujah, Baby!'' It was 1968, not 1967. The obituary also misstated the name of the Brooklyn high school he attended. It is Erasmus Hall, not Erasmus.

House Speaker John A. Boehner will nominate the Rev. Patrick J. Conroy, a Jesuit priest and former Georgetown University chaplain, to become the 60th House chaplain. ''We are honored that Father Conroy has agreed to serve as House chaplain,'' Mr. Boehner said in a statement announcing the decision. ''His dedication to God's work, commitment to serving others and experience working with people of faith from all traditions will make him an asset to the House community.''

The narrative of the Civil War revolves around the metaphor of neighbor against neighbor, brother against brother. But in the mountains of the Upper South, this was no metaphor: counties, towns and even families split between the two sides, and then set upon each other with gruesome fury in one of the bloodiest - and least understood - theaters of the war.

On May 5, the historian Ellen Schrecker of Yeshiva University gave back an honorary degree she had received from John Jay College because the playwright Tony Kushner had been denied the same honor by the CUNY Board of Trustees.  At the urging of a trustee who objected to Kushner’s  views on Israel, the nomination, which had been forwarded by the faculty and administration of John Jay, was tabled.  (Kushner had been informed of the impending honor.)

I'm convinced that the United States will be better off keeping existing nuclear power stations running, where their management can be demonstrated to be reliable, rather than initiating a decades-long decommissioning process that would not resolve community concerns about spent fuel and many other sources of risk.

Back in the olden days of photography - maybe 10 years ago - you carefully picked the film you used because it contributed as much to the look of your images as lighting or a lens filter. Each film had it own distinctive grain, color and contrast. If you wanted eye-popping greens for scenery, Fuji Velvia 50 was the stuff. Flattering skin tones? Kodak Portra. The list goes on.

Ironic or not, the singer-songwriter Alanis Morissette does not welcome rain or clouds this Mother's Day. The Los Angeles-based mother is looking forward to repeating her family's one-year-old Mother's Day tradition of picnicking with snacks on the beach and nestling in a hammock with her husband, Mario Treadway, and son, Ever Imre, also known as "lil' man." She may be "new to the momma gang," as she calls it, but Morissette isn't opposed to enjoying every minute of her son and the holiday's perks. On her wish list? A Gracious Home picnic basket, Lainey blanket and beach bag from Heather Heron for the family's beach excursion and a Loup Charmant slip dress. Older traditions die hard. "I always sing 'Happy Mother's Day' to my mom in the tune of 'Happy birthday,' " Morissette says. "It's a sweet little offering-a thank you for having me."

I recently received a panicked text from a friend who had bumped into his handsome crush on the street, an unrequited love interest who had stood him up after the two made plans for a casual date. He wanted to know what he should do. I hastily tapped out a reply. I tried to send “RUNNNNNN!” which my phone mistook for “SEEEEEEEEEEEEEE” and I accidentally sent that instead. My poor friend sent back a frantic “HUH!?” and I had to send a handful more to clarify and calm him down.

As the Romans expanded their territory and conquered the Mediterranean, they, in turn, were captivated by the portraiture of their subjugated peoples. Images of private citizens, politicians and philosophers in Etruria (what is now central Italy) and Greece influenced the way the Romans portrayed themselves in their own artwork. These external factors were blended with local traditions and gave birth to a portraiture style that was uniquely Roman.

BRODIE--M. Scott, Banker, died on Wednesday at his home in Charlotte, NC after a battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was 78. He will be profoundly missed by his family, friends and colleagues in both the New York and Charlotte financial communities. Survived by his wife of 40 years, Roberta Jane Brodie. Predeceased by his first wife, Gloria Sherman Brodie. Loving father of John Sherman Brodie of Manhattan. Devoted stepfather to Stephen Symmes of West Palm Beach, FL and Jay Symmes of Atlanta. Adored "Grandpa Scott" to Nicholas and Alexandra Brodie as well as Christopher, Amanda and Emily Symmes. Born and raised in New York City, Mr. Brodie graduated from Poly Prep Country Day School, the University of Vermont and the University of Virginia School of Law. He worked at Manufacturers Hanover, Merrill Lynch and Thomson McKinnon Securities before becoming a trust and investment officer at Virginia National Bank in Charlottesville. and The Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. He spent the final twenty years of his career in the trust department of Bank of America in Charlotte, NC from which he retired as a senior vice president. In addition to his career in finance, Mr. Brodie served his country in the U.S. Army. He entered military service on October 26, 1954 as an enlisted man. He earned his commission in the U.S. Army in October 1960. Captain Brodie retired from the U.S. Army Reserve in December 1992. He enjoyed movies, fine restaurants, travel, walking his Cairn terriers, and playing racquet sports at the various clubs he belonged to including The Princeton Club of New York, Farmington Country Club, and the Charlotte Indoor Tennis Club. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Virginia Alumni Fund.

People who know food know that Singapore is a top culinary destination, with its variety of hawker food stalls and abundant seafood. For those unfamiliar with the flavors of the city-state and having no plans to visit, just wait -- Singapore might come to you. It is sending some of its top chefs, along with a pop-up kitchen, on a yearlong journey around the world, as part of the Singapore Takeout project. Started last month in Singapore, the kitchen will visit nine cities -- London, Paris, Moscow, New York, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Delhi, Dubai and Sydney -- with one of the chefs in tow.

ALTCHEK--Dr. Albert. Dr. Albert Altchek, 85, passed away on May 2. He was a world-renowned professor and author of textbooks and articles on obstetrics, gynecology and reproductive science. He was a founding father of research in the field and Chief of Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine attending there for over 50 years. Teaching medicine was the overwhelming passion of his life. He practiced medicine without regard for monetary reward, and often stated that for him the patient's well being was sufficient reward for his labors. He published nearly 200 research papers in various medical journals over his 63 years as a practicing physician. For the last ten years, he served as Editor in Chief, in collaboration with his dear friend and colleague Dr. Liane Deligdisch in authoring seven medical text books. Sweden recognized him as a groundbreaking thought leader in advancing the possibility of uterine transplant. Mexico elected him, in recognition of his groundbreaking research, as the Honorary President of the Mexican Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. He was a true renaissance man with interests that ran the gamut from pre-Columbian art to music and photography. He was a wealth of knowledge in all areas of history, science and current events, sharing his stories with all his family and friends. He was son of the late Solomon and Blanche Altchek, beloved husband of the late Miriam Altchek, loving brother of Rita Angel, the late Dr. Martin Altchek and Olga Karasik,. Loved as uncle to Nicole Wachter, Spencer Angel, Dr. David Altchek, Dr. Pamela Karasik and David Karasik and great-uncle to Michael and Matthew Wachter, Sophia and Joshua Angel, Charles, Christopher, Chloe and Sophie Altchek.

An article on April 24 about wedding dress designers trying to anticipate and copy the gown of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, omitted the name of the line for which Jim Hjelm designs. It is James Clifford by Mon Cheri, not Jim Hjelm. (Mr. Hjelm is no longer associated with the line that carries his name, which is owned by JLM Couture.) The article also referred incorrectly to United States laws on knockoffs of designer clothing. Clothing companies do not have to modify a design in any way before copying it.

NEW YORK CITY can seem like a mighty unpleasant place if you're trying to get into or out of the Holland Tunnel. The horns, the gridlock and the crush of cars competing for fewer and fewer lanes -- it is easy to wonder who would live amid such madness in the northern reaches of TriBeCa. What misery it must be for those poor apartment dwellers.

BROWN--Patricia Anne Meegan, 82, beloved mother and grandmother, died after a brief illness on May 4 in Sarasota, FL. Born in the Bronx, educated at the Academy of Mt. St. Ursula and Our Lady of Good Counsel College, she married Walter J. Brown, Jr. in 1951 and they raised their four children in Westchester Co. She was predeceased by her one and only love in 1983 and since then divided her time between homes in Bronxville, NY and Siesta Key, FL. She had strong and lasting friendships in both places. In lieu of flowers, the family invites donations to Mt. St. Ursula, 330 Bedford Park Blvd, Bronx NY, 10458. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, May 9 at 11am at the Church of St. Joseph, 15 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY.

GENERAL MOTORS is recalling all of its 2011 Chevrolet Cruze compact sedans to check for a steering problem and a condition in which the automatic transmission can appear to be in Park, but may still be in gear. In a telephone interview Wednesday, Alan Adler, a G.M. spokesman, said the steering recall covered about 129,000 vehicles in the United States. The action also covers about 25,000 vehicles built for the Canadian market.

Roach, who will be the director of boxing strategy, said he had always dreamed of winning an Olympic medal. The former heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield, 48, stopped Brian Nielsen of Denmark on a technical knockout in the 10th round in Copenhagen. (AP)

Alabama HANGOUT MUSIC FESTIVAL Gulf Shores, May 20-22. Anyone looking to combine two timeless summer pastimes -- beach lounging and festivalgoing -- will be well served by the Hangout Music Festival, which sets up on Alabama's white sand gulf shore for three days each summer. A boon for the less rustic among us (''Shed the mud boots and sleeping bags and wake up each morning from a fully equipped condo,'' its Web site suggests), the lineup includes Paul Simon, Foo Fighters, Widespread Panic, the Black Keys, the Flaming Lips, My Morning Jacket, Cee-Lo Green, the Avett Brothers, Girl Talk, Primus and Ween. hangoutmusicfest.com.

An article last Sunday about a study on liposuction that found that fat returned within about a year of being removed misstated the average amount of fat removed from study participants. It was about 5.8 pounds, not a pound.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Archarcharch was pulled up past the finish line of the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday after fracturing his left front leg. The injury was not life-threatening, according to an on-call veterinarian, Dr. Larry Bramlage.''He's in no distress at all,'' Bramlage said. ''He walked right on the ambu- lance. He was lame when he pulled up, but it wasn't a situation where he was in that much trouble.''The colt's rider, Jon Court, said Archarcharch, the Arkansas Derby champion, never took to the track after breaking from the No. 1 hole. Archar- charch was sent off at odds of 9-1 and trailed the field throughout the race. When Court asked the late runner for his kick, it was not there. He passed a cou- ple of tiring horses down the stretch to finish 15th. Court, 50, was making his Derby debut aboard a horse trained by another Derby rookie, his father-in-law, Jinks Fires. He pulled Archarcharch up immediately.''He had never felt like that under- neath me, so I had the vet take him back as a precaution,'' Court said.Comma on the Top, the last-place fin- isher, chipped an ankle, according to his trainer, Peter Miller. ''He's got to go to the sidelines for at least 60 days,'' Miller said. ''This isn't the end of the world.'' GET STORMY WINS WOODFORD Get Stormy led all the way Saturday in the $576,000 Woodford Reserve Turf Classic, the main event on the Kentucky Derby undercard at Churchill Downs.Get Stormy, a 5-year-old trained by Tom Bush, held off Smart Bid by three- quarters of a length for his second straight Grade 1 victory. Get Stormy won the Makers Mark Stakes at Keene- land in his previous outing. Ramon Dominguez was aboard for the one and one-eighth miles in 1 minute 50.81 sec- onds. Get Stormy earned his 10th win in 22 starts, paying $17 on a $2 bet to win.Other undercard winners were Aike- nite in the $348,900 Churchill Downs Stakes, Aviate in the $227,800 ChurchillDistaff Turf Mile, Sassy Image in the$345,600 Humana Distaff for fillies andmares, and Regally Ready in the $111,200 Twin Spires Turf Sprint. (AP)

BALK--Phyllis, former resident of Manhattan, died peacefully at age 81 on May 4, 2011. She was born Phyllis Lorraine Munter in Moline, IL on December 27, 1929 to Fritz and Alma (Eldean) Munter, both of Swedish heritage. Mrs. Balk graduated from Moline High School in 1948 and received her RN from Presbyterian-St. Luke's School of Nursing in Chicago in 1951. Upon graduation she served as an occupational health nurse for Deere & Company in Moline. After marriage to journalist Alfred Balk on June 7, 1952, she returned to Chicago, where she served as clinic head nurse and emergency room head nurse at Presbyterian-St. Luke's. During their 58-year marriage, the couple lived in Chicago, IL, Evanston, IL, New York, NY, Katonah, NY, Syracuse, NY, and Huntley, IL. Mrs. Balk was known in all these communities for her volunteer work and quiet activism, as well as her excellent cooking and extraordinary kindness. In New York City she served as PTA President of Hunter College High School during a critical time in the school's life, when it was threatened with closure due to lack of public funds. She led the high school community in a successful march on City Hall which was highlighted by Geraldo Rivera on local television news. She was also active in Girl Scouts, helping foreign immigrants settle in the U.S. and a beloved member of Park Avenue Methodist Church. In 1975, she joined Manufacturer's Hanover bank (now part of Chase) as an occupational health nurse, retiring in 1991, when her husband joined the faculty of Syracuse University's Newhouse School. She resumed long-deferred study towards a Bachelor's Degree, and in 1997, at age 67, became the oldest alumna in nursing of the State University of New York's Upstate Medical University. The school used a photo of Mrs. Balk in cap and gown with her young granddaughter on the cover of its brochures for several years. She and her husband moved to Huntley, IL in 1999 and visited New York City several times a year to visit friends and see Broadway plays. The couple had a happy partnership until his death on Thanksgiving Day in 2010. Mrs. Balk served as an important support throughout her husband's distinguished career, as indicated in Balk's scholarly papers in the collections of the Newberry Library in Chicago and Syracuse University. She is survived by two daughters, Laraine Balk Hope of Rockville, MD and Diane Balk Palguta of Indianapolis, IN, two grandchildren, Anna and Andrew Palguta, and first cousins Herb, Roger, and Judy Eldean of Macatawa, MI. A Memorial service will be held at 11:00 a.m. on Friday, May 20th at the First Congregational Church of Huntley, 11628 E. Main Street, Huntley, IL. Contributions can be sent to the Huntley Area Public Library Friends Foundation, 11000 Ruth Road, Huntley, IL 60142, the First Congregational Church of Huntley, Hospice and Palliative Care of Northeastern Illinois, 405 Lake Zurich Road, Barrington, IL 60010 or your local hospice organization. For further information, please contact DeFiore Jorgensen Funeral Home at 847-515-8772 or www.defiorejorgensen.com.

In Fort Wayne, Ind., fans root for the snarling apple logo of the Tin Caps, in honor of Johnny Appleseed. In Las Vegas, home of the 51s, folks cheer for an alien with a baseball-shaped head. A bear with a suitcase once promoted the Asheville (N.C.) Tourists, who now use a smiling moon wearing sunglasses. But for pure logo wackiness, we present the Wilmington (Del.) Blue Rocks. It is old news to frequent visitors of Frawley Stadium, but for those who have never been, the story of Mr. Celery is too amusing not to share. As the team broadcaster John Sadak wrote in an e-mail, ''More casual fans know the Blue Rocks for Mr. Celery over anything else.''

SLIDING doors. Charging stations for mobile devices. Reading lights. Even passenger air bags. The Nissan NV200 van, a light commercial vehicle already in use in Asia and Europe, has won New York City's Taxi of Tomorrow competition, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Tuesday.

CHIARA--Marco, friend, father and grandfather passed away peacefully in Milan, Italy on May 1st, 2011 with many of his friends and family at his side. Marco, the son of Jula Scherb and Piero Chiara was born in Zurich Switzerland on July 7, 1937. He was predeceased by his ex-wife and best friend Judy Chiara. Marco's compassion and insight, love and acceptance were a source of great joy to both friends and family. In addition to his friends, his loss will be felt by his beloved companion Jaia, his children, Daniela, Charlie, and John, their siblings, Richard, Frances, Anne, Nancy, Susan, his grandchildren, Julian, Lucas, Sophie, Aliana, Karma and by all of the members of the vast family to which he belonged and to whose lives he brought a light that will be sorely missed.

There are theme parks tied to movie studios and there are theme cruises, and now, the themed hotel stay. The Gaylord hotel company has teamed up with DreamWorks to feature ani- mated characters at its four re- sorts, in Nashville, Tenn., Kis- simme, Fla., National Harbor, Md., and Grapevine, Tex., the company that owns the hotels an- nounced recently.The characters -- including those from ''Shrek,'' ''Kung Fu Panda'' and ''Madagascar'' -- will interact with hotel guests at breakfasts, during parades and during poolside activities. The of- ferings, called ''DreamWorks Ex- perience at Gaylord Hotels,'' will also augment the hotels' already substantial holiday programs, which have in the past featured intricate landscapes of carved ice and real snow (even at its Texas and Florida resorts). And if guests want to buy merchandise after hobnobbing or seeing Shrek at a show, themed trinkets will be on sale as well.The first packages go on sale in July for programming in Novem- ber, when the holiday events will have their debut.MONICA DRAKE

ARONIN--Kevin J.,beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend died suddenly on Wednesday, May 4th at his vacation home in Pontoon, County Mayo, Ireland. Kevin was born in New York City on August 23, 1954. A brilliant businessman and foresighted entrepreneur, he had a knack for creating something from nothing, a relentless drive for success and unbeatable instincts. Most recently, he founded PlasmaNet, Inc. in 1999 and its FreeLotto website, capitalizing on the promise of internet entertainment early in its heyday. Charity was his passion. He was guided by the concept of noblesse oblige the obligation to make the best of an individual's gifts and skills in order to better the world we live in. With each success in business, he was determined to contribute to the greater good. He was a notable philanthropist who supported many charities over his lifetime. He enjoyed learning about other cultures and had a particular soft spot for immigrants seeking the American Dream. He had a charisma that made him the life of any party and a natural leader. Kevin was at his best when he was cooking and entertaining for others, finding the greatest joy in feeding people and putting smiles on their faces. He was a gifted storyteller and teacher, and had a seemingly endless supply of funny jokes, which he loved to share with his friends and family. He read all three New York papers every day, and he could never seem to satisfy his thirst for knowledge. He is survived by his wife Anne; his four children, Shannon, Sean, Caitlin, and Lauren; his adopted son, Kevin Wong; his son-in-law, Edward Eppright; his dearly loved and only grandson, Eamon Eppright; his siblings, Michael, Patricia, and Nancy; and his uncle, Howard Aronin. He also leaves behind his Newfoundland, Duke, whom Kevin considered his sixth child. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues, but he would rather his life be celebrated. Visiting hours at the Lloyd Maxcy Funeral Home, 16 Shea Place, New Rochelle, NY 10801 will be on Sunday, May 08, 2011 from 7pm-9pm, Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial will be held at Blessed Sacrament Church at 10.30am on Tuesday, May 10, 2011. Interment immediately following Mass. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to HOPE Community Services, 50 Washington Ave., New Rochelle, NY 10801 is appreciated.

After Sept. 11, it took nearly a decade to locate and kill Osama bin Laden, perhaps giving the nation, and especially the families of those lost in the attacks, some sense of closure. It will take much longer than that to heal the gaping wound in the Lower Manhattan cityscape. Blame politics, finances, legalities and the challenge of making the many compromises necessary for such an enormous reconstruction effort. But after spending much time on cleanup and foundation work, progress is ever more visible: The soaring 1 World Trade Center and another skyscraper are rising by about one floor per week; a spacious memorial is to open on the 10th anniversary of the attack this fall.

COLUMBIA, S.C. - A week after resigning his post as ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. made his debut on the American political stage here on Saturday and defended his service in the Obama administration as he began exploring whether to join the Republican presidential race. A commencement speech at the University of South Carolina provided a backdrop for Mr. Huntsman to introduce himself as a leader who rose above partisanship when answering President Obama's call to represent the United States in Beijing. He said public service was a central tenet of patriotism.

WALSH--Dr. James P.,a leading American Colonial Historian, passed away on March 10, 2011 at the age of 75. Dr. Walsh was a Professor Emeritus from Central Connecticut State University, where he taught Early American History from 1965 to 1996. After earning his doctorate from Columbia University in 1961, he taught at Brooklyn College from 1961 to 1965. Jim published frequently in his field of Colonial American History, having essays published in the William and Mary Quarterly, the American Quarterly, the Connecticut Historical Society Bulletin, Connecticut History, and two monographs commissioned by the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission of Connecticut. Jim also published outside of his academic field in The Hedgemaster, the newsletter of the Irish Cultural Society. His literary side can be discovered in his story "Sherlock Holmes at Lourdes" published by the Baker Street Irregulars. Jim's imagination and quest for knowledge had a Holmesian component to it throughout his active and worthy life. He is survived by his daughter Carolyn Walsh Parry, Esq. (Vincent), his sister Mary Walsh Lally (Richard), his brothers John (Joan) and Joseph (Deborah) and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife Anna. Donations can be made in his honor to The Oak Hill School for blind and disabled children ciboakhill.org.

EDDY--George A. Jr.,90. Eddy was a Navy Lieutenant and Corsair fighter pilot in WWII, an avid racing sailor, New York Yacht Club member, and Publisher of Sailing World magazine. He authored four books, including FLY BOY. Survived and beloved by his wife Kay, his children George, Ellary, and David, and his grandchildren Trevor, Eliza, Isabelle, Odile, Anders, and Anneli. George Eddy was a true original.

THE NEWS A team of scientists who spent 52 years and $750 million on an experiment said the results agreed with Einstein's general relativity theory. BEHIND THE NEWS The experiment involved putting two gyroscopes made of superconducting spheres of niobium into orbit to detect a slight sag and an even slighter twist in space, caused by Earth's gravity and rotation. When the project, the most direct measurement so far of the effects Einstein predicted, was conceived in 1959, no one had the technology to pull it off. The device was launched in 2004, and analyzing the data took years.

MAGAZINE The cover article this weekend, on Page 38, about the disappearance of Air France Flight 447 in 2009, makes several references to unrecovered data cylinders from the plane's black boxes. Beloved son of the late Franziska and Walter Petschek, beloved brother of the late Stephen Petschek and of Susan Petschek, devoted uncle of Jennifer and Alexandra Petschek, and great-uncle of William Baskerville Robson. An article last Sunday about the Memphis Grizzlies' success- ful playoff run three years after making a much-maligned trade misstated Shane Battier's history with the franchise. Battier is the only player on the Grizzlies' cur- rent roster to have played for the team in 2001, its first season in Memphis after moving from Vancouver; he is not the lone member of the team to have played with the organization in Vancouver. (Battier was drafted by the Grizzlies in 2001 the week before the move to Memphis received the final approval from the N.B.A.; he never played for the team in Vancouver.)

An article last Sunday in the Summer Movies section about Kenneth Branagh, the director of the new ''Thor'' movie, misstated the job title of Kevin Feige. He is president of Marvel Studios, which controls the movie rights to the film, not its president of production.

IN the last week I've been in the South of France for the Hyères Fashion Festival and in San Francisco to meet students at the Academy of Art University, with a stop in New York for the opening of the Alexander McQueen exhibition. What links these places is not just fashion, but the design process itself and how the ideas of designers evolve over time. That evolution is one of the pleasures of Andrew Bolton's selections for the McQueen show, especially in the tailoring choices. It was inspiring to see how his cutting methods changed over his career, yet how certain assumptions remained fixed. One of the most rewarding and maddening of these assumptions is that design is a learning process. And Mr. McQueen always wanted to learn.
Art Roberta Smith

NATIONAL An article last Sunday about the Obama administration's search for the next director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation misstated the current employer of a potential candidate, James B. Comey, a former deputy attorney general. He works for the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates, not Lockheed Martin. The article also misstated the political affiliation of another potential candidate, Raymond W. Kelly, the New York City police commissioner. While Mr. Kelly was a Treasury Department official during the Clinton administration, he is registered as an independent voter, not as a Democrat.

As reporting opportunities go, few can have been more spectacularly flubbed than the one that came my way on a long-ago spring day in the former Northwest Frontier Province of Pakistan. The year was 1989; the location a cramped room at a ramshackle indoctrination camp for Arab militants in the hinterland outside Peshawar, the frontier town that was a staging area for the mujahedeen who forced Soviet troops to withdraw from Afghanistan earlier that year. At the back, in a corner, sat a tall, straggly-bearded man in his early 30s, silent, taut-faced, and plainly, by his body language, deeply upset by a reporter's intrusion. His name, I learned later from an officer of Pakistan's military intelligence agency, the Directorate of Inter-Services Intelligence, was Osama bin Laden. I never spoke to him that day, on what proved to be the only firsthand sighting I would have of the man whose terrorist murderousness -- and success for so long in eluding history's biggest manhunt -- was to recast the story of our time.

WOOD--J. Austen Flint, born September 17, 1922 in Rotherham, England died on April 6 in Tryon, NC. During the Second World War, he was commissioned in the Royal Navy Fleet Air Arm and served as one of the youngest carrier-based fighter pilots and production test pilots. During his business career in marketing, he traveled throughout the world often to Japan, Russia and Europe. He is survived by daughters Rowena Wood of New York and Nicola Edwards of London, grandchildren Lindsey, Romaine and Lauren and great-grandchildren Laila and Rufus. Memorial Service to be held on June 9, 2011 at 11:00am, in New York at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue.

GORELICK--Leonard, D.D.S.,died on May 5, after a long illness. He had combined a career in dentistry with a passion for science and art to make significant contributions in the study of technologies used to make ancient seals and other objects. An article in the New York Times, in 1981, described Dr. Gorelick's work as "shedding light on how ancient man transformed stones into works of art and instruments of commerce." Born in 1922, he emigrated to the United States from Ukraine with his family as a very young child, settling in Brooklyn, New York. He attended Tilden High School and graduated from Brooklyn College in 1942. Then, he served in the Navy in both World War II and the Korean War. Dr. Gorelick received his D.D.S. and Postgraduate Certificate in Orthodontics from New York University College of Dentistry. In 1944, Len Gorelick married Shirley Fishman. They had two children, Jamie Gorelick, a Washington, D.C. lawyer and a former Deputy Attorney General of the United States, and Steven Gorelick, the Cyrus F. Tolman Professor at Stanford University. Shirley Gorelick was an artist a painter, sculptor and teacher and much of their life together involved the making and appreciation of art. Dr. Gorelick combined his interest in the scientific aspects of orthodonture especially, electron microscopy - with his love for and interest in ancient cylinder seals, in which he became quite expert. He eventually built one of the world's finest collections of seals, celebrated in a book called "The Mark of Ancient Man: Ancient Near Eastern Stamp Seals and Cylinder Seals: The Gorelick Collection", which accompanied a show of that name at The Brooklyn Museum. These seals are now part of the collection of the Royal Ontario Museum. He was often consulted by scholars and served on the Visiting Committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Ancient Near East Department. He co-authored "Ancient Seals and the Bible" as well as over forty-five scholarly papers on techniques that can be used to date and explain ancient seals and other artifacts. They are collected in the Special Collections and University Archives at Stony Brook. Dr. Gorelick also edited the Journal of the Queens County Dental Society and was President of the Society. He was the long-time editor of the Forum of the Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, with which he was affiliated, and became Associate Professor in the Department of Children's Dentistry (Orthodontics) at Stony Brook School of Dental Medicine. Dr. Gorelick's wife, Shirley, died in 2000. He leaves his sister, Beatrice, her husband Leonard, and their children Anne, Richard and Scott. He was a loving father and father-in-law of Jamie Gorelick, Dr. Richard Waldhorn, Steven Gorelick and Stephanie Knott, and he was the proud and affectionate grandfather of artist Alyssa Gorelick (and her husband, Max Warsh) and Daniel and Dana Waldhorn, all of whom brought him great joy. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Shirley Gorelick Fund at the National Museum for Women in the Arts.

LAURENTS--Arthur, died May 5, 2011 after a brief illness in his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Born in Flatbush, Brooklyn on July 14, 1917, he graduated from Cornell University and was a resident of Greenwich Village, New York and Quogue, Long Island. He spent 52 extraordinary years with Tom Hatcher, his beloved companion, who died in 2006. A giant both on Broadway and in films, Laurents had written countless plays, musicals and screenplays. Among his Broadway credits are the books for the musicals "West Side Story," "Gypsy," "Anyone Can Whistle," "Do I Hear A Waltz?" and "Hallelujah, Baby!" He directed the original Broadway production of "La Cage Aux Folles" in 1983 and enormously successful revivals of "Gypsy" (three times) and "West Side Story." A partial list of his plays includes "Home of the Brave" (his 1945 Broadway debut), "The Time of the Cuckoo," "A Clearing In The Woods," "Invitation To A March," and "Jolson Sings Again." Highlights of his screenwriting career include "Rope," "The Turning Point," "Anastasia" and "The Way We Were." He received three Tony Awards (all for Best Direction of a Musical) for his work on Broadway as well as five Academy Award nominations. In 2000, Laurents published an acclaimed autobiography, "Original Story By Arthur Laurents: A Memoir of Broadway and Hollywood," and in 2009 republished Mainly On Directing: "Gypsy," "West Side Story" and Other Musicals. He will be remembered not only as having one of the most extraordinary careers in contemporary history, but for his fierce beliefs and fierce personal convictions. In 2010, he created the Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award to be given annually to a deserving young playwright. He is survived by a niece and nephew. Donations may be made to The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation 608 Northville Turnpike, Riverhead, New York 11901.

CARRICK--Elizabeth Bates Born in Summit, NJ. on October 27, 1913, to Captain Guy and Anne Greene Bates. She graduated from the Kent Place School in 1931. She spent one year at the University of Arizona where she was a member of Kappa Kappa Gamma and graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1936 with a major in History. She taught lipreading at the Nitchie School for the Hard of Hearing in New York as well as at the New Brunswick Adult School. She married Alan W. Carrick in 1939 and moved to Princeton, NJ. She was active in the Girl Scouts of America, locally and nationally, for over 25 years. She was a member of both the Garden Club of Princeton and the Garden Club of America. She was on the Altar Guild of Trinity Church of Princeton, a member of the Washington Association of New Jersey and a trustee of the Rockingham Foundation in Rocky Hill. She was also a member of the Colonial Dames of America, the New Jersey Historical Society and a lifetime member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She died April 10, 2011 and is survived by her son, Rob, of Ouray, Colorado, and two grandsons, Devin, of New York City and Shane, of Fort de France, Martinique. She was 97 years old.

(13) BEARS OF THE LAST FRONTIER In this special three-part edition, ''Nature'' rides along as Chris Morgan, an adventurer and ecologist, takes a yearlong motorcycle odyssey through five different ecosystems in Alaska -- coastal, urban, mountain, tundra and pack ice -- and explores the uncanny resiliency and adaptability of the state's bears. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY The topic on the news program circuit this morning is the death of Osama bin Laden. Thomas E. Donilon, President Obama's national security adviser, will be a guest, joined by Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the secretary general of NATO. Mr. Donilon is also scheduled to appear with former Vice President Dick Cheney on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; with former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Husain Haqqani, the Pakistani ambassador to the United States, on ''This Week with Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC; and with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC. The discussion continues on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, with Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. An excerpt from Steve Kroft's interview with President Obama on ''60 Minutes,'' at 7 p.m., will also be broadcast.

Known primarily for its dreadlocked denizens and enormous warehouse nightclubs, Berlin's Friedrichshain district has lately developed a reputation as a retail destination. Chain stores are few and far between, but a growing number of offbeat independent shops sell their wares for prices much lower than those found in more polished city center neighborhoods. Most of the action happens around Boxhagener Platz, a park that hosts a popular farmers' market on Saturdays and an excellent flea market on Sundays. And the area's night-life scene is still thriving; stores often stay open until 8 p.m., catering to a crowd that may have stayed out late the night before. RACHEL B. DOYLE

Here's a sampling of readers' responses to Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott's column about the growing number of girls and young women playing cold-blooded killers in action movies. The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from April 29 to May 5. 1. DAVE DUERSON FOUND TO HAVE THE BRAIN TRAUMA HE SUSPECTED The former Bear shot himself in the chest rather than the head, presumably so his brain could be examined. (Published May 2)

In the global race to erect iconic structures that command attention and therefore tourists, the city of Seville, Spain, recently opened the Metropol Parasol, an inventive wooden canopy of six interconnected parasols, built using fire-treated wooden beams. The Berlin-based architect Jürgen Mayer H., who is 45, designed the open-air structure after winning an international competition with his stated intention to build a ''cathedral without walls,'' which he proposed situating amid the Plaza de la Encarnación's preserved Roman ruins. An air-conditioned interior market bustling with fishmongers and meat and produce vendors is open for business, as are restaurants, concessions stands, shops and a podium for concerts and events. It's still too early to tell whether the Metropol Parasol's growing renown will help revitalize a struggling local economy, but it has succeeded on one count: it is making headlines. Years under construction: 2005 to 2011

AT 8 in the morning, I expected some old woman to be working behind the counter of the pharmacy -- the kind of person who usually gets up at 6 a.m. anyway. Instead, there was a young guy in tight jeans and one of those faux-ethnic kaffiyeh scarves. I thought about how cold it wasn't inside the pharmacy. When he asked me if I needed anything, I stepped aside to let my girlfriend, Sam, walk up to the counter. ''Yeah, a morning-after pill?'' she said.

An article on March 20 about the four limited-production Pike cars that Nissan once sold in Japan misstated their size classification there. They are not kei cars, which are lighter and less powerful models exempt from some Japanese taxes and regulations. Larger cars, including the Pike models, are not eligible for such benefits. A reader pointed out the mistake in March; this correction was delayed for research and by an editing lapse.

DURING the week, he was a taciturn and dark-suited auditor from Queens, a son of Swedish immigrants, who toiled at a bank and suffered from a respiratory injury sustained during a mustard gas attack in World War I. But come the weekend, Frank Oscar Larson would shed all that. He woke at dawn every Sunday and set off from his home in Flushing to Chinatown, Hell's Kitchen, Times Square and Coney Island, among other New York locales, armed with his favorite Rolleiflex camera and a keen eye for finding the lyrical in the prosaic.

PHILADELPHIA - The Philadelphia Phillies led the Washington Nationals by a run in the seventh inning last Tuesday at Citizens Bank Park. Shane Victorino hit a leadoff single, and Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel called for a hit-and-run. He knew he could trust the hitter, Placido Polanco. As Victorino broke for second, Polanco dug out a low pitch and advanced him with a groundout to the pitcher. Ryan Howard then drove in the run with a single , and the Phillies went on to win. Polanco went hitless, but as usual, he had made an important contribution.
Film Neil Genzlinger

NIEDERMAN--Susan. Born in Czechoslovakia, she survived concentration camp to emigrate to the United States in 1946, at age 17. While raising three children she worked her way through a high school equivalency and both college and master's degrees to become a teacher extraordinaire at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, where she dedicated herself tirelessly for 21 years. Susan joins Leslie her beloved husband of 58 years (founding partner of Fischer Bros & Leslie), leaving behind heartbroken children Steven, Marcy and Mark and their spouses Carolyn, Paul and Gail. Adored grandmother of Talia, Zachary, Janine, Cory, Alexis, Lisa, and Jacob. Her nurturing, guidance, friendship and love will be missed by friends, family, and all the lives she touched with kindness throughout her 82 years of life well-lived. Contributions in Susan's memory may be made to World ORT, or charities benefiting the State of Israel or Holocaust Remembrance.

For the first time in this reporter's memory, it rained on the annual luncheon of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, held on Wednesday. But the weather did not stop the nearly 1,300 guests from showing off their spring finery. Hats more than recalled the royal wedding in London, including a takeoff on Princess Beatrice's frame hat in tin foil. Some guests waved from their grand cars. The tulip garden remained empty, as guests stayed in tented walkways, although the occasional umbrellas were deftly handled. The event honored Judith-Ann Corrente (inset) and raised $3.2 million.

GUINNESS--Alma E. Beloved sister of Arthur and John, both deceased, was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1930 of parents, Alma Vestergaard Guinness and Arthur Guinness, MD. She was a graduate of Cornell University. Possessing an extraordinary way with words, Alma began her editorial career in Des Moines, Iowa, at Meredith's "Successful Farming," and immediately following, moved to Manhattan and never ventured west again. Alma's sharp wit, insightful observations and epic story-telling served her well, both within the publishing circle she worked-- Meredith, Scholastic and Reader's Digest General Books--her behind-the-scenes involvement designing and creating costumes and hats for the all-male Amateur Comedy Club and the all-female Snarks. Both theatrical troupes share space at their Sniffen Court carriage house theatre where Alma was known as "Mrs. Hat"; a reflection of her legendary hat designing prowess. Never married, Alma mentored her young co-workers into editorial slots, was a keepsake-quality letter-writer, and would quote poetry with the best of them. Alma Guinness will be sorely missed. Three of the many titles Miss Guinness edited for Reader's Digest were "The Joy of Nature," "America A to Z" and "Mysteries of the Bible". In her latter years, Alma could often be found perusing a volume of one of her favorite books, the Oxford English Dictionary. A celebration of her life is being planned by the Snarks and The Amateur Comedy Club and will be announced.

The rain-swollen Mississippi River crested to an all-time high last week as it surged past Cairo, Ill., exceeding the 1937 record by 2 feet. Government engineers were left with two choices: Let Cairo flood or explode a levee to save the town. They blew up the levee. But while Cairo was saved, other communities may not be so lucky. ''We're going to fight this river all the way down to the Gulf of Mexico,'' said Col. Vernie L. Reichling Jr. of the Army Corps of Engineers. The battle against North America's longest river is never-ending, as The Times's Isabel Wilkerson found in 1993, another year of record flooding.

Before the Minnesota Twins' Francisco Liriano threw a no-hitter against them last week, the Chicago White Sox had not been no-hit since Bret Saberhagen stymied them on Aug. 26, 1991. The crosstown Cubs, though, have gone much longer. For all their futility, the Cubs entered the weekend having not had a no-hitter thrown against them since Sandy Koufax's perfect game on Sept. 9, 1965. Every other team has been victimized since; the Pittsburgh Pirates are next closest, without a no-hitter against them since Bob Gibson in 1971.

The Pirates' Charlie Morton was historically terrible in 2010. In 17 starts, he was 2-12 with a 7.57 earned run average . Only one other pitcher has made so many starts with an E.R.A. so high and a winning percentage so low: Ed Holley, who was 1-11 with an 8.12 E.R.A. for two teams in 1934. Holley finished that season with Pittsburgh and never played again. Morton got another chance, and he is making the most of it.

The praise continued Monday for Graham Motion, the trainer of Kentucky Derby winner, Animal Kingdom. Joe Drape in the New York Times writes that Animal Kingdom “is trained by an Englishman who has never been cited for violating a medication rule and believes a horse should be allowed to be a horse as much as possible.” Drape adds: “The trainer came to the United States 30 years ago but adheres to European principles of horsemanship. It's the creation of Playtype, a self-described "online type foundry" that was established by e-Types, a Copenhagen design agency, to showcase over 20 years of type design, including commissioned works for fonts "created out of pure passion and typographical heartache." E-Types collaborated on the project with the architecture office Bjarke Ingels Group and V1 Gallery in Copenhagen. Late last year, Playtype opened a concept store - which will operate for one year only, until Dec. 1 - in Copenhagen's trendy Vesterbro neighborhood, a former red-light district. The store's wares, which include the aforementioned T-shirt and type-adorned notebooks, wine labels and ceramic mugs, are not sold online, alas, but inquiries are invited at info@playtype.com. In 1962, Andy Warhol produced “Campbell’s Soup Cans”: 32 paintings, each representing a flavor of Campbell’s condensed soup. “With these works, Warhol took on the tradition of still-life painting, declaring a familiar household brand of packaged food a legitimate subject in the age of Post-War economic recovery,” according to Christie’s. Warhol appropriated the famous soup can and reinvented it as a work of art. He can be credited with converging the world of high art and supermarket branding, propelling the pop-art movement forward and possibly even boosting the sales of canned soup, but the label that he rode to stardom was not his design at all.

Around them were the personal items with which they had been packed: heaps of clothing, sandals, DVDs, combs, bottles of perfume, cooking utensils, razors, toothbrushes, several teapots, bundled blankets and a few biscuits, broken and dry. Every several yards a dropped suitcase rested on the dirt, looted bare.

Every season, there is inevitably one "It" item on every fashion editor's list. And you know what it is when everyone at the office turns up wearing it. This spring's entry is the Balenciaga motorcycle boot. On any given day you can be sure to find the T fashion editors Vanessa Traina and Sara Moonves, as well as the fashion associate Rae Boxer, buckled in. The boots are boyishly bulky but undeniably cool, not to mention surprisingly versatile - the perfect anchor to brightly colored socks, black tights or slouchy leather pants. Stephanie LaCava, a contributor to T, likes to wear hers with white socks with a little frill at the top for that girly/grunge effect. Anyone looking to join the gang will have to get in line, since, predictably, the boots have sold out. But you can call Balenciaga's New York store (212-206-0872) to add your name to the list. Take our word for it: they're worth the wait.

I'm imagining the "Two and a Half Men" writers these days thusly: four days without sleep, living off Ho Ho's and Coke (that's the cake and the drink, people), clumps of hair strewn on the ground. As Bill Carter reported in The Times in late April, the writers have been given less than three weeks to come up with a newish version of their hit comedy. They are no doubt under just a teensy bit of pressure to produce something with the same award-winning, ratings-generating, money-raking-in qualities as the original, while also having to abruptly write out a major character, Charlie Harper, the jingle-writing cad brother played by Charlie Sheen until he was fired by Warner Brothers in March.

It can be a bit of a buzz kill to walk into one of those cozy little “time-capsule” museums that feature the private collection of an enlightened prince or recreate life in that particular place during an earlier century, only to discover that the museum has brought in contemporary art to “dialogue” with their historical holdings. Such presentations can easily break the spell of time travel that so-called house museums typically offer, without helping the visitor appreciate or understand the art of either epoch.

This is the year that billions of dollars in government incentive payments are set to begin flowing to the nation's doctors and hospitals to encourage them to adopt computerized patient records. The goal is to help improve the quality of care and curb costs. But what about the environmental impact? Kaiser Permanente, which covers 8.7 million people in nine states and the District of Columbia, asked that question, using its own system of 454 clinics and 36 hospitals using electronic health records as its laboratory. The answer, published last Wednesday in the journal Health Affairs, is that the potential environmental benefit is to reduce carbon dioxide emissions as much as 1.7 million tons a year. That's the pollution equivalent of taking more than 300,000 cars off America's roads.

(13) SOUNDTRACK FOR A REVOLUTION ''American Experience'' chronicles the civil rights movement through the songs that protesters sang while fighting for justice and equality, from the bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., to the march on Washington. Archival footage is mixed with interviews with Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia; the singer Harry Belafonte; the social activist Julian Bond; and Andrew Young, the former mayor of Atlanta. NOGALES, Ariz. -- A group of migrants was hustling north through the southern Arizona desert the other night when one of their cellphones vibrated with a text message. ''Watch out,'' it warned. ''Things are hot up ahead. Take cover in the bushes.'' The message, signaling the presence of the Border Patrol, was sent by a smuggler watching the group's progress through binoculars from a hillside on the Mexican side of the border, members of the group said later. It was part of what border officials and immigrant activists say is an emerging trend in illegal border crossing -- the use of what is being called the cybercoyote.

LOS ANGELES -- JDate, the Web-based dating service, has been helping singles ''find friendship, romance and lifelong partners within the Jewish faith.'' It can also hook you up with a movie. On Monday, Film Movement is announcing what it calls North America's first Jewish Film-of-the-Month Club, with JDate as its sponsor. The service plans to send a new, Jewish-themed feature film on DVD and via Internet streaming to subscribers once every two months - and then monthly, when things get swinging - for an annual subscription rate of $108, or $68 for six months and $3.25 in shipping and handling costs per disc.

GORELICK--Leonard, D.D.S.,died on May 5, after a long illness. He had combined a career in dentistry with a passion for science and art to make significant contributions in the study of technologies used to make ancient seals and other objects. An article in the New York Times, in 1981, described Dr. Gorelick's work as "shedding light on how ancient man transformed stones into works of art and instruments of commerce." Born in 1922, he emigrated to the United States from Ukraine with his family as a very young child, settling in Brooklyn, New York. He attended Tilden High School and graduated from Brooklyn College in 1942. Then, he served in the Navy in both World War II and the Korean War. Dr. Gorelick received his D.D.S. and Postgraduate Certificate in Orthodontics from New York University College of Dentistry. In 1944, Len Gorelick married Shirley Fishman. They had two children, Jamie Gorelick, a Washington, D.C. lawyer and a former Deputy Attorney General of the United States, and Steven Gorelick, the Cyrus F. Tolman Professor at Stanford University. Shirley Gorelick was an artist a painter, sculptor and teacher and much of their life together involved the making and appreciation of art. Dr. Gorelick combined his interest in the scientific aspects of orthodonture especially, electron microscopy - with his love for and interest in ancient cylinder seals, in which he became quite expert. He eventually built one of the world's finest collections of seals, celebrated in a book called "The Mark of Ancient Man: Ancient Near Eastern Stamp Seals and Cylinder Seals: The Gorelick Collection", which accompanied a show of that name at The Brooklyn Museum. These seals are now part of the collection of the Royal Ontario Museum. He was often consulted by scholars and served on the Visiting Committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Ancient Near East Department. He co-authored "Ancient Seals and the Bible" as well as over forty-five scholarly papers on techniques that can be used to date and explain ancient seals and other artifacts. They are collected in the Special Collections and University Archives at Stony Brook. Dr. Gorelick also edited the Journal of the Queens County Dental Society and was President of the Society. He was the long-time editor of the Forum of the Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, with which he was affiliated, and became Associate Professor in the Department of Children's Dentistry (Orthodontics) at Stony Brook School of Dental Medicine. Dr. Gorelick's wife, Shirley, died in 2000. He leaves his sister, Beatrice, her husband Leonard, and their children Anne, Richard and Scott. He was a loving father and father-in-law of Jamie Gorelick, Dr. Richard Waldhorn, Steven Gorelick and Stephanie Knott, and he was the proud and affectionate grandfather of artist Alyssa Gorelick (and her husband, Max Warsh) and Daniel and Dana Waldhorn, all of whom brought him great joy. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Shirley Gorelick Fund at the National Museum for Women in the Arts.

The Hallmark Hall of Fame franchise of made-for-television movies no longer has a home on network television. CBS has chosen not to extend its three-movie-a-year deal with Hallmark, so the franchise is now being shopped to others, Variety reported on Friday. CBS confirmed the decision in a statement that read: ''This is a partnership that has served CBS very well for many years. Hallmark Hall of Fame is a first-class organization, and we wish them nothing but success in their future.'' Hallmark Hall of Fame movies have been a television staple for 60 years and have been shown on NBC, PBS and ABC in the past. In recent years CBS has telecast the emotional, upbeat movies around holidays like Thanksgiving and Valentine's Day.

LAURENTS--Arthur, died May 5, 2011 after a brief illness in his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Born in Flatbush, Brooklyn on July 14, 1917, he graduated from Cornell University and was a resident of Greenwich Village, New York and Quogue, Long Island. He spent 52 extraordinary years with Tom Hatcher, his beloved companion, who died in 2006. A giant both on Broadway and in films, Laurents had written countless plays, musicals and screenplays. Among his Broadway credits are the books for the musicals "West Side Story," "Gypsy," "Anyone Can Whistle," "Do I Hear A Waltz?" and "Hallelujah, Baby!" He directed the original Broadway production of "La Cage Aux Folles" in 1983 and enormously successful revivals of "Gypsy" (three times) and "West Side Story." A partial list of his plays includes "Home of the Brave" (his 1945 Broadway debut), "The Time of the Cuckoo," "A Clearing In The Woods," "Invitation To A March," and "Jolson Sings Again." Highlights of his screenwriting career include "Rope," "The Turning Point," "Anastasia" and "The Way We Were." He received three Tony Awards (all for Best Direction of a Musical) for his work on Broadway as well as five Academy Award nominations. In 2000, Laurents published an acclaimed autobiography, "Original Story By Arthur Laurents: A Memoir of Broadway and Hollywood," and in 2009 republished Mainly On Directing: "Gypsy," "West Side Story" and Other Musicals. He will be remembered not only as having one of the most extraordinary careers in contemporary history, but for his fierce beliefs and fierce personal convictions. In 2010, he created the Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award to be given annually to a deserving young playwright. He is survived by a niece and nephew. Donations may be made to The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation 608 Northville Turnpike, Riverhead, New York 11901.

CHEVEN--Raymond, 83, of Sand Point, NY, died peacefully on May 6, 2011. He was the son of the late Sam and Fannie Cheven. As a very young man, he served in the U.S. Army during World War II. He is survived by his loving wife of over 49 years, Barbara Ann Cheven. He is also survived by his daughter and son-in-law, Heidi and Michael; daughter Jennifer, son and daughter-in-law Zachary and Candice, son and daughter-in-law Adam and Jennie; and grandchildren Sam, Ben, Amanda, Arthur, Jacob and Alex. Raymond Cheven was devoted family man, and he possessed a good heart and a positive spirit. He was admired for his great humor and his ability to always find kind and fitting words for his family, his friends, and his associates. He was the long-time Chairman and President of Country-Wide Insurance Company in New York City, and his innovative approach to his business allowed the company to grow during his tenure. He was a pious man, and he viewed his charitable nature as obligatory to better the lives of those in need. He was an avid traveler and an aficionado of fine art, and he easily made friends in every part of the world. He will be greatly missed by his dear wife, his family, his business associates, and all those who loved and admired him. Burial is private. Shiva is being held at the Jaffe residence at 1 Bridle Path, Sands Point, NY through Thursday, May 12, 2011 between 3pm and 8pm. Donations may be made in his loving memory to the United Jewish Appeal, the Jewish National Fund, or any charity.

YOKELL--Edith H.,1922-2011, of Boulder, Colorado, died on May 3, 2011, at age 89. She is survived by her loving husband, Stanley, of 67 years. She was born in Brooklyn and was raised in Elizabethtown, New York, a small village high in the Adirondacks by her parents Alexander and Manya Gersen, a country doctor and dentist respectively. She graduated as valedictorian of her high school at the age of fifteen, going on to receive a degree in psychology from Smith College and a Masters from the University of Pennsylvania's School of Social Work (1944). After moving to Boulder from North Caldwell, New Jersey, where she worked as a social worker at several Jewish family service organizations helping with the elderly, she relocated to Boulder where she was a 30 year resident. In Boulder she worked at the Youth Employment Service of the YMCA arranging jobs for local high school students. She enjoyed staying active, playing tennis, swimming, bicycling, hiking, and traveling extensively with her husband. She was a member of the Garden Club in North Caldwell and was active in the Garden Club and Happy Hazels in Boulder. She will be remembered for her ever-present support, keen intellect, and as a loving wife and mother. She is survived by her son Michael and daughter-in-law Debra Rahm of Boulder, daughter June of San Rafael, California, son Larry of Louisville, Colorado, brother Daniel Gersen of New York City and sister-in-law Adeline, grandchildren Benjamin of Denver, Colorado, Abraham of San Francisco, California, Lauren Scotten of Honolulu, Hawaii, and Katherine and Stephanie of Boulder. A memorial service celebrating her life will be conducted in last week of July in Boulder. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to Planned Parenthood 2525 Arapahoe Ave, Suite C-200 Boulder CO 80302.
SHENFELD--Sheila, We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to her family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

Simon Cowell's televised singing competition ''The X Factor,'' coming to Fox in September, now appears to have a complete cast. Fox announced on Saturday that the singer Nicole Scherzinger and British television personality Steve Jones would host the show. And on Sunday Paula Abdul was named a judge. Ms. Abdul will fill the final seat at the judges' table, where Mr. Cowell, Antonio Reid (known as L..A.) and Cheryl Cole will also sit. Mr. Cowell and Ms. Abdul had been together on ''American Idol,'' Fox's other singing competition. Ms. Scherzinger is known to some American viewers for performing in the pop group the Pussycat Dolls and for winning Season 10 of ''Dancing With the Stars.'' Mr. Jones is less well known, but Mr. Cowell hopes to turn him into a star like Ryan Seacrest.

Rehearsal for Broadway's ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' on Friday was no normal slice of scene work for Christopher Tierney, the actor who fell 30 feet from a platform and nearly died during a performance on Dec. 20. Mr. Tierney, who plays the masked super-hero in stunt sequences, flew Thursday for the first time since rejoining the cast last week; Friday's work call had him back at the moment in the musical when his accident occurred. Mr. Tierney, who said he was ''85, 90 percent'' recovered when he returned for work at the Foxwoods Theater on April 25, did not rush himself on Friday. Standing at the back of the stage, he spent several minutes with a half-dozen crew members affixing a tethered harness - the safety device that had failed him in December - to his torso. A safety inspector from the New York State Department of Labor stood nearby, assessing the safety procedures and taking photographs.

Amazon.com introduced a flash sale site, Myhabit, last Tuesday. Myhabit sells high-end apparel for men, women and children at deep discounts. The sales, like those on similar sites, start at the same time each day, and shoppers must make their purchases before the clock -- or the quantity -- runs out. Amazon is late to a crowded field. It joins private flash sale sites like Vente-privee, Gilt, HauteLook, Ideeli and Rue La La, as well as a host of smaller start-ups and big retailers like Saks. But with its large customer base, it has a distinct advantage.

President Obama was a YouTube star twice over the last week. His late-night address to the nation announcing that Osama bin Laden had been killed on May 1 was watched nearly 5.4 million times in the week that followed. ARONIN--Kevin J.,beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, and friend died suddenly on Wednesday, May 4th at his vacation home in Pontoon, County Mayo, Ireland. Kevin was born in New York City on August 23, 1954. A brilliant businessman and foresighted entrepreneur, he had a knack for creating something from nothing, a relentless drive for success and unbeatable instincts. Most recently, he founded PlasmaNet, Inc. in 1999 and its FreeLotto website, capitalizing on the promise of internet entertainment early in its heyday. Charity was his passion. He was guided by the concept of noblesse oblige the obligation to make the best of an individual's gifts and skills in order to better the world we live in. With each success in business, he was determined to contribute to the greater good. He was a notable philanthropist who supported many charities over his lifetime. He enjoyed learning about other cultures and had a particular soft spot for immigrants seeking the American Dream. He had a charisma that made him the life of any party and a natural leader. Kevin was at his best when he was cooking and entertaining for others, finding the greatest joy in feeding people and putting smiles on their faces. He was a gifted storyteller and teacher, and had a seemingly endless supply of funny jokes, which he loved to share with his friends and family. He read all three New York papers every day, and he could never seem to satisfy his thirst for knowledge. He is survived by his wife Anne; his four children, Shannon, Sean, Caitlin, and Lauren; his adopted son, Kevin Wong; his son-in-law, Edward Eppright; his dearly loved and only grandson, Eamon Eppright; his siblings, Michael, Patricia, and Nancy; and his uncle, Howard Aronin. He also leaves behind his Newfoundland, Duke, whom Kevin considered his sixth child. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues, but he would rather his life be celebrated. Visiting hours at the Lloyd Maxcy Funeral Home, 16 Shea Place, New Rochelle, NY 10801 will be on Sunday, May 08, 2011 from 7pm-9pm, Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial will be held at Blessed Sacrament Church at 10.30am on Tuesday, May 10, 2011. Interment immediately following Mass. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to HOPE Community Services, 50 Washington Ave., New Rochelle, NY 10801 is appreciated.

When Victoria Bartlett, the designer behind the Visible Panty Line label, opened her first boutique in New York late last year, she intended it to be more than just a showcase for her clothes — it would also be a gallery, where the artistic collaborations that are a regular feature of her work could be put on display. She put the plan into action for the first time on Monday night, when the Mercer Street shop was the site of an installation by the artist Orly Genger, who’s known for knotting thick nylon climbing rope into massive, room-filling shapes and who has collaborated with Bartlett on installations for her runway shows and also on accessories. “Squat,” as the new piece is called, has an unusual twist: For the duration of the event, it incorporated two live models, both clad in VPL underwear. “The idea was to have it look like something had blown through like a tornado and swept up against the window, engulfing the girls,” Bartlett explained as she surveyed the scene. “It’s this enormous muscle of rope that’s come crashing through the store.”

Did we always think in search terms and we just didn’t know it? Thoughts melded into words, and the words, if you squinted, began to yield Dominant Nouns. The dominant nouns then formed their own relationships. Early Internet searching was an art. The available results were mostly useless, so you had to “refine your search” — you had to try to think like the algorithm just as the algorithm was trying to think like you. An unexpected partnership. I always thought this was why search took off: you had the vague feeling that you were working with someone else, on the path to refinement.

When Joyce Carol Oates’s memoir, “A Widow’s Story,” came out in February, some reviewers took her to task for not mentioning that 13 months after the death of her husband, Raymond Smith, in February 2008, she remarried. Writing in The New York Review of Books, Julian Barnes said “some readers will feel they have a good case for breach of narrative promise.” In a letter in the current issue of The New York Review Ms. Oates defended her choice , writing that the book was meant to be about the immediate experience of widowhood, not her subsequent life. For her latest collection, the jeweler Monique Péan went in search of sustainable pearls — and wound up working in a lagoon in the South Pacific. Péan says she furthered her commitment to eco-minded jewelry during her CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund mentorship at Tiffany & Company; she and the company’s C.E.O., Michael Kowalski, share what he calls “an approach to precious materials that is sustainable and benefits the communities involved.” The quest led Péan to the Ahe atoll in French Polynesia, where the Kamoka Pearl Farm uses fish and sponges to clean its oyster shells. The farm harvests without chemicals, feeds its employees (“Raw oysters, fried oysters, oyster risotto, a lot of oysters!” Péan says) and turns the shells into beads. Péan’s line uses Kamoka’s keshi pearls in hues of blue, aubergine and gold for pieces like a ring set with delicate pavé-diamond tendrils (conflict-free, of course), which Péan says was inspired by Ahe’s “pollution-free midnight sky reflecting against the waves and the light.”

Every year, Major League Soccer Players Union releases the salaries of all players under contract in M.L.S. Those figures are just out, and they’re worth a look. (Other people’s salaries always are.) Depending on how you feel about lockouts and LOOGYs who get $8 million for two years, they might make you feel a little bit better about pro sports in America. Yes, there have been some ugly leg-breaking tackles of late. But at least our soccer players aren’t a lot of spoiled rich guys, you know? By my quick count, only six players make more than the $1.2 million Bobby Bonilla will be getting from the Mets every year for the next 25 years (he retired from baseball in 2001, in case you’re wondering why you haven’t heard that name in a while). And if you pool the salaries of the two biggest names in M.L.S., David Beckham and Thierry Henry, you still won’t have enough to cover Eddy Curry’s $11 million-plus salary this past season.

As an employee of the Walt Disney Company, Kermit the Frog may have lost his role in vintage Muppet specials like "Emmet Otter's Jug-Band Christmas," but his gig affords him other perks, like getting his own celebrity-interview station at the red carpet -- make that the black carpet -- for the premiere of the new "Pirates of the Caribbean" movie at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. In a winking style more reminiscent of "The Muppet Show" than "Sesame Street," Kermit is introduced to "Pirates" stars like Geoffrey Rush, Penélope Cruz and Johnny Depp (who appears baffled by the concept of a talking frog), mingles with stray guests like Steven Tyler and Bruno Tonioli, and steals kisses from Vanessa Hudgens and Kirstie Alley. (Miss Piggy might want to skip those scenes.) Yes, it's all a promotion for a coming Disney-produced Muppets movie, and while we would have preferred to see Gonzo introduced to Keith Richards, Kermit's brief encounter with that randy Rolling Stone is still worth the price of admission.

A loyal supporter of NAC, Peter created our logo twenty-nine years ago, his wisdom and foresight demonstrated by the fact that his design continues to represent the agency's mission today. Our deepest sympathies go out to Barbara and their entire family. Virginia Aaron, Board President Arlene Goldsmith, Executive Director

Opening night of the World Science Festival in New York is going to feature a more glittering lineup of stars than most Broadway shows. Meryl Streep, Amy Adams, Allison Janney, Liev Schreiber, David Morse and Bill Camp are among the actors coming together on June 1 at Alice Tully Hall to participate in a reading of a new play written by Alan Alda about the scientist Marie Curie. Mr. Alda, who has written five screenplays and a carton-full of television scripts, said on Monday that ''Radiance: The Passion of Marie Curie,'' is his first attempt at playwriting. The idea struck him about three years ago when he was planning to organize a reading of excerpts from Curie's letters for the World Science Festival. ''Then I found out her letters were all still radioactive and I switched to Albert Einstein,'' said Mr. Alda, who has a passion for science. ''But I love Marie Curie and I think her story is so important and dramatic, I wanted to explore it and write a play about it.''

From the department of long national nightmares that are now over: criminal charges against two key members of Justin Bieber's team, stemming from a 2009 mall appearance that turned unruly, have been resolved, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bieber, now 17, got one of his earliest tastes of national exposure in November 2009 when some 3,000 people turned out for a public appearance the then-ascendant floppy-hair pop singer planned to make at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y. But within that throng of tween- and teenage girls, excitement turned to screaming, screaming turned to shoving, and by the time it was over, five fans were sent to a hospital with minor injuries.

A timeline chart last Tuesday with an article about the relatively low radiation risk from the Japanese nuclear disaster compared with all other global sources of radiation referred incorrectly to the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. Although the United Nations credits 1994 as the start of the substantive negotiations that led to the treaty's formal adoption by the General Assembly, the testing ban was adopted in 1996, not 1994. .

When it comes to deals, attitude matters. On Monday, Hertz Global Holdings made a new bid for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, offering $2.24 billion - a deal that trumps its earlier offer and a current proposal by the Avis Budget Group.

Live Nation Entertainment, the world's biggest concert promoter, is teaming with the popular coupon site Groupon to sell discounted tickets. The companies announced on Monday that they had formed a joint venture, GrouponLive, which, like Groupon, will offer consumers discounts on tickets for limited periods of time. GrouponLive is to become operational ''in time for the summer concert season,'' the companies announced. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
