LOS ANGELES -- The irony was thick. Alan Schwartz, the former chief executive of Bear Stearns who oversaw its near-demise and subsequent government-aided rescue, was here at Michael Milken's annual conference - a West Coast version of Davos for financiers - moderating a panel last week about whether the Dodd-Frank Act had ended ''too big to fail.''
4:44 p.m. | Updated HSBC said on Monday that profit rose 58 percent in the first quarter after the quality of its loan portfolio improved.

PALMA, MAJORCA -- The old stones of the historic quarter of the Spanish island of Majorca are worn smooth with secrets ignored by most tourists that pour into this city from cruise liners on the sparkling Mediterranean. Rarely do visitors come with missions as precise as Joseph Wallis and a small contingent of Orthodox rabbis from Israel: To touch the smooth sandstones of a 14th-century synagogue turned into a Roman Catholic church. To offer a special 15th-century version of the Kaddish, a prayer for the dead that was once forbidden under threat of death and was delayed for 320 years.

The American Repertory Theater's reconceived production of ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' looks well-positioned for Broadway in the 2011-12 season, if Sunday's three-hour developmental performance in Manhattan for potential investors and others was any indication. An audience of 200 invited guests was quick to its feet with a sustained standing ovation after Porgy (Norm Lewis) left Catfish Row in search of his love, Bess (Audra McDonald), who had run off with the drug-dealing Sportin' Life (David Alan Grier). And the project's commercial producers expressed optimism that they would move the show to New York after its premiere run at the A.R.T. in Cambridge, Mass. ''Porgy and Bess,'' which was last mounted on Broadway in the 1976-77 season, is scheduled to run Aug. 17-Oct. 2 at the A.R.T.

TOKYO -- The accident at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant has done more than spew radiation into the air and sea and force tens of thousands of people to evacuate their homes. It has blown a big hole in Japan's energy policy, which had assumed that nuclear power would supply a growing part of the country's needs. Prime Minister Naoto Kan and other government officials said over the weekend that Japan would not abandon nuclear power as an important energy source.

In the annals of injudicious disappearances from Manhattan's mean streets, before there was Judge Crater there was Judge Lansing. And, before Judge John Lansing Jr. vanished in 1829, not so far from where Judge Joseph Force Crater went missing 99 years later, Judge Lansing was already famous - as a Founding Father and New York delegate to the Constitutional Convention in 1787. He also violated the convention's ban on note-taking for publication. Two of those notebooks will go on public exhibition beginning May 14 at Sotheby's on York Avenue and will be auctioned off May 20.

INTERNATIONAL An article on April 21 about two war photographers who were killed in fierce fighting in Misurata, Libya, erroneously included a survivor for one of them, Chris Hondros. Mr. Hondros had no children; he did not have a 3-year-old son.

LIEBLEIN--Edward, Ph.D.,died Saturday at his home in Plantation. He was 76. Dr. Lieblein retired two years ago as Dean of the Graduate School of Computer and Information Sciences at Nova Southeastern University, serving in that role for 16 years. He graduated with a B.S. and M.S. in Electrical Engineering from New York University, and earned his Ph.D. at the Moore School of Electrical Engineering at the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Lieblein had more than 50 years of experience as an executive and manager in both the public and private sectors in the field of computer science. While at the DoD, he delivered numerous keynote addresses at conferences and workshops. He was an avid photographer and bicyclist as well as an exercise enthusiast. In addition to his wife Sharon, his survivors include a sister, June, of Rego Park, NY, two daughters, Sheryl of Pittsburgh, PA and Susan of Highland Beach, FL, five grandchildren, a great-grandchild, and several nieces and nephews. Family requests in lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Edwards' name to the American Cancer Society. Online condolences may be sent at FredHunters.com.

9 P.M. (OWN) BECOMING CHAZ (2011) Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato (''The Eyes of Tammy Faye,'' ''RuPaul's Drag Race'') follow the sex change of Chastity Bono, the daughter of Sonny Bono and Cher, into a man named Chaz, above. This show traces the twists and turns of hormone injections, mood swings and breast removal. Providing support is Chastity's longtime girlfriend, Jennifer Elia. ''Mr. Bailey brings up a fascinating moment in the film: He asks Cher a question, and she just stares, motionless and unblinking as a cobra -- an excruciatingly long and pregnant pause,'' Cintra Wilson wrote in a profile about Chaz and the movie in The New York Times. ''Then her whole posture shifts. She says, 'If I woke up tomorrow in the body of a man, I couldn't get to the surgeon fast enough.' Right then and there it occurs to her how to relate to it.'' In ''The Doc Club With Rosie O'Donnell,'' at 10:30, Chaz discusses the extremes people will go to in realizing their authentic selves. 7:30 P.M. (BET) NOTORIOUS (2009) Jamal Woolard plays the Brooklyn rapper Christopher Wallace, a k a Biggie Smalls; Angela Bassett is his mother, Voletta Wallace; and Derek Luke is Sean Combs, known then as Puffy, in this drama about the larger-than-life Smalls, who was killed in 1997 at 24. A. O. Scott, writing in The Times, said, ''Biggie Smalls's best songs are so vivid -- and the circumstances of their making are so vividly reconstructed here -- that the usual nostalgic biopic haze never settles over 'Notorious.' '' He added: ''It's half pop fable, half naturalistic docudrama. Not a bad movie, but nowhere near as strong as its soundtrack.''
Scientist at Work Roland Kays of the New York State Museum posted at nytimes.com/scientistatwork.

HONIG--Erwin, 83, of Floral Park and Manhattan, on May 7, 2011. Cherished companion of Ellen Jacobs, father of Cantor Sharon Citrin of Woodbury, CT and Les Honig and his wife Susana of Brooklyn, grandfather of Michael and David Citrin, and Daniel and Faye Honig. He is predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Eleanor Honig. An electrical engineer with a career spanning six decades, the last 23 years at Kleinberg Electric, he was valued throughout the industry for his unmatched skills, experience and good judgment. An avid tennis player and home improvement enthusiast, he will be remembered for his kindness, generosity, calm and steady presence, and devotion to family. He was adored by all who had the privilege to know him.

FLAHERTY--Curtis. It is with great sadness that we mourn the untimely passing of Curtis Flaherty, an important and beloved member of the AHRC New York City family. For twenty years, Curt was the Director of AHRC's Department of Adult Day Services, but his role at AHRC was far greater. Curt was a leader and talented administrator: a creative and intelligent man who possessed vision and the ability to turn dreams into reality. He had a wonderful sense of humor, the ability to see through the insincere, and the political savvy to know what to say and when. Curt was a passionate advocate for the individuals served by AHRC. His passion was a manifestation of his humanity. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, Danny, Meagan and Emma, his wife Judy, his brothers Todd and Scott and his sister Mary Ann. Curt was with us for too short a time, but he left his mark and will be remembered by everyone whose life he touched. A wake will be held at the William Dangler Funeral Home in Summit, New Jersey on Tuesday, May 10th from 3-6pm followed by a service. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be sent to the AHRC New York City Foundation to be used for Assistive Technology for the people supported in the Department of Adult Day Services that he so loved. Dr. Melvin Gertner, 1st Vice-President Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director AHRC NYC

Uncle Mo, last year's juvenile champion, was sent to WinStar Farm in Versailles, Ky., on Monday to convalesce as he tries to recover from a gastrointestinal infection. While his return to the races this year is possible, another leading 3-year-old, Archarcharch, has been retired after surgery on his injured left foreleg revealed cartilage damage. Uncle Mo was scratched Friday from the Kentucky Derby when his owner, Mike Repole, and trainer, Todd Pletcher, decided he was still bothered by the infection that had been diagnosed after a disappointing third-place finish in the Wood Memorial on April 9.

Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois, who already had the distinction of being the youngest member of the House, has a new feather in his cap (or maybe, his gym bag): he is the first member of Congress to appear shirtless on the cover of Men's Health magazine. Mr. Schock and his abs appear on the cover of the June issue of the magazine, which hits the stands May 24. The congressman, a Republican who starts his days on Capitol Hill working out and running before digging into his legislative business, was chosen by the magazine to inspire Americans to get a jump-start on their summer fitness routine.

A review on Saturday about a concert by the New York Philharmonic that celebrated Carnegie Hall's 120th anniversary, using information from the program, misstated the orchestra that played at the premiere of Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' which was played at the anniversary concert. It was the New York Philharmonic, not the Symphony Society of New York. The review also misstated when in 1928 the premiere took place at Carnegie Hall. It was shortly after the Symphony Society merged with the Philharmonic Society of New York to form the New York Philharmonic, not shortly before.

ZEMSKY--Shirley, passed away peacefully on May 8, 2011 in her 83rd year. Beloved wife of Sam for 62 years, loving mother of Michael, Randi and Howard (Leslie), grandmother of Kayla, Jared, Harry and David, and sister of Anne Kass and Myra Kushner, Shirley was a woman of unwavering strength and vitality. Born and raised in Brooklyn, she raised her family in Woodbury, Long Island and enjoyed many years in Stuart, Florida. Shirley was a passionate follower of the arts who loved attending concerts, dance performances, and art exhibits. She was a voracious reader who took great pleasure in traveling to new places and meeting new people. She had an avid interest in the interests of others and was a dear friend to generations of families. She loved children and they loved her. She was a life long learner in the truest sense, attending college after she had raised her three children. She graduated from Hofstra University in 1979, at the age of 50 but took courses and attended lecture series throughout her life. Shirley loved following the many activities of her children and grandchildren and she was their biggest fan. She was a board member of the Atlantic Classical Orchestra and the Lyric Theatre in Stuart Florida. Other Institutions supported by Shirley include the Tourette Syndrome Association, Martin Memorial Foundation, Council on Aging, Temple Beit Ha Yam, Florida Oceanographic Society, Planned Parenthood, and the Chautauqua Institution. We will miss her dearly. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to The Atlantic Classical Orchestra in Stuart Florida, The Martin Memorial Foundation or the National Tourette Syndrome Association, www.tsa-usa.org

Y'all get a good intellectual property lawyer now, you hear? Come and listen to our story about a woman named Donna Douglas, an actress who for nine seasons kept herself fed by playing Elly May Clampett, the comely daughter of mountaineer Jed Clampett on ''The Beverly Hillbillies.'' But then one day, some 40 years after that hit comedy series went off the air, Ms. Douglas took notice of a Barbie doll designed to look like the Elly May character and filed suit against Barbie manufacturer Mattel, saying the toy uses her likeness without her permission, Reuters reported. Well, the first thing you know, Ms. Douglas, who lives in Zachary, La., and still makes public appearances based upon her ''Beverly Hillbillies'' celebrity, said in her suit that the doll ''creates the false public impression that Ms. Douglas has endorsed'' it, even though she said she has not. Mattel's folks said in an e-mail to Reuters that the toy company had ''licensed the rights to Beverly Hillbillies for this product through the appropriate channels.'' Ms. Douglas, who is asking for damages and seeking to stop Mattel from using her name or likeness, has lawyered up and filed her suit in federal court in Baton Rouge. (Louisiana, that is.)

EDWARDS--Fern (Belmont, Fox, Sheppard) died May 8, Lantana, FL, at age 90. Born February 24, 1921 to devoted parents Gus and Dena Belmont in Brooklyn, NY, and to a large, loving family that she never stopped speaking about with great sentiment. Survived by sons David (Beth), Mark (Susan) and Myles (Jo); grandchildren Dean (Karen), Lauren (Greg) and Lacey; great grandchildren Zoe, Sam, Jonah and Ella, stepchildren James, Jay and Joan, step-granddaughter Bram and step-great-grandchildren Peter and Nikey. Predeceased by cherished brother Jim Belmont. Also survived by cousins Sonny (Joan), Lola, Penny (Clyde) and Hank (Irene) and beloved sister-in-law Paula. Married to A. Harold Fox (deceased) for 24 years, Herman "Shep" Sheppard (deceased) for 26 years and Jackson Edwards (deceased) for 12 years. She led a glorious, full life, highlighted by romance, friendships spanning decades, travel, arts and many fun times with the people she loved. Most importantly, she made her children and their loved ones central to her life. Vibrant, strong, loving. An informed advisor in matters of heart, character and etiquette. Always compassionate and sensitive to others. A left-handed painter of abstracts of beauty, emotion and tumult. She engaged in lifelong charitable endeavors. Resident of Brooklyn, Woodmere, Manhattan and Boca Raton. Always deeply involved in her sons' lives and generous with her care and support for all. Now at peace. Services Wednesday, May 11 at 11am, Gardens Memorial Park, 4103 Military Trail, Boca Raton.

WINNER'S CIRCLE Carl Pascarella, an executive at TPG Capital, the private equity firm, owns a piece of the colt that shocked the horse racing world on Saturday with a victory in the Kentucky Derby. Animal Kingdom, left, who had never run on dirt and had only four races under his belt, covered the mile and a quarter in 2:02.04. The 68-year-old Mr. Pascarella and his wife, Yurie Pascarella, have owned several thoroughbreds, but Animal Kingdom is their first to run in the Derby. PETER LATTMAN

WEEKEND An review on April 29 about ''Breaking Ground: The Whitney's Founding Collection,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art, referred imprecisely to the group of New York painters known as the Eight, who initiated a brand of realism that focused on subjects like back streets, boxing matches and the urban poor and gained early support from Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, founder of the museum. Some of the Eight were disparaged as the Ashcan School -- not all were.

Representative Joe Donnelly, Democrat of Indiana, announced Monday that he would run for the Senate, declaring, ''I want to take the fight for American jobs and opportunity to the United States Senate.'' Lugar, a six-term Republican who faces a primary challenge from the state treasurer, Richard Mourdock, a favorite of the Tea Party movement.

LANSILL--Carol Jean, 76, a third generation San Franciscan and long term resident of Bucks County, PA, died at Temple Hospital in Philadelphia Friday May 6th after battling a long illness. Daughter of the late Claire and Bernard Flanigan, Carol became a renaissance woman, thriving as a wife, mother, interior designer, art historian, food adventurer, Bible scholar, accomplished gardener, political expressionist, docent, visionary volunteer, adventurous traveler, and meaningful friend to so many people. Her versatile passion, fierce intelligence, extravagant humor, as well as room brightening smile and charm will be missed by her friends and extended family across the globe, and especially by her devoted husband (and best friend) of 52 years, Frederick Lansill, of New Hope, Pennsylvania; her children, Janet, Florence, Italy; James (Jane), Brooklyn, New York; Brad (Kim), Los Angeles, California; and grandchildren Camilla and Filippo, Florence, Italy; Quinn and Lucinda, Brooklyn, New York; and Hannah and Stella, Los Angeles, California. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am Thursday, May 26th, at Trinity Episcopal Church, 6587 Upper York Road, Solebury, PA 18963.

There was a strange symmetry in how Phil Jackson's 20-season coaching run ended Sunday in Dallas, with his Lakers reprising the role of Coach Chuck Daly's Pistons against Jackson's rising Bulls in 1991. Just as the Lakers were swept four straight by the Dallas Mavericks and behaved badly on the way to exiting the playoffs as two-time defending champions, the Pistons reacted poorly when they were swept by Michael Jordan and the Bulls, along the way to the first of Chicago's six titles in eight years.

A Critic's Notebook on April 21 about the Easter Festival in Switzerland misstated how many Swiss francs a donor pledged for a new opera house for the larger Lucerne Festival, which is held in the summer, and the equivalent in dollars. The pledge, which has been withdrawn by the donor's foundation, was 120 million Swiss francs, about $137 million. It was not 125 million francs -- which is about $143 million, not $141 million.

PIA SUNDHAGE, the coach of the United States women's national team, on Monday named 21 players to the roster for the Women's World Cup, which will be played in Germany from June 26 to July 17. While the squad is anchored by the veterans HOPE SOLO, ABBY WAMBACH, CHRISTIE RAMPONE, HEATHER O'REILLY and SHANNON BOXX, Sundhage also selected nine women who have not played in previous World Cup tournaments. Rampone, 35, the likely team captain, played her way back into the national team picture after taking 2010 off while she was pregnant.

Diego Chavarri is a household name in his own household, which happens to be in Lima, Peru. His English may be spotty, but his soccer is solid. Perhaps most important of all, Chavarri owns a cherished document: a United States passport. ''I was born in Queens, don't know exactly where, and moved back when I was 2 months old,'' Chavarri, 22, said in a telephone interview from Lima, where he plays for Sporting Cristal in the top Peruvian league. ''I don't know if I could help, but I would love to play in and for the U.S.''

Administrivial Alert-From-the-Future! Because some people don’t read the blog until after they have solved, I wanted to post this today. There will be a notepad at the top of the Friday puzzle that does not interfere with solving, but might be interesting to read. In addition, the print version has no clue numbered 13, and goes from 12 to 14. This was not possible in Across Lite (clues have to be numbered normally), so the online version will have different clue numbers from the print version after 12. This may be confusing when referring to clues in the blog, because I solve using the Across Lite version. It may be more satisfying to solve using the PDF.

One of the most frustrating facts of the recently abated financial crisis is that those who might have been partly responsible for it have got off scot-free. The only two people prosecuted criminally — the Bear Stearns hedge fund managers Ralph Cioffi and Matthew Tannin — were found not guilty by a jury in Brooklyn. Other potential culprits — Angelo Mozilo, chief executive of Countrywide Financial, Joseph Cassano, chief executive of AIG Financial Products, and Dick Fuld, the chief executive of Lehman Brothers — were either slapped with a small civil penalty, in the case of Mozilo, or the Justice Department made the decision not to prosecute after months of investigation.

One thing I see fairly often in comments, and which has been picked up by gullible pundits, is the notion that the true rate of inflation is vastly higher than the official statistics say. I could offer a defense of the BLS, which to my knowledge is quite scrupulous in its work. But let me also point out that independent measures are not very far from the official consumer price index.

Last year there was a flurry of interest in the apparent fact that there were many more job vacancies than one should have expected given the high level of unemployment — a shift in the so-called Beveridge curve. And this was seized on by a number of people as evidence that much of our current unemployment is structural, that we need to accept a “new normal” of high unemployment rates. See Mike Konczal on this eagerness.

Josh Green has a great piece in the latest Atlantic on the Sarah Palin who might have been — Palin the reformist governor of Alaska, that is, rather than Palin the spotlight-chasing, media-feuding avatar of right-wing identity politics that we’ve come to know since the 2008 election. The Alaskan Palin fought corruption within her own party, attacked the nexus of government and big business, avoided polarizing feuds and cut successful bipartisan deals; in the process, Green notes, “she succeeded to a remarkable extent in settling, at least for a time, what had seemed insoluble problems, in the process putting Alaska on a trajectory to financial well-being.” This was the Palin that I liked from afar, before John McCain elevated her to national prominence: The charismatic pro-life working mom who was also a good-government reformer capable of thinking outside the ideological box. (Imagine Mitch Daniels crossed with Michelle Bachmann — in a good way.) And it’s a Palin who was swallowed up, almost immediately, by the national culture war, which made her both a right-wing icon and a left-wing hate figure almost instantaneously, and effectively erased her more interesting and complicated past.

I’m generally skeptical about the predictive value of special elections. They occur, by definition, under special circumstances — after a Congressman has died or left office unexpectedly. There may be unusual rules for nominating candidates; turnout is usually low; and they occur in isolation. Any one race can only tell you so much about the mood of the country, since there are always idiosyncrasies related both to the candidates and the district.

Lori Eiler-Hunter was a dynamo, a leader, a force. She was the kind of woman who left instructions for her obituary: “In lieu of flowers Lori requested that you read to your children, call your mother, say please and thank you and mind your P’s and Q’s.” When her brain cancer was first diagnosed six years ago, she made it clear she planned to fight hard to hang in for her husband, Art, and their then middle-school-aged children. Statistics said she should never have had those six years, but Lori used them to see Max and Alexandra both get settled into life at college.

When the hotel clerk recommended that I set my alarm at 3 a.m. for my 6:15 a.m. flight to Miami, I gasped. Why is it that arrangements that seemed so reasonable a month ago are now horrifying? Maybe I should just cancel, spend an extra day in Canada, tour a cattle farm, chill? But no: The Florida trip is important, and so there I was, dutifully, in a cab at 4 a.m., to join a couple of hundred other bleary-eyed travelers on a long customs line that lasted until 4:45 a.m. (or maybe it was 5 a.m.? Who can remember, even only a couple of hours later) and led to a series of steel shutters. The customs officers were not as eager as the rest of us.

A. L. Steiner is as well known for her thought-provoking and politically charged work as she is for her witty art world mischief. Sharp of tongue and nimble of mind, Steiner often touches on feminist, sometimes lesbian themes, and she is never afraid to court controversy. Steiner’s critically acclaimed installation at last summer’s Greater New York show at MoMA P.S.1 featured a vast collage of images of naked women, nature and beaten body parts, in a somehow celebratory homage to queer culture. She recently completed a film — she likes to call it a “sociosexual” video, but the more usual term is “porno” — in collaboration with the artist A. K. Burns. Titled “Community Action Center,” the film explores queer sexuality and runs an almost impossibly hilarious 69 minutes.

Young, upset at how the U.S.T.A. was allotting the wild-card entry it had to the French Open this month (the association used a playoff that Young lost), leveled a tweet at the organization that we can’t print. Considering Mumbai’s reputation as India’s night-life capital, it is something of an anomaly that the city is still technically under prohibition. Imposed by the state government shortly after India achieved Independence, prohibition has been gradually eased over the years but was never completely lifted. One of the remaining constraints is that anyone attempting to purchase or consume alcohol must obtain a “permit” declaring that they “continue to require foreign liquor and country liquor for preservation and maintenance of my health.”

THE ARTS Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Danza Contemporánea de Cuba dance troupe, which is at the Joyce Theater in New York as part of its first American tour, misstated the site of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Massachusetts, where another Cuban dance company, DanzAbierta, will perform this summer. It is in Becket, Mass., not Tanglewood. (There is no Tanglewood in Massachusetts; that is the name of the Boston Symphony Orchestra's summer home, which is in Lenox, Mass.)

KAYE--Lloyd S.,longtime executive and innovator in employee benefits consulting, died of lung cancer on May 10, 2011 at age 83. A managing director of Marsh & McLennan, he joined the firm in 1975 and was a respected expert on legal changes in pension and healthcare plans until his retirement in 1996. After graduation from Harvard Law School in 1952, he was a vice president at Johnson & Higgins and then Allied Stores before joining Marsh. In retirement, he returned to his lifelong passion for history, studying at Columbia University, lecturing at the New School's Institute for Retired Professionals and DOROT's University Without Walls. He is survived by his wife, Lael French Scott; son Seth, from his first marriage; and son Joshua and daughter, Sarrah, from his second marriage.

LET me immediately declare my bias: I love Austrian rieslings. I say that knowing I'm speaking very generally, but don't we always about wine? Of course we do, because we are speaking about ideals, born of experience and nurtured on realized potential. In discussing wine passions, we say, ''I love Barolos,'' or, ''I love Napa cabernets.'' But when we apply critical judgment to particular wines, a clearer picture emerges. We don't love all Napa cabs or all Barolos. In fact, we don't like quite a few of them. The ones we like best meet internal standards that have developed over time.

For the year before the brewer Mark VanGlad arrived at Friday's Union Square Greenmarket lugging cases of his new beer, he was a busy man. Last spring, Mr. VanGlad, 25, who owns Tundra Brewery, planted his own barley and hops, which he harvested in the fall. As the company's only deliveryman, Mr. VanGlad drove the barley from his family's farm in Stamford, N.Y., to Massachusetts to be malted. He developed the recipe for his maple-infused pale ale, and brewed it in a facility that he rigged up from old steel dairy tanks. And in Albany, Mr. VanGlad was the one who navigated the bureaucracy to get Tundra's microbrewery licenses.

LEEDS--Douglas B. The American Theatre Wing mourns the passing of its dedicated trustee, leader and friend, Doug Leeds. He served in many capacities on the board during his 21-year tenure, including President from 2004 to 2008. While professionally he was an expert in marketing and advertising, his dedication to theatre and the Wing was unmatched, particularly his unbridled joy at the annual Tony Awards. His enthusiastic, optimistic spirit set the tone for so much of the Wings work and relationships; he will be sorely missed in our meetings and public activities. We send our condolences to his wife Anki, daughter Victoria, mother Nancy and sister Connie and thank them for allowing Doug to share so much of his time and energy with us. The American Theatre Wing Ted Chapin, Chairman, Board of Trustees Howard Sherman, Executive Director

In one of the more unusual U-turns in the publishing business, Scott Moyers, a top agent at the Wylie Agency, will return to the Penguin Press as its publisher. Ann Godoff, currently the president and publisher of the Penguin Press, will hand over the title of publisher and become president and editor in chief. Mr. Moyers will begin in his new role on Monday.

She served the Congregation in leadership, formation and most recently as Chairperson of the former Franciscan Health Partnership. Memorial Service will be at St. Rose Home (now Sacred Heart Convent) at 71 Jackson St., NY, NY 10002 at 2:00pm on Thursday, May 12. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Franciscan Sisters of the Poor Foundation, 780 Third Ave., Suite 1858, NY, NY 10017.

When Joyce Carol Oates's memoir, ''A Widow's Story,'' came out in February, some reviewers took her to task for not mentioning that 13 months after the death of her husband, Raymond Smith, in February 2008, she remarried. Writing in The New York Review of Books, Julian Barnes said ''some readers will feel they have a good case for breach of narrative promise.'' In a letter in the current issue of The New York Review Ms. Oates defended her choice , writing that the book was meant to be about the immediate experience of widowhood, not her subsequent life. But she also wrote that ''in retrospect I can see that I should have added something like an appendix, to bring my personal history up to date,'' and said that she hopes to add such an appendix to later editions. This was news to her editor, Daniel Halpern, the president and publisher of Ecco. ''I completely disagree, and I thought I had talked her out of that,'' he said. ''She wrote a book about what it's like to be in limbo - about what it was like to lose the man she had been married to all her life. Why include the next husband? That's not what the book is about. What is she supposed to say - that she finally met someone and got married? That certainly breaks the spell of the book, which is written differently and perceived differently from anything she's ever done before.''

FINAL OFFER DuPont confirmed on Tuesday that its $6.4 billion bid for the Danish food ingredient company Danisco would not be raised again, a day after it emerged that Elliott Advisors, the activist hedge fund, had increased its stake to just above 10 percent. DuPont was forced to increase its bid to 700 Danish kroner a share from 665 kroner late last month to win over shareholders who thought the company was being undervalued. ''These terms represent our best and final offer,'' said Ellen J. Kullman, above, chief executive of DuPont. CHRIS V. NICHOLSON

The 2011 Calder Prize, which honors contemporary artists who have completed exemplary work early in their careers, will be awarded to the American artist Rachel Harrison, the Calder Foundation and the Scone Foundation have announced. In addition to a cash prize of $50,000 Ms. Harrison will receive a residency at the Atelier Calder in Sache, France, and one of her signature works will be placed in a major public collection. The ceremony will take place in early June at the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice, where a work by the artist will be on view during the opening week of the Venice Biennale. Ms. Harrison, who was born in New York in 1966 and lives and works in Brooklyn, is the fourth artist to receive the Calder Prize.

BAUM--Myron. The officers and employees of Essex Mfg Inc., Baum Bros. Imports, Inc. and Baum-Essex HK note with deep sorrow and regret the passing of our chairman, Myron Baum. Our deepest sympathies and condolences are with his wife, Barbara, son Bill, daughter-in-law Robin and grandchildren Michael and Carli.

Whatever can Newt Gingrich be thinking? That's the question a lot of political handicappers are asking now that Newt, as he is universally known in Washington, has decided to enter the 2012 campaign, with an announcement expected on Wednesday. Until recently, most of my colleagues assumed that the former speaker of the House, who flirted with running four years ago, was merely doing the same thing now, just to stay in the news.

BLACK--Wendy Lipkind, adored by her son, Harry, her husband Hillel, and a world of loving friends, passed away after a brief but valiant fight against an insatiable cancer on May 9, 2011 at the age of 68. She began her career as a teacher of troubled teenagers and young adults and spent most of her working years as a literary agent who embraced her many authors to whom she was deeply devoted and whom she zealously defended. She profoundly touched all those who knew her for her compassion, kindness and delicious sense of humor. She was simply beloved and will be deeply missed. A private funeral service will be held. Donations in Wendy's memory may be made to the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids or The Bonnie J. Addario Lung Cancer Foundation.

The Warner Music Group, the only one of the four major record labels that reports its financial information in detail as a stand-alone public company, had a net loss of $38 million for the first three months of 2011, with slight growth in its recorded music and publishing operations. The company had $682 million in revenue for the period, its fiscal second quarter, up 2.4 percent from the same quarter last year. Warner took in $550 million for its recorded music and $137 million for music publishing, both segments up about 2 percent. (The company attributes the $5 million difference in revenue totals to overlap between divisions.)

RIENDEAU--Emile C.,Died with a song in his heart on Saturday, May 7, 2011. Emile was born in Bristol, CT the son of the late Wilfred and Yvonne (Taillon). He enjoyed homes in New York City, Fire Island Pines, NY, Atlantic City, NJ and Sarasota, FL. He served his country in WWII assigned to the U.S. Seventh Army participating in the D-Day Landing and four major campaigns. He received one of the highest and most prestigious honors "The French Croix de Guerre" with Silver Star by the French Army. After completing military service he graduated with the class of '48 from Bryant College (now Bryant University). Emile was employed at IBM for 36 years in marketing where he was a top producer and won the Golden Circle Awards in many years. His many acquaintances and friends, especially his life partner H.R. (Henry) Nicholson and Rev Dr. Paul Hasselbeck wish him God-speed. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a Memorial Service on Sunday, May 15, 2011, at 12 noon at the Green Room at Ocean Club Condominiums, 3101 Boardwalk, Atlantic City, NJ or June 4, 2011 at Fire Island Pines, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to University of Pennsylvania Pulmonary Disease 3400 Spruce Street, Philadelphia., PA 19104 or the Fire Island Care Center, PO Box 5333 Fire Island Pines, NY, 11782. To share your fondest memory of Emile, please go to: www.lifecelebration.com

In a year when offbeat experiments with the hosts of major award shows haven't always yielded satisfying results, it's understandable that the organizers of the Tony Awards would turn to someone with experience to serve as their master of ceremonies. Neil Patrick Harris, who hosted the 2009 Tony Awards program - not to mention the 2009 Emmy Awards and, for some reason, the 2010 Spike Video Game Awards -- will return as host of next month's Tonys show, the award program's press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Harris, a star of the CBS comedy ''How I Met Your Mother'' who starred in the New York Philharmonic revival of ''Company,'' said in a statement: ''I'm honored and stoked to have been asked to host the 2011 Tony Awards. It should be a great show -- we've got a fantastic mix of live performances, a few secret surprises, and since they're closed for retooling, we're using all the rigging equipment from 'Spider-Man.' What could possibly go wrong?''

The British actor Simon Russell Beale will return to the New York stage this summer as a London taxi driver in Atlantic Theater Company's production of ''Bluebird,'' a tender drama by Simon Stephens about chance encounters and coming to grips with one's past. Mr. Beale, a Tony Award nominee for best actor in 2004 for ''Jumpers,'' and a two-time winner of the Olivier Award (London's version of the Tonys), will be cast with the Atlantic company member Mary McCann as Jimmy's wife Clare and the actors Kate Blumberg, Tobias Segal and Todd Weeks. The production is scheduled to begin preview performances on Aug. 9 and will open on Aug. 22; it is scheduled to run through Sept. 9 at the company's Atlantic Stage 2, on West 16th Street in Chelsea.

GAVASCI--Rachele, (nee Nardella). Cherished wife of the late Alberto Paolo Gavasci, passed away peacefully on May 9, 2011, surrounded by her loving family. An accomplished women in her own right, Rachele began a career as a fashion designer who married and then dedicated the remainder of her life to her husband and family. Rachele gave many years of her life toward public service, and her involvements included the Girl Scouts of America, local educational projects and multiple community organizations. She is survived by her beloved children, her son Alberto and wife Elizabeth, and her daughter Piva and her husband Gerard. Rachele was the adored grandmother of Noelle and her husband Theodore, Christian and Thomas. She was the cherished sister of Ramona Nardella and her brother, the late Ralph Nardella. Rachele was an extraordinary women who always lavished love, support and compassion to her family and all who knew her. Her passing will leave a void that can never be filled. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday May 13 at 11am.

He was unselfconscious excellence - it was wonderful to be with him. The Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola Cathedral, 999 N. Military Trail, Palm Beach Gardens, Florida, at 11am on Friday, May 13, 2011. The McAllister Family

An article last Wednesday about a traveling bistro on the L subway line from Manhattan to Brooklyn that was staged on May 1 by several supper clubs misidentified the host who said: ''We might mention that we really love the slow food movement, but today we're not really about slow food. So eat quickly.'' He was Jonathan Cristaldi, not Michael J. Cirino.

MIRSKY--Harvey, 71, of Manhattan died Tuesday May 9 of heart failure. He was born in Brooklyn and spent his youth being a proud Brooklynite and Dodgers fan. After attending Winthrop in East Flatbush, he went to Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. While working at Associated Metals and Minerals, he received his undergraduate degree from Brooklyn College. Then onto the University of Chicago where he worked in development and earned an MBA. Using his marketing skills, he worked for Proctor and Gamble in France and Britain. He was in both the Army and Air Force reserves, serving in Europe. After returning to the US, he explored a teaching career at Tuskegee Institute in Alabama but finally settled back in his beloved New York, and began his own marketing business focusing on the drug industry. Nearing retirement his boyhood interest in stamp collecting was rekindled and he developed into a noted postal historian specializing in US first issues. His collection received many international awards. He is survived by his wife, Carol Bommarito; his son, Sam Mirsky; his daughter-in-law, Ashlea Mirsky; and their children Emily, Benjamin and Joseph. Funeral Services will be held Thursday. For more information call (212) 724-4126 ext. 203.

His career as a licensed master, a pilot, the President of McAllister Towing, Ltd. When a group of investors offered to pay eBay $1.9 billion for a controlling stake in Skype two years ago, the technology veterans were derided for buying a fallen Internet darling hobbled by losses and lawsuits. After agreeing to sell the company for $8.5 billion to Microsoft, the owners - including a private equity firm, a venture capital firm and a pension fund - are now poised to reap a windfall. Even eBay, which took a $1.4 billion hit on its original investment, looks to collect more than $2 billion on Skype.

SALZMAN--Robert, 69, on May 8, 2011. Beloved husband, brother and friend. In practice as a CPA with a law degree for forty years, he earned an MBA degree from The Wharton School and a law degree from New York Law. He was known by his clients and associates for his integrity and professionalism. Robert was an avid sailor, swimmer and scholar, who enjoyed the beauty of the beaches and woods of the East End of Long Island. He and his devoted wife of 20 years, Dr. Constance Freeman, Director of Psychology, Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, shared homes in The Hamptons, Florida and New York City. He is also survived by his brother, psychologist Dr. Michael Salzman, of Hawaii. Services will be held on Wednesday, May 11, 2011 at 1:30pm the Weinstein Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY. Donations in Robert Salzman's name may be made to the Heart Health Program at the New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center.

RON LEVY never intended to become a tandoor mogul. In fact, he had never heard of tandoors -- Indian clay cooking vessels that are part oven and part barbecue pit -- until 1986, when a New York gallery exhibited six-foot pots he had made, inspired by amphorae on Crete. A man with an Indian accent called, wondering whether Mr. Levy, a ceramic artist, could make a large pot with a tapered mouth, no bottom and no glaze: a tandoor.

For those of us who don't have the $625 (or the upper-body strength) to buy ''Modernist Cuisine,'' the six-volume, 40-pound high-tech food encyclopedia released with great fanfare last month, the 12 pages of corrections and clarifications that went up on the book's Web site last week is worth a read for its own sake. At times the errata read like science fiction -- fleeting glimpses into the world of ''beet flexicurd,'' ''halibut cheek gel base'' and ''scallop mochi.'' It's a place where oysters, before they meet their demise, are fed sieved beet juice (and the juice should be strained through a 25-micron sieve, not a 500-micron one).

SMITH--Robert I.,1918-2011. Father of Ruth, Debra, Lee (Wendy); Grandfather of Maaret, Cary; Brother of Thelma. A graduate of NYU, he worked as the head of public relations at UJA Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, New York City, for 35 years, where he helped raise more than two billion dollars. He loved the arts, travel, wrote haikus and was an FDR liberal and Brooklyn Dodgers fan. Member of the Workmen's Circle. The last few years he planned cultural excursions for the people at his assisted living. He loved and was proud of his family. He was open to diverse perspectives and loved a good argument. Memorial Service on May 15, 1-3pm at the Samuel Field YMHA, 58-20 Little Neck Pkwy. Donations can be made in his name to Doctors Without Borders: doctorswithoutborders.org

8 P.M. (Sundance) THE HISTORY BOYS (2006) Two teachers -- Hector (Richard Griffiths), a middle-aged, poetry-spouting, married homosexual who cares deeply about how knowledge is applied to life, and Irwin (Stephen Campbell Moore, above right with Mr. Griffiths), a young Thatcher-era go-getter -- square off over the question of how to interpret history in what Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, called a ''ferociously engaging'' screen adaptation of Alan Bennett's Tony Award-winning play. ''The acting is wonderful,'' Mr. Holden said of this streamlined interpretation of the critically acclaimed National Theater production in London, set in a boys' school in northern England in 1983, as eight teenagers prepare to apply to Oxford and Cambridge.''Mr. Moore's avid Irwin and Mr. Griffiths's shambling Hector are matched by the extraordinary Frances de la Tour as Dorothy Lintott, the droopy, horse-faced history teacher with a baritone voice who is the wisest and most balanced member of an academic triumvirate. Dorothy belatedly has her say when she observes with an amused exasperation: 'History is a commentary on the various and continuing incapabilities of men. History is women following behind with the bucket.' '' Still, ''For all its delights, 'The History Boys' is not a world-changing work of art,'' Mr. Holden wrote. ''It is exactly what Irwin calls history: entertainment, a scintillating contrivance that is only as good as its epigrams. Below the surface lies a gooey custard filling.'' 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Little more than a week after the royal wedding, Ms. Winfrey interviews Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York (who was not invited), and her daughters, Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie (who were). Ms. Ferguson's new reality show, ''Finding Sarah,'' has its premiere on June 12 on OWN.

New York theater critics had an awfully hard time on Monday selecting the best play of the year for their annual award. Four rounds of balloting by the New York Drama Critics' Circle revealed strong preferences for three Broadway plays that have also been nominated for this year's Tony Award for best play -- ''Good People,'' ''Jerusalem,'' and ''The ------------------------ with the Hat.'' ''Good People,'' by David Lindsay-Abaire,'' and ''Jerusalem,'' by Jez Butterworth, were neck-and-neck at one point in the voting. By the final round, ''Good People'' emerged as the winner, with Jon Robin Baitz's ''Other Desert Cities,'' which ran Off Broadway at Lincoln Center Theater this winter, a close-runner-up.

She is survived by her children Henry, Joan, and David, her brother Sidney Shapiro, five grandchildren and two great-grandsons. Our love and respect for her live on.

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Tillinghast's loving daughters, Katherine, Abigail and Susan and their families; brother David Tillinghast HM 1947 and his wife, Lisa; his nieces, nephews and many friends. He will be deeply missed. Thomas M. Kelly, Ph.D. Head of School Steven M. Friedman '72 Chair, Board of Trustees

Two star singers have backed out of the Metropolitan Opera’s tour to Japan, the Met said on Thursday. The news is sure to stir dissatisfaction among some members of the company who have expressed worry over safety risks following the nuclear emergency in Japan caused by the March earthquake and resulting tsunami. The Met, citing reassurances from the State Department and experts, has said it was going ahead with the two-week tour in June, and that all company employees — chorus and orchestra members and others — would be required to go.

If you have ever felt guilty about eating octopus because of its relatively large brain size, prepare to feel doubly so. As Boing Boing reports: “videos of cirrate octopuses filmed swimming in the deep ocean and set to classical ballet music seem well on their way to becoming a YouTube genre.” Boing Boing links to a recent Guardian article that describes what has made this glimpse into the balletic life of our favorite cephalopod possible. Thanks to improvements in digital technology — a high-definition underwater video camera that can film at 6,600 feet where “less than 1 percent of the sun’s rays ever penetrate” — we can now take a “rare look at a mysterious benthopelagic sea animal: Grimpoteuthis bathynectes, one in a group of 14 recognized species that are often referred to as ‘Dumbo octopus’ because their fins resemble the large ears that the fictional character, Dumbo the elephant, used to fly.” (O.K., maybe these aren’t exactly the ones you eat, but still.)  The video below, filmed 200 miles off the Oregon coast, shows you what you’ve been missing:

This morning I left Immokalee, Fla., the source of almost all the winter tomatoes grown in the United States. Its inspiring tomato workers have gone from enduring slavery, beatings, wage theft (and sub-minimum wage pay) and 12-hour days in the blazing heat with no shade, to a victory that, that, while not quite complete, is possibly the most successful labor action in the United States in 20 years, the details of which will have to wait for a column or even a story.
More than a third of consumers report having had a bad experience with a service provider, and the vast majority of them took time to complain about it, a recent survey finds.

In an article I wrote for the Week in Review section last Sunday, I noted that no federal laws existed to punish companies when customers’ personal information and data were stolen in cyber-attacks, or mishandled by companies. And so punishment in these cases is left up to the states. Yet in many instances, state officials don’t have the resources to tackle this problem, and even acknowledge that they don’t always understand the technical aspects of breaches.

Herman Cornejo, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will not perform during the first two weeks of the company’s season, Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director, announced on Thursday. Mr. Cornejo, who withdrew due to an injury, was scheduled to perform in “Don Quixote” on May 19 and in Antony Tudor’s “Shadowplay” on May 24 and 25. Rolando Sarabia, a veteran of the National Ballet of Cuba and Miami City Ballet, will replace Mr. Cornejo for the performances of “Don Quixote.” Craig Salstein, a soloist, will replace Mr. Cornejo in “Shadowplay” at both performances. The company earlier announced that Ethan Stiefel, another principal, would withdraw from the entire season. This is the first time Mr. Sarabia will appear with the company.

N.B.A. teams have reached the point in the playoffs when they are hindered by the most basic of human limitations: physical fatigue. Like it or not, basketball players are not conceptual beings nor robots, and as such they’re limited by what their bodies are able to do. Obvious though that may be, it’s a factor of performance sometimes lost in the “one game at a time” playoff mentality, an inescapable component of teams failing or succeeding.

In this Sunday’s magazine, I write about Shawn Ryan and Cathy Wood, who are leading a new gold rush in the Yukon. I first met Ryan and Wood while reporting a story for T magazine about a commercial boom in wild morels near Dawson City in 2005. As soon as I had the assignment, I called my friend David Arora and asked if he wanted to go along. Arora is famous among mushroom pickers; nearly all of them own a copy of his giant field guide, “Mushrooms Demystified.” Arora seems to know everybody, but the two people he recommended as most important to talk to in the Yukon were Ryan and Wood.

Yale is going first. The university, in New Haven, announced that it is opening its entire digital image collection to the public for free – the first Ivy League institution to take this step toward open access. Yale houses millions of images in its archives, museum and libraries, including a sonata written by the hand of Mozart and a watercolor by William Blake. “The open access policy allows us to more fully harness the potential of digital and networked technologies in service to scholarship as well as to creative use and reuse of our rich cultural heritage,” said Meg Bellinger, director of the Yale Office of Digital Assets and Infrastructure. “It frees us to concentrate on our core mission to create, preserve and disseminate knowledge in digital form.”

CANNES, France — There are a record number of female filmmakers competing for the biggest prizes in competition for the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival this year: four. That’s 4 out of 20 (last year, there were zero women in the competition). As lopsided as that 20 percent figure may still be, some of the buzzed-about films around the Croissette this year are directed by women, including Lynne Ramsay’s “We Need to Talk About Kevin” and Julia Leigh’s “Sleeping Beauty.” An entry far out of the competition, “Kung Fu Panda 2,” the animated sequel starring Angelina Jolie, Jack Black and Dustin Hoffman, was directed by Jennifer Yuh, who was a story artist on the first film; at a press conference on Thursday, a journalist asked Ms. Jolie if her character was more developed because of Ms. Yuh’s involvement. (Ms. Jolie, who plays a tigress, hedged an answer. “I do feel if we had a male director, I would have had a bigger part,” Mr. Hoffman – red panda – said jokingly.) Other films have notable female performances, like “The Beloved,” in which Catherine Deneuve stars, and sings, with her daughter, Chiara Mastroianni. It is scheduled to be the festival’s closing film.

Karen Alexander says she is “one of the lucky ones.” Ten years after learning she has Parkinson’s disease, she takes two drugs to control her symptoms and so far has few of them. A tremor on her left side can make it hard to balance a teacup and saucer, but “at 74, it doesn’t bother me much,” she said. Luckily, Ms. Alexander, who lives in a suburb west of Chicago, is right-handed.

CANNES, France — Not everything was official pomp and circumstance on the opening day of the Cannes Film Festival; there were also some unofficial stunts. The first red carpet event was around a film that’s not even close to being in competition, the animated “Puss in Boots,” a prequel spinoff from “Shrek,” starring Antonio Banderas as Puss and Salma Hayek as Kitty Softpaws.

On June 1, people who love meat will have a new way to express their feelings: by joining the Butcher’s Guild, a new trade organization for butchers. The guild was started last month, complete with a mission statement, a crest (a hand, a heart, a steer, a book) and an oath. The founders, Tia Harrison (a chef and butcher) and Marissa Guggiano (a writer), say the goal is to build an active national community of butchers and meat-centric chefs. Charter members include the nose-to-tail celebrities Chris Cosentino of Boccalone in San Francisco, Guy Arnone of Eataly in Manhattan and the women behind the hip new butcher shop Lindy & Grundy in Los Angeles, Erika Nakamura and Amelia Posada. (Tattoos are not required for membership, though they are prevalent.)
The influence of Friends, Fans and Followers on purchasing decisions.

In Chapter 2 of a long story that is growing longer, the Metropolitan Museum of Art filed suit Tuesday in United States District Court in Manhattan seeking possession of a painting now in the hands of Robert Wylde, a British collector. The 1981 painting, “The Innocent Eye Test” by Mark Tansey, was bought by Mr. Wylde for $2.5 million from the Gagosian Gallery in 2009. Last year, the gallery told Mr. Wylde it had learned that the Met already owned 31 percent of the painting — which depicts a cow gazing at a portrait of other cows — and that the other owner had promised that the museum would eventually own the whole thing. Mr. Wylde filed suit in federal court in Manhattan against the gallery in March of this year, contending it had misled him, and held on to the painting.

It’s notoriously difficult to figure out which top collegiate quarterbacks will succeed in the NFL. Pro teams give prospects an SAT-type test called the Wonderlic test, which doesn’t predict all that accurately.  A company called Achievement Metrics, on the other hand, studies the words college athletes use in media interviews. Turning a historic house — whether designed for laborers or lords — into a hotel is never easy. When Fred Krehbiel, a Chicago industrialist, decided to buy Ballyfin, a Georgian manor on 600 acres in Ireland’s County Laois, the property was being used as a school, he says, “and we had to give them six years to build a new building.” During that time, Krehbiel’s team of more than 100 workers began transforming the 1812 mansion into a hotel with 15 rooms, all while working around 500 teenagers. Krehbiel and crew restored ornate plasterwork, bought back some of the previous owner’s paintings, rebuilt the conservatory (which had to be disassembled and shipped to England for repairs) and even uncovered a Roman sarcophagus bathtub, now installed in one of the guest rooms. (Appropriately, a family motto of Ballyfin’s original owner, Sir Charles Coote, was “coûte que coûte” — “cost what it may.”)

LEEDS--Douglas B. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with sadness the passing of former Trustee and longtime friend, Doug Leeds. In 1985 he founded the Museum's Lobby Gallery Associates, a visionary young donor group that paved the way for many young art councils throughout the city including Whitney Contemporaries. A member of the museum for almost three decades and a passionate supporter of the arts, Doug will always be remembered for his affable nature and warm smile. Our deep sympathies to his wife Anki, daughter Victoria, mother Nancy and his sister Connie. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. WITH summer in sight and bright colors in abundance, isn't it time to play with some new makeup? Illamasqua, a London cosmetics brand led by the avant-garde makeup artist Alex Box; the legendary punk leader of the Damned, Dave Vanian; and the artist Anja Huwe encourages uninhibited self-expression. The heavily pigmented cream products of its new Toxic Nature collection have a painterly texture -- less for a sheer effect, more for full coverage -- and they're surprisingly pretty. Try Bedaub, a mint shade, or Dab, a lilac, on your lids for a statement in pastel. To further intensify the color, layer eye shadow on top of the pigment. Neon fans should make for nail varnishes in Gamma, an electric orange hue, or Radium, a killer lime-green. If acid tones are outside of your comfort zone, test the line with Stagnate, a deep gray-mauve polish. Illamasqua cream pigments, $24; nail polish, $14; at Sephora.

Moving forward, every Kanye West show should conclude with a rant. In November, at the intimate concert he played at the Bowery Ballroom to celebrate the release of his latest album ''My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy,'' he closed the night with 10 or so minutes of wounded tongue lashings and self lacerations. Tuesday night, for the Museum of Modern Art's annual Party in the Garden, he opted for something a little more melodious. For most of the 45 or so minutes that he was onstage, Mr. West was moody, dour, even irritated at points, a star who enthralled even at low wattage.

He leads the team in home runs with seven and in runs batted in with 25, which was tied for fifth in the National League before Wednesday's games. He is batting .302.

McALLISTER--Captain James P.,III. The officers and employees of McAllister Towing and Transportation Company mourn the passing of our beloved former colleague, Captain James P. McAllister III. A World War II Veteran, James served in the U.S. Navy in the South Pacific. Thereafter, he joined the McAllister family tugboat business. His career as a licensed master, a pilot, the President of McAllister Towing, Ltd. Montreal, and ultimately, an owner of our company was always distinguished by his intelligence, good fellowship, and great wit. Our condolences to his wife of 60 years, Kathryne; his children James IV, Marianne, Capt. Jeff and Helen; his four grandchildren and his sister, Ellen Perrott.

With the government securing a conviction against Raj Rajaratnam of the Galleon Group on Wednesday, federal prosecutors will shift their focus to expert networks - the intricate web of money managers, corporate executives and consultants at the center of another wave of insider trading cases. Over the last few years, the Justice Department has built dozens of insider trading cases. The government's effort has sent shivers through the hedge fund industry, the influential investors that have figured prominently in an investigation into Wall Street.

Jennifer Lopez has had a prime television role as a judge on ''American Idol'' and plenty of airtime to promote her new album, ''Love?'' But it wasn't enough for her to top new releases from the Beastie Boys and Fleet Foxes on this week's Billboard 200 albums chart, Billboard reported. The British pop singer Adele's ''21'' was No. 1 for its seventh week, with 155,000 in sales. She is closing in on Taylor Swift's record for the longest run at the top of the chart by a female performer since 2000. (Ms. Swift's album ''Fearless'' racked up 11 weeks in 2008 and 2009.)

KOSLO--William Joseph, Jr.,a 21 year resident of Darien, CT passed away May 5, 2011. He was 51. Raised in Garden City, NY, he was a 1978 graduate of Chaminade High School and of Dartmouth College in 1982. Prior to joining Bank of Ireland in June 2010, Bill spent 5 years at CIT, during which he ran the firm's Capital Markets Group and was President of its broker-dealer. Prior to joining CIT, Bill served as a Managing Director in Leveraged Finance at CIBC World Markets. Bill's previous experience includes approximately 25 years of leveraging loans, private placements and high yield debt. He also spent several years at regional investment bank, Rodman & Renshaw, specializing in executive IPOs, secondary offerings, and M&A transactions. Bill began his career in the Manufacturers Hanover Credit Training Program. Bill was actively involved in coaching both Darien Little League and CYO basketball. Bill is survived by three children, Elizabeth, Amanda, William III, and their mother, Lisa Koslo, all of Darien, CT. Also two brothers, Mark Koslo and Patrick Koslo, of Garden City, and, a sister, Karen Koslo Bingham, also of Garden City. In addition, Bill is survived by many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his parents, Margaret and William Koslo, of Garden City, NY. His father was former President & CEO of Diamond International Corp. Calling hours will be held Friday, May 13, 2011 from 4-8pm at The Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Saturday, May 14, 2011 at 10am at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, 40 Maple St. New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St Aloysius School, 33 South Ave, New Canaan, CT 06840.

Call your sponsor, hide your distinguishing headwear and find yourself a spot on Cousin Julio's couch: ''The ---------------------- With the Hat'' is extending its run on Broadway. Press representatives for that Stephen Adly Guirgis play, about the intertwined lives of a former drug dealer struggling with sobriety, his girlfriend, his cousin, his sponsor and the sponsor's wife, said that it will play at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater through July 17; it was previously scheduled to end its run on June 25. While Chris Rock is making his Broadway debut in this dark, dark, dark comedy - did we mention it was dark? - most of the critical praise for the play, which opened on April 11, has been directed at the performances of Bobby Cannavale and Elizabeth Rodriguez. Last week, it was nominated for six Tony Awards, including best play, direction of a play (Anna D. Shapiro), leading actor in a play (Mr. Cannavale), featured actress in a play (Ms. Rodriguez) and featured actor in a play (Yul Vazquez). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WEISSMAN--Vivian J. March 22, 1921 May 10, 2011. Lee Vivian Betty Jacobs grew up in Baltimore, Maryland, daughter of Gustav and Bertha Jacobs. In the 1940s, she moved to New York City to seek her fortune. She landed a job in high-tech, which at the time meant radio, working at WNEW. She also met the love of her life, Lester Weissman, and the two married in 1950. After the birth of her only child, Robert, Vivian became a full-time homemaker while Lester successfully supported the family with his Jersey City clothing store, Danforth Factory Outlet, and, later his second store in Closter, Danforth Wearhouse. In 1960, the family moved to Tenafly, New Jersey, which remained their longtime home. Eventually, Vivian returned to college to complete her education, receiving Bachelor's and Master's degrees from Fairleigh Dickenson University. After Lester's death in 2002, Vivian struggled with memory loss and dementia. Her decline was rapid and tragic. In 2004, she moved into an assisted living facility in Edgewater, NJ, where she spent her remaining years. She is survived by her son Robert and daughter-in-law Judy, of Sunnyvale, California. At Vivian's request, no memorial will be held. A graveside service only will be held at Cedar Park Cemetery at Forest Ave. and Soldier Hill Rd. in Paramus, NJ, on Monday, May 16, 2011 at 10:30am.

An article on Tuesday about a study on the economic viability of capturing carbon dioxide from the earth's atmosphere misstated the ranking of the American Physical Society, the group that released the findings. It is the world's second-largest group of physicists, not the largest. (It ranks behind the German Physical Society.)

An article in some editions on April 30 about the Giants' second-round draft pick, Marvin Austin, overstated the extent of his disciplinary trouble at North Carolina. Before he was suspended for the 2010 season for improper contact with an agent, he played in every game of the 2008 and 2009 seasons; he was not suspended for two games in 2008 and for two more games in 2009. (In those four games, he played but did not start.) The error was repeated in an article on May 1 in some editions.

ROLL in to work in your pajama bottoms, and you're likely to hear from Human Resources. But not if you show up in a chic alternative: print pants that have the ease of pj's but with a bit more panache. Billowy trousers, many with drawstring waists, were a runway hit for spring -- for at least one plausible reason. ''Print pants are really flattering,'' the designer Rachel Comey said. ''They don't show a body's every flaw.'' Her playful patterns are summery yet urban, as are the African-inspired mixed-up prints of Suno. For styling tips, take a cue from the model Ksenia Kahnovich (right), who wore hers with a loose knit and sandals. Got a meeting with the bosses? Throw on a blazer. From left below: Rachel Comey silk pants with an elastic waistband, $368 at Creatures of Comfort, 205 Mulberry Street, (212) 925-1005, creatures of comfort.us; Suno drawstring silk pants, $414 at Maryam Nassir Zadeh, (212) 673-6405, 123 Norfolk Street, mnzstore.com; Suno silk pants, $396 at Otte, 121 Greenwich Avenue, (212) 229-9424, otteny.com.

KAYE--Lloyd S.,longtime executive and innovator in employee benefits consulting, died of lung cancer on May 10, 2011 at age 83. A managing director of Marsh & McLennan, he joined the firm in 1975 and was a respected expert on legal changes in pension and healthcare plans until his retirement in 1996. After graduation from Harvard Law School in 1952, he was a vice president at Johnson & Higgins and then Allied Stores before joining Marsh. In retirement, he returned to his lifelong passion for history, studying at Columbia University, lecturing at the New School's Institute for Retired Professionals and DOROT's University Without Walls. He is survived by his wife, Lael French Scott; son Seth, from his first marriage; and son Joshua and daughter, Sarrah, from his second marriage.

INDIANAPOLIS -- Cheri Daniels has made no secret of her distaste for politics. She did not campaign for her husband, Mitch Daniels, during two races for governor. She did not fully move into the governor's mansion after his election. She has never delivered a political speech. But as leading Republicans step up their efforts to urge Mr. Daniels to run for president, the attention has suddenly turned to Mrs. Daniels, who makes her debut here on Thursday when she delivers a keynote address at the spring dinner of the Indiana Republican Party.

Bush's administration, announced that she would leave the F.C.C. when her term expires at the end of June. BEIJING -- Rare handicrafts from a private museum in Hong Kong that were on display at the Forbidden City in Beijing were stolen on Sunday, forcing a shutdown of one part of the ancient palace, according to an article on Wednesday in the English-language edition of Global Times, a government-run newspaper in Beijing. The missing items date to the early 20th century and include jewelry boxes. They belong to Feng Yaohui, a Hong Kong collector, and were part of the Liangyicang private museum. The last attempted burglary at the Forbidden City took place in 1987, Global Times reported, citing a Web site administered by the Ministry of Public Security. At least 1,600 antitheft alarms, 3,700 smoke detectors and 3,700 cameras monitor the Forbidden City after it closes to the public at 5 p.m., Global Times reported, citing an article in Legal Mirror on May 1. The exhibition was scheduled to run from April 29 to June 27.

Because of an editing error, an article on May 4 about an academic program at Texas Tech University called Land Arts of the American West, in which students travel throughout the West, misstated the site of a residency program run by another environment-focused art initiative, the For-Site Foundation in San Francisco. The residency program is in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada mountain range in California, not in ''the Sierra, Nev., foothills.'' (There is no town in Nevada named Sierra.)

BLACK--Wendy Lipkind, adored by her son, Harry, her husband Hillel, and a world of loving friends, passed away after a brief but valiant fight against an insatiable cancer on May 9, 2011 at the age of 68. She began her career as a teacher of troubled teenagers and young adults and spent most of her working years as a literary agent who embraced her many authors to whom she was deeply devoted and whom she zealously defended. She profoundly touched all those who knew her for her compassion, kindness and delicious sense of humor. She was simply beloved and will be deeply missed. A private funeral service will be held. Donations in Wendy's memory may be made to the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids or The Bonnie J. Addario Lung Cancer Foundation.

OPENINGS MILLY is due to open its first store in the United States on Saturday, at 900 Madison Avenue (East 73rd Street); (212) 395- 9100; millyny.com. It will carry the label's sunny ready-to-wear and accessories, as well as a new line of jewelry and a bridal collection.

With the government securing a conviction against Raj Rajaratnam of the Galleon Group on Wednesday, federal prosecutors will shift their focus to expert networks - the intricate web of money managers, corporate executives and consultants at the center of another wave of insider trading cases. Over the last few years, the Justice Department has built dozens of insider trading cases. The government's effort has sent shivers through the hedge fund industry, the influential investors that have figured prominently in an investigation into Wall Street.

Q.I often see links posted on my friends' Facebook pages that I know are some sort of virus, even though it says my friend ''liked'' the page. Can I get infected myself if one of these links shows up on my Facebook News Feed or Wall? A.Many of those links promising a look at outrageous videos or photos are part of what is called a clickjacking scam. In this situation, the user is typically tricked into clicking on a provocative link, but hidden code within the page posts a copy of the tainted link to the profiles of all the user's friends.

PARIS -- As the film world and its attendant paparazzi and army of scribes descend upon the 64th Cannes Film Festival that begins today and runs through May 22, the French media has mused less about the plot of the opening film, Woody Allen's ''Midnight in Paris,'' than over whether one of its cast members, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, the first lady of France, would be one of those descending. Mr. Allen's film, showing out of competition, stars Owen Wilson and Rachel McAdams, and features Ms. Bruni-Sarkozy in a small role. She said Tuesday that she would not attend, amid speculation in the French news media that she is pregnant.

Making room for new shows, Fox on Tuesday gave pink slips to five series, including the dramas ''Lie to Me,'' which lasted for three seasons, and ''Human Target,'' which lasted for two. The other three shows to be canceled had been introduced midway through the current television season: ''The Chicago Code,'' a cop drama; ''Breaking In,'' a comedy starring Christian Slater; and ''Traffic Light,'' a comedy that was adapted from an Israeli series.

AFTER the royal wedding tizzy over hats -- who knew Princess Beatrice could spark an Internet meme? -- that bare summer straw may seem a bit ... bare. It's time to test your crafty skills with a D.I.Y. trick or two. Try twisting a leopard scarf over a solid ribbon for a layered effect, or weave grosgrain ribbon with a lightweight chain and stitch to the brim. For a Lanvin look, affix pieces of fluffy tulle to the sides. But Molly Yestadt of Yestadt Millinery on the Lower East Side advises that you keep the personalized touches light. ''It can be as simple as stitching your initials on the side of the crown,'' Ms. Yestadt said. One of her friends sewed a small carabiner to her hat so she can hook it on a belt strap when she rides her bike. Alternatively, choose one from the selection here. From top: woven fedora with loopy bows, $44 at Anthropologie, 50 Rockefeller Center, (212) 246-0386, anthropologie.com; sea grass topper embroidered with flowers, $305 at eugeniakim.com; raffia boater with linen trim, $270 at eugeniakim.com; Yestadt straw hat with a silk scarf, $358 at sales@yestadtmillinery.com.

Wagner Graduate School of Public Service from 1988 to 1994 and longtime professor of healthcare administration. It may seem the only way to improve voice mail is to do away with it. But an app called ''On Voicefeed,'' which lets you customize messages for different callers, makes voice jail a bit more palatable. When you download Voicefeed, which is available free for the iPhone, all of your contacts show up in the app. Your contacts can then be sorted into groups. They initially show up in the ''everyone else'' category, which means they will get a generic message that you can record. You can also type it in and let a robotic voice speak your message for you.

A new Broadway musical based on a classic series of children's books and updated for a modern audience? Should be bigger than ''Wicked,'' right? Not on this side of the looking glass, buddy. ''Wonderland,'' a costly production based on Lewis Carroll's novels, will close on Sunday, its press representatives said on Tuesday night, not quite one month after it opened at the Marquis Theater.

The fate of the Islanders' long quest for another home may be decided on Aug. 1, when Nassau County residents will vote in a special referendum to approve or reject a $400 million bond issue to finance a new arena for the team. County Executive Edward P. Mangano announced the referendum at Nassau Coliseum, where the Islanders have a lease that expires after the 2014-15 season. The plan calls for roughly $350 million in bonds for a new arena, construction of which would begin in 2012 alongside the Coliseum. The other $50 million would go toward building a minor league baseball stadium on the site.

Spring vegetables are the star of this week’s Eat column on pasta primavera, but water plays a key supporting role, and in fact, the most important step of many pasta recipes is scooping up a cupful of pasta-cooking water right before you drain the pasta. The unofficial sub-theme of our Money Issue is, What now? The worldwide recession is over (fingers crossed), and the developing world has seemingly forgotten that anything untoward ever happened. Meanwhile, in the U.S. and Europe, doubt, confusion and recriminations reign. While the recovery lurches ahead, dangers loom everywhere — the deficit battle in Washington, dissension in the European Union, oil-price shocks. For this year’s Money Issue, we went out in search of narratives that reflect this mixed-up state of affairs.

As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, despite a brutal crackdown in Syria, protesters took to the streets in at least five neighborhoods in Homs, Syria’s third-largest city and a center of the two-month uprising. Activists said protests ranged in numbers from hundreds to thousands, and at least two people were killed when security forces opened fire.

Nearly every teenager I’ve ever known likes to go to bed late and wake up late. So why does high school often start at 8 a.m.? Robert Daniel Vorona and a team of researchers decided to take advantage of a natural experiment. High schools in Virginia Beach, Virginia start 75-80 minutes earlier than high schools in the neighboring town of Chesapeake, which has similar demographics. Vorona and his team investigated whether students in Virginia Beach also had more automobile crashes. They did. Virginia Beach crash rates were significantly higher and their peak crash times were one hour earlier than peak Chesapeake crash times.  The study was published in the Journal of Clinical Sleep Medicine.

Does the future of female-driven comedy rest on on how well “Bridesmaids” fares at the box office? Writers around the Web are standing up for the film, hoping it will lead to more projects and opportunities for funny women in Hollywood. In her review, The Times’s Manohla Dargis praises the screenwriters Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo, saying they “know what female moviegoers want: honest laughs with, and not solely about, women.” She added that the film offers “irrefutable proof that along with producing and starring in a hit TV series (thank you, Tina Fey), women can go aggressive laugh to aggressive-and-absurd laugh with men. All they need, beyond talent and timing, a decent director and better lines, is a chance.”
