CANNES, France — For the last decade the director Gus Van Sant, a regular presence at the Cannes Film Festival, has undergone an artistic rebirth with movies about death. In 2003 he won the festival’s top prize, the Palme d’Or, for “Elephant,” his minimalist evocation of a Columbine-like school shooting. He returned to the competition here with “Last Days” (2005), an opaque antibiopic about the final hours of a suicidal rock star modeled on Kurt Cobain, and “Paranoid Park” (2007), a coming-of-age tale whose teenage hero wrestles with his culpability in a man’s gruesome trainyard demise.

The dearth of women television writers is well documented. But it reached a sort of negative milestone last year when Neely Swanson, a former development executive and adjunct professor at the U.S.C. School of Cinematic Arts, published her essay “Women Can’t Create and White Men Can’t Jump” at the behest of the Deadline Hollywood blogger Nikki Fink, who called 2010 the “worst network pilot season for women.” Melissa Silverstein, of the blog Women and Hollywood, was one of many to pick up the story. She compared the numbers and showed, for example, that there was an 11 percent decline in comedy pilots by women writers between 2009 and 2010.

After about seven years of collaborating with various retailers, the men behind Salvor Projects will open their first shop this Saturday. “The store is like a lab,” the designer Ross Menuez says, having sought a space where he could continue to experiment with his designs as well as bring together everything Salvor has done in the past. Specializing in screen prints, they hope to cater to a range of customers from the Madison Avenue woman interested in a graphic tote bag to your average skateboarder looking for a printed shirt. At the shop, these mostly one-of-a-kind pieces are displayed against an austere, monotone interior that allows the clothes to be the focal point — an architectural decision that should attract many a design enthusiast. Prices range from $140 – $300. Salvor Projects, 172 Forsyth Street. Go to www.salvorprojects.com.

Life on Earth is getting stranger by the minute. Parakeets are flocking in Britain, as described in Elisabeth Rosenthal’s news story today. But don’t forget the monk parrots in Brooklyn, the American bullfrogs in Japan and France, the Burmese pythons in the Everglades, the West Nile virus spanning the Americas. (Oh, and the American squirrels that are also displacing their kin in Britain.) You get the idea.

“In a city that thrums with opportunity and a veritable buffet of wonderful things to do — theaters! museums! parks! — flea markets have somehow emerged as many people’s first choice of a way to spend the weekend,” writes Ashley Parker in this week’s Metropolitan cover article, “The Flea Marketing of New York.” Over the last few years, the markets, with their vintage clothing, handmade jewelry and profusion of handcrafted foods have proliferated, as have the crowds drawn to them. On Brooklyn Flea’s opening weekend, about 25,000 people filed through the Fort Greene and Williamsburg markets, according to the organizers, and SuChin Pak, a founder of the Hester Street Fair, estimated that 11,000 people came to her market’s opening day this year. Read Ms. Parker’s explanation of how shopping for vintage clothing, old typewriters and artisanal cheese became the hippest way to spend your weekend here.

Many parents dread homework time, and the struggle they will have to go through to get their kids to do it. So, is all this effort worthwhile? Over the years a disturbing amount of evidence has emerged suggesting that it is not.  For a forthcoming study in the journal Economics of Education Review, Ozkan Eren and Daniel Henderson measured the effect of homework on math, science, English and history tests for 8th grade students in the United States. They used a method that controlled student and teacher traits.  They found that doing additional math homework had large and statistically significant effects on math test scores. They found that additional homework in science, English and history had little or no impact.

By now we can assume that Prince William and the new Duchess of Cambridge have consummated their marriage, or anyway we can hope. These things can be problematic. It’s said, for example, to have taken seven years for the Dauphin Louis-Auguste of France, later Louis XVI, and the Hapsburg Archduchess Maria Antonia, known as Marie Antoinette, to consummate their union. (They were just teenagers, 15 and 14, at the time of their wedding in 1770, though on the face of it that would hardly explain the delay.) But at least William and Kate can spend time alone. In the old days, servants and witnesses would have been spending the night in the royal bedchamber with them.

In this weekend’s Your Money column, I encouraged readers to storm the barricades (but nicely!) to suggest improvements to their 401(k) or other retirement plans. Namely, I suggest that the majority of plans could use more index mutual funds.

Arthur Kulkov, the Siberian born, Coney Island raised in-demand model currently towering over Port Authority in an ad over five stories tall, is known around town for his eccentric and super-stylish way. His ease with fashion and sense of humor about his style adds to his appeal as a professional model, certainly. But his eye-catching outfits and lack of self-consciousness are what really sets him apart. “I hate to say that this business has influenced my style, but it certainly did. All these years you have no choice but to pick up on things here and there, but obviously with my own spin on things. Ha.” While on the set for a campaign shoot in Sarasota, Fla., he caught stares sporting these Day-Glo orange pieces (athletic sandals and shorts by Adidas, hat by American Apparel). He ordered the flip-flops from a soccer magazine, got the shorts at Y-3 and snagged the hat from another shoot. “I thought it was brightly cool … I wouldn’t rock all together, but I think it looks cool in parts.”

“Catch Me if You Can” might have gotten mixed reviews, but pretty much everyone agrees that Norbert Leo Butz’s rendition of “Don’t Break the Rules” in the first act is the kind of showstopper you don’t see on Broadway all that often. Except this season, which is notable for numbers that, through the alchemy of song, sound, legs, lights and star power — not to mention tap dancing — build into something more joyful than the sum of their parts.

In this weekend’s Times Magazine, I have a column explaining the tight link between education and income for religious groups in this country. The most educated groups, like Hindus and Jews, are the most affluent, while the least educated are the least affluent. The chart with the column has more details.

CANNES, France— We’ve traversed the red carpets and the publicity stunts. But there is another side to the film festival here: the maritime side. We’re talking, of course, about yachts. Big ones and bigger ones, they crowd the harbor, drawing gawkers and aspirants (and Diddy). Really, no trip to the French Riviera is complete without a yacht party. And though the festival may be the pinnacle of the “glamour racket,” as Manohla Dargis noted in The New York Times, but that doesn’t mean it’s without its share of left-field come-ons.

Thousands of people swear by the philosophy of Dave Ramsey, an up-by-the-bootstraps kind of guy who doles out tough financial advice about getting out of debt and living within your means. His legions of fans call his nationally syndicated radio show to seek his advice, attend his self-help seminars in both big arenas and small church classrooms and buy his best-selling books and DVDs. He’s part entertainer, part financial coach.

The composer and lyricist Adam Gwon and the book writer and lyricist Michelle Elliott are the recipients of the 2011 Kleban Prize, which recognizes talent and promise in musical theater, the sponsors of the prize said this week. Each award comes with a cash prize of $100,000, payable over two years.

“This is going to be the sexiest salon uptown,” said Ric Pipino, whose sprawling new beauty destination, Ric Pipino-Wella Professional Flagship, is more like a really cool apartment. Conceived by Rawlins Calderone Design, the space is superglam, with black and white walls that serve as graphic foil to a colorful mix of vintage and custom furniture and accessories. The front desk is an homage to the ’70s designer Paul Evans, while the slick red “color bar” is pure Donald Judd. Besides a full menu of services, there’s a boutique selling art books and chocolate, and a bar stocked with Scotch and tequila for clients needing something stiffer than Elnett. 115 East 57th Street; (212) 355-5544.

A “machine for living” was how Le Corbusier famously described his vision for the home. Le Corbusier, the Swiss architect, however, was transfixed by machines of less metaphorical form, like airplanes, ocean liners and locomotives. He called steam shovels and fountain pens the “fauna of the new age.” And he was particularly fascinated with the car, or so argues the author of a new book.

Undiscovered truths are a big part of comic-book stories. On our hardcover list this week, “S.H.I.E.L.D.: Architects of Forever” (No. 10) shares some big secrets about the Marvel Universe. The story, by Jonathan Hickman and Dustin Weaver, collects the first six issues of an adventure that reveals how some luminaries of the past – including Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo and Isaac Newton – protected the Marvel Universe long before heroes like Captain America, Iron Man and Spider-Man were born.

Those of us who follow fashion and photography tend to have a favorite image of Kate Moss. I have two: Corinne Day’s portrait (styled by Melanie Ward) of a laughing and feather-headdressed Kate for a 1990 cover of The Face; and Mario Sorrenti’s 1993 image of her, with its deep shadow and her eyes looking at once tender and wary. The early ’90s announced a more stripped-down view of fashion — call it grunge, if you like — and the waif Kate fit the bill as she inspired an industry.

Alexandra Zissu is wondering what your children call their grandparents. In an article in yesterday’s Styles section, she notes that Gwyneth Paltrow’s kids, Apple and Moses, call Blythe Danner “Lalo” (even though Ms. Danner tried at first to get them to call her “Woof”). Inflation rose again last month, roughly in line with economists’ expectations, to 3.1 percent over the last year. Core inflation — a measure that removes volatile and food and energy prices — also rose, with airfares, car prices and toy prices up. Core inflation is not a particularly good measure of how prices are affecting people’s lives, because food and energy prices obviously matter, but it does tend to be a better guide to where overall inflation is headed.

One thing I’ve been meaning to post about for a while is a common misunderstanding of what monetary doves — not just me, but also Ben Bernanke, Bill Dudley at the NY Fed, and others — believe about commodity prices and broader inflation. Specifically, I often find people assuming or asserting that for the dovish view to be proved right, commodity prices have to go back down. But that’s not at all right; the dovish view relies only on the assertion that the rapid rate of rise in prices since last summer will not continue indefinitely.

Well, it was a club,” says Eleanor Stefani, the longtime owner of the Colony of Wellfleet. “It was a private club. You had to have your name in the Social Register — literally!” The 10 Bauhaus-style cottages, which have housed devoted guests for decades, were first known as the Mayo Hill Colony Club. They were built on the bay side of Wellfleet, the little Cape Cod town, in 1949 by Nathaniel Saltonstall, an architect from a prominent Boston family who was a founder of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston. Along with his business partner Oliver Morton, he designed it as a midcentury Modern retreat for high-society art collectors, with views of the sparkling bay and grassy fairways of the Chequessett Yacht and Country Club through the pines.

If you use the Mozilla Firefox browser and do not like the program's Downloads window cluttering your screen when you are snagging files off the Web, you can tidy things up with the Downloads in Tab add-on. The add-on is available on Mozilla's site here.

Art fairs and auctions are usually seen as playgrounds for high-flying insiders, like dealers and collectors. What most travelers don’t know is that they are often also open to the public. And in Hong Kong, a city with tepid museum options, they are often a better bet than the places written about in travel guides. The trick is being in town at the right time and finding events that are not widely advertised.

The Mark Twain Prize for American Humor is named for one of history's most distinguished satirists and has, since 1998, been awarded to noteworthy comedians and writers like Whoopi Goldberg, Bob Newhart, Neil Simon and Bill Cosby. But somehow, it just got a little classier: Will Ferrell, the ''Saturday Night Live'' alumnus turned star of hit films like ''Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby'' and ''Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy,'' will be the 14th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts said on Thursday morning. Mr. Ferrell said in a statement that he was ''truly honored to receive this distinction,'' adding: ''I will now begin cultivating a Mark Twain-esque mustache in anticipation of the event.'' The award - which comes with a copy of an 1884 bronze portrait bust of Twain sculptured by Karl Gerhardt - will be officially presented to Mr. Ferrell at a Kennedy Center ceremony on Oct. 23. (The ceremony will be taped for television, though a broadcast date was not immediately announced.) Mr. Ferrell, who recently wrapped a four-episode stint on ''The Office'' and appears in the new film ''Everything Must Go,'' is one of several ''S.N.L.'' figures to receive the Twain Prize, including last year's winner, Tina Fey; Lorne Michaels, the creator and executive producer of ''S.N.L.,'' who won in 2004; and Steve Martin, a frequent ''S.N.L.'' host, who won in 2005.

MIAMI - On the night he finally vanquished the Boston Celtics, LeBron James was consumed by an odd blend of emotions: elation and contrition, satisfaction and vindication. In the moment, it all made sense. He knelt in quiet reflection late Wednesday. He hugged Dwyane Wade. He smiled and exulted. And he apologized.

Two public broadcasting anchor chairs are getting new occupants. Audie Cornish, National Public Radio's Congressional correspondent, will be the new host of ''Weekend Edition Sunday,'' NPR announced Thursday, while Jim Lehrer of PBS said he is stepping down from a regular anchor role on the ''PBS NewsHour'' effective June 6. Mr. Lehrer, 76, said he would continue to appear on the program many Fridays. But for the rest of the week he'll step out of the anchor rotation that the newscast instituted in December 2009, which was the same time that Mr. Lehrer took his name off the program.

It was a fall game in 1986 between the Boston Red Sox and the Mets. An error by Bill Buckner led to a run and helped open the door for a Mets victory. But it wasn't Game 6 of the 1986 World Series; it was a September exhibition game to benefit Boston's Jimmy Fund and the New York Amateur Baseball Foundation. While in-season exhibition games are largely a thing of the past, baseball's connection to the Jimmy Fund remains. The latest chapter begins May 21, when some of the game's top minds will gather at Harvard for a two-day seminar, ''Sabermetrics, Scouting and the Science of Baseball.''

8:15 p.m. | Updated Ending a five-year court battle over music piracy, the major record companies on Thursday settled a copyright infringement lawsuit with LimeWire, a popular file-sharing network, for $105 million, the Recording Industry Association of America announced. In the suit, filed in 2006, the labels and the R.I.A.A., their trade group, accused LimeWire of running a Web service ''devoted essentially'' to piracy by allowing users to upload and download songs without permission. LimeWire began in 2000, and the labels contend that Mark Gorton, 44, the site's creator and a defendant in the case, continued to operate it even after the Supreme Court ruled in 2005 that a similar service, Grokster, could be held liable for infringement.

The headline of an obituary on April 27 about Madame Nhu, the official hostess in South Vietnam's presidential palace in the early years of the Vietnam War, misstated her age. She was 86, not 87. As the obituary said, at the time of her death she was believed to be 87. The Times was unable then to determine her exact date of birth. Subsequent research has established that she was born on Aug. 22, 1924, which means she was 86 when she died.

An obituary on Tuesday about the physicist Willard S. Boyle erroneously attributed a distinction to him and a colleague, Don Nelson. In 1962 they developed the first ruby laser to emit a continuous beam of light; they did not develop the ruby laser, which was invented by Theodore Maiman in 1960.

An article on Wednesday about problems in the microlending industry paraphrased incorrectly a quote by Vikram Akula, chairman of the Indian company SKS Microfinance. Mr. Akula said that loan repayments might go up in Andrhra Pradesh state if the government there eased rules on new lending, not if it restricted such lending there.

In Chapter 2 of a long story that is growing longer, the Metropolitan Museum of Art filed suit Tuesday in United States District Court in Manhattan seeking possession of a painting now in the hands of Robert Wylde, a British collector. The 1981 painting, ''The Innocent Eye Test'' by Mark Tansey, was bought by Mr. Wylde for $2.5 million from the Gagosian Gallery in 2009. Last year, the gallery told Mr. Wylde it had learned that the Met already owned 31 percent of the painting -- which depicts a cow gazing at a portrait of other cows -- and that the other owner had promised that the museum would eventually own the whole thing. Mr. Wylde filed suit in federal court in Manhattan against the gallery, contending it had misled him, and held on to the painting. According to the suit filed by Mr. Wylde on Tuesday, the owner of the other 69 percent of the painting is Jan Cowles, the mother of Charles Cowles, a longtime art dealer who had previously owned the painting. Mr. Cowles, reached by The New York Times in March, said the whole dispute was his fault: ''I didn't even think about whether the Met owned part of it or not.'' He added, ''And one day I saw it on the wall and thought, 'Hey, I could use the money' and so I decided to sell it.''

BERYLSON--Kermit J.,died on May 9, 2011 at age 97. He was a senior partner at KPMG in New York City, and was on General Eisenhower's staff planning D-Day in World War II. Born in NYC in March 1914, he received his BA and MBA degrees with distinction from City College of New York and Columbia University, respectively; worked on development of the Hoover Dam in Nevada before joining the armed forces; and was certified as a CPA in the states of New York, Illinois and California after the War. His military service began at the War Department in the Pentagon, moved on to the desert war in North Africa with General Patton, and then to SHAEF (Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force) in London working on airborne logistics for the invasion of Continental Europe. After participating in the invasion, he rejoined General Patton in the 3rd Army fighting at the battles of Huertgen Forest and the Bulge (Bastogne). After U.S. victory at the Bulge, he was with the Allied troops held at the Elbe River by General Eisenhower in order to allow the Russian Army to be the first to enter Berlin. His War service included participation in the liberation of Paris, Munich and Dachau (concentration camp), was honored by four major service medals for valor, and culminated with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. After the war, while building his distinguished accounting career, he was also a member of the ERISA Advisory Council of the U.S. Department of Labor, was a management consultant to the Pension Benefits Guaranty Corporation, served as President of the New York State Society of CPAs, and was awarded the Royal Order of Vasa by the Kingdom of Sweden for services to the Crown. He was the loving and beloved husband of the late Marjorie Cantor Berylson for 50 years before her death. He is survived and lovingly remembered by his daughter and her husband, Jane and Stephen Flechner of Denver, and by his son and his wife, John and Amy Smith Berylson of Boston. He is also survived and remembered by his adoring grandchildren, Jennifer (and her husband Jonathan Block), Laura, James, and Elizabeth. He was respected and admired by all who had the privilege of knowing him. Private family interment service will be held at Mt Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson.

RECHTSCHAFFEN--Frances, died peacefully on May 11, 2011, many years after Alzheimer's had sadly deprived her family and friends of Fran's wit and wisdom. Fran was that rare, honest voice; she spoke her mind, never hesitating to give her opinion, challenging those around her about matters great and small, and that is what everyone expected from her. Family and friends including many with far more formal education than she ever attained sought her wisdom and made major life decisions based on her insights and intuitive knowledge of the right choice. She had an innate curiosity about intriguing topics, relishing conversations with interesting people, but not suffering fools or bores gladly. She was good at everything she tried she could sing and dance like the Broadway star she might have been, she was a Life Master in bridge, she could unclog a sink, cook a gourmet meal and design a house (friends would never dream of remodeling without Fran reviewing the blueprints). Her sense of style, grace and design were so incredibly natural. Her sense of humor and mischievousness were ever present her threats to tip over the table in response to bad restaurant service or her telling her young children, to their embarrassment in front of their classmates, that they needed to hurry home after school to skin the elephants she kept in the basement (because that's where corned beef comes from!). She always had games to play with her grandchildren thumbs wars and hand-slap contests and old jokes to tell. With her beloved husband Joe, who died three years ago, she treasured living in New York. She loved dining at Shun Lee Palace and Il Nido but was happy having a frank at Papaya King. She loved visiting museums but was just as happy sitting for hours with Joe by the sailboat pond in Central Park. She loved taking her grandchildren shopping at Bloomingdales but she could not pass up a bargain at Loehmann's. Fran will live on through her children, Stephan, Rob, Lisa and Scott, and her 10 grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She was a remarkable woman, so ahead of her time and yet so perfect in every moment of the day. We will miss her.

Two star singers have backed out of the Metropolitan Opera's tour to Japan, the Met said on Thursday. The news is sure to stir dissatisfaction among some members of the company who have expressed worry over safety risks following the nuclear emergency in Japan caused by the March earthquake and resulting tsunami. The Met, citing reassurances from the State Department and experts, has said it was going ahead with the two-week tour in June, and that all company employees - chorus and orchestra members and others - would be required to go. The Met said that Jonas Kaufmann withdrew from the title role of ''Don Carlo'' for ''personal reasons'' and that Olga Borodina would not sing the role of Eboli because doctors had told her to rest her voice for two months. ''She has real vocal issues that have caused her to pull out of a number of engagements,'' said Peter Clark, a spokesman for the Met.

An article on Saturday about the Boston Bruins' elimination of the Philadelphia Flyers in the N.H.L. Eastern Conference semifinals misstated the given name of a Bruins center. It is Rich Peverley, not Nick. The article also misstated the time when several players were acquired by the Bruins. Tomas Kaberle, Chris Kelly and Peverley were acquired during the regular season, not the off-season. Brad Marchand, a Bruins center, was a rookie with the team in the 2009-10 season.

WEISSMAN--Vivian J. March 22, 1921 May 10, 2011. Lee Vivian Betty Jacobs grew up in Baltimore, Maryland, daughter of Gustav and Bertha Jacobs. In the 1940s, she moved to New York City to seek her fortune. She landed a job in high-tech, which at the time meant radio, working at WNEW. She also met the love of her life, Lester Weissman, and the two married in 1950. After the birth of her only child, Robert, Vivian became a full-time homemaker while Lester successfully supported the family with his Jersey City clothing store, Danforth Factory Outlet, and, later his second store in Closter, Danforth Wearhouse. In 1960, the family moved to Tenafly, New Jersey, which remained their longtime home. Eventually, Vivian returned to college to complete her education, receiving Bachelor's and Master's degrees from Fairleigh Dickenson University. After Lester's death in 2002, Vivian struggled with memory loss and dementia. Her decline was rapid and tragic. In 2004, she moved into an assisted living facility in Edgewater, NJ, where she spent her remaining years. She is survived by her son Robert and daughter-in-law Judy, of Sunnyvale, California. At Vivian's request, no memorial will be held. A graveside service only will be held at Cedar Park Cemetery at Forest Ave. and Soldier Hill Rd. in Paramus, NJ, on Monday, May 16, 2011 at 10:30am.

SACKS--Rhoda, Aged 82, she peacefully died on April 24, 2011 in hospice care at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center. Her husband of 63 years, Joe; her children, Lorna and David Rubin, Bill and Millie Sacks, and Amy Krafft; and her grandchildren, Elizabeth and Michael Clements, Kathryn, Geoffrey, Laura, Samantha, Bennett, and John; her sister Florence and Sy Rappel; all miss and mourn her. Known for her fierce competition on the golf course and at the bridge table, she was an even fiercer advocate for her husband and children. She was an accomplished painter and the family arbiter of fashion. And she made a superlative brisket. We miss all these things, but most of all we miss her laughter that filled the space around her and made the world a more cheerful place. Instead of transient flowers, the family request contributions to be sent to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL, 33407. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Nassau, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY on May 16, 2011 at noon.

SIEGEL--Anita, 72, Artist, best known for her collages made from found images, died May 3, 2011 in Manhattan. She had been ill for several years. Her death was confirmed by her longtime friend Nancy Grossman, an artist with whom Siegel was famously photographed with a scarf tied around both of their heads by Richard Avedon. Born in Brooklyn, 1939, and entirely self-taught, she worked in sculpture, constructions of wood, metal and cloth, but is most recognized for her sardonic collages seamlessly combining pictures into biting satires. Siegel was one of the first artists whose work was used on the Op-Ed page of the New York Times when the use of art was initiated by Editor Charlotte Curtis and Lou Silverstein. Her memorable images appeared frequently during the Vietnam and Watergate Eras. Between 1956 and 2004, her work was exhibited in Museums and Galleries such as The Brooklyn Museum, Krasner Gallery, The Riverside Museum, Art Directors Club, Frank Rehn Gallery, The American Institute of Graphic Art, The Jewish Theological Seminary -- all in New York; The Weatherspoon Museum of Art, North Carolina; Louvre Musee des Arts Decoratifs, Paris, France; Musee des Beaux-Arts, Bordeaux, France; Palais des Beaux-Arts, Brussels, Belgium. Her collages appeared in numerous publications such as Harper's Bazaar, Esquire, Ms. Magazine and The Saturday Review. She was honored by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, Art Director's Clubs of New York and New Jersey and the Society of Publication Designers respectively in 1972, '73 and '74 with Certificates of Merit and Excellence. She is survived by her sister Arlene Gindoff and her niece Allana Syllvan, both of Jackson, NJ.

MISURATA, Libya - If the official statements by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi about the battle for this city were true, then much that was visible around the airport on Thursday did not actually happen or exist. There were no clusters of rebels and machine-gun trucks at the traffic circle by the outdoor bazaar and huge mosque. The empty fighting holes, left in haste on Wednesday by fleeing Qaddafi soldiers, were not empty. The loyalist soldiers there were just especially well-camouflaged.

Violet, her injured leg, and her week-old baby are staying put after all. After a day of closely observing Violet, the red-tailed hawk who has nested high above the New York University campus, a medical rescue team decided that she was functioning well enough, and that the dangers posed by intervention -- both to her and the baby -- were so great that the best course of action was not to act.

The American Theater Wing, which is a presenter of the Tony Awards and has expanded theater education and internship programs in recent years, announced on Wednesday that its next executive director would be Heather Hitchens, who now holds the same position at the New York State Council on the Arts. During her nearly four years at the state arts agency, Ms. Hitchens has overseen the distribution of $123 million in grants to more than 2,000 groups covering the artistic spectrum, according to a statement from the American Theater Wing. Appointed as the council's executive director in 2007 by Eliot Spitzer, who was governor at the time, Ms. Hitchens has presided over an annual budget that has declined from $55 million when she arrived to roughly $35 million for the 2011-12 fiscal year - a four-year period during which New York State government grappled with budget deficit after deficit.

In February 1861, just weeks after Louisiana seceded from the Union, Randall Lee Gibson enlisted as a private in a state army regiment. The son of a wealthy sugar planter and valedictorian of Yale’s Class of 1853, Gibson had long supported secession. Conflict was inevitable, he believed, not because of states’ rights or the propriety or necessity of slavery. Rather, a war would be fought over the inexorable gulf between whites and blacks, or what he called “the most enlightened race” and “the most degraded of all the races of men.” Because Northern abolitionists were forcing the South to recognize “the political, civil, and social equality of all the races of men,” Gibson wrote, the South was compelled to enjoy “independence out of the Union.” (Read Randall Lee Gibson’s article, “Our Federal Union.”)

TUNICA, Miss. - Like countless communities up and down the Mississippi River, life these days in this town of 1100, and its surrounding countryside, depends on which side of the levee you're on. The town center, shielded from the river, looks nothing more than a bit bedraggled, while on the other side, flood waters have invaded homes, displaced hundreds and submerged crop fields.

Jake Halpern has an exuberant curiosity about people in their natural habitats; I think of him as a kind of maestro of attentively hanging out (for instance here and here). So when we sent him to Iceland to report on that country’s small steps toward economic recovery, we knew we’d get a great tale about people. We did. And we got a bonus. Even before he’d even left Iceland, Jake sent an e-mail containing another, more personal tale (see what I mean about exuberant?), this one about scalding rivers running through an icy landscape, a snowstorm and what’s best left to the imagination.

In recent weeks, while traversing the wet, wooded areas of friends’ backyards in Greenwich, Conn., and Westchester County, I discovered lush carpets of two-leaved plants under the dappled light of deciduous trees. Crouching down low among last year’s foliage, I found that while the stems of the plants in Greenwich were white and the ones in Westchester were reddish, the air in both areas was filled with the distinctive fragrance of onions. Ramps. I quickly considered the culinary possibilities — savory ramp pie, scrambled eggs with ramps, ramps with morels.

Dozens were injured in the attack, which took place in an area northwest of China’s Gansu Province.

BRADLEY--Janet Rich. Died on May 12 of congestive heart failure in her home in Scottsdale, AZ at the age of 90. She was the widow of John S. Bradley, Jr., and the sister of Rita Rich Fraad and Paula Rich Ainsley, both of New York and both deceased. She is survived by her three children, Anne Bradley of Washington, D.C., Betsy Kammerle of Scottsdale, AZ, and James Bradley of Bangkok, Thailand, two grandsons, Benjamin of New York City and John of Portland, OR; and her son-in-law, Robert Kammerle of Scottsdale AZ. She is also survived by her two nieces, Sara Fraad Henderson and Martha Fraad Haffey. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations are made to Hospice of the Valley in Scottsdale, AZ.

8 P.M. (HBO) HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON (2010) In this 3-D feature from DreamWorks Animation, a teenage Viking named Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) befriends an injured dragon on a windswept island, pleases his demanding father (Gerard Butler) and saves the world in the process. The airborne sequences made the movie particularly compelling when seen in a theater with special glasses. ''When Hiccup first climbs on Toothless's back and urges the dragon to take wing, the hearts of the audience soar with a primitive and durable delight,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The techniques that enabled this feeling may be dauntingly complicated, but the feeling could not be simpler.'' At the beginning and the end, '' 'How to Train Your Dragon' is noisy and action-packed in the usual way,'' Mr. Scott added, with ''eye-straining, ear-popping large-scale effects.'' But they are worth sitting through, he said, ''for the tenderness, beauty and exhilaration that are the movie's great strengths.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro reports from Ethiopia on Dr. Catherine Hamlin, a former missionary who, with her husband, founded a hospital to treat women suffering from obstetric fistulas, a complication of childbirth that afflicts an estimated two million women in underdeveloped countries, and which often leads to their being shunned in their communities.

PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. - While controversy continued to swirl around him, Rory Sabbatini played himself into contention for a second consecutive week. Sabbatini, who finished third in the Wells Fargo Championship, carded a one-under-par 71 Friday and is four strokes off the lead at the halfway point of the Players Championship. His fine play coincides with his appeal to avoid suspension by the PGA Tour over a loud on-course argument with a playing partner, Sean O'Hair, at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans three weeks ago. According to The Associated Press, it was the second time this year that Sabbatini has run into trouble because of his behavior on the golf course. The first incident came at the Northern Trust Open in Los Angeles, where Sabbatini reportedly had harsh words for a teenage volunteer who was trying to help him find a lost ball.

Because of an editing error, a classical music entry in the Listings pages in some editions on Friday about the Little Opera Theater of New York's production of Mozart's ''Mitridate, re di Ponto'' included an outdated Web address. The correct site for more information is www.lotny.org.

The approaching end of federal guarantees for very expensive mortgages is worrying potential home buyers - and sellers - in high-cost markets. Will they be able to get financing? How much more will they have to pay for that financing? The limits on mortgages that can be backed by the federal government were raised in 2008 to ease the pain of the housing debacle in areas with high home prices. (Without government backing, many lenders would have refused to finance such loans when the housing bubble burst.) But the current higher limits are due to expire Sept. 30 unless Congress acts to extend them.

Oprah Winfrey is powerful, but she did not single-handedly reschedule the Eastern Conference finals. However, she will be borrowing the Chicago Bulls' home court for 48 hours next week. The Bulls and the Miami Heat open the conference finals Sunday night at the United Center. Winfrey will occupy the arena the next two days, to set up and tape a farewell show. The playoffs resume Wednesday night.

A music review on Friday about the Dallas Symphony Orchestra and Chorus's performance of the oratorio ''August 4, 1964,'' at Carnegie Hall, misidentified the type of American vessel attacked by North Vietnamese torpedo boats on Aug. 2, 1964, an attack that was part of what became known as the Gulf of Tonkin incident, a subject of the oratorio. It was a destroyer, not a battleship. (While United States officials initially believed that two American destroyers were also attacked on Aug. 4, 1964, and President Lyndon B. Johnson ordered retaliatory bombing, many historians have since concluded that there was no second attack.)

Senator Herb Kohl, the four-term Democrat from Wisconsin, is to announce Friday that he will not seek re-election, making him the sixth member of the Democratic caucus to retire and handing his party another competitive open seat to defend. Democratic officials confirmed the decision of the quiet lawmaker who owns the Milwaukee Bucks and whose name is widely known in Wisconsin from the team ownership as well as the chain of Kohl's department stores his family formerly owned.

An article on Friday about Tiger Woods's withdrawal from the Players Championship misstated the year of his last tournament victory. It was November 2009, not 2008.

Ashton Kutcher, one of the former stars of the sitcom ''That 70's Show,'' has been selected to replace Charlie Sheen on the hit comedy ''Two and a Half Men,'' Warner Brothers and CBS announced on Friday. The selection of Mr. Kutcher had been rumored since Thursday, when he signaled the news to his followers on Twitter with the cryptic message ''What's the square root of 6.25?'' (The answer: 2.5.)

The composer and lyricist Adam Gwon and the book writer and lyricist Michelle Elliott are the recipients of the 2011 Kleban Prize, which recognizes talent and promise in musical theater, the sponsors of the prize said this week. Each award comes with a cash prize of $100,000, payable over two years. Mr. Gwon, a 31-year-old New Yorker, won the prize for most promising musical theater lyricist. His musical ''Ordinary Days,'' about four young New Yorkers trying their wings in the city, had a sold-out run at the Roundabout Theater Company and was followed by productions in London's West End and at theaters across the United States. His musical, ''The Boy Detective Fails'' (with a book by Joe Meno), is to have its premiere at the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., this fall.

We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Adrienne, his daughter, Wendy, and his son, James, and to all other members of the Weill family. Murray was a pioneer in the commercial real estate industry, paving the way for future generations to benefit from his foresight. He will be sorely missed.

An article on Wednesday about a report by a research group in Afghanistan that challenged the quality of information used by NATO forces to identify and kill suspected Taliban insurgents misstated the report's conclusion concerning an Afghan man, identified by NATO as a Taliban insurgent, who was targeted and killed in a NATO attack in Takhar Province. The report concluded that NATO had used flawed intelligence and killed the wrong man, partly because his name had been used as an alias by a Taliban insurgent -- not that the episode illustrated how shifting allegiances and identities among a number of players in Afghanistan make it ''nearly impossible to make accurate judgments about them.'' The article also misstated the name of the group that produced the report. It is the Afghanistan Analysts Network, not the Afghan Analysts Network.

A late-game scoring burst enabled LeBron James to vanquish the Celtics and silence those detractors who had said he couldn't close. Now that he has finally beaten the Big 3 - Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen and Paul Pierce - in a playoff series, James will turn his attention to the Chicago Bulls in the Eastern Conference finals. When he glances at the Chicago sideline, he will see an old nemesis, Coach Tom Thibodeau.

LIEBERMAN--Dr. Florence, a pioneer of clinical social work, was 93. She battled breast cancer for 25 years, but still was editing a new book and seeing clients. Professor emeritus at Hunter College School of Social Work, she wrote "Social Work with Children," "Before Addiction" and other books and established the Child & Adolescent Social Work Journal. When the National Academies of Practice was formed to honor distinguished figures in health fields, she was elected the first president of its Social Work Academy. Survived by daughter Dr. Joan Kellerman and son Paul Lieberman. Services, 1:30pm, Monday at Frank E. Campbell funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue.

An obituary on Tuesday about Willard S. Boyle erroneously attributed a distinction to him and a colleague, Don Nelson. In 1962 they developed the first ruby laser to emit a continuous beam of light; they did not develop the ruby laser, which was invented by Theodore Maiman in 1960. A correction in this space on Friday misstated Mr. Boyle's profession in some copies. He was a physicist, not a physician.

If you are a stay-at-home mom (or dad) and want a credit card, you should consider applying for one, pronto. A pending change in the way card companies must evaluate applications will probably make it much harder for people who don't have their own, independent income to get one. As part of a clarification of the Credit Card Act of 2009, the Federal Reserve board has made it tougher for stay-at-home spouses to get their own credit cards. (Discussions of the Fed's rule can be found in U.S. News & World Report's Alpha Consumer blog, and on creditcards.com.)

Herman Cornejo, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will not perform during the first two weeks of the company's season, Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director, announced on Thursday. Mr. Cornejo, who withdrew due to an injury, was scheduled to perform in ''Don Quixote'' on May 19 and in Antony Tudor's ''Shadowplay'' on May 24 and 25. Rolando Sarabia, a veteran of the National Ballet of Cuba and Miami City Ballet, will replace Mr. Cornejo for the performances of ''Don Quixote.'' Craig Salstein, a soloist, will replace Mr. Cornejo in ''Shadowplay'' at both performances. The company earlier announced that Ethan Stiefel, another principal, would withdraw from the entire season. This is the first time Mr. Sarabia will appear with the company. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DuBOURG--Antoine, of Newport, RI, died in his sleep on Thursday, May 12, at age 82. In collaboration with Clare Gesualdo his dear friend and companion for over 40 years Tony enabled thousands of high school students to profit from his contagious love of music. First for 46 years at the Pingry School in New Jersey, and then at St. George's School in Middletown, RI, he invigorated existing gleeclub and choir curricula. He also introduced Brass Choirs to each institution. Their performances reflected Tony's exceptional talent in generating adolescent enthusiasm. This was his all consuming focus in life. Nothing came in the way of his fierce loyalty to his students. They sang and played at celebrated concert halls in England, Europe and the United States. They even toured behind the Iron Curtain in the 1970s. Through Tony's generosity both Pingry and St. George's increased the quality and quantity of instruments available for student performances. Tony's second teaching discipline was physics, a lifelong interest. As was sailing, shared with Clare. With headquarters on Cape Cod or Martha's Vineyard they were joined by friend and students on summer sailing adventures. Born in Paris, Tony came to the Untied States at age 11. He first attended the Buckley School in New York City and then the Harvey School. He was in the Class of 1947 at St. Paul's School, Concord, NH and in the Class of 1951 at Hamilton College. Tony served in the US Army before beginning his teaching career in the mid 1950's. His half brother Joseph McCrindle died some years ago. Donations may be made to Music at St. George's, St. George's School, P.O. Box 1910, Newport, RI 02840

DÜSSELDORF, Germany -- When the Armenian singer known as Emmy appeared onstage sitting in an oversize boxing glove on Tuesday night, European viewers knew that at least one performer was upholding the traditions that the Eurovision Song Contest is known for: an over-the-top stage performance and a forgettable tune sung in questionable English. Eurovision, a Continental battle of the bands that has been building to a climax this week with live televised semifinals, is often dismissed as tacky, politicized and rarely capable of producing durable stars. Yet this wildly popular song contest may also be just the thing that Europe needs right now.

COHN--Howard, passed away peacefully on May 12, 2011, at age 88. A World War II veteran (Pacific theater), Howard was an accomplished writer and editor who worked at Collier's, Pageant, and True magazines before joining McGraw-Hill in 1968, where he spent the next 19 years primarily as editor-in-chief of Medical World News and Graduating Engineer. He is survived by his loving wife of 62 years Regina (Jean), sons Steven and Robert, daughters-in-law Joanna and Susan, and grandchildren Danielle, Corey, Mikael, Evan, Adam, and Aliyah. Funeral service will be Sunday, May 15, at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

Shiva Sunday through Tuesday at the Goodman home.

The state's ethics commission on Friday charged the president of the research foundation of the State University of New York, John J. O'Connor, with giving a no-show job to the daughter of the former Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno. The commission said Mr. O'Connor in 2003 hired Mr. Bruno's daughter, Susan Bruno, to a position for which she was unqualified, and then employed her for years as a special assistant even as she rarely came to the office and ''did virtually no work'' on behalf of the foundation.

BERYLSON--Kermit J.,died on May 9, 2011 at age 97. He was a senior partner at KPMG in New York City, and was on General Eisenhower's staff planning D-Day in World War II. Born in NYC in March 1914, he received his BA and MBA degrees with distinction from City College of New York and Columbia University, respectively; worked on development of the Hoover Dam in Nevada before joining the armed forces; and was certified as a CPA in the states of New York, Illinois and California after the War. His military service began at the War Department in the Pentagon, moved on to the desert war in North Africa with General Patton, and then to SHAEF (Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force) in London working on airborne logistics for the invasion of Continental Europe. After participating in the invasion, he rejoined General Patton in the 3rd Army fighting at the battles of Huertgen Forest and the Bulge (Bastogne). After U.S. victory at the Bulge, he was with the Allied troops held at the Elbe River by General Eisenhower in order to allow the Russian Army to be the first to enter Berlin. His War service included participation in the liberation of Paris, Munich and Dachau (concentration camp), was honored by four major service medals for valor, and culminated with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. After the war, while building his distinguished accounting career, he was also a member of the ERISA Advisory Council of the U.S. Department of Labor, was a management consultant to the Pension Benefits Guaranty Corporation, served as President of the New York State Society of CPAs, and was awarded the Royal Order of Vasa by the Kingdom of Sweden for services to the Crown. He was the loving and beloved husband of the late Marjorie Cantor Berylson for 50 years before her death. He is survived and lovingly remembered by his daughter and her husband, Jane and Stephen Flechner of Denver, and by his son and his wife, John and Amy Smith Berylson of Boston. He is also survived and remembered by his adoring grandchildren, Jennifer (and her husband Jonathan Block), Laura, James, and Elizabeth. He was respected and admired by all who had the privilege of knowing him. Private family interment service will be held at Mt Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson.

When you're getting unemployment benefits, you by definition don't have a lot of cash to spare. So it seems especially unfair that people who receive their jobless benefits on prepaid debit cards are subject to a variety of fees they can ill afford to pay. A report out this week from the National Consumer Law Center lays out a host of ways in which banks nibble away at jobless benefits with fees the center called ''junk.'' The prepaid cards are most often used by jobless recipients who don't have checking accounts, and so are ineligible for direct deposit. Practices vary from state to state because jobless benefits are distributed at the state level, and state governments negotiate the terms of agreements with card providers. In many states, charges apply for using A.T.M.'s, even if they're in network; checking balances; and even for not using the card enough (inactivity fees, as high as $3).

WATSON--Timothy J. Family and friends of Timothy J. Watson who died on April 9, 2011 are gathering for a celebration of his life at his home Sunday, May 15, 2011, 4pm-7pm.

Could this be the first event at the Museum of Modern Art where a full-body blast suit, a parachute and a rubber Richard M. Nixon mask might be appropriate attire? The museum said on Friday that it would host a retrospective of the works of Kathryn Bigelow, the Academy Award-winning director of films including ''The Hurt Locker'' and ''Point Break.'' The series, ''Crafting Genre: Kathryn Bigelow,'' will open on June 1 with screenings of ''The Loveless,'' Ms. Bigelow's 1982 feature-length directorial debut starring Willem Dafoe as the leader of a motorcycle gang, and ''Set-Up,'' a short film she created in 1978 as a graduate student in Columbia's film program. Ms. Bigelow is to introduce these screenings at MoMA's Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters and take part in a question-and-answer session afterward.

WASHINGTON - A Federal Communications commissioner who announced this week that she planned to join the lobbying office of Comcast defended her actions on Friday, saying she had no contact with Comcast about a potential job while the company's takeover of NBC Universal was pending before the commission this year. Meredith Attwell Baker, a Republican who was appointed to the F.C.C. by President Obama two years ago, defended her decision to join Comcast on Friday after it drew objections this week from groups that opposed the company's acquisition of NBC Universal. Ms. Baker supported the takeover and the commission approved it in January on a 4-to-1 vote. The merged company is now known as NBCUniversal.

CANNES, France— International sex scandals with likely candidates for the French presidency have not disrupted proceedings at the film festival here. On Sunday afternoon, Frédéric Mitterrand, the French minister of culture, gave Faye Dunaway a medal and the honor of being an officer in “L’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.” Ms. Dunaway, whose kohl-eyed, sex-kitten image, photographed by Jerry Schatzberg in 1970, graces program guides and advertisements all over town, and hangs stories high above the Palais des Festivals, seemed to deserve the title, or at least she was ready to defend it. At the opening night dinner following the premiere last Wednesday of Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris,” she bristled at the notion that Cannes might have a commercial bent. “Don’t say that, because it’s wrong,” she said. “Cannes is not commercial, for God’s sake. Cannes is the only festival in the world, and the only entity in the world, that honors great film, from all over the world.”

On today’s front page, Tara Siegel Bernard uncovers something you’ve probably suspected for a long time: Equifax, Experian and TransUnion has one system for solving important people’s credit report errors and another for everybody else.

On Saturday morning, I met three friends and headed over to Fair Hill to watch Animal Kingdom train. We met at the local deli, formerly named Prizzios, and drove to the clocker’s stand. There was light chatter among my friends, who had not yet seen the Derby champion.

For those of us fortunate enough to regularly patronize New York City’s wondrous bodegas, the appearance of cut tulips ($7 a bunch, two for $12) in mid-February is our first inkling that spring is coming. Most of us don’t have access to real trees, after all. Besides, those other, more fluorescent flowers, the ones that require a certain level of patience to sift through, don’t appear to be tied to a particular season — or to Earth, even — as they sit huddled in green buckets, illuminated by fluorescent lights.

Rafael Marquez, the captain of Mexico’s national team, is in his second season with the Red Bulls of M.L.S. The veteran, who has played in France and for Barcelona in Spain, is back at his natural center back position and has helped to steady the club’s defense as the Red Bulls prepare for Sunday’s game against visiting Chivas USA. Marquez, a superstar in Mexico, has often times seemed like that other guy as the club and league promote the exploits of Thierry Henry, who was also his teammate in Spain. Marquez spoke recently with Jack Bell of The Times.
While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

When Ritsuko Koga met Ayako Wakahara, the president of the Young Japanese Calligraphers collective, she was “moved by her ambition and her objective to make the value of Japanese calligraphy known to the world.” Ms. Koga, who oversees the gallery space at Espace Japon (12 rue de Nancy; 33-1-47-00-77-47; www.espacejapon.com), then invited the group to display their oeuvre in Paris. All of the artists studied calligraphy at Tokyo’s University of Taito-bunka, an institution that puts special emphasis on Eastern traditions and culture. By working as a collective, the Young Japanese Calligraphers’ communal nature fortifies the solitary aspects of this written art.

Jorge Posada and Derek Jeter have been friends for nearly 20 years, since they were teammates at Class A Greensboro in 1992. Their daily interaction is part of the fabric of the Yankees’ clubhouse. Jeter, holding a cup from Starbucks, grabs a pair of sanitary socks and belts out, “Sado!” – his nickname for Posada. They have won together – five World Series championships – and they have lost together, and now they are, almost inevitably, declining together, a 36-year-old shortstop and a 39-year-old designated hitter.

Jorge Posada’s late scratch from the Yankees’ lineup shortly before a 6-0 loss to the Boston Red Sox on Saturday at Yankee Stadium led to a night of speculation and disagreement over why he did not play.
Jorge Posada’s decision to sit himself reflects the difficulties facing a team that had gotten a lot of miles out of a core of aging stars.

A pair of biographies connect a pre-eminent primatologist’s lifelong work to her childhood fascinations.
A science project in the “Babymouse” graphic novel series takes on a life of its own in “Squish: Super Amoeba.”

Picture books about pets and working animals.
In this supernatural romance inspired by the myth of Persephone, a girl flirts with a death deity.

Andrew Chesler and Amanda Robb wanted a bigger apartment, but their self-employed status was a turnoff to co-op boards. Then, Mr. Chesler’s mother had an idea: Why not chop her four-bedroom apartment in two?
The performance artists Allora & Calzadilla have brought a military tank, a pipe-organ A.T.M. and a cast of gymnasts to the American pavilion at the Venice Biennale.
Readers also ask about issues involving friendship, a nose piercing and accepting a birthday dinner out.
The largest survivor of the old Pennsylvania Station is the odd 15-foot setback, 200 feet long, in front of the Hotel Pennsylvania, itself soon to be demolished.
The Ariel West is one of the first apartment buildings in the city to approve a smoking ban that affects not only prospective residents but also current ones.
Faced with the possibility of becoming an “upscale retirement community,” Salisbury is taking a serious look at creating affordable housing.
For the last six years, James A. Bednar, or “Grim,” was wary of New Jersey real estate; today he is a homeowner.
A universe of wallet-conscious potential buyers — both young adults and empty nesters — has motivated Suffolk County developers of two new subdivisions.
Keep the pictures on the fridge, please; billing a tenant for legal expenses; no guarantees on code compliance; who can file a mechanic’s lien.
For would-be owner-occupants without cash, the federally insured 203(k) loan is key.
Mr. Kohn is a co-founder and the chairman of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, one of the world’s largest architecture firms.
Making sense of a courtship set amid 19th-century log cabins and pioneers — in 2008.

A shop in the Prospect-Lefferts Gardens neighborhood in Brooklyn has gained a large following with its offerings of ital food and vegetarian ice cream.

A bad economy has inspired a number of new plays on Broadway that feature working-class characters.
Two seemingly moribund staples, the musical and the comic drama, have come throbbing back to life.

Stuart Woods has had 10 books on the hardcover fiction list over the past three years. His “Bel-Air Dead” debuts at No. 3 this week.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Animal Kingdom's Win Is Victory for the Sport,'' May 9: For years, I've been saying we need outside blood from Europe to make our racehorses stronger. In the Kentucky Derby, two horses broke their legs. All the drugs in the world can't hold these guys together. It's nice to see good horsemanship produce a winner.

KOLLISCH--Stephen, phenomenal husband, father, and grandfather, died at age 87 on May 10, 2011. He escaped from Austria in 1939 on the Kindertransport with his sister Eva and brother Peter. Steve was married for 63 years to the love of his life, Betty (Kahn) of Staten Island, NY whom he met on the ferry. They lived in Great Neck, NY for 53 years before retiring to San Diego in 2005. He graduated from CCNY as a Mechanical Engineer, and worked in plastics for 55 years. He served in the Army Signal Corps in WWII. In addition to being an active Ham Radio operator, Steve had a deep love for sailing on Long Island Sound in his well-maintained Rhodes-19, The Loon, and was past-Commodore of the Steppingstone Sailing Club. A fine handyman, he was meticulous with his tools. He was a terrific father to Nancy Kollisch, M.D. (Jeffrey Pressman, M.D.) and Donald Kollisch, M.D. (Patricia Glowa, M.D.) He also leaves his four beloved granddaughters Sarah, Anya, Mindy, and Shelley. In lieu of flowers, donations to CCNY or to a charity of your choice.

''Catch Me if You Can'' might have gotten mixed reviews, but pretty much everyone agrees that Norbert Leo Butz's rendition of ''Don't Break the Rules'' in the first act is the kind of showstopper you don't see on Broadway all that often. Except this season, which is notable for numbers that, through the alchemy of song, sound, legs, lights and star power - not to mention tap dancing - build into something more joyful than the sum of their parts. As the droopy F.B.I. agent Carl Hanratty, Mr. Butz spends much of ''Catch Me'' on the trail of the snazzy con man Frank Abagnale Jr. (Aaron Tveit). But in ''Don't Break the Rules,'' he takes center stage.

SO compelling are the clothes featured on the mannequins in ''Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty,'' the current show at the Met's Costume Institute, that it was difficult to imagine how to top them off. Enter Guido Palau, the super stylist responsible for McQueen's runway coiffures. ''Hair was always an important part of his shows,'' Mr. Palau said. ''Many times, the dress became part of the head treatment.'' Mr. Palau wanted to complement the exhibition without overpowering it, and he didn't want to resort to anything as pedestrian as wigs. To that end, he and his team painstakingly made 90 or so masks that incorporated things like leather, jewels, burlap, lace, felt, fur and feathers. Would the designer have approved? ''I think so, he was always in my mind.'' SANDRA BALLENTINE

The Tigers' Justin Verlander became the 30th pitcher to throw multiple no-hitters when he blanked the Toronto Blue Jays last Sunday. The first pitcher to throw a no-hitter twice actually threw three gems in a brief career in the 1880s. He was Larry Corcoran, the relatively unknown name among the five pitching legends who have pitched three or more no-hitters.

TYRAN--Benjamin, who was an oil executive in charge of international operations with the Natomas Company and served under its Chairman, Ralph K. Davies, during the 60's and 70's, died in his sleep on April 30 in Medford, Oregon at the age of 90. He is survived by his children, Garry (and wife Barbara) of Chevy Chase, Maryland; Cindy (and husband Randy) of Phoenix, Oregon; and Craig (and wife Kristi) of Bellingham, WA; his grandchildren Keith, Charlotte, Serena, Andrew and Chesney; and his spouse Lynn. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 47 years, Jeanne Deckman Tyran, who passed away in July 1994. Mr. Tyran was born in Little Falls, NY. For many years he was a resident of Hillsborough, CA, before moving to Southern Oregon. He attended Rider University, Lawrenceville, NJ receiving a BS degree in Education in 1944. Following a brief teaching assignment, he was recruited by the Arabia American Oil Company (Aramco) to work in the oil fields of Eastern Saudi Arabia, where he was stationed for two and a half years. In 1947, he was transferred to Aramco's offices in New York City, simultaneously receiving his MBA in 1950 from New York University. Subsequently, he worked for the US Department of State and with the Labor-Management Maritime committee in Washington, D.C. In 1960, Mr. Tyran founded and served as President of the Independent Petroleum Supply Company (IPS) with offices in New York City, San Francisco, Tokyo, London, Toronto, Paris and Rome. In 1963, IPS merged with the Natomas Company of San Francisco, with Mr. Tyran becoming Director and Vice President in charge of Natomas's newly-started international oil activities. During the late 1960s and early 1970s Natomas became one of the largest independent oil companies operating in Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Europe and North America. Mr. Tyran retired from Natomas in 1973 and started Tyran Associates in 1974 specializing in petroleum consulting services, particularly in the Middle East. Following his move to Ashland in 1975, Mr. Tyran became involved in numerous civic, university and charitable activities, including: President of the Southern Oregon University Foundation; Chairman, Ashland Economic Development commission; and President of the Council for Economic Development of Oregon. Mr. Tyran completed an autobiography in October 2002 entitled, Bonsey's World: A Personal Chronicle, published by Minuteman Press. A private memorial service will be held later this summer. The family prefers gifts be made to the Tyran Chair at Southern Oregon University, Ashland.

These diagrams are the early fruits of a new approach to the most important unsolved problem of the last century: how to make a rich country out of a poor one. Development economists have many theories about how the trick is done but few proven answers. A compelling solution would be useful closer to home, too: understanding the process of economic development would help us work out whether it matters that service jobs are replacing manufacturing ones or whether there is anything the government can and should do to stimulate new industries like biotechnology or green energy. Strip away the mathematical language of economists, and conventional theories of economic growth are rather crude. Economies produce ''stuff,'' and if you want more stuff to come out of the process, put more stuff in (like human capital, say). Yet economies do not produce stuff so much as billions of distinct types of goods -- perhaps 10 billion, according to Eric Beinhocker of the McKinsey Global Institute -- ranging from size 34 dark stonewash boot-cut jeans to beauty therapies involving avocado. The difference between China's economy and that of the United States is not simply that China's is smaller; it has a different structure entirely.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Researchers Employ New Test to Estimate Concussion Risk for Helmets,'' May 10: It's heartening to read about work being done to improve football helmet design and reduce the risk of concussion in young athletes. But public awareness of the risk of traumatic brain injury still lags behind the science. We now know that it does not necessarily take a blow to the head to cause T.B.I. Injuries to other body parts -- particularly injuries that cause significant inflammation -- can lead to swelling of the brain and T.B.I.-like effects. Parents and coaches need to be more alert to signs of ''trauma spectrum disorder,'' even when there's no blow to the head.
LAWRENCE COLONIAL $1,199,000
To the Sports Editor: ''A Golf Ball That Won't Slice Comes With a Catch: It's Illegal'' (May 10) creates a world where achievement loses its meaning.

7 P.M. (Animal Planet) PRAIRIE DOG CHATTER ''Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom'' chronicles the efforts of Con Slobodchikoff, a biologist, who, after 30 years of studying the calls of prairie dogs, believes that he has discovered a language second in complexity only to that of humans. He's hoping that his bold claim will lead to the conservation of these cousins of the squirrel, who for decades were seen merely as pests and subjected to large-scale eradication campaigns in North America. 10 A.M. And Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker who also officially declared his candidacy last week, visits ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Evening Hours column, about an awards dinner held in Manhattan by the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture in Maine, misidentified one of the guests photographed. She is Ursula von Rydingsvard, not Kate Haw.

Centuries before the collapse of Sun Belt real estate, Dutch tulips were the original symbol of speculative excess and market correction. Brought to the Netherlands from Asia in the 16th century, the flower sparked an acquisitive fever that culminated, in 1637, with a single bulb of one variety selling for what was then an unheard-of 5,200 guilders -- the price of a house. Suddenly the market disintegrated and Tulipomania passed, leaving the Netherlands to tighten its grip on the global market by providing dominant auction houses and, according to Fred Wever of the auction house FloraHolland, ''the perfect soil and weather circumstances'' for growing the flowers. Despite the recent financial crisis' lingering effects, Dutch auction houses are still handling about $300 million in tulip sales each year. Presumably U.S. suburban real estate also will bloom again someday. FLYOVER Additional images are atnytimes.com/magazine.

Mia Hamm is soccer's leading international scorer in history, man or woman, with 158 goals. She was a leader on the United States team that won the inaugural Women's World Cup in 1991, the 1999 Cup, and Olympic gold medals in 1996 and 2004. Now 39, Hamm, who has 4-year-old twin girls with her husband, the former baseball player Nomar Garciaparra, took part in ESPN the Weekend at Walt Disney World in Florida. Q. How do you spend your time now?

An essay on May 1about the so-called Gang of Six bipartisan Senate group working on a deficit reduction proposal referred imprecisely to Senator Richard Durbin. He is an Illinois liberal, not a Chicago liberal. (Durbin grew up in East St. Louis, Ill., and as a congressman, he represented a district that included most of Springfield.)

An article on May 1 about the effects of electronic devices on family life at home misidentified the video-game player used by a child on an episode of ABC's ''Modern Family'' as he ignored his mother at breakfast. It was a Nintendo DS, not a Sony PSP. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the fantasy sport played by the father on his iPad during the same scene. It was football, not baseball.

DuBOURG--Antoine, of Newport, RI, died in his sleep on Thursday, May 12, at age 82. In collaboration with Clare Gesualdo his dear friend and companion for over 40 years Tony enabled thousands of high school students to profit from his contagious love of music. First for 46 years at the Pingry School in New Jersey, and then at St. George's School in Middletown, RI, he invigorated existing gleeclub and choir curricula. He also introduced Brass Choirs to each institution. Their performances reflected Tony's exceptional talent in generating adolescent enthusiasm. This was his all consuming focus in life. Nothing came in the way of his fierce loyalty to his students. They sang and played at celebrated concert halls in England, Europe and the United States. They even toured behind the Iron Curtain in the 1970s. Through Tony's generosity both Pingry and St. George's increased the quality and quantity of instruments available for student performances. Tony's second teaching discipline was physics, a lifelong interest. As was sailing, shared with Clare. With headquarters on Cape Cod or Martha's Vineyard they were joined by friend and students on summer sailing adventures. Born in Paris, Tony came to the Untied States at age 11. He first attended the Buckley School in New York City and then the Harvey School. He was in the Class of 1947 at St. Paul's School, Concord, NH and in the Class of 1951 at Hamilton College. Tony served in the US Army before beginning his teaching career in the mid 1950's. His half brother Joseph McCrindle died some years ago. Donations may be made to Music at St. George's, St. George's School, P.O. Box 1910, Newport, RI 02840

This N.B.A. postseason has featured the two-time defending champion Los Angeles Lakers' being swept away, the verification of the Miami Heat conglomerate in the vanquishing of the Boston Celtics, and an unlikely upstart in the Memphis Grizzlies, who were involved in a triple-overtime game against the Oklahoma City Thunder. Now, Memphis and Oklahoma City are offering another first this spring with Sunday's seventh game of their Western Conference semifinal series.

CLEVELAND - Reverse the letters on the back of Johnny Damon's jersey, and they spell nomad. That is what Damon has become as he bounces around the American League, from the Yankees in 2009 to the Detroit Tigers last season to the Tampa Bay Rays now. Damon, 37, is one of those modern stars who will be an alumnus of many teams, mostly because of short-term free-agent contracts. Rickey Henderson played for nine teams, Gary Sheffield eight, Roberto Alomar seven.

Passengers from the lower 48 traveling to Alaska using its ferry system will be able to go farther north than before with new service that deposits them 60 miles south of Anchorage. Beginning June 4, the new service, from the Alaska Marine Highway System (ferryalaska.com), will run every other week, departing Bellingham, Wash., and arriving in Whittier four and a half days later. Much of the route follows the same Inside Passage plan popular with cruise ships, including stops in Ketchikan, Juneau and Yakutat.

An answer last weekend in the Q&A column, about touring the sewers and catacombs of Paris, misstated the position of Sarah J. Wachter, a writer who contributed suggestions. She is a freelance writer based in Paris and an occasional contributor to the International Herald Tribune, not an editor at the International Herald Tribune.

EISNER--Shirley, on May 12, 2011. Beloved wife of Harold for 70 years; devoted mother to Barbara and Gayle; loving grandmother and adoring great-grandmother. You'll live in all our hearts forever. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's 175 N. Longbeach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

HARDY--David Thomas, April 20, 1939 May 7, 2011, son of Thomas and Relda Hardy of Salt Lake City, Utah. Attended University of Utah, where he made lifelong friendships at Kappa Sigma. Lived 50 years in San Francisco, CA, where he met the love of his life, James Patrick Brentano. They were together for 30 years and married on October 25, 2008. David called himself a "Jack of all trades and master of them all!" While employed at MGM, Walt Disney, bookstores, and restaurants, David indulged a love of movies, theater, symphony, and opera. David exemplified how to live heroically with a debilitating illness, fighting with grace, dignity, and extreme courage, which will forever be a guiding light to all who knew him. Survivors include his spouse, his siblings John Hardy (Fran), Stephan (Cathy), Richard (Lynda), and Charlene (Richard), their children, and his chosen family in San Francisco, notably Michael Ehrenzweig, a special support throughout his life and in his final days. Many children unrelated by blood considered him their uncle by choice. David will be remembered and cherished for his sense of humor, wit, passion for life, and his ability to make a lasting impression. "The Journey is the Reward" and David had one amazing journey! We will love and miss you always! Sogni d'oro, David.

Best known for its backcountry hut-to-hut hiking system in the White Mountains, the Appalachian Mountain Club (outdoors.org) is seeking to encourage the next generation of trekkers with new youth-oriented program called ''Kid Spoken Here.'' The campaign by the organization, which operates six full-service lodges in Maine and New Hampshire as well as eight huts and assorted cabins in the Northeast, offers youth lodging discounts, kids' meals and more family-focused activities.
