SCHNITZER--Harold J.,Harold J. Schnitzer, businessman, philanthropist, and civic leader, passed away in Portland, Oregon early Wednesday morning, April 27, at the age of 87 of complications from cancer and diabetes. He was born in Portland, June 8, 1923. He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in metallurgy from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1944 and, immediately thereafter, served in the U.S. Army until his discharge in 1947. Upon returning to Portland he joined his brothers in the family scrap and steel business, Schnitzer Steel, working alongside them until 1950, at which time he left and founded Harsch Investment Properties, a leading diversified owner and operator of industrial, office, retail and multi-family properties in five Western states. He served as President and Chairman of the Board for two decades before being joined by his son Jordan in 1970, who now serves as President. Together, he and his son grew the company into one of the largest, privately held real estate companies in the western United States. Throughout his life he focused on three things: family, the business and his community. Harold learned early on from his parents, Sam and Rose Schnitzer, who immigrated to the United States in the early 1900s, the responsibility of making a difference with his life. They taught him and his siblings (Manuel, Morris, Mollie, Edith, Gilbert and Leonard) the importance of giving back to your community. In 1949 he met and married Arlene Director. Married for 62 years, they were life-long partners in business, the arts and philanthropy. Their son Jordan was born in 1951. Over a career of 60 years there have been hundreds of organizations and causes that have benefited from his leadership and financial support. Harold served on the board of Lewis & Clark College for 16 years, a Life Trustee since 1995. His service to the Portland Art Museum spanned 21 years, ultimately as Chairman of the Board from 1997 to 2001. He and Arlene are especially proud of establishing the Center for Northwest Art, and a curatorial and annual artist awards program. They also were major collectors of Han and pre-Han ceramics that led to establishing the nationally recognized Arlene and Harold Schnitzer Collection of Early Chinese Art. They gifted a number of works from the collection to the Portland Art Museum along with endowing the position of Curator of Asian Art. In addition to all of the philanthropic support in the Pacific Northwest, Harold and Arlene also have also been strong supporters of arts and cultural institutions in the Bay Area and Palm Springs, where they have residences. More recently Harold provided the lead gift establishing the Harold Schnitzer Diabetes Health Center at Oregon Health Science University (OHSU) in 2007, one of only ten centers in the nation treating children and adults and the only one on the West Coast. A diabetic since his early 40s, he valued good health care and appreciated its connection to the quality and longevity of life. The Center is his expression of helping others in their struggle with diabetes. Harold was always interested in ensuring that young people have the same educational opportunities that he had. He had a lifelong interest in funding scholarships and educational grants, and that ultimately led to him establishing Judaic studies programs at both the University of Oregon and Portland State University. Harold served the City of Portland on a variety of projects including the development of the Portland Center for the Performing Arts. Because of his leadership and philanthropy, the city named its symphony hall, the Arlene Schnitzer Concert Hall, in honor of his wife, Arlene. He has been honored by numerous civic organizations regionally and nationally in partnership with his wife Arlene including the following: Doctor of Humane Letters from Portland State University, Distinguished Service Award from the University of Oregon, Aubrey Watzek Award from Lewis & Clark College, Portland First Citizen Award 1995, the Outstanding Philanthropist Award from the National Society of Fundraising Executives and an honorary doctorate degree from the Pacific Northwest College of Art. Harold is survived by his wife, Arlene, his son Jordan, his two granddaughters Arielle and Audria, his brother Gilbert who resides in San Francisco, California, his sister Mollie who resides in Beverly Hills, California, and numerous nieces and nephews. Even during the last days of his life he was still working and planning on how to make life better for everyone else around him. A Memorial Service was held on Wednesday, May 11th, 2011.

SIEGEL--Jesse S. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished member of its extended family. Mr. Siegel was a unique and most interesting person. He was an independent thinker whose objectivity put things in a different perspective. He was a successful businessman who took over H. I. S., the company founded by his father, Henry I. Siegel, when his father died unexpectedly in 1949. Jesse, only 19 years old and a recent graduate of Columbia, led the company to new heights through his creative marketing and practical approach. Mr. Siegel's mother, Henrietta, was an ardent supporter of Boys Town and dedicated the Henrietta Siegel Residence Hall. Mr. Siegel honored his mother through his continued generous support of Boys Town. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Dr. Wilma Bulkin Siegel and the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Robert Kaswell, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald Gray, Ex. V. P.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

EINHORN--Abraham "ABE", May 30, 1925 to May 4, 2011. "A Backstage Broadway Icon is Gone" Master Property Man on Broadway and Playwright. Born on the Lower Eastside, he married his childhood sweetheart Rena Gatti. They were together for 69 years when she passed away several years ago. In World War II he was in the Navy, a Sea B stationed in Okinawa. When he returned to New York he began his theatre career. He spent 30 years back stage on some of the longest running plays on Broadway. The laughter backstage was often louder than the audience laughter. He wrote his first play "Agatha Sue I Love You" produced by George Abbott and opened at the Henry Miller Theatre in New York City on December 14, 1966. After he retired he spent his summers in East Hampton and the rest of the year in Laughlin, Nevada. Walking, gambling, reading and writing were his passions and he did all four everyday of his life. Everywhere he went he kept them laughing. He will be missed by all who knew him. His death was sudden, he lived on the fast track and died the same way. A Celebration of his Life will be held at the Vista Apartments in Laughlin on what would have been his 86th Birthday May 30th. He is survived by his daughter Janice Robinson of East Hampton, NY, where he spent his summers, and a son Richard Einhorn, a brother Jerry Einhorn.

''Dear Honorable Judge Holwell,'' the handwritten note from the foreman read last Wednesday morning, ''the jury has come to a unanimous decision.'' Then, minutes later, the stress and emotion that had been building for two months spilled out into the tight quarters of the deliberation room at the United States District Court in Manhattan. Tears flowed. Jurors hugged, trading words of comfort, while others stepped into the bathroom to compose themselves. One juror asked that they say a prayer, so the group huddled and prayed.

The excitement of the exhibition ''Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty'' has spilled out onto the front steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with visitors dressing to the nines to view it. Farther down Fifth, Bergdorf's tribute windows are also drawing some amazing turnouts. One man, bottom, performed a dance to this god of fashion, and a woman, left, reached back into her closet for two 20-year-old McQueen designs. The designer, who committed suicide last year, brought fashion as theater to its apex, topped only by Lady Gaga. It now appears to be headed in an opposite, low-key direction. But to fully understand him, you had to visit his showroom to see his wearable collection of superb tailored clothes, inset, a contrast with the dreams on his Paris runway.

When the Seattle Mariners cut the troubled Milton Bradley last week, they opened a spot for a player with a deep appreciation of his chance. Outfielder Mike Wilson, who spent 10 seasons in the team's farm system, earned his first promotion to the majors. ''Best day of my life,'' he said last Tuesday in Baltimore, on his first day as a big leaguer.

ON command, Eze Schupfer reads aloud the numbers on a worksheet in front of her: ''42, 43, 12, 13.'' Then she begins to trace them. ''Is that how we write a 12?'' her instructor, Maria Rivas, asks. ''Erase it.''

THOSE of us who follow fashion and photography tend to have a favorite image of Kate Moss. I have two: Corinne Day's portrait (styled by Melanie Ward) of a laughing and feather-headdressed Kate for a 1990 cover of The Face; and Mario Sorrenti's 1993 image of her, with its deep shadow and the eyes of Kate looking at once tender and wary. The early '90s announced a more stripped-down view of fashion -- call it grunge, if you like -- and the waif Kate fit the bill as she inspired an industry. A decade later, in 2003, the artist Chuck Close was still justified in saying of Ms. Moss: ''She's not selling a product. The product is her.'' His remark was made in the context of a special issue of W magazine, for which 17 artists, including Mr. Close, were asked to make works around her. She had already served as an artist muse, for Lucian Freud and Gary Hume, among others. Despite his initial reservations about working with Ms. Moss, by then a celebrity, for a mainstream magazine, Mr. Close said, ''It couldn't have been lovelier.''

Once, Bethlehem Steel was a mighty industrial force, churning out metal for skyscrapers, bridges and warships. But its plant in Bethlehem, Pa., closed for good in 1995, and the company was sold in 2003, a victim of changing economic realities. ''I find that the erosive effects of the elements have transformed the facades of the mill into textural canvases,'' says Alyssha Eve Csük, a photographer and resident of Bethlehem. She has turned images of disused pipes, furnaces and engines into art in a collection called ''Abstract Portraits of Steel.'' It includes photographs of the Bethlehem plant, eight of which are shown here, as well as other sites that ''embody bygone industry.''

IN the cutthroat world of high-end New York City real estate, there is a simple maxim among brokers: Sell what you have seen. And as the spring selling season enters its peak days, open houses for brokers, or broker parties, are a critical component of the marketing strategy. To that end, more than 200 brokers gathered the other evening for a cocktail party in two penthouses on the 60th floor of the Setai Fifth Avenue Residences, sipping Zardetto prosecco and nibbling on black pepper Angus beef with sweet-and-sour shallots, foie gras and porcini tartlet.

RIESS--Elsa, beloved sister of the late Dr. Anneliese Riess, passed away peacefully on 7th May 2011 in her 104th year. SHE gave a chuff and pulled up short, as surprised to see us as we were to see her. Her dense, fluffy fur was blond. I watched her square, expressive face very closely because this bear -- maybe 300 pounds and 10 yards away -- would be the one deciding how the encounter played out. An adrenaline-driven voice in my head said, ''This could go badly.'' But it was also telling me how incredibly thrilling it was to be so near this animal. Not being on top of the food chain certainly heightens one's awareness. We were four people and a dog tucked against a slope, partly hidden by waist-high grass. The bear looked and sniffed for almost a minute, trying to decide what she had come across. Then she pivoted onto a trail and moved away, choosing flight over fight. I was grateful for that; an older male might have stood his ground.

LAURE HÉRIARD DUBREUIL and Frederic Dechnik, founders of the Webster Miami, have a penchant for sun. It's reflected in what they buy for their store, but also in their personal itineraries. June will always be remembered as a wonderful mother and grandmother as well as a dedicated dental hygienist for over 20 years. June is survived by her loving husband of 41 years, David Ainsworth, her brother Howard (Marlene) West, her children, Campbell (Juliette) Ainsworth, Russell (Courtenay) Ainsworth, and Nell (Joshua) Oakes, her niece Dayna (Philip) Aroeste, her nephew Todd West, her six grandchildren, Faustine, Oliver, Charlotte, Tobias, Madeline, and Luca, and her grandniece Olivia. HAMPTON--Aubrey, Aubrey Hampton, 76, founder and CEO of Aubrey Organics, and co-founder of Gorilla Theatre in Tampa, FL, passed away May 9 after a brief illness. He is survived by sons Mitchell and Trevor, and a sister, Millie Newman. A pioneer in natural hair and skin care, Aubrey operated one of the first natural cosmetic companies in the U.S., with plant-based products sold all over the world. He was born October 23, 1934, in New Albany, IN. In 1967, he founded Aubrey's Nature Labs with just two products, simple beginnings he grew into Aubrey Organics, the multi-national company that bears his name. A prolific author, his books include Natural Organic Hair and Skin Care, What's in Your Cosmetics, and The Take Charge Beauty Book. He was publisher of Organica: A Magazine of Arts and Activism. Aubrey enjoyed a second career as an award-winning playwright and producer, and co-founded Gorilla Theatre with his late wife, playwright Susan Hussey. He published two plays, GBS and Company, based on the life of George Bernard Shaw, and Wolf Trilogy. In 2000 he founded the Young Dramatists Project, a playwriting competition for middle and high school students. At the heart of his legacy is his joyful and generous spirit. He will be deeply missed. The family requests that, in place of flowers, his memory be honored with donations to the Gorilla Theatre, the American Cancer Society, or St. Jude's Children's Hospital.
Film Stephen Holden

WASHINGTON -- When a man stalks the world as a mass killer, it distracts from the ordinary interest we might otherwise take in the mundane details of his life. And so it was with Osama bin Laden. But after he was cornered and killed on May 2 in an upstairs bedroom of his house in Pakistan, Bin Laden the terrorist and Bin Laden the family man came together. At home with him were three of his wives, the youngest of whom was shot in the leg; a son, who was killed; a daughter, who witnessed her father's death; and other children, some of whom may be Bin Laden's.

Travelers unsatisfied with in-flight entertainment choices may soon get more options. American Airlines (aa.com) is testing a system by its Internet provider, Aircell (gogoinflight.com), that will allow passengers to view streaming video on their laptops, tablets and other portable wireless devices. Passengers on two American aircraft may be able to use the service early this summer. Once the service passes Federal Aviation Administration approval, the airline plans to install it on its entire domestic fleet.

A DECADE ago, in a moment of inspiration, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority stumbled on a way to help the environment and its own bottom line: donating retired subway trains to the little-known cause of creating artificial reefs. More than 2,500 obsolete subway cars -- including 1,269 of the classic ocher-hued Redbird cars -- were packed up, shipped out and then, with a splash, dropped into silent graves at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, somewhere off the coasts of six states up and down the Eastern Seaboard.

Trading hands for the first time since the 1950s,a 10-room co-op at the San Remo was the highest sale of the week, according to transaction sposted on Streeteasy.com. The three-bedroom three and-a-half-bath apartment retains the original bathrooms and kitchen -- with St. Charles steel-and-glass cabinets -- installed in 1930, when the San Remo, designed by Emery Roth, was built. The kitchen and pantry lead to a ''servants' hall and three maids' rooms waiting for your touch,'' according to the listing.

KATHLEEN MARSHALL, DIRECTOR-CHOREOGRAPHER, ON ''ANYTHING GOES'' ''The lyrics announce that this is a topsy-turvy world. Reno Sweeney is a little bit of a Pied Piper, and over the course of the number everybody gets caught up in her philosophy. And in Sutton [Foster, center] we have a Reno Sweeney who can lead the whole number -- it all swirls around her. The number develops in sections, and because we have this three-level set I knew that at the end of the number people would dance on all three levels of the set. We call it the 'All Skate' section -- like at a roller rink where sometimes it's Girls' Skate, sometimes Boys' Skate, and then there's All Skate, where everyone skates. It's not just a group of dancers surrounded by a chorus of singers. The powerful moment is to build to everyone facing front and tapping at the audience. By the end it's 20 pairs of feet tapping. We wanted the number to have this relentless energy, and it does.''
Theater Steven McElroy

MIRSKY--Harvey, 71, of Manhattan died Tuesday May 9 of heart failure. He was born in Brooklyn and spent his youth being a proud Brooklynite and Dodgers fan. After attending Winthrop in East Flatbush, he went to Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. While working at Associated Metals and Minerals, he received his undergraduate degree from Brooklyn College. Then onto the University of Chicago where he worked in development and earned an MBA. Using his marketing skills, he worked for Proctor and Gamble in France and Britain. He was in both the Army and Air Force reserves, serving in Europe. After returning to the US, he explored a teaching career at Tuskegee Institute in Alabama but finally settled back in his beloved New York, and began his own marketing business focusing on the drug industry. Nearing retirement his boyhood interest in stamp collecting was rekindled and he developed into a noted postal historian specializing in US first issues. His collection received many international awards. He is survived by his wife, Carol Bommarito; his son, Sam Mirsky; his daughter-in-law, Ashlea Mirsky; and their children Emily, Benjamin and Joseph. Funeral Services will be held Thursday. For more information call (212) 724-4126 ext. 203.

THE world's first Corvette returned to its birthplace last weekend. The Corvette concept was unveiled at the 1953 Motorama show in the ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria hotel on Park Avenue in Manhattan. That car, a white model with red accents, was on hand last Saturday to illustrate a presentation by Ed Welburn, the General Motors global vice president of design, to the company's international sales executives.

''Catch Me if You Can'' might have gotten mixed reviews, but pretty much everyone agrees that Norbert Leo Butz's rendition of ''Don't Break the Rules'' in the first act is the kind of showstopper you don't see on Broadway all that often. Except this season, which is notable for numbers that, through the alchemy of song, sound, legs, lights and star power - not to mention tap dancing - build into something more joyful than the sum of their parts. As the droopy F.B.I. agent Carl Hanratty, Mr. Butz spends much of ''Catch Me'' on the trail of the snazzy con man Frank Abagnale Jr. (Aaron Tveit). But in ''Don't Break the Rules,'' he takes center stage.

''This is going to be the sexiest salon uptown,'' said Ric Pipino, whose sprawling new beauty destination, Ric Pipino -- Wella Professional Flagship, is more like a really cool apartment. While much attention has been focused on rebel efforts in eastern Libya and in the city of Misurata, rebels have held control of most of the Nafusah Mountain region since the unrest began in February. For authors, choosing a book cover is the fraught moment their very private creation starts putting on its game face and getting ready to enter the market. For cover designers, it can also be the beginning of their own struggle on behalf of their favorite ideas. A proposed cover can be killed for any number of reasons. It's too dark. It's too light. (White covers don't look good on Amazon, and tend to get dirty in stores.) It looks too much like Y.A. fiction. It won't appeal to men. And can't that monkey in the corner look more ''literary''? The death blow can come from any direction: not just from the author and the agent, but from the publisher, the in-house sales force or buyers for the major retailers, who have been known to reduce the size of an order unless a cover is changed. Designers can generate as many as 50 covers for high-profile books, though a half-dozen or so is more typical, and sometimes they get lucky with the first shot. Do designers sometimes know when they've gotten a cover exactly right? ''Yes,'' said Allison Saltzman, art director at Ecco. ''But there are others you feel totally confident about and then somebody kills them too.'' Below are some killed covers whose creators couldn't quite let them rest in peace.

An article last Sunday about the gender transitioning of Chaz (formerly Chastity) Bono misstated the classification of gender identity disorder. Although many in the psychiatric and transgender communities consider it a medical issue and there is considerable debate over whether to classify it as such, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual -- IV, the standard reference for psychiatric disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association, classifies it as a mental disorder; that classification did not end in 1999.

RARE is the mother and daughter who agree about style. But Lily Mandelbaum, an N.Y.U. student, and her mom, the fashion editor and stylist Elisa Goodkind, are so sartorially in sync that for the last three years they've been at the helm of Stylelikeu.com. The popular Web site features closet tours, style mantras and video interviews with their fashion muses. (Above, Danielle, right, and Jeffertitti, musicians and jewelry designers.) Now they've released a book, ''Stylelikeu'' (PowerHouse, $29.95), full of club kids posing in their bedrooms, awesome collages of transgressive jewelry and little old ladies who refuse to hang up their toreador pants. As Tziporah Salamon, one such senior, said: ''Every single day you get a chance to invent yourself. How fun is that?'' HOLLY SIEGEL

SINCE 2006, when Arctic Monkeys appeared on the British music scene, Alex Turner, the frontman, has been acclaimed as a songwriter wise beyond his years. (He was 20 when the group hit it big, thanks in part to the tendency of the British press to trumpet and acclaim.) Through lineup changes and side projects, and a recent foray in New York with his girlfriend, Alexa Chung, the MTV personality and Madewell designer, Mr. Turner has gravitated toward classic musicians, like Gene Clark of the Byrds, and films like the 1959 western ''Rio Bravo.'' His retro sensibility is evident on the band's fourth album, ''Suck It and See'' (Domino), to be released June 6. The title seems cheeky but it's not, Mr. Turner said. ''It's an old Britishism, like a bit Dick van Dyke-y, like 'give it a try' almost -- it'd be a slogan for some candy,'' he said. ''That's not really traveled very well.'' In a conversation peppered with other Britishisms (''nice one, love'' he said, often, alongside saucier phrases) he recently spoke with Melena Ryzik from Stockholm, where the band members were starting their tour, performing together for the first time in over a year. ''I'm a bit nervous, to be honest with you,'' Mr. Turner said. ''I have just opened a beer, actually. We'll see if that's going to help it out. I don't want to do too much of that. I'm worried I might become forgetful, and there's a lot of words in our songs.'' Here are excerpts from their conversation. Q: What were you listening to when you wrote the album?

WALSH--Billie Ryan, died peacefully at home in Vero Beach, Florida, on May 10, 2011. Married for 60 years to Thomas L. Walsh, who predeceased her, she lived for over fifty years between Quogue, NY and Palm Beach, FL. She is survived by her daughters, Barbara Freehill and Constance Walsh, daughter-in-law Barbara Kutz Walsh, son-in-law George B. Freehill, eleven granddaughters, two grandsons, and twenty-one great-grandchildren. Her son, Thomas A. Walsh, passed away in 2009 from ALS. Known as Billie by her friends and as Gracie by her grandchildren, she was born in Manhattan, raised her family in Riverdale, and had deep New York roots, adding to the city's cultural landscape and history as a founding partner of Jimmy Ryan's 52nd Street, a jazz club on New York's venerable Swing Street in the 1940s and 50s. She is a co-founder, former board member and long time supporter of Little Flower Children and Family Services of New York. A survivor, a mother and a devoted grandmother, she was loved by all whose lives she touched and will be greatly missed. A memorial mass will be held at a time to be determined at Immaculate Conception Church in Westhampton Beach, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to either Little Flower Children and Family Services (www.littleflowerny.org) or Compassionate Care ALS (www.ccals.org)

More than a few of the respondents to my column about CUNY’s on-again-off-again-on-again awarding of an honorary degree to Tony Kushner say that while I may be correct about the “technical” definition of academic freedom, I miss the larger point. That’s because there isn’t one. A board of trustees with every right to make a decision made it in a way that (a) ran counter to its previous practice (b) permitted a single member (Jeffrey Wiesenfeld) to derail a process that had seemed to be on a familiar track and (c) put CUNY right in the middle of the briar patch called the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Maladroit, unfortunate and (as I said) dumb. But that’s it. It was just the board screwing up with the predictable public-relations disaster as the result. No one’s freedom was curtailed, no one’s speech was censored, no harm, except to the board’s reputation and by extension to CUNY’s, was done.Because Wiesenfeld’s objections were to Kushner’s views on Israel, the uproar that followed the board’s decision to table his nomination quickly escalated into a shouting match between those who said that Israel was engaged in ethnic cleansing and those who replied that people who said that were anti-Semites and/or self-hating Jews. The responses to my column followed the same pattern. No one wanted to hear the topic of academic freedom “parsed” (a word used in derision by one reader, as if parsing something, trying to get it right, were a crime). MSP Shiloh complained that “Dr. Fish misdirects our attention to the arcane and off topic of the academic honorary degree process,” when “[t]his was, and is, about Israel’s persecution” of Palestinians. Other respondents were just as sure that “this was, and is, about” a university honoring a “self–righteous hack” (mcghostoflectricity) who spews “current day Palestinian propaganda” (neilrobert). Both sides are wrong, not about Israel – I did not and will not come down on that issue — but about what “this” is about. It’s about institutional ineptness, a relatively small matter that nevertheless can teach us some lessons. The back-and-forth trading of ritual insults is hardly edifying, but a proper understanding of what academic freedom is might be.

The laid-back Basque town of Biarritz has been Europe’s surf capital since the 1950s. Yet despite the crowds and the casinos, it has retained its scruffy coolness. The Bay of Biscay provides the town with two main waves: the Plage de la Côte des Basques, a popular and consistent sandbar break; and the Grande Plage, an unpredictable, high-performance beach break up the coast. At least a dozen groups give surfing lessons, among them Jo Moraiz (011-33-6-62-76-17-24; jomoraiz.com), France’s first surf school. Biarritz’s plushest beach hotel is the Hôtel Du Palais (011-33-5-59-41-64-00; hotel-du-palais.com; doubles from about $665), a palace-turned-hotel where Alain Ducasse worked one of his first kitchen jobs. You’re less likely to see surfers there than at one of the campgrounds on Biarritz’s outskirts. A happy medium between opulence and outdoors is Hôtel Le Caritz (011-33-5-59-24-41-84; hotel-lecaritz-biarritz.com; doubles from $210), a handsome inn with a terrace restaurant. For the closest surf proximity, try the basic but comfortable Carlina Lodge (011-33-5-59-24-42-14; carlina.com; doubles from $190), which has direct access to the Côte des Basques. For post-surf refueling, the lovely covered market Les Halles (halles-biarritz.fr) offers outdoor fish and tapas restaurants, palpable reminders of the city’s vicinity to Spain. And Le Surfing (011-33-5-59-24-78-72; lesurfingbiarritz.fr), an inviting bar and restaurant where vintage surf memorabilia serves as décor, might be the only brasserie in town that allows sandy feet.

Now that Costa Rica’s best breaks have been overrun, Nicaragua is luring wave riders with low-key surf camps and undiscovered beaches. Popoyo, on the southern Pacific coast, has the most consistent barrel, along with hotels like the Popoyo Beach Lodge (popoyobeachlodge.com; doubles from $55 ). But two and a half hours north of Managua and just west of the town of Chinandega lies the country’s undeveloped northern Pacific coast — and dozens of breaks so new that many don’t have names. This is where the pro surfer and model Holly Beck set up her camp, Suave Dulce (surfwithhollybeck.com) after she stopped competing in 2008. Nicaragua, says Beck, a California native, is the ideal place to “help people experience the joy of getting pushed by the ocean.” Many of Beck’s students stay at El Coco Loco (011-505-8999-8662; elcocolocoresort.com; doubles from $100), a rustic resort near the town of Santa Maria del Mar with five palm-thatch cabanas near several surf spots. La Bahia Beach Hodel (011-505-8958-5075; labahiabeachhotel.com; doubles from $150) is a more luxurious option: four stone-and-teak casitas with outdoor showers, private pathways to one of Nicaragua’s most beautiful beaches and three breaks in front of the hotel (with more nearby). Both resorts serve seafood delivered daily by local fishermen, and there’s also plenty of the local catch at Al Cielo (011-505-8993-4840), a popular open-air palapa run by two French guys, with 360-degree views.

Listen up. Now you can tune into the National Jukebox, the Library of Congress’ new online collection of popular recorded music, monologues and more from the early decades of the 20th century. At the moment, the Jukebox includes more than 10,000 recordings on 78-r.p.m. discs made by the Victor Talking Machine Company from 1901 to 1925, but the library plans to expand the collection regularly. You can hear the opera star Enrico Caruso, Tin Pan Alley and Irving Berlin’s Broadway hits. The site enables you to create your own playlist. The collection also include hundreds of offensive, though historically significant, ethnic, religious and racial characterizations that come with a warning label. There is also a detailed explanation of the painstaking process of transferring these old discs into digital recordings.

A computer illustration created by the wildlife activist group WWF-Indonesia using Google Earth provides a tour of Sumatran rain forest areas at risk of destruction by logging companies and palm oil producers. The animation focuses on Bukit Tigapuluh, a hilly region that provides habitat to endangered tigers, elephants, orangutans and other rare species. Camera trap footage from this area released by WWF this month showed a dozen tigers living in a logging concession. [Yale Environment 360]

Jemma Kidd has been busy: the 36-year-old former model runs the Jemma Kidd Makeup School in London, looks after two successful cosmetics lines — JK for Target, available at the mass retailer, and her makeup “academy,” for which she makes the QVC rounds — and last year, had twins with Arthur Wellesley, the Earl of Mornington (when she married him in 2005, it made her an official countess). All of this left her feeling, understandably, sluggish, until she adopted the Metabolic Balance Diet. “It’s this German diet. They take your blood and they analyze your hormone levels, vitamin levels, what’s right for you, your body type, your height, your weight. They analyze everything and give you this big list of what you can and cannot eat,” Kidd explained while previewing her summer and fall collections. “But the main rules are one type of protein for each meal, you’ve got to wait five hours between each meal, no snacking, an apple a day. The first thing you eat should be protein — it’s all about leveling your blood sugar and your hormones. Weight loss is the third thing. It’s detox for the first two weeks — you’re not allowed any fat. I’ve lost 23 pounds since January, 15 of them in the first 10 days.” The svelte Kidd was in New York a couple of weeks ago for the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Gala (she wore McQueen), where she was privy to some testimonials to one of her Target products, Show Stopper Year-Round Body Glow. “It’s organically grown into quite a successful little product,” she said. “I had five people at the Met ball come up to me and say, ‘My makeup artist put it on me. It’s fabulous!’”

CBS’s “Survivor: Redemption Island” topped the ratings on Sunday as 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the reality show’s two-hour season finale, according to Nielsen’s estimates. After three previous tries, Rob Mariano, a k a Boston Rob, was finally victorious, winning this season’s $1 million prize. CBS ranked No. 1 for the night, leading at 7 p.m. with “60 Minutes” (12 million) as well as at 10, following the “Survivor” finale with a reunion special (11.3 million). ABC placed second for the night, garnering 10 million viewers from 9 to 11 for the season finale of “Desperate Housewives.” NBC was third with “Dateline” at 7 (5.2 million), “Minute to Win It” at 8 (3.5 million) and “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11 (6.6 million). Fox and its animated comedy lineup finished fourth.

The Museum of Modern Art will pay $31.2 million for the American Folk Art Museum’s building, according to a notice the folk art museum filed to its bondholders. The two museums announced the planned sale last week but had not disclosed the price. The folk art museum took on $32 million of debt to construct the building on West 53rd Street, but attendance never met expectations, and after sustaining investment losses in the financial crisis, the museum defaulted on its debt. The folk art museum had said that the sale would allow it to retire its debt, as well as pay fees to lawyers and consultants. The numbers are close: As of June 30, 2009, the museum owed a principal of $29,945,000 on the bonds.

California announced that it would shutter 70 of its 278 state parks because of budget cuts, Ian Lovett of The Times reported on Friday. “Officials worked to keep open those with the most attendance and historical significance, as well as those that bring in the most revenue,” Mr. Lovett wrote. The California Department of Parks and Recreation said in a press release that the parks that remain open would allow it would to retain at least 92 percent of its attendance rate and 94 percent of its revenue. Parks slated for closure include Fort Humboldt State Historic Park, the Governor’s Mansion, Shasta State Historic Park and Sugarloaf Ridge.

In response to my column on religion and income (and my follow-up post on Economix), several readers have asked whether geography plays a big role. As one reader wrote, “Jews (and Asians) live primarily on the coasts, where above average incomes are earned (and needed).” The implication here is that Jews and Hindus aren’t the most affluent religions largely because they’re the most educated; according to this view, much of their affluence instead stems from the fact that they tend to live in expensive, high-income metropolitan areas, like New York, San Francisco, Washington and Boston.

KLEINMACHNOW, GERMANY -- They are called ''Wutbürger.'' And they have become the bane of every political party in Germany. Loosely translated as ''enraged citizen,'' the Wutbürger has stepped outside the classical political and parliamentary system by organizing demonstrations and town-hall meetings, protest marches and sit-ins.

EWALD--L. Philip, died at the age of 91 in Greenwich, CT, on May 8, 2011. A graduate of Groton School and Yale, he served as an Officer in Naval Intelligence during WWII. After a long career in publishing management, he joined Frank Pace, Jr. and David Rockefeller to build and expand the International Executive Service Corps. to 150 countries. Married for 57 years to Elizabeth Johnston Ewald, who predeceased him, he is survived by their two sons, Duncan and Douglass and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Round Hill Community Church on 1st of June 2011, at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT 06831

Shapeways, a company that allows people to print 3-D objects, announced on Thursday that it will now let you print things in a ceramic material that is ''food safe.'' Until now, 3-D printers have primarily printed in plastics or other materials that you wouldn't want to eat off of. In a release, Shapeways said it hopes customers will take advantage of the food-safe material to create ''ceramic tableware, including salt and pepper shakers, plates, mugs and more that actually can be used for eating and drinking.''

MANDEL--Jack. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are profoundly saddened by the passing of our cherished friend Jack Mandel, beloved brother of Morton and Joseph Mandel and brother-in-law of Barbara Mandel, Deputy Chair of The Hebrew University Board of Governors and Honorary President of AFHU. Jack, Morton and Joseph, founders of The Mandel Foundation of Cleveland, became key architects of the American Jewish community's enduring relationship with Israel. Their magnanimous support for The Hebrew University through the Mandel Foundation has benefited Israel and the global Jewish community in enduring ways, including through the creation of the Mandel Institute of Jewish Studies, its pioneering Scholion Interdisciplinary Research Center, and the Mandel Center for the Humanities. Over the decades, and with immense creativity, the Mandel family has enhanced The Hebrew University's intellectual growth and international stature. Visionary leadership initiatives have fostered scholarship and research of the highest level. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Menahem Ben-Sasson, President The Hebrew University of Jerusalem George A. Schieren Chairman, AFHU Martin E. Karlinsky President, AFHU Peter T. Willner National Executive Director, AFHU

HANDWERKER--Murray. son of the late Nathan and Ida, brother to Sol and Leah, passed away Saturday at the age of 89. Murray was the loving husband of the late Dorothy for 67 years. Murray was a brilliant entrepreneur, community supporter and visionary who developed Nathan's Famous into a chain of restaurants. The huge set for Wagner's ''Ring'' being staged at the Metropolitan Opera picked a fine time to misbehave. A technical problem left about 175,000 people in movie theaters around the world (and nearly 4,000 people at the Met itself) twiddling their thumbs while waiting for the start of a live high-definition broadcast of the cycle's second installment, ''Die Walküre,'' above. Finally, after about 45 minutes, the performance started. The 45-ton set consists of a row of giant planks that revolve around an axis, which can also move up and down. Each plank has an encoder that transmits information about its position to a computer, the Met's technical director, John Sellars, explained during the first intermission. One of those encoders was not working and had to be fixed, he said. The malfunction was reminiscent of the ''Ring's'' opening night, the first performance of ''Das Rheingold'' in September, when a problem prevented the formation of the bridge over which the gods cross into Valhalla.

LOS ANGELES- Hollywood still couldn't shake its box-office slump, as ''Thor,'' the top performer for a second weekend, posted $34.5 million in North American tickets sales for Marvel and Paramount Pictures, down 34 percent from $52 million on the same weekend last year for ''Iron Man 2,'' another Marvel-Paramount action fantasy that was also in its second week. ''Thor,'' starring Chris Hemsworth, above, has had $119.3 million in domestic ticket sales to date. ''Bridesmaids,'' a saucy R-rated comedy from Universal Pictures, with Judd Apatow among its producers, opened in second place at the domestic box office with $24.4 million in ticket sales, down 32 percent from the $36.1 million in sales posted by Universal's ''Robin Hood'' on the same weekend last year. Universal's ''Fast Five,'' in its third week, had $19.5 million in sales for the weekend, for a total of $168.8 million, while ''Priest,'' from Sony Pictures Entertainment and its Screen Gems unit, had $14.5 million in opening-weekend sales. ''Rio,'' an animated film from 20th Century Fox, in its fifth week, placed fifth, with about $8 million in sales, for a total of about $125 million.

The entertainment industry threw its weight behind a proposed law that would give law enforcement officials and others new authority to move against Internet sites that traffic without permission in copyrighted material. The bill was introduced last Thursday in the Senate, with bipartisan support from a group of sponsors that included Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah.

If heads are turning more than usual next summer in Los Angeles, it may be because a stage adaptation of ''The Exorcist,'' about a 10-year-old girl possessed by the devil and the Catholic priest who tries to save her, is set to open there at the Geffen Playhouse. The playwright John Pielmeier (''Agnes of God'') is writing the stage version of ''The Exorcist,'' based on William Peter Blatty's 1971 novel. John Doyle, who brought a stripped-down, bloody sensibility to the 2005 Broadway revival of ''Sweeney Todd,'' will direct the show, which is set to begin performances on July 3, 2012.

Science fiction buffs have long dreamed of replacing books, magazines and even computers with a digital flexible display that can be rolled up and stuffed in a pocket or bag. According to some Canadian researchers, this dream may soon come true. Researchers at the Queens University Human Media Lab in Kingston, Ontario, have developed a prototype flexible computer and display that is completely bendable and comes with a built-in touch screen.

The music industry scored a victory against online piracy last week by winning a $105 million settlement against the file-sharing network LimeWire. But where will that money go? And will any of it end up with the artists whose work was illegally downloaded? According to the major record labels, which sued LimeWire along with their trade group, the Recording Industry Association of America, some of the LimeWire money - which the service's creator, Mark Gorton, may have to pay personally - should and will go to artists' accounts.

There are at least two irrefutable facts about the practice of people communicating by cellphones while driving cars. First, it is a big problem, with studies estimating that more than 500,000 traffic accidents and 2,600 deaths a year are caused by cellphone-distracted drivers. No one has documented the problem as thoroughly as my colleague, Matt Richtel. The second is that cars are not going to become monastic cones of silence. America is a car culture, and the pressures of modern work and life mean that people are going to communicate from their cars, despite the potential danger.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. - Golf was going to form a wedge between Al Del Greco and his son Trey. The younger Del Greco was convinced it would as he nervously rehearsed what he planned to say to his father, a former N.F.L. place-kicker. It was the summer before Trey's junior year of high school, and he wanted to quit the football team to pursue a college golf scholarship. The decision was easy. The hard part was telling Del Greco, a former Auburn star who had dreamed of his firstborn son one day kicking for his alma mater.

Mobilewalla offers a search engine for mobile applications, by platform (BlackBerry, Apple, etc.), category, developer, fastest movers and keyword, as well as ratings of each platform's apps. It is rare in the tangle of games, navigation tools, camera enhancers and social networking apps to find overlap between top Apple and Android products. Only Pandora Radio, above, made both top 10 free app lists. Android, with 271,206 apps, has made progress catching up to Apple, which has 389,591. But Apple leads in the race for paid apps, 245,176 to 93,181. SHELLY FREIERMAN

ALLETZHAUSER--Albert. Albert Alletzhauser, on May 10th, we lost a true treasure of a human being in our dearly loved husband, father and friend, Al Alletzhauser. Al died in Phuket, Thailand of a heart attack at the age of 51. For many of us, 51 is only half a life. But Al packed three incredible lives into those 51 years. His achievements were wider in range and more extreme in their intensity than most people can imagine cramming into one full term life. Al was born in Rochester, NY, grew up in Madison, CT. and graduated from Colgate University. He was the author of the best-selling House of Nomura, Quake and the yet unpublished biography of Harry Oppenheimer. He was a financier extraordinaire with a career in investments and start-up businesses that started in Hong Kong; moved to Japan (where he met and married his adoring and adored wife Anne Cabot-Alletzhauser); London, where he helped found TIR, the global investment research house, and fund the fledgling publishing company Bloomsbury Press; and then on to South Africa, where he briefly took the helm of Penrose Holding, provided the initial kindling for the multi-manager business that morphed from Time Life, m Cubed and then Advantage Asset Management, ran the Cabot South African Hedge Fund and funded Nutrihealth Holdings. In the last phase of his business career he spearheaded the Jumeirah CuluCulu Polo Resorts project in Argentina and provided support and funding to the frontier asset management business Siam Knight Financial Securities Company in Bangkok Thailand. Al was a sunriser who went through life open to everything. Sunrisers believe you never know where the next great adventure and idea might be hidden. Al knew what it meant to be a true friend without boundaries. Friends continue to stay connected from every continent. He was an ardent polo player, a true global itinerant, and above all an absolutely amazing husband and father. For his three children: Arianna, Max and Chloe, Al was an incredible life force who made each of us feel we could achieve anything. He loved each of us for our own uniqueness and he had a brilliant capacity to identify what it was about each of us that made us special. Al has been loved and cherished and will be sorely missed. He is survived by his father Al and four siblings, Kurt, Amy, Eric and Judy, his wife Anne, his children Arianna, Max, and Chloe, and his friends from everywhere. A private memorial will be held at his home on Wednesday, May 18th at 3:00pm.

WASHINGTON - The president needed an increase in the federal debt limit. His partisan adversary, a powerful Ohio congressman, wanted something in return: deep spending cuts. The president was Richard M. Nixon, the congressman was Charles A. Vanik and the year was 1970. Mr. Vanik, a Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, did not win his $6 billion in spending cuts (equivalent to $34 billion today).

Yale is going first. The university, in New Haven, announced that it is opening its entire digital image collection to the public for free - the first Ivy League institution to take this step toward open access. Yale houses millions of images in its archives, museum and libraries, including a sonata written by the hand of Mozart and a watercolor by William Blake. ''The open access policy allows us to more fully harness the potential of digital and networked technologies in service to scholarship as well as to creative use and reuse of our rich cultural heritage,'' said Meg Bellinger, director of the Yale Office of Digital Assets and Infrastructure. ''It frees us to concentrate on our core mission to create, preserve and disseminate knowledge in digital form.'' So far, 250,000 images are available; it will take years until the entire collection is online. Yale is taking the unusual step of imposing no limits on the use of the images and is not requiring any licensing.

ANTIGUA, Guatemala — A gem of a town nestled in the central Guatemalan highlands, Antigua attracts plenty of Americans. They come for all sorts of reasons — to see the ruins of this one-time Central American capital, to climb the picturesque volcanoes that surround the city, and to get a taste of a region known as the land of eternal spring.

When he took office, Abraham Lincoln faced the greatest strategic challenge of any American president before or since: that of holding the country together as political and moral tensions that had risen steadily over the course of nearly 100 years strained mightily to tear it apart. But he also confronted a standard of civil-military relations that internalized domestic political intrigue and countenanced soldierly insubordination. Epitomized by Gen. George B. McClellan, this organizational problem was a crippling impediment for Lincoln early in the Civil War that required all of his political and psychological acumen to overcome. It was substantially a product of the Mexican War of 1846-48.

Promotional band videos — virtually without exception — are joy vacuums. No one wants to see a musician droning on about how this new record is a break with the past/a return to his roots. Rock star, your lack of introspection is compensated by the fact that you can play guitar: no more self-analysis for you! And yet, the “electronic press kit” persists.

Lincoln Center Theater on Tuesday started a program to provide $30 seats to its performances for people ages 21 to 35, theater officials announced. The program, called LincTix, allows members to buy tickets for productions at the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse Theaters at Lincoln Center, as well as to Lincoln Center Theater productions on Broadway. A limited number of LincTix will be available for every performance and available in advance. Once registered online, LincTix members (memberships are available at LincTix.org) can buy tickets for coming productions and to “War Horse,” now at the Vivian Beaumont Theater (regular tickets cost $75 to $125), and to “A Minister’s Wife,” now at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater (regular tickets are $85). LincTix members will also have a chance to purchase seats together with other LincTix members and will get invitations to free LincTix parties and other special events. Mem Membership includes advance notice of the $20 tickets for all LCT3 productions, which showcase the work of new playwrights, directors and designers.

Tavarua, the small, heart-shaped island in the Fijian archipelago, has two of the world’s most sought-after waves, Cloudbreak and Restaurants. Since 1984, access to them had been controlled by the Tavarua Island Resort (tavarua.com). But last year, Fiji’s military dictatorship put an end to the hotel’s exclusive rights, to the delight of local Fijians and international surfers, who have begun boating to the breaks from neighboring islands. Look for other resorts to spring up nearby and take advantage of the new access.

Location-based services, the mobile-phone applications that make use of a person’s geographic location, are attracting growing attention in Washington following reports that phone and software companies might have been sharing location information with third parties.

David Roberts, the Grist blogger, has written a double-barreled book review for the American Prospect that’s well worth reading. It explores “The Climate War,” Eric Pooley’s deconstruction of the long, and ultimately failed, effort to pass a comprehensive climate bill in the United States. But Roberts focuses most on David Victor‘s new book “Global Warming Gridlock,” which I’m way overdue to read. Victor, from the University of California, San Diego, has been a frequent and welcome voice on Dot Earth.

The Center for Biological Diversity says that a federal judge in Washington has temporarily blocked an accord on speeding government decisions on endangered species. The center had filed a court motion to delay the accord on Monday, arguing that it was unenforceable and left out important species of animals and plants. The Obama administration will resume talks with environmental groups, the center says.

The New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday made permanent a set of emergency regulations regarding the deaccessioning of artworks. In September the Regents approved the expiration of the regulations, which enjoined museums from selling artworks for operating costs and had been in effect since 2008.

Whatever final-season plans the creators of the Fox drama “House” may have had for sending the curmudgeonly and lovelorn title character off into the sunset with his boss, Dr. Lisa Cuddy, were dashed Tuesday when the actress Lisa Edelstein announced she would not return to wrap up the popular series.

On Thursday, I head to Spain to begin what sounds like a foolhardy adventure: high season in the Mediterranean on a budget. For 10 weeks, I’ll be just one soul among the gobs of tourists descending on its azure waters from around the world. Why would someone with a schedule as flexible and a wallet as light as mine want to fight the hordes of Italian and British and Norwegian and Chinese and Pennsylvanian vacationers and their affiliated bathing suit styles?

For my trip around the Mediterranean, I’m asking readers to plan a fun-filled, smartly-themed, low-budget five-day trip to somewhere on the Italian coast. It’s up to you to come up with a destination and associated theme. A multiday hike through gorgeous countryside and small towns? A lesser-known side of a much-visited tourist destination? Sampling the seafood specialties along a string of coastal villages? Anything goes, as long as you can get me there from Naples (where I’ll be the week before) and keep the budget light.

From the late ’80s through the early 2000s, much of surf culture was marked by homogeneity. The gear companies became behemoths, and the most popular boards (many shaped by computers) looked largely the same. In recent years, though, surfing’s zeitgeist has begun to celebrate individuality — a shift back to the homespun ethos of the sport’s early days. A surfer now is more likely to be riding a board he made himself, often a radically new shape. Even high-ranked pros are working collaboratively with their preferred shaper to come up with original, untested designs. Here, from left to right, some of the California-based gear guys who are leading the way.Mitch Abshere The owner of the Captain Fin Company produces surfboard fins and wet suits from Japanese rubber, which is especially soft, allowing for more agility (captainfincompany.com).

The California-based surfer and shaper Ryan Burch is fast gaining recognition for his iconoclastic D.I.Y. board designs and ability to ride almost any shape and size with spontaneity and grace. Here, Burch shapes from scratch a five-foot, two-inch asymmetrical board he calls the Sledgehammer.

A two-hour installment of semifinal performances on “Dancing With the Stars” topped the ratings on Monday night as 21.4 million viewers tuned in to the ABC reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Rafael thanked me for offering him a dream job. A fisherman since childhood, a painter of fish by day and a server at night, he had been waiting for a sustainable seafood place in which to work. He was well-spoken and mannerly, a good listener. We talked for an hour, going over his experience, his ambitions, how he stretched his canvases. He wanted to start work immediately. We agreed he would start the next day, at noon, train and taste and get familiar with our steps of service. That was a month ago. We have not heard from Rafael since.

Like most conductors, Georg Solti marked up his scores, noting tempos, voices to emphasize and the occasional cut. But he was also a prodigious reviser of his interpretations, according to scholars, leading him sometimes to acquire four or five copies of a score to note his ideas freshly each time. That has led to a large collection of scores — some 500 — that Harvard University has just received. The family of Solti, who died in 1997, donated the collection to the Loeb Music Library at Harvard, university officials said on Tuesday. “They are the most heavily marked-up scores I have ever seen,” said Virginia Danielson, the Loeb’s librarian, and a source of valuable insight into Solti’s musical thinking.

Not all musical groups are following the Metropolitan Opera’s lead in forging ahead with tours to post-earthquake Japan. Newt Gingrich did his level best to appear level in his “Meet the Press” interview Sunday, maintaining a mostly subdued, thoughtful tone except for one telling moment — when David Gregory, the host, asked him if his labeling of President Obama as the “food stamp president” might have racist connotations. “Oh, come on,” the former House speaker huffed. “That’s bizarre.” All he meant, Mr. Gingrich went on to explain, was that Mr. Obama’s policies would turn all of America into Detroit, which probably didn’t endear him to Eminem.

In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Jacques Demy‘s 1964 musical “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.” The film stars Catherine Deneuve and Nino Castelnuovo as a couple in love who are separated by war. Mr. Scott calls it “one of the most romantic films ever made.” With every line of dialogue sung, the film plays more like an opera than a musical. “This is singing as conversation,” Mr. Scott says, “a way for the actors to express their emotions, simply, sincerely and with a minimum of artifice.” Yet the film itself uses the artifice of cinema to its advantage, with bright colors and an attractive cast. Have you seen “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg?” Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

To separate the middle class from the wealthy, federal income tax policy sets the dividing line at $250,000 for family income. For six months, the new imprint at Penguin Group USA headed by David Rosenthal has remained stubbornly nameless. No longer, Mr. Rosenthal said on Monday: it will be called Blue Rider Press, a name inspired by the group of painters in early 20th-century Germany who bucked convention and promoted individual expression. “The Blue Rider name historically represents individuality and quality in the arts,” Mr. Rosenthal said in an e-mail. “And that same intent will be reflected in the eclectic fiction and nonfiction books Blue Rider Press will publish.” Mr. Rosenthal’s imprint will release its first titles in the fall, including “The New New Rules” by Bill Maher and a bedtime story parody, “Goodnight iPad.” It has also acquired books by Valerie Plame Wilson, Delia Ephron and R. A. Dickey. Mr. Rosenthal was offered his own imprint at Penguin after losing his job as publisher of the flagship imprint of Simon & Schuster last summer, and joins other Penguin imprints like Riverhead Books, Portfolio and the Penguin Press.

ROSENTHAL--George, 82, of Midland Park, NJ, died Sunday, May 15th of heart failure. He was raised in the Bronx and was a Veteran of the US Army. George spent his entire career as a respected property and casualty insurance broker. After retirement, he dedicated his personal time to The Insurance Information Institute in Manhattan. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lillian, his children, Caren, David, and Steven, their spouses, Barry, Leslie, and Angela, and his five cherished grandchildren, Eric, Matthew, Emma, Jack, and Sam, who all loved him dearly. He was a dear friend to many, had a wonderful sense of humor, and he will be missed by all.

Over the past few years, scientists have been working to transform education from the inside out, by applying findings from learning and memory research where they could do the most good, in the classroom. A study published in the journal Science on Thursday illustrates how promising this work can be -- and how treacherous. The research comes from a closely watched group led by Carl Wieman, a Nobel laureate in physics at the University of British Columbia who leads a $12 million initiative to improve science instruction using research-backed methods for both testing students' understanding and improving how science is taught.

Jim Crane, who lost a bid to buy the Texas Rangers last year, announced a deal Monday to acquire the Houston Astros from Drayton McLane for $680 million, which includes the lease on Minute Maid Park. ''Owning the Houston Astros in my hometown is all I can wish for,'' Crane said in a news conference. The sale price trails only the $845 million purchase of the Chicago Cubs by the Ricketts family two years ago. Crane, a Houston freight executive, was viewed by creditors to the Rangers as the higher and preferable bidder for that team when it was auctioned last year in federal bankruptcy court. Crane and Mark Cuban, the Dallas Mavericks' owner, lost out to a bid led by Chuck Greenberg and the Hall of Famer Nolan Ryan

MOFFAT--Keith Mali, 88, of Cold Spring Harbor, New York City, and Sanibel, Florida died on May 14, beloved husband of Frances S. Moffat and loving father of Gertrude, David, Harry, and Leslie (Little). He is survived by 12 grandchildren. He was the son of the late Douglas and Gertrude M. Moffat of New York City and Cold Spring Harbor and the brother of the late Virginia (Bateson) Nickerson. He was a graduate of the St. Bernard's School, St. Paul's School, Yale University (44) and Yale Law School (48). He studied Japanese and was an interpreter with the Marine Corps from 1943-46. He became a partner in the law firm of Casey, Lane, and Mittendorf. He was an avid tennis player, gardener, reader, outdoorsman, and fly fisherman. He was a member of the Angler's Club, the Union Club, the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, the Piping Rock Club, and the Huntington Country Club. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 20 at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor. Memorial donations may be made to the Nature Conservancy or the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

(TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: PLAYING THE PONIES Turner Classic Movies presents five for horse lovers, starting with ''National Velvet'' (1944), starring Mickey Rooney as a young drifter who tames the Pie, the wild steed of a 12-year-old British girl (Elizabeth Taylor, above, with Mr. Rooney), training the horse for the Grand National steeplechase. The Museum of Modern Art will pay $31.2 million for the American Folk Art Museum's building, according to a notice the folk art museum filed to its bondholders. The two museums announced the planned sale last week but had not disclosed the price. The folk art museum took on $32 million of debt to construct the building on West 53rd Street, but attendance never met expectations, and after sustaining investment losses in the financial crisis, the museum defaulted on its debt. The folk art museum had said that the sale would allow it to retire its debt, as well as pay fees to lawyers and consultants. The numbers are close: As of June 30, 2009, the museum owed a principle of $29,945,000 on the bonds. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Those cinematic siblings Joel and Ethan Coen are such mensches that their 2009 film ''A Serious Man'' was released in Israel under a Hebrew title that translates as ''The Good Jew.'' But in picking up a $1 million prize in Tel Aviv over the weekend, the Coens could not say for certain if their Jewish background had an impact on the movies they make. ''Who knows?'' said Joel Coen, according to the Israeli newspaper Haaretz. Mr. Coen, who with his brother, Ethan, has written and directed films like ''No Country For Old Men'' and last year's remake of ''True Grit,'' added: ''We don't think about it. There's no doubt that our Jewish heritage affects how we see things.''

DICK--Harold Michael. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Harold M. Dick, MD, a longtime distinguished member of our medical center and a leader in the field of orthopaedics in pediatric orthopaedic oncology, limb lengthening and hand surgery. Dr. Dick spent his entire professional life at our medical center, having completed his residency in 1966 and hand fellowship in 1967. He was appointed to the Columbia faculty in 1969, on which he served until his retirement in 2001 as Frank E. Stinchfield Emeritus Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery. From 1984 to 1998, Dr. Dick served as chairman of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and as director of service and chief medical officer at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia. Dr. Dick's accomplishments are numerous. In 1984, he established a world-renowned orthopaedic research laboratory and the Microsurgery Research and Training Laboratory. In 1997, he established the Anne Youle Stein Center for Orthopaedic Research. Dr. Dick served as president of the Academic Orthopaedic Society, the American Orthopaedic Association, and the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery. We extend our condolences to his wife, Joyce Geller, and daughter, Victoria Schnure, and her three children, and surviving siblings Denise Wetter, Carol Olenik, Nan Jones, Norman Dick and 34 immediate nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that memorial gifts be directed to Columbia Orthopaedics, Columbia University Medical Center, 622 West 168th Street, PH-11, NY, NY 10032. Lee Goldman, M.D. Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Louis U. Bigliani, M.D. Frank E. Stinchfield Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery and Chairman, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons Orthopaedic Surgeon-in-Chief, NewYork-Presbyterian/ Columbia

LEWIS--Ann. It is with great sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the passing of our beloved member Ann Lewis of Sydney, Australia, after a battle with cancer. Annie joined the Council in 1972 and became a Vice President in 1993. She attended meetings of the Council each spring in countries around the world. In 1975 and 1992, she was instrumental in arranging Council Spring Meetings in Australia. Each year, we looked forward to Annie's presence at our New York Fall Meetings, which she invariably attended. She passionately loved art and was a source of great inspiration and support, in Australia and around the world. She will be sorely missed by us all. Brian Urquhart H.R.H. Angelina Jolie's directorial debut, a film about the 1990s Bosnian war that stoked controversy during its production, will be released in theaters at the end of the year. Representatives for the distributor FilmDistrict, a subsidiary of GK Films, said that it would release the film, ''In the Land of Blood and Honey,'' in the United States on Dec. 23. FilmDistrict said the movie, which Ms. Jolie also wrote, stars Zana Marjanovic, Goran Kostic and Rade Serbedzija and features ''a completely local cast, most of whom were children of the war.''

Consumer Reports, famous for its ratings of appliances and cars, has jumped into the diet wars. When Goldman Sachs went public 12 years ago this month, an elite group of 221 executives controlled the strategy and shares of the investment bank. While the clubby culture remains, the tight-knit group has lost its viselike grip on the company, as the wishes of the insular partnership have given way to the demands of the outside shareholders. The roughly 480 partners currently own less than 10 percent of the company, down from approximately 60 percent at the initial public offering in 1999.

Eight million New Yorkers. Thirteen thousand yellow cabs. It is a ratio that can flummox, particularly during a rainstorm at rush hour. A new proposal by the city, however, promises relief: more than 1,500 additional yellow cabs could soon be plying the streets, bringing the total taxi fleet to around 15,000, its biggest size since the Great Depression.

MYERS--Shirley D.,passed away last Wednesday morning, predeceased by her husband Bernard S. Myers, Ph.D., and survived by her son Peter L. Myers, Ph.D. her daughter Lucie E. Myers two granddaughters, Emma and Molly Myers, and a great-grandson. She was born Shirley Diana Levene, lifelong New Yorker and prolific intellectual. In the 1930's she was active in support of democratic Spain against fascism, and later advocated civil rights and peace issues. She was a founder, curriculum chair and Past President of Quest, a peer-led community for lifelong learning, and coordinated and taught a wide range of courses in history, science, and the Humanities until she became ill in 2011. She edited or co-edited numerous books and encyclopedias on art history, including the McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Art.

Kristoffer Diaz's play ''The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,'' a comic drama about televised professional wrestling and identity politics, won the Obie award for best new American play on Monday night at a ceremony marking the 56th year of the awards, presented by The Village Voice to honor Off Broadway theater. Among other prizes were the Ross Wetzsteon Award (which includes a check for $1,000) to the Belarus Free Theater, which fled its country during a government crackdown this winter and performed at the Public Theater's Under the Radar Festival in January and then worked in repertory at La MaMa until last Sunday. And the Obie lifetime achievement award went to the Spanish-language theater Repertorio Espanol and its artistic director, Rene Buch, who helped found the company in 1968.

GREENSPAN--Bernice Greenspan, passed sweetly and peacefully in her daughter Jayne's arms on Friday evening, May 13th. While Bernice was a longtime resident of Deal, New Jersey, with her beloved husband Mortimer (Morty) who were married for 41 years, she was always a southern belle at heart having had a magical childhood growing up in Charleston, SC. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Morty, dear sisters, Flossie Arnold, Lilla Levine and Edna Banov and her handsome brother Isadore Ginsburg. While Bernice was a courageous double breast cancer survivor, her greatest heartbreak was losing her precious daughter, Joann Weber to cancer a few years ago. She is survived by her daughter, Jayne Butlein and husband Eric, and son, Jay Greenspan and wife, Louise and Joann's husband Drew Weber; her grandchildren Alex DeToro (and John), David (and Willow) and Adam (and Katrina) Butlein, Michael (and Kathy) and Kate Weber, Rachel, Noah and Sam Greenspan and her great grandchildren Annie, Jonah, Ella, Eve and Jake DeToro and James Weber. A woman of exceptional beauty inside and out, grace and charm, she was committed to supporting the community and those in need serving as President of Camp Oakhurst for the Handicapped, Jewish Family and Children's Service of Greater Monmouth County as well as an ardent supporter of Israel for which she was very proud to have been a Lion of Judah. Bernice was an amazing and loyal friend with many relationships extending 50 years or more. Known by many to be a perfectionist in many ways, she even made sure this notice and the thank you notes to be sent were of a particular quality as well as ensuring that all the children and grandchildren's grammar and manners were impeccable a daunting task. Bernice and Morty had a strong partnership whether in support of Flagstaff Liquors' success or to entertaining at their beautiful house on the beach in Deal. She lived a full life surrounded by family and friends and said towards the end of her 88 years that she had a fabulous run and was ready to move on and be with Morty, her parents and Joann again. Incredible thanks to the people who took such great care of Bernice over her life especially Felice Cardoza. Graveside services will be for family on Tuesday in New Jersey. Donations in her memory can be made to Jewish Family & Children's Service of Greater Monmouth County, 705 Summerfield Ave., Asbury Park, NJ 07712.

PLEVA--Eugene, 86, of Riverdale, New York passed away at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital on May 15, 2011. He is survived by a wife, Estelle Pleva of New York, and devoted daughters, Lisa Shepard and her husband Daron, Carolyn Rowan and her husband Marc and Susan Rahman and her husband Fraidoon. He is also survived by 10 adoring grandchildren, David, Elizabeth, Jennifer, Michael, Joshua, Zachary, Andrew, Charlotte, Michelle and Emily. Eugene served in the army during WWII, and returned to attend college at City College of New York. He began his career working for the Government, and from there had many entrepreneurial pursuits. He had many interests ranging from his love of the stock market, sports, opera and classical music, to living a holistic/homeopathic life. He would research and treat anyone in need with the appropriate natural remedy. He inspired two of his daughters to pursue careers in the health profession, Susan as a dentist and Lisa as a registered dietician. His daughter Carolyn was inspired to pursue a career in art and fashion. Eugene's most cherished job was being a father and grandfather. A private memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 17, 2011, 3pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, NY 10023. There will be no calling hours and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Child Life at Mt. Sinai Hospital or the Stamford Hospital Bennett Cancer Center. To leave online condolences please visit Eugene Pleva's guestbook: www.riversidememorialchapel.com/obituaries.

BRAND--Rose. Beloved mother of Gabrielle, Adrienne and Jason. Grandmother of Zachary and Devon and wife of late husband Ascher. Funeral services to be held at Mt. Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY, Tuesday, May 17 at 12:45pm.

For six months the new imprint at Penguin Group USA led by David Rosenthal has remained nameless. No longer, Mr. Rosenthal said on Monday: it will be called Blue Rider Press, a name inspired by the painters in early 20th-century-Germany who bucked convention and promoted individual expression. ''The Blue Rider name historically represents individuality and quality in the arts,'' Mr. Rosenthal said in an e-mail. ''And that same intent will be reflected in the eclectic fiction and nonfiction books Blue Rider Press will publish.'' Mr. Rosenthal's imprint will release its first titles in the fall, including ''The New New Rules,'' by Bill Maher, and a bedtime story parody, ''Goodnight iPad.'' It has also acquired books by Valerie Plame Wilson, Delia Ephron and R. A. Dickey. Mr. Rosenthal was offered his own imprint at Penguin after losing his job as publisher of the flagship imprint of Simon & Schuster last summer, and joins other Penguin imprints, including Riverhead Books, Portfolio and the Penguin Press. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

In Washington, Chris Lehane, a Democratic consultant, is known - and this is a compliment in that world - as a fervent advocate of the dark arts of politics: the cutthroat, destroy-your-enemies, do-what-it-takes-to win approach to political campaigns. ''In the last five days, it always comes down to a knife fight in a telephone booth,'' Mr. Lehane said, commenting on the final days of the 2008 presidential campaign. Mr. Guttentag, a director of documentaries, said that he originally intended to do a documentary on campaigns but decided that he would never get the necessary behind-the-scenes access. He met Mr. Lehane after enlisting him in 2008 to speak on crisis management at a class he teaches at the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University on the film business. Mr. Lehane offered behind-the-scene anecdotes from his years in politics, including working for the presidential campaigns of Al Gore and John Kerry, as well as in the White House of Bill Clinton. He decided shortly after to instead do a fictional film and asked Mr. Lehane to join as a writer.

It was a dignified mainstay of Automobile Row, the line of glittery showrooms and automobile-related offices that stretched up Broadway from the West 50s to somewhere north of Columbus Circle. President Obama is a millionaire with assets that could reach as much as $12 million, mostly from proceeds from his two best-selling books, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Monday. The disclosures require only that Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, list the value of their assets in wide ranges. For example, the president lists royalties from his memoir ''Dreams From My Father'' as between $1 million and $5 million.

The operator of the Nasdaq market withdrew its $11 billion rival bid for the New York Stock Exchange's parent on Monday after the Justice Department said it would challenge the deal, raising questions about Nasdaq's next steps as exchanges around the world merge to remain competitive. Nasdaq, fierce rivals with the N.Y.S.E. for years, had sought to derail a planned merger between NYSE Euronext and the Deutsche Borse. In April, the Nasdaq OMX Group joined forces with the IntercontinentalExchange, known as ICE, a commodities futures and derivatives marketplace, to make a bid for NYSE Euronext. Under their proposal, Nasdaq would take the Big Board, while the IntercontinentalExchange would get the NYSE's derivatives business.

SHERMAN--Saul L.,died May 15, 2011. He will be greatly mourned by his wife of 34 years, Judith nee Kofsky; his children Kate and Bill, stepson David Shonkoff, and grandson Cooper. He was pre-deceased by his first wife, Carol nee Esberg. A graduate of Harvard Law, he served in the U.S. Foreign Service during the occupation of Germany. He was a partner in Rivkin, Sherman, and Levy, specializing in international trade law. He co-authored the definitive guide to the GATT and served on NAFTA panels as an international arbitrator. He was beloved by his family and will be remembered for his brilliance, wit, and lifelong commitment to the highest ethical ideals. Funeral: 2pm. Tuesday at Plaza Community Memorial Chapel. The family will be receiving visitors in both New York and Long Island; please call for details.
