Ron Lieber’s Your Money column last weekend urged investors to ask their employers for more index-fund choices in their 401(k) retirement plans. Many plans are heavy on actively managed funds, even though index funds offer lower administrative costs and relatively lower risk that benefit investors as they build their nest eggs.

When I ventured into the world of personal manufacturing for last Sunday’s magazine article, “The Kitchen-Table Industrialists,” I found myself itching to make something myself. Like many urban professionals, I spend a lot of time producing things on a screen and very little time making anything tangible — besides lunch. As I describe in my article, I tried, on a trip to Detroit, to make an iPad stand, based on a design I downloaded from the Web. But the 3-D printer — yes, this exists — kept botching it. So I scaled back my ambitions and 3-D printed this lovely hexagonal nut. It’s not much, and it’s not much use without a bolt, but it’s something.

Jazz at Noon, the end-of-the-workweek lunchtime jam session that has been running continuously since 1965, will end on June 10. The series at the Players club on East 20th Street is a haven for jazz-playing New Yorkers with day jobs, but it has also hosted notable guest musicians over the years, including Benny Goodman, Dizzy Gillespie and Stan Getz. Leslie Lieber, the saxophonist who founded and still leads the sessions, turned 99 in March, but he said age had nothing to do with his decision to end the series after 46 years. “I could keep right on going,” he said. “It’s just that we don’t get the numbers of players we used to get. It’s harder to keep the sessions going.”

The Japanese photographer Rinko Kawauchi is finely tuned to what she likes to call the small voices in our world — those that whisper. Her eyes, she says, naturally focus on small things. And her latest body of work, “Illuminance,” which provides the content for both an exhibition, opening Friday at the Hermès gallery, and a lush book published by Aperture, is resplendent in them. A tiny green frog perches on the palm of a seemingly enormous hand; a lit cigarette, its ash a fiery orange, juts from the fingers of another. A slab of raw tuna is approached in such proximity that it takes on the monumentality of landscape. An image of goldfish packed to the gills in a plastic bag brings to mind the Tokyo subway during rush hour.

At 43 square feet, Missbibi, the recently opened jewelry store in Paris’s Palais Royal, is so small, if you blink on your way down the arcade you might miss it. The lead story on the Triple Crown trail is the decision of the owner Amed Zayat not to enter his horse Nehro in the Preakness. Nehro finished second in the Kentucky Derby. Zayat’s racing manager said in the New York Post, “The main decision came down to Mr. Zayat feeling it was a little much to ask the horse to run four great races in an eight-week time frame.”  Zayat told the Daily News, “”I let my horse tell me what the next step is. In the last six weeks he’s run a lot. I’ve got to be kind to him. Patience rewards you. I don’t want to get my ego involved. You do what is right by the horse.”

CANNES, France— Outspoken in interviews and in his offscreen role as a political activist, the Italian writer, director and actor Nanni Moretti tends to take a lighter touch in his films. “Habemus Papam” (“We Have a Pope”), screening in the official competition at the Cannes Film Festival, concerns a newly elected pope named Melville (the French actor Michel Piccoli), whose existential panic attack prompts the cardinals to call in a psychoanalyst (Mr. Moretti). But while the shrink is sequestered at the Vatican, the pope goes on a walkabout through the streets of Rome, rekindling an old love of acting as he stumbles into a theater production of Chekhov’s “Seagull.”

If there is a place that the name Astier de Villatte conjures, it is most definitely Paris. For 15 years, Ivan Pericoli and Benoît Astier de Villatte have been creating furniture and wonderfully goopy, overglazed ceramics which they sell from their charming shop on the rue Saint Honoré. But when the two set out to create a new collection of candles, they broadened their horizons, following their noses — in their imaginations, at least — to far flung places like Brasilia and Kobe. Of the 20 different destination-oriented scents, created in collaboration with the fragrance company Takasago, some might seem vaguely familiar: Naples, for example, is a bouquet of “almond, orange blossom, and Ylang-Ylang, lightened by a refreshing touch of petitgrain and neroli.” Alcatraz, on the other hand (“Indian blond tobacco, yerba maté with its notes of dried hay, smoked lignum vitae and cinnamon spiced with black pepper”) seems to have been conjured not from an actual three-hour tour but a dream. And what is the smell of home? Rue Saint Honoré is described as a powdery cloud in which a few delicate green notes and a jasmine rose accord merge deliciously with the amber and leather atmosphere.

Tim Harford, a columnist for The Financial Times, has a book out this month, “Adapt: Why Success Always Starts With Failure.” It’s an argument about the virtues — and necessity, really — of trial and error. In his words, there are three essential steps: “to try new things, in the expectations that some will fail; to make failure survivable, because it will be common; and to make sure that you know when you’ve failed.” It sort of seems like common sense, but the book’s wealth of fascinating case studies shows just how uncommon and difficult it often is for people and institutions to follow such a program.

Recently scientists at Penn State sewed tiny weighted vests and slipped them around the middles of healthy laboratory rats, hoping to discover how animals’ muscles respond to changes in body size. The vests increased the animals’ weight by as much as 36 percent. After five days, the scientists found that the rats’ muscles contained increased amounts of certain proteins involved in the generation of muscle force. The muscles were redesigning themselves to be stronger.

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about organ donations by Julio Garcia, a resident of Stamford, Conn., who died of a brain hemorrhage in 2010, omitted a first reference to the Manhattan hospital where patients who received Mr. Garcia's heart, liver and lung were being treated. It is New York-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital. The article also misstated the telephone number for Donate Life America, a group that provides information about organ donation. The correct number is (804) 377-3580.

The Yankees put reliever Rafael Soriano on the disabled list Tuesday, but, befitting their fortunes recently, they also dealt with a matter unrelated to his ailing right elbow. Soriano, who had pitched once in the Yankees' last seven games, will miss at least another two weeks after magnetic resonance imaging revealed inflammation in his elbow. But also problematic were comments he made after the Yankees' loss to the Tampa Bay Rays on Monday, their sixth in a row.

NEW YORK An article on Tuesday about a desire by James E. McGreevey, the former New Jersey governor, to be accepted as a candidate for the priesthood in the Episcopal Church misstated the timing of the rejection of his application to become a postulant, the next step following his graduation from divinity school. It was in May 2010, not last month. .

Oaktree Capital Management is planning to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, the latest private investment firm to tap the public markets. Oaktree, which manages about $82 billion, mostly in fixed-income strategies, is expected to transfer its shares from a private exchange to the Exchange, according to a person familiar with the planned move who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss it.

2:18 p.m. | Updated HarperCollins has acquired the world English-language rights to an autobiography by Pete Townshend, the guitarist and main songwriter for the Who, whose memoir inspired a bidding war among publishers. David Hirshey, an executive editor at Harper, will edit the book.

The New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday made permanent a set of emergency regulations regarding the deaccessioning of artworks. In September the Regents approved the expiration of the regulations, which enjoined museums from selling artworks for operating costs and had been in effect since 2008. Former Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat who had tried to pass a bill that would make such sales illegal, commended Tuesday's vote. ''It is New York reasserting its leadership on cultural issues,'' he said. ''It explicitly says that museums cannot use the sale of art objects for operating expenses.'' The Regents oversee many museums in the state because they are chartered as educational institutions. Institutions chartered by the legislature will not be subject to the regulations.

After 45 years as the spirited host of his annual Labor Day telethon to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association, Jerry Lewis said this year's broadcast will be his last. ''As a labor of love, I've hosted the annual Telethon since 1966,'' Mr. Lewis said in a statement reported by The Associated Press, ''and I'll be making my final appearance on the show this year by performing my signature song, 'You'll Never Walk Alone.''' Mr. Lewis, 85, will remain as national chairman of the Muscular Dystrophy Association, a position he has held since the 1950s. That organization said its telethons have raised more than $1 billion and that Mr. Lewis has logged some 900 live hours of television as the program's master of ceremonies, going back to his inaugural hosting gig in 1966, when the show was carried on one New York station and took in about $1 million in pledges.
7:03 p.m. | Updated A few months ago, LinkedIn's market debut looked to be relatively modest. Its value on a secondary exchange had stagnated at roughly $2.5 billion.

8 P.M. (HBO2) BURMA SOLDIER (2011) Like many young, unemployed men in Burma -- now known as Myanmar -- Myo Myint Cho, above, joined the army at 17 to find security and respect and to earn a living. While undergoing training that encouraged torture and even killing to suppress insurgency, he began working as an engineer, mapping and clearing landmines. But after witnessing atrocities against civilians and losing an arm, a leg and several fingers to a mortar blast, Mr. Cho left the army. He built a secret library of banned books and organized demonstrations against the regime. This film from Nic Dunlop, Annie Sundberg and Ricki Stern uses testimony, archival film footage and smuggled photographs to trace the country's history and expose abuses inflicted by the one-party system established in 1962 by Gen. Ne Win. After serving 15 years in prison for his pro-democracy political beliefs, Mr. Cho joined his brother and sister in Fort Wayne, Ind., home to one of the largest Burmese communities in the United States. Colin Farrell narrates. 7:15 P.M. (HBO Signature) TRANSAMERICA (2005) Felicity Huffman plays Bree, a preoperative transsexual who, though still technically a man, passes for a woman through the use of tasteful pink outfits, meticulously applied makeup and a breathy voice. But before her gender-reassignment surgery she needs to tie up a loose end, and soon Bree is on the road with the previously unknown son (Kevin Zegers) she long ago fathered when she was known as Stanley. ''In this debut feature by Duncan Tucker, who wrote and directed it, 'Transamerica' sets out to affirm Bree's dignity, to liberate her and others like her from any association with camp or freakishness,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''That the film succeeds without slipping too far into sentimentality or didacticism is in no small measure the result of Ms. Huffman's wit and grace. (She may also be the first film actor of either sex to do frontal nudity, in a single movie, as both.)''

KELLER--Barbara T. 85, passed away peacefully on May 6th joining her beloved husband of 60 years, C. Lawrence Keller. Originally from South Orange, NJ, Barbara was a longtime resident of Short Hills, NJ, and Londonderry, VT. Barbara graduated from Miss Beard's School and in 1945 from Bennett Junior College before working at J. Walter Thompson until her marriage in 1949. In 1977 Barbara graduated with honors from Union County Technical School in occupation therapy. She began her career in health care at Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation catalyzing her interest in alternative healing. She studied Therapeutic Touch at the NYU College of Nursing and advocated the contemporary healing modality as a practitioner and teacher for 30 years. Barbara was a dedicated humanitarian who supported numerous causes. Most notably, she served nine years on the Board of Trustees of Cheshire Home in Florham Park, a residence for the disabled. She also was a board member of Canterbury Village in West Orange and an early supporter the Interweave Center for Holistic Living in Summit. An avid sportswoman, Barbara was a member of the Short Hills Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, VT, Sankaty Head Golf Club in Nantucket, MA, and Tuscarora Club in Margaretville, NY. Barbara is survived by four children; Cord, Jim (Elissa), Linny Andlinger (Rick) and Nick (Marnie) and four grandchildren; Nick Andlinger, Emily, Franny and Everett. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Stephen's Church in Millburn, NJ at 11am on May 26. In lieu of flowers, she requested sending a donation to Cheshire Home, Inc., 9 Ridgedale Ave., Florham Park, NJ, 07932 or Interweave, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ, 07901. For online condolences, please visit: moriartyfuneralhome.com

It should be no surprise that the ferment in the Arab world has touched the Palestinians, whose promised two-state solution is no closer than ever. On Sunday, the anniversary of Israel's creation, thousands marching from Syria, Gaza, Lebanon and the West Bank breached Israel's borders and confronted Israeli troops. More than a dozen people were killed; scores were injured. According to The Times's Ethan Bronner, the protests were coordinated via social media, but they also appeared to have support from Lebanon and President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, who is eager to divert attention from his crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.

Six months ago Woody Allen heard from the theater producer Julian Schlossberg that he was thinking of staging a new one-act play by Elaine May. Did Mr. Allen have anything in the drawer? After all, Ms. May and Mr. Allen had enjoyed critical success, with David Mamet, in 1995 with their trio of one-acts, Off Broadway's ''Death Defying Acts,'' which ran for nearly a year with Mr. Schlossberg among the producers. As the gods would have it, Mr. Allen said in a telephone interview on Tuesday, he indeed had an idea for a play, and after four weeks of writing he had it done - this time, for a Broadway-bound production.

Is Derek Jeter, who had his lowest full-season batting average last year (.270), past his peak? Perhaps the answer will arrive with next year's baby-name list. According to the Social Security Administration, 47 baby boys were named Jeter nationwide in 2010, the year after the Yankees won the World Series, with Jeter batting .334. In fact, the number of newborn Jeters has climbed fairly steadily since 1998, when five babies were given the name. In 2009, there were 39 new baby Jeters, up from 27 in 2008 and 16 in 2006.

Opening HIGHLINER If people look at the Highliner in what was the Empire Diner and think nothing has changed, then Charles Milite, an owner, has achieved what he wanted after a gut renovation. The chef, Jeremie Tomczak, said of his menu, ''I had to stay true to the diner, and I don't believe in shocking people.'' Still, his mac and cheese comes with mustard greens, and an omelet with bone marrow croutons: 210 10th Avenue (22nd Street); (212) 206-6206.

MOFFAT--Keith Mali, 88, of Cold Spring Harbor, New York City, and Sanibel, Florida died on May 14, beloved husband of Frances S. Moffat and loving father of Gertrude, David, Harry, and Leslie (Little). He is survived by 12 grandchildren. He was the son of the late Douglas and Gertrude M. Moffat of New York City and Cold Spring Harbor and the brother of the late Virginia (Bateson) Nickerson. He was a graduate of the St. Bernard's School, St. Paul's School, Yale University (44) and Yale Law School (48). He studied Japanese and was an interpreter with the Marine Corps from 1943-46. At long last, there may be a serious investigation into the mortgage mess -- the kind that results in clarity as well as big fines and maybe even accountability. Gretchen Morgenson reported in The Times on Tuesday that Eric Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, wants to discuss mortgage operations during the housing bubble with executives of Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. He has also requested documents and information from the banks, examined material given to his predecessor, Andrew Cuomo, and studied issues raised in lawsuits against the banks.

NATIONAL An article on Thursday about a suit by a parent against the Sidwell Friends School in Washington, D.C., misstated the relationship of Nancy Reagan, the former first lady, to the school. Mrs. Reagan attended the school in the 1920's, a Sidwell official said, but she did not graduate from there.

When you think of who or what constitutes an American master your mind probably flashes first on artists or writers like Norman Rockwell, Ernest Hemingway or Georgia O'Keeffe, and not necessarily the guys whose song ''Evenflow'' you spent many a night singing along with in the collegiate taprooms of your youth. But there you have it: Pearl Jam will join the ''American Masters'' roster when Cameron Crowe's documentary about that influential Seattle rock band, ''Pearl Jam Twenty,'' makes its PBS debut on Oct. 21, representatives for PBS said on Monday. The documentary, compiled from some 1,200 hours of footage chronicling Pearl Jam's 20-year history, will be shown as part of the recently announced PBS Arts Fall Festival; KCTS, a PBS member station in Seattle, will also create a short documentary about that city's art scene to coincide with the broadcast. Other shows planned for the PBS Arts Fall Festival include an ''American Masters'' profile of Bill T. Jones, the dancer and choreographer; ''Great Performances'' on the Los Angeles Opera's production of ''Il Postino'' and San Francisco Ballet's ''Little Mermaid''; as well as programs titled ''Give Me the Banjo'' and ''Women Who Rock.''

COMING Saturday from the folks who unleashed Brooklyn Flea on an unsuspecting universe: Smorgasburg, a conglomeration of about 100 purveyors, including hawkers of handmade food, Greenmarket farmers and cookware vendors, gathering weekly at the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. With pupusas from a Salvadoran immigrant, strawberry-turnip-jam hamantaschen from two young hipsters and B.L.T.'s by the farmers who cured the bacon, this food festival will offer the work of rank newbies, established restaurants with bright ideas and kitchen professionals on a lark.

Not all musical groups are following the Metropolitan Opera's lead in forging ahead with tours to post-earthquake Japan. The Collegium Vocale Gent, a highly regarded ensemble that helped open the newly renovated Alice Tully Hall two years ago, has canceled a June tour that was to have included three performances in and near Tokyo because of concerns over nuclear safety brought on by the March quake and tsunami that crippled a nuclear power plant, resulting in releases of radiation. The Collegium tour was also to have included several stops in China. The group was to perform Bach's B minor Mass. Because the work is religious in nature, Mr. De Laender said, Chinese officials needed to give special approval. The approval process was cut short when the group decided to cancel over safety concerns in Japan, he said, acknowledging that ''there might be a problem'' in gaining approval for a Mass performance in China. ''We were ready to do everything for approval,'' Mr. De Laender said. The issue of Chinese approval of performances by Westerners arose last month when Bob Dylan played in China.

This week, I reported on the First Book Marketplace, which sells new books at steep discounts to schools and reading programs serving low-income children. Based on sales growth, First Book, which is a nonprofit, anticipates that the marketplace will be financially self-sustaining within a few years. It’s hard to find fault with a social-purpose business that makes quality books more affordable for underprivileged children. But, surprisingly, many readers responded to the idea by suggesting that the problem of book access can be adequately addressed through rummage sales, thrift shops, used book outlets and libraries. This reflects a misunderstanding of the problem, which I’d like to clarify.

Reading the story in The Times earlier this week about Tristane Banon, a 31-year-old journalist who said that Dominique Strauss-Kahn tried to rape her during an interview in 2002, I was struck by the conversation she had soon after with her mother, who discouraged her from filing charges against a powerful man who was a friend of the family. As Banon’s mother, Anne Mansouret, a Socialist Party official, recounted the conversation, she told her daughter: “Listen, you know, if he had raped you, I wouldn’t have any hesitation, but that wasn’t the case. Surf culture has long produced its own aesthetic, along with a tradition of surfer-artists. On the visual vanguard at the moment are Alex Kopps and Tin Ojeda. Kopps’s films, graffiti and collage-like prints (alexkopps.com) give an urban edge to what is usually a beachy domain. “The content and events that have influenced my artwork were not discovered at the beach,” says Kopps, who lives in the Bay Area and sells some of his T-shirts and posters (right) at Mollusk Surf Shop. His film “Displacement,” about “displacement hull” surfboards, uses 1970s Super-8 footage with abstract effects. Ojeda, the Argentinian-born painter and surfer behind the Drug Money Art clothing line (drugmoneyart.com), is bringing the beach to the city. His tees, on which he hand-prints phrases (“Beauty Is Boring,” says one), first gained a following in his home base of Montauk, N.Y. Now they’re at Barneys and in stores in Tokyo, Berlin and London.

Contrary to popular stereotype, computer programmers have not always been caffeine-fueled men in T-shirts coding deep into the night. In fact, some of the earliest programmers were female mathematicians, originally recruited to calculate ballistics trajectories for the Army during World War II.  Several of these pioneering women went on to program ENIAC, the world’s first all-electronic computer. In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Kathy Kleiman of the ENIAC Programmers Project about their valuable contributions to computing history.

In this week’s magazine, Daniel Bergner writes about the “American Idol” of opera — the Metropolitan Opera’s annual National Council Auditions. A borderline apocalyptic scene awaits when you enter Spreepark, Berlin’s only theme park, in the Treptow-Köpenick district in the former East Berlin. Life-size replicas of dinosaurs lie toppled on the ground. A pirate ship sits disintegrating in an algae-covered pond. A rusty Ferris wheel stands askew. Spreepark has been dormant since its insolvency in 2002. But from May 26 through 29, the fairground will come alive with the arrival of a multimedia festival called Lunapark Berlin.

A collision between a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus and a car at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday night left one person dead and several people injured, officials said. The crash occurred at 10:25 p.m. on Pan Am Road near parking lot eight. The crash is still under investigation.

An article on Sunday about the creation of a mercenary battalion in the United Arab Emirates misstated the past work of Executive Outcomes, a former South African mercenary firm whose veterans have been recruited for the new battalion. Executive Outcomes was hired by several African governments during the 1990s to put down rebellions and protect oil and diamond reserves; it did not stage coup attempts. (Some former Executive Outcomes employees participated in a 2004 coup attempt against the government of Equatorial Guinea, several years after the company itself shut down.)

9:51 p.m. | Updated The United Federation of Teachers filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in an effort to halt two tools the city's Education Department uses to change the school system: closing schools for poor performance and giving charter schools space in buildings occupied by traditional public schools. The litigation, filed in State Supreme Court, escalates the tensions in the fraying relationship between the city and the teachers' union, whose members have worked without a contract for more than a year and now face the likelihood of 4,100 layoffs, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed as a way to balance the budget.It also threatens to upend the coming school year for the thousands of students who have secured a spot in charter schools whose locations are being challenged and in new high schools that are set to replace closing schools.

PRESTON--Patricia Ann Tunison, a prolific travel writer and enthusiastic advocate of Ireland and Irish travel, died at her home in Red Hook, NY on May 17 following a short illness. She was 67 years old. After a distinguished career at the Irish Tourist Board, Pat published 15 books about travel in Ireland the most by any American-born writer as well as numerous newspaper and magazine pieces. She also wrote more than a dozen books about other travel destinations. While at the Irish Tourist Board, Pat met and fell in love with John Preston; they married in 1983. In addition to being her husband and constant travel companion, John was her writing partner on several books. Theirs was an extraordinary personal and professional collaboration over a quarter century. John died in December of last year. When not writing about Ireland, she and John led more than 30 tours there over the past 20 years. Pat is survived by her sister, Mary Tunison, of Ellington, CT; her sisters-in-law, Kathleen Sabalis of Davidson, NC and Bernice Preston of Hawley, PA; and 10 nieces and nephews. Visitation is at Burnett & White Funeral Home in Red Hook, NY, on Thursday, May 19, from 7 to 9pm, and on Friday, May 20, from 2 to 4 and from 7 to 9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 11am on Saturday, May 21, 2011 at St. Christopher's Church, Red Hook, NY. For more information, contact: www.Burnett-White.com.

The tablet computer, with those wonderful apps that display recipes and color pictures, is one of the best new kitchen tools. But if you cook like Julia Child did - splashing the bouillabaisse and tossing the flour all over the counter- there is no way you'd bring it into the kitchen. An iPad, after all, doesn't rinse off like a cutting board. Moisture is its chief enemy. The solution is obvious: wrap it in plastic. Trendy Digital (www.trendydigital.com) sells clear waterproof cases for iPads for $23.49 and $27.49 as well as for other tablets and e-readers. But the cases have straps that can get messy and awkward in the kitchen.

BARBEOSCH--William P. 1954-2011. GenSpring Family Offices mourns the death of esteemed friend and colleague, William P. Barbeosch, Esq. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife and family.

HENRY--Thomas P.,61, passed away on Sunday, May 15 after a battle with cancer. Born in Manchester, Connecticut to Thomas and Ellen (Lahey) Henry, he is survived by his wife, Diane (Thomas) Henry; his mother Ellen Henry; brother Robert Henry; children Michael, Alisa, and Adam Henry; grandchildren Josephine, Colin, and Cadel Henry; as well as several cousins, nieces, and nephews. Tom graduated from Manchester High Schol and went on to honorably serve his country in the United States Navy during the Vietnam War. Following his military service, he graduated from Central Connecticut State University and pursued a career in private and public taxation, becoming a Supervisory Agent with the Internal Revenue Service, a Partner in one of the largest international taxation firms, a Principal with a New York accounting and consulting firm, and until his death as a Partner with AugustinPartners LLC in New York City. Tom was beloved by those who knew him and his family and friends looked to him for guidance, support, and humor. He was a man of grit, energy, and integrity, who was as adept at building a stonewall or framing a doorway as he was with complicated matters of taxation. His deep love for family and friends, passion for life, quick wit, personality, sharp intellect, practical sense, and moral compass set him apart. He was taken too soon and will be sorely missed.

PAPER CUT The mountains of paperwork are one of the few certainties of home buying. Now, regulators are aiming to cut back on some mortgage documents, as the new federal consumer watchdog announced plans on Wednesday to revamp crucial forms. ''The current forms can be complicated and difficult for consumers to use,'' Elizabeth Warren, above, the Obama administration official setting up the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, said in a statement, adding that the forms are also ''redundant and can be costly for lenders to fill out.'' BEN PROTESS

CANNES, France - It wouldn't be a film festival without a little controversy. On Wednesday at the Cannes Film Festival, the director Lars von Trier caused a media firestorm when, at a news conference for his film ''Melancholia,'' he seemed to sympathize with Hitler. At the end of the news conference, Mr. Von Trier, the Danish director of austere films like ''Dancer in the Dark,'' which won the Palme d'Or in 2000, was asked to expound on a recent interview in which he expressed interest in the Nazi aesthetic. ''I thought I was a Jew for a long time and was very happy being a Jew,'' Mr. Von Trier said; on his mother's deathbed, she revealed that the man he thought was his father was not in fact his father.

NOVICK--Shirley, passed away on Monday, May 16, at the age of 102. Born Shulamit Rabinowitz in Brestovitz, Poland, Shirely settled in New York City in 1930 where she began her working life of 47 years as a seamstress and became a lifelong labor union and civil rights activist. She was married to Paul Novick, editor of the Yiddish Daily, Morgen Freiheit, for 29 years until his death in 1989. Shirley is survived by her step-son, Allan Novick, and her family in New York, London, and Israel. Service will be held at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street on Friday, May 20, at 4pm.

Lincoln Center Theater on Tuesday started a program to provide $30 seats to its performances for people ages 21 to 35, theater officials announced. The program, called LincTix, allows members to buy tickets for productions at the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse Theaters at Lincoln Center, as well as to Lincoln Center Theater productions on Broadway. A limited number of LincTix will be available for every performance and available in advance. Once registered online, LincTix members (memberships are available at LincTix.org) can buy tickets for coming productions and to ''War Horse,'' now at the Vivian Beaumont Theater (regular tickets cost $75 to $125), and to ''A Minister's Wife,'' now at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater (regular tickets are $85). LincTix members will also have a chance to purchase seats together with other LincTix members and will get invitations to free LincTix parties and other special events. PARIS -- The French finance minister, Christine Lagarde, was on a panel at the World Economic Forum in Davos this January when her usual smile turned into a frown. Next to her, Robert E. Diamond Jr., chief executive of Barclays and one of the most powerful bankers in the world, thanked regulators and finance ministers for their role in shaping a better environment after the financial crisis. Ms. Lagarde looked him in the eye. ''The best way for the banking sector to say thank you would be to actually have, you know, good financing of the economy, sensible compensation systems in place and reinforcement of their capital,'' she replied, to a burst of applause.

Like most conductors, Georg Solti marked up his scores, noting tempos, voices to emphasize and the occasional cut. But he was also a prodigious reviser of his interpretations, according to scholars, leading him sometimes to acquire four or five copies of a score to note his ideas freshly each time. That has led to a large collection of scores - some 500 - that Harvard University has just received. The family of Solti, who died in 1997, donated the collection to the Loeb Music Library at Harvard, university officials said on Tuesday. ''They are the most heavily marked-up scores I have ever seen,'' said Virginia Danielson, the Loeb's librarian, and a source of valuable insight into Solti's musical thinking. The library will also receive correspondence, photographs and private recordings over the next five years, Ms. Danielson said. It will eventually scan the scores and make some of the materials available at the scores and libretti section of the library's Web site. Other Solti materials rest with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, where he was music director from 1969 to 1991.

Dominique Strauss-Kahn resigned Wednesday as head of the International Monetary Fund after explosive accusations that he had sexually attacked a housekeeper in a Midtown Manhattan hotel room. ''It is with infinite sadness that I feel compelled today to present to the Executive Board my resignation from my post of managing director of the I.M.F.,'' he said in a statement dated Wednesday and released early Thursday by the I.M.F. ''I think at this time first of my wife -- whom I love more than anything -- of my children, of my family, of my friends.''

LAST spring, Miu Miu sparked a mini-obsession -- see Tavi -- with its sweet cat-print collars. This spring, at Balenciaga, Nicolas Ghesquiere sent out a series of shirts with Western-inspired metal collar tips. The jeweler Delfina Delettrez, of the Fendi clan, also turned her attention to collars, designing witty creations of solid silver. And in New York, two young designers, Linh Thi Do and Christine Rhee, have introduced a collection of embellished collars, called Eleven Objects. Collars in pony-hair with brass studs or in silk embroidered with vintage jewels will transform any otherwise minimal neckline. ''You're immediately doubling your wardrobe,'' Ms. Do said. And they're awesome with a summer tee. Top, Eleven Objects taffeta collar embroidered with crystals and hardware, $325 at elevenobjects.com. Left, Balenciaga silver-plated collar tips, $285 a pair at Balenciaga, 542 West 22nd Street, (212) 206-0872. Right, Delfina Delettrez sterling silver button-down necklace, $1,575 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street, (212) 219-2688; openingceremony.us.

JOHN LENNON (2006) How did John Lennon go from beloved musician to antiwar activist and inspiration for peace? And why did the United States government want to deport him? This documentary from David Leaf and John Scheinfeld covers the years from 1966 to 1976 and argues that Lennon was a better person than President Richard M. Nixon. The filmmakers share unfettered access granted by Lennon's wife, Yoko Ono, to the couple's archives and vignettes featuring some of the period's more notable figures, including Angela Davis, Bobby Seale, Walter Cronkite, G. Gordon Liddy, John Dean, Ron Kovic, Gore Vidal, Mario M. Cuomo and George McGovern.

SOME of the city's most fashionable women are putting a sexy new spin on the LBD: see-through crochet and lace with -- sacré bleu! -- visible underwear. At a MoMA dinner this month, Rosario Dawson was ladylike in a stretch lace Dolce & Gabbana dress with visible underpinnings. Jen Brill, at the Tribeca Film Festival in sheer Chanel, managed to keep the focus on her upper body with a floral-embroidered leather jacket despite her exposed bikini panties. But the ever-stylish editor Giovanna Battaglia (left) did it best. At an art opening, she wore 1950s-style Dolce & Gabbana panties under vintage Thierry Mugler. Somehow she looked covered up, conservative even, though the dress was virtually transparent. If you're game, you might test the waters for less with, say, a scoop-neck crochet dress from Free People ($268 at freepeople.com) over opaque high-waist lingerie.

AS a founder of Paper Denim & Cloth and Earnest Sewn, Scott Morrison knows a thing or two about making jeans. At 3x1, opening today, he invites you to commission your own dream jeans from a daunting range of fabrics, washes and hardware. The new shop, named for a type of denim weave, also stocks ready-made styles (25 for women, 40 for men), starting at $295. ''I designed the space to emphasize complete transparency,'' Mr. Morrsion said of the glass walls at the center of the store, behind which an in-house team of patternmakers, cutters and 11 seamstresses will make about 22 pairs of jeans a day. ''I wanted it to be something no one had seen before.'' The best part: hemming while you wait. 3x1, 15 Mercer Street, (212) 391-6969; info@3x1.us.

A Memo From France article on Tuesday about French sensitivities toward public disclosures about the private lives of powerful people erroneously attributed a distinction to Cecilia Sarkozy in 2005 when a photograph of her and her reputed lover was published on the cover of Paris Match, a weekly magazine. Mrs. Sarkozy was the wife of Nicolas Sarkozy, who was France's interior minister at the time. She was not the country's first lady. (Mr. Sarkozy was not elected president of France until 2007.)
